The demon having been cast out, the dumb one spoke. The crowd was in awe and said, "We have never seen anything like it in Israel."
But the Pharisees said, "By the prince of demons, he casts out demons."
Jesus went through all the cities and villages, teaching in the synagogues, preaching the Good News of the Kingdom, and healing every sickness and ailment among the people.
But when he saw the crowds, he was moved with compassion for them, for they were harassed and scattered, like sheep without a shepherd.
He then said to his disciples, "The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few.
Pray therefore to the Lord of the harvest to send laborers into his harvest. »
He called his twelve disciples to himself, and gave them authority over unclean spirits, to cast them out, and to heal every sickness and infirmity.
Here are the names of the twelve apostles. The first, Simon, called Peter; André, his brother; James, son of Zebedee; Jean, his brother;
Philippe; Barthélemy; Thomas; Matthew, publican; James, son of Alphaeus; Lebbeus, also called Thaddeus;
Simon the Zealot; and Judas Iscariot , who also betrayed him .
Jesus sent these twelve people and gave them this order: "Do not go among the Gentiles, nor enter into any city of the Samaritans.
Go instead to the lost sheep of the house of Israel.
On the way, preach saying, "The Kingdom of Heaven is at hand."
Heal the sick, purify the lepers, cast out demons. You have received freely, give freely.
Do not take gold, silver, or brass in your belts.
Do not take a bag for your journey, nor two tunics, nor sandals, nor staff; for the worker deserves his food.
In whatever town or village you enter, seek who is worthy of it, and remain there until you go.
When you enter a house, greet it.
If the house is worthy, let your peace come upon it, but if it is not worthy, let your peace return to you.
If anyone does not receive you or listen to your words, when you leave this house or this city, shake the dust from your feet.
Verily, I say to you, on the day of judgment, the land of Sodom and Gomorrah will be more tolerable than this city.
"Behold, I am sending you out as sheep in the midst of wolves. Be wise therefore as serpents and harmless as doves.
But beware of men, for they will deliver you up to the councils, and in their synagogues they will scourge you.
Yes, and you will be brought before governors and kings for my sake, as a witness for them and for the nations.
But when you are betrayed, do not be anxious about what you say or how you will do it, for what you say will be given to you at that very hour.
For it is not you who speak, but the Spirit of your Father who speaks in you.
"The brother shall deliver his brother to death, and the father his child. Children will rise up against the parents and put them to death.
You will be hated by all because of my name, but he who endures to the end will be saved.
But if you are persecuted in this city, flee to the next; for I tell you with all certainty, you will not have passed through the cities of Israel until the Son of Man has come.
"The disciple is not above his master, nor the servant above his lord.
It is enough that the disciple be like his master, and the servant like his lord. If they called the master of the house Beelzebub, how much more so those of his house!
Therefore do not be afraid of them, for there is nothing hidden that is not revealed, nor concealed that is not known.
What I say to you in darkness, speak in full light; and what you hear whispered in the ear, proclaim it from the rooftops.
Do not fear those who kill the body, but cannot kill the soul. Rather fear him who is able to destroy the soul and body in hell.
"Aren't two sparrows sold for a piece of assarion? None of them falls to the ground without the will of your Father.
But the hairs on your head are all numbered.
So don't be afraid. You are more valuable than many sparrows.
And so, whoever confesses me before men, I will confess him also before my Father who is in heaven.
But whoever denies me before men, I will also deny him before my Father who is in heaven.
"Do not think that I have come to bring peace to the earth. I have not come to send peace, but a sword.
For I have come to set man against her father, daughter against her mother, and daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law.
Man will have the people of his own house as enemies.
Whoever loves his father or mother more than me is not worthy of me, and whoever loves his son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me.
Whoever does not take up his cross and follow me is not worthy of me.
He who seeks his life will lose it, and he who loses his life for my sake will find it.
"He who receives you receives me, and he who receives me receives him who sent me.
Whoever receives a prophet in the name of a prophet will receive the reward of the prophet. Whoever receives a righteous person in the name of a righteous person will receive the reward of a righteous person.
Whoever gives one of these little ones a simple glass of cold water to drink in the name of a disciple, most certainly, I tell you, he will not lose his reward in any way. »
When Jesus had finished giving instructions to his twelve disciples, he set out from there to teach and preach in their cities.
Now when John heard the works of Christ in the prison, he sent two of his disciples
and said to him, "Are you the one who is coming, or must we look for another?"
Jesus answered them, "Go and tell John the things that you hear and see:
the blind receive their sight, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, and the good news is preached to the poor.
Happy is he who finds in me no occasion to fall! »
As they were leaving, Jesus began to say to the crowd about John, "What did you go to see in the wilderness? A reed shaken by the wind?
And you, what did you go to see? A man dressed in soft clothes? Behold, those who wear soft garments are in the houses of kings.
But why did you go out? To see a prophet? Yes, I tell you, and much more than a prophet.
For it is he of whom it is written: "Behold, I send my messenger before you, who will prepare your way before you."
I tell you with all certainty, among those who were born of women, there was no one greater than John the Baptizer; but the least in the Kingdom of Heaven is greater than he.
From the time of John the Baptist until now, the Kingdom of Heaven has been subjected to violence, and the violent take possession of it by force.
For all the prophets and the law prophesied unto John.
If you are willing to receive him, this is Elijah, who is to come.
Let him who has ears to hear, hear.
"But what shall I compare this generation to? She looks like children sitting in the public squares, calling out to their companions
and say, 'We played the flute for you, and you did not dance. We wept for you, and you did not lament."
For John came without eating or drinking, and they say, "He has a devil."
The Son of Man came eating and drinking, and it is said, "Behold a glutton and a drunkard, the friend of publicans and sinners." But wisdom is justified by its children. »
Then he began to denounce the cities where most of his exploits had been accomplished, because they did not repent.
"Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the miracles that were done among you had been done at Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, with sackcloth and ashes.
But I say to you, on the Day of Judgment, Tyre and Sidon will be more tolerable than you.
You, Capernaum, who have ascended to heaven, will descend to hell. For if the miracles that were done in Sodom had been done in your house, it would have remained until today.
But I tell you that on the day of judgment it will be more bearable for the land of Sodom than for you. »
At that time, Jesus answered, "I thank you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that you have hidden these things from the wise and prudent, and have revealed them to children.
Yes, Father, for it has been pleasing in your sight.
All things have been entrusted to me by my Father. No one knows the Son, except the Father; and no one knows the Father, except the Son and the one to whom the Son wishes to reveal him.
"Come to me, all you who labor and are burdened, and I will give you rest.
Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am meek and humble in heart; and you will find rest for your souls.
For my yoke is easy, and my burden is light. »
At that time, Jesus was walking through the wheat fields on the Sabbath. His disciples, who were hungry, began to pluck ears of corn and to eat.
But the Pharisees, seeing this, said to him, "Behold, your disciples are doing what it is not lawful to do on the Sabbath."
But he said to them, "Have you not read what David did when he was hungry, and those who were with him?
how he entered the house of God and ate the shewbread, which he was not lawful to eat, nor to those who were with him, but only to the priests?
Have you not read in the law that on the Sabbath the priests of the temple profane the Sabbath and are not guilty?
But I tell you that someone greater than the temple is here.
But if you had known what it means, "I want mercy and not sacrifices," you would not have condemned the innocent.
For the Son of Man is the Lord of the Sabbath. »
He left there and entered their synagogue.
And behold, there was a man there with a withered hand. They asked him, "Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath?" in order to accuse him.
He said to them, "Who among you is the man who has a sheep and who, if it falls into a pit on the Sabbath, does not take it up and pull it out?
How much more valuable is man than a sheep! It is therefore permissible to do good on the Sabbath. »
Then he said to the man, "Stretch out your hand." He stretched it out; and it was made whole, like the other.
But the Pharisees went out and conspired against him, in order to destroy him.
Jesus, perceiving this, withdrew from thence. A great crowd followed him; he heals them all,
and commanded them not to make it known,
that what was foretold by Isaiah the prophet might be fulfilled, in these words:
"This is my servant whom I have chosen, my beloved, in whom my soul delights. I will put my Spirit upon him. He will proclaim justice to the nations.
He will not fight, he will not shout, no one will hear his voice in the streets.
He will not break a bruised reed. He will not extinguish a flax that smokes, until he leads righteousness to victory.
In his name, the nations will hope. »
Then a demoniac was brought to him, blind and dumb, and he healed him, so that the blind and the dumb spoke and saw.
The whole crowd was amazed, and said, "Is this the son of David?"
But the Pharisees, when they heard this, said, "This man casts out demons only through Beelzebub, the prince of demons."
Knowing their thoughts, Jesus said to them, "Every kingdom divided against itself is devastated, and every city or house divided against itself cannot stand.
If Satan casts out Satan, he is divided against himself. How, then, will his kingdom stand?
If it is by Beelzebub that I cast out demons, by whom do your children cast them out? That is why they will be your judges.
But if it is by the Spirit of God that I cast out demons, then the Kingdom of God has come upon you.
Or how can one enter the house of a strong man and plunder his goods, if one does not first bind the strong man? Then he will plunder his house.
"He who is not with me is against me, and he who does not gather with me is scattered.
Therefore I say to you, all sin and blasphemy will be forgiven to men, but blasphemy against the Spirit will not be forgiven to men.
Whoever speaks against the Son of Man will be forgiven; but whoever speaks against the Holy Ghost will not be forgiven him either in this world or in the one to come.
"Either make the tree good and its fruit good, or make the tree corrupt and its fruit corrupt; for the tree is known by its fruit.
Races of vipers, how can you, being wicked, say good things? For it is of the abundance of the heart that the mouth speaks.
The good man, from his good treasure, draws good things, and the evil man, from his bad treasure, draws bad things.
I say to you, whatever idle words men speak, they will give an account of it on the day of judgment.
For by your words you will be justified, and by your words you will be condemned. »
Then some of the scribes and Pharisees spoke up and said, "Master, we want to see a sign from you."
But he answered them, "A wicked and adulterous generation is looking for a sign; but he will be given no other sign than that of the prophet Jonah.
For just as Jonah spent three days and three nights in the belly of a huge fish, so the Son of Man will spend three days and three nights in the heart of the earth.
The men of Nineveh will stand up in judgment with this generation and condemn it, for they repented at Jonah's preaching; and behold, someone greater than Jonah is there.
The queen of the south will rise at the time of the judgment of this generation and condemn it, for she has come from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon; and behold, there is one here greater than Solomon.
"When an unclean spirit has gone out of a man, he passes through places without water, seeking rest, and he finds it not.
Then he said, "I will return to my house from which I came"; and when he returned, he found it empty, swept and put away.
Then he goes and takes with him seven other spirits more evil than himself, and they enter and dwell there. This man's last state becomes worse than the first. The same will be true for this evil generation. »
While he was still talking to the crowd, behold, his mother and brothers were standing outside, trying to speak to him.
Someone said to him, "Here are your mother and your brothers who are outside and trying to talk to you."
But he answered the one who spoke to him, "Who is my mother? Who are my brothers? »
He stretched out his hand to his disciples, and said, "Behold my mother and my brothers!
For whoever does the will of my Father who is in heaven, he is my brother, and my sister, and my mother. »
On that day, Jesus went out of the house and sat down by the sea.
Great crowds gathered around him, so that he got into a boat and sat down; and the whole crowd was standing on the beach.
He spoke to them of many things in parables, and said, "Behold, a peasant has gone out to sow."
As he sowed seeds fell by the side of the road, and the birds came to devour them.
Others fell on rocky ground, where there was not much earth, and immediately they grew, because they had no depth of earth.
When the sun rose, they were burned. As they had no root, they dried up.
Others fell among the thorns. The thorns grew and suffocated them.
Others have fallen into the good soil and have borne fruit: some a hundred times more, others sixty, others thirty.
Let him who has ears to hear hear. »
The disciples came to him and said, "Why do you speak to them in parables?"
He answered them, "It is given to you to know the mysteries of the Kingdom of Heaven, but it is not given to them.
For to him who has, he will be given, and he will have abundance; but to him who has not, even what he has will be taken away from him.
Therefore I speak to them in parables, because seeing they do not see, and hearing they do not hear and do not understand.
In them is fulfilled the prophecy of Isaiah, who says, "By hearing you shall hear, and in no way will understand; By seeing, you will see, and will in no way be perceived;
for the hearts of this people have become insensible, their ears are deaf, and they have closed their eyes; or else they might be able to perceive with their eyes, hear with their ears, understand with their hearts, and turn again, and I would heal them.
"But blessed are your eyes, for they see, and your ears, for they hear.
For verily, I say to you, many prophets and righteous people have desired to see the things that you see, and have not seen them; and hear the things which you hear, and have not heard them.
"Listen therefore to the parable of the farmer.
When someone hears the word of the Kingdom and does not understand it, the evil one comes and plucks up what has been sown in his heart. Here is what has been sown by the wayside.
That which has been sown on the rocks is he who hears the word and immediately receives it with joy;
but it has no root in itself, it only endures for a time. When oppression or persecution arises because of speech, he immediately totters.
That which has been sown among thorns is he who hears the word; but the cares of the present age and the seduction of riches stifle speech, and he becomes sterile.
That which has been sown in the good soil is he who hears the word and understands it, who certainly bears fruit and produces, some a hundred times more, others sixty, others thirty. »
He offered them another parable, saying: "The kingdom of heaven is like a man who sowed good seed in his field.
While the people were sleeping, his enemy came and also sowed tares among the wheat, and then he went away.
But when the grass grew and produced grain, the tares appeared too.
The servants of the master of the house came to him and said, "Sir, have you not sown good seeds in your field? Where do these tares come from?
"He said to them, 'It is an enemy who has done this.' The servants asked him, "Do you want us to go and pick them up?"
But he answered, "No, lest by uprooting the tares you uproot the wheat with it.
Let them grow together until the harvest, and at the time of harvest I will say to the reapers, "First gather the tares, and bind them in bundles to burn; but gather the wheat in my barn. »
He offered them another parable, saying: "The kingdom of heaven is like a mustard seed which a man has taken and sown in his field,
and which is smaller than all the seeds. But when it has grown, it is taller than the grasses and becomes a tree, so that the birds of the air come to lodge themselves in its branches. »
He tells them yet another parable. "The kingdom of heaven is like leaven which a woman took and hid in three measures of flour, until all was leavened."
Jesus said all these things in parables to the multitudes; and without parable, he did not speak to them,
that what was foretold by the prophet might be fulfilled, saying, "I will open my mouth in parables; I will reveal things hidden since the foundation of the world. »
Then Jesus sent the crowd away, and entered the house. His disciples came to him, saying, "Explain to us the parable of the tares of the field."
He answered them, "He who sows the good seed is the Son of man;
the field is the world; the good seeds are the children of the Kingdom; The tares are the children of the evil one.
The enemy who sowed them is the devil. The harvest is the end of the world, and the reapers are the angels.
As therefore the tares are gathered up and burned in the fire, so it will be at the end of this century.
The Son of Man will send his angels, who will snatch from his kingdom all scandals and those who work iniquity,
and will cast them into the fiery furnace. There will be crying and gnashing of teeth.
Then the righteous will shine like the sun in their Father's kingdom. Let him who has ears to hear hear.
"Again, the Kingdom of Heaven is like a treasure hidden in a field, which a man has found and hidden. In his joy, he will sell everything he has and buy this field.
"Again, the Kingdom of Heaven is like a merchant looking for beautiful pearls,
and who, having found a pearl of great price, went and sold all that he had and bought it.
"Once again, the Kingdom of Heaven is like a dip net that was thrown into the sea and collected fish of all kinds,
and that, when it was filled, the fishermen brought back to the beach. They sat down and gathered the good ones into containers, but they threw away the bad ones.
It will be the same at the end of the world. The angels will come, will separate the wicked from the righteous,
and will cast them into the furnace of fire. There will be crying and gnashing of teeth. »
Jesus said to them, "Have you understood all these things?" They answered him, "Yes, Lord."
He said to them, "Therefore every scribe who has been made a disciple in the kingdom of heaven is like a householder who brings out of his treasury new things and old things."
When Jesus had finished these parables, he went away from there.
When he came to his own country, he taught them in their synagogue, so that they were astonished and said, "Where do these wisdom and miracles come from?
Is he not the carpenter's son? Is not his mother's name Mary, and his brothers James, Joses, Simon, and Judas?
Are not all his sisters with us? Where then did this man find all these things? »
They were offended by him. But Jesus said to them, "A prophet is not without honor, except in his own country and in his house."
He did not perform many miracles there because of their unbelief.
At that time, Herod the tetrarch heard the news about Jesus,
and said to his servants, "This is John the Baptizer. He rose from the dead. That is why these powers work in him. »
For Herod had arrested John, bound him, and put him in prison for the sake of Herodias, the wife of Philip, his brother.
For John had said to him, "It is not lawful for you to have this wife."
As he wanted to put him to death, he feared the crowd, because they considered him a prophet.
But when Herod's birthday arrived, Herodias' daughter danced among them and pleased Herod.
He therefore promised with an oath to give her whatever she asked.
She said, urged by her mother: "Give me here, on a tray, the head of John the Baptist."
The king was grieved, but because of his oaths and those who were at table with him, he ordered it to be given,
and he sent John to be beheaded in the prison.
His head was brought on a tray and given to the young girl, who carried it to her mother.
His disciples came, took the body, and buried it. Then they went and told Jesus.
When Jesus heard this, he withdrew from there in a boat, to a deserted place, out of the way. The crowd, having heard the news, followed him on foot from the towns.
Jesus went out, and he saw a great crowd. He took pity on them and healed their sick.
When evening came, his disciples came to him and said, "This place is deserted, and the hour is already late. Send the crowd away, so that they may go to the villages to buy food. »
But Jesus said to them, "They need not go away. You give them food. »
They said to him, "We have only five loaves and two fish here."
He said, "Bring them here to me."
He ordered the crowd to sit on the grass; then he took the five loaves and the two fishes, and raising his eyes to heaven, he blessed, broke, and gave the loaves to the disciples; and the disciples gave to the crowd.
All ate and were satisfied. They carried away twelve baskets full of what was left of the broken pieces.
Those who ate were about five thousand men, not counting the women and children.
Immediately Jesus put the disciples in the boat and made them pass before him on the other bank, while he sent the crowds away.
After sending the crowd away, he went up the mountain alone to pray. In the evening, he was there, alone.
The boat was then in the middle of the sea, agitated by the waves, because the wind was contrary.
On the fourth watch of the night, Jesus came to them, walking on the sea.
When the disciples saw him walking on the sea, they were troubled and said, "It is a ghost!" and they cried out in fear.
But immediately Jesus spoke to them, saying, "Courage! This is me! Don't be afraid. »
Peter answered him, "Lord, if it is you, command me to come to you on the waters."
He said, "Come!" Peter got out of the boat and walked on the water to come to Jesus.
But seeing that the wind was strong, he was afraid, and beginning to sink, he cried out, "Lord, save me!"
Immediately Jesus stretched out his hand, seized him, and said to him, "You who are of little faith, why did you doubt?"
When they got into the boat, the wind ceased.
Those who were in the boat came and prostrated themselves before him, saying, "You are truly the Son of God!"
After crossing , they came to the land of Gennesareth .
The inhabitants of that place, having recognized him, sent to all the neighborhoods to bring him all the sick,
and they begged him to allow them to simply touch the fringe of his garment. All who touched it were healed.
Then Pharisees and scribes came from Jerusalem to Jesus, saying,
"Why do your disciples disobey the tradition of the elders? For they do not wash their hands when they eat bread. »
He said to them, "Why do you also disobey the commandment of God because of your tradition?"
For God has commanded, "Honor your father and your mother, and, 'Whoever speaks evil of his father or mother be put to death.'"
But you say: "Whoever says to his father or mother, 'The help you could have obtained from me is a gift consecrated to God',
will honor neither his father nor his mother. You have nullified the commandment of God because of your tradition.
Hypocrites! Isaiah has prophesied well about you, saying,
These people approach me with their mouths, and honor me with their lips; but their hearts are far from me.
And they worship me in vain, to teach as a doctrine rules made by men."
He summoned the crowd, and said to them, "Listen, and understand.
What enters the mouth does not defile a man; but what comes out of the mouth defiles the man. »
Then the disciples came and said to him, "Do you know that the Pharisees were scandalized when they heard this word?"
But he replied, "Every plant that my heavenly Father has not planted will be uprooted.
Leave them alone. It is the blind who guide the blind. If the blind man guides the blind man, both will fall into a pit. »
Peter replied, "Explain the parable to us."
Then Jesus said, "Do you not understand yet?
Don't you understand that what goes into the mouth passes into the belly and then out of the body?
But the things that come out of the mouth come out of the heart, and they defile the man.
For it is from the heart that evil thoughts, murders, adulteries, sexual sins, thefts, false witnesses, blasphemies come.
These are things that defile man; but eating with unwashed hands does not defile man. »
Jesus left there and withdrew to the region of Tyre and Sidon.
Behold, a Canaanite woman came out of those borders and cried out, "Have mercy on me, Lord, son of David! My daughter is severely possessed by a demon! »
But he did not answer her a word. His disciples came to beg him, saying, "Send her away, for she cries out after us."
But he answered, "I was sent only to the lost sheep of the house of Israel."
But she came and worshipped him, saying, "Lord, help me."
But he answered, "It is not proper to take the bread of the children and throw it to the dogs."
But she answered, "Yes, Lord, but even dogs eat the crumbs that fall from their masters' table."
Then Jesus answered her, "Woman, great is your faith! Let it be done to you as you wish. And his daughter was healed from that hour.
Jesus set out from there and approached the Sea of Galilee; he climbed the mountain and sat down there.
Great crowds came to him, having with them the lame, the blind, the dumb, the crippled, and many others, and they laid them at his feet. He heals them,
so that the crowd was in awe when they saw the dumb speak, the wounded healed, the lame walk, and the blind see, and they glorified the God of Israel.
Jesus summoned his disciples and said to them, "I have pity on the crowd, for they have been with me for three days and have nothing to eat. I don't want to send them back on an empty stomach, because they might faint on the way. »
The disciples said to him, "Where can we find so much bread in a desert place to satisfy so great a multitude?"
Jesus said to them, "How many loaves have you got?" They said, "Seven, and a few little fish."
He ordered the crowd to sit on the ground,
and he took the seven loaves and the fishes. He gave thanks, broke them, gave them to the disciples, and the disciples to the crowd.
All ate and were satisfied. They took away seven baskets full of the pieces that remained.
Those who ate were four thousand men, not counting the women and children.
Then he sent the crowd away, got into the boat, and came to the territory of Magdala.
The Pharisees and Sadducees came, and, after testing him, they asked him to show them a sign from heaven.
But he replied, "In the evening you say, 'It will be fine, for the sky is red.'
And in the morning, you say, "It's going to be bad weather today, because the sky is red and threatening. Hypocrites! You know how to discern the aspect of the sky, but you do not know how to discern the signs of the times!
An evil and adulterous generation is looking for a sign, and no sign will be given to them except the sign of the prophet Jonah. He left them and went away.
The disciples arrived on the other side and had forgotten to take bread.
Jesus said to them, "Beware and beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and Sadducees."
They reasoned among themselves, saying, "We have not brought bread."
When Jesus saw this, he said, "Why do you reason among yourselves, you people of little faith, because you have not brought bread?
Do you not understand yet, and do you not remember the five loaves for the five thousand, and the number of baskets you have carried away,
or of the seven loaves for the four thousand, and of the number of baskets you have taken away?
How come you don't realize that I didn't tell you about the breads? But beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and Sadducees. »
They then understood that he had not told them to beware of the yeast of the bread, but of the teaching of the Pharisees and Sadducees.
Now when Jesus arrived in the region of Caesarea Philippi, he questioned his disciples, saying, "Who do they say that I am the Son of man?"
They answered, "Some say John the Baptizer, some Elijah, and still others Jeremiah or one of the prophets."
He said to them, "But who do you say I am?"
Simon Peter answered, "You are the Christ, the Son of the living God."
Jesus answered him, "Blessed are you, Simon Bar Jonah, for it is not flesh and blood that has revealed this to you, but my Father who is in heaven.
I also say to you that you are Peter, and that on this rock I will build my church, and that the gates of hell will not prevail against it.
I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven, and whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven. »
Then he commanded the disciples not to tell anyone that he was Jesus the Christ.
From then on, Jesus began to show his disciples that he had to go to Jerusalem, that he should suffer much at the hands of the elders, the chief priests and scribes, that he should be killed and that he should rise again on the third day.
Peter took him aside and began to rebuke him, saying, "Far from you, Lord! This will never be done to you. »
But he turned around and said to Peter, "Go behind me, Satan! You are a stumbling block to me, for you do not meditate on the things of God, but on the things of men. »
Then Jesus said to his disciples, "If anyone wants to come after me, let him deny himself, take up his cross and follow me.
For whoever wants to save his life will lose it, and whoever loses his life for my sake will find it.
For what good would it do a man to gain the whole world if he lost his life? Or what will man give in exchange for his life?
For the Son of Man will come in the glory of his Father with his angels, and then he will repay each one according to his works.
I tell you with certainty, there are some here who will not taste death until they have seen the Son of Man come into his Kingdom. »
Six days later, Jesus took Peter, James, and John, his brother, with him, and led them up a high mountain alone.
He was changed before them. His face shone like the sun, and his garments became white as the light.
And behold, Moses and Elijah appeared to them, speaking with him.
Peter answered and said to Jesus, "Lord, it is good for us to be here. If you will, let us make three tents here: one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah. »
While he was still speaking, behold, a luminous cloud covered them with his shadow. And behold, a voice came out of the cloud, saying, "This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased. Listen. »
When the disciples heard this, they fell on their faces and were very frightened.
Jesus came and touched them, and said, "Arise, and do not be afraid."
Raising their eyes, they saw no one, except Jesus alone.
As they came down from the mountain, Jesus commanded them, "Tell no one what you have seen, until the Son of Man is raised from the dead."
His disciples questioned him, saying, "Then why do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?"
Jesus answered them, "Elijah comes first, and he will restore all things;
but I tell you that Elijah has already come, and that they have not recognized him, but have done to him as they pleased. In the same way, the Son of Man will also suffer through them. »
The disciples then understood that he was speaking to them about John the Baptist.
When they came to the crowd, a man came up to him, knelt down and said:
"Lord, have mercy on my son, for he is epileptic and suffers cruelly; it often falls into fire, and often into water.
So I brought him to your disciples, and they could not heal him. »
Jesus answered, "Unfaithful and perverse generation! How long shall I be with you? How much longer shall I bear with you? Bring him here to me. »
Jesus threatened the devil, who came out of him, and the boy was healed at that hour.
Then the disciples came to Jesus in private, and said, "Why couldn't we drive her out?"
He said to them, "It is because of your unbelief. For verily, I say to you, if you have faith like a mustard seed, you will say to this mountain, 'Move from here to there,' and it will move; and nothing will be impossible for you.
But this kind of grain does not come out, except through prayer and fasting. »
While they were sojourning in Galilee, Jesus said to them, "The Son of Man is going to be delivered into the hands of men,
they will kill him, and on the third day he will rise again. They were extremely sorry.
When they arrived at Capernaum, those who were collecting the didrachm coins came to Peter and said to him, "Does not your master pay the didrachma?"
He answered, "Yes." When he entered the house, Jesus waited for him, saying, "What do you think, Simon? From whom do the kings of the earth receive rights or tributes? Of their children, or of strangers? »
Peter said to him, "Strangers." Jesus said to him, "Children are therefore exempt.
But, in order not to trip them, go to the sea, cast a hook, and catch the first fish that comes along. When you have opened his mouth, you will find a piece of stater. Take it, and give it to them for me and for you. »
At that hour the disciples came to Jesus and said, "Who is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven?"
Jesus called a little child to himself and placed him in the midst of them
and said, Verily I say to you, unless you are converted and become like little children, you will not enter the kingdom of heaven.
Whoever humbles himself like this little child is the greatest in the Kingdom of Heaven.
Whoever receives such a little child in my name receives me myself,
but whoever causes one of these little ones who believe in me to stumble, it would be better for him to have a huge millstone hung around his neck and to sink him into the depths of the sea.
"Woe to the world, because of the occasions of falling! For opportunities must come, but woe to him through whom the opportunity comes!
If your hand or foot causes you to trip, cut them off and throw them away from you. It is better for you to enter life mutilated or crippled, than to have two hands or two feet to be thrown into eternal fire.
If your eye causes you to stumble, pluck it out and throw it away from you. It is better for you to enter life with only one eye, than to have two eyes to be thrown into the hell of fire.
Be careful not to despise any of these little ones, for I tell you that in heaven their angels always see the face of my Father who is in heaven.
For the Son of Man came to save what was lost.
"What do you think? If a man has a hundred sheep and one of them goes astray, does he not leave the other ninety-nine, does he not go into the mountain and seek the one that has gone astray?
If he finds it, I tell you truly, he rejoices more than the ninety-nine who have not gone astray.
In the same way, it is not the will of your Father who is in heaven that any of these little ones should perish.
"If your brother sins against you, go and show him his guilt, between you and him alone. If he listens to you, you have regained your brother.
But if he does not listen, take one or two others with you, so that every word may be established by the mouth of two or three witnesses.
If he refuses to listen to them, tell the assembly. If he also refuses to listen to the assembly, let him be to you as a pagan or a publican.
Verily, I say to you, whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven.
Truly I say to you, if two of you agree on earth to ask for anything, it will be granted to them by my Father who is in heaven.
For where two or three are gathered together in my name, I am in the midst of them. »
Then Peter came and said to him, "Lord, how often will my brother sin against me, and I will forgive him? Up to seven times? »
Jesus answered him, "I do not say to you up to seven times, but up to seventy times seven.
Therefore the kingdom of heaven is like a king who wanted to settle accounts with his servants.
As he was beginning to settle, one was brought to him who owed him ten thousand talents.
But as he could not pay, his master ordered that he be sold, with his wife, children, and all that he possessed, and that the payment be made.
So the servant threw himself on the ground and knelt before him, saying, "Lord, have patience with me, and I will repay you all.
The master of this servant, moved with compassion, released him and forgave him the debt.
"But this servant went out and found one of his companions in the service who owed him a hundred denarii, and he seized him and took him by the throat, saying, 'Pay me what you owe!'
His companion on duty threw himself at his feet and begged him, saying, "Have patience with me, and I will reciprocate you."
He would not, but he went to throw him in prison until he had repaid what was due to him.
When his fellow servants saw what had happened, they were deeply sorry and came to tell their master all that had happened.
His master sent for him and said to him, "Wicked servant! I forgave you all this debt because you begged me.
Ought thou not to have pity on thy companion in service, as I have had pity on thee?
His master became angry and handed him over to the executioners until he paid all that was owed to him.
This is how my heavenly Father will also treat you, if you do not forgive your brother every one of your hearts for his misdeeds. »
When Jesus had finished these words, he left Galilee and entered the territory of Judea, beyond the Jordan.
Great crowds followed him, and there he healed them.
The Pharisees came to him, testing him and saying, "Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife for any reason?"
He answered, "Have you not read that He who created them from the beginning made them male and female?
and that he said, "Therefore shall a man leave his father and mother, and be joined to his wife, and the two shall become one flesh?"
Thus, they are no longer two, but one flesh. What God has therefore joined together, let not man tear it apart. »
They asked him, "Why then did Moses command us to give him a certificate of divorce and divorce?"
He said to them, "Moses, because of the hardness of your hearts, allowed you to divorce your wives, but from the beginning it was not so.
I tell you that whoever divorces his wife, except on account of sexual immorality, and marries another, commits adultery; and whoever marries her while she is divorced commits adultery. »
His disciples said to him, "If this is the case with a man and his wife, it is not expedient to marry."
But he said to them, "Not all men can receive this word, but those to whom it is given.
For there are eunuchs who are thus born from their mother's womb, and there are eunuchs who have been made eunuchs by men, and there are eunuchs who have become eunuchs for the sake of the kingdom of heaven. Let him who is able to receive it, receive it. »
Then little children were brought to him to lay his hands on them and pray; and the disciples rebuked them.
But Jesus said, "Leave the little children and do not forbid them to come to me, for the kingdom of heaven belongs to those who are like them."
He laid his hands on them and went away from there.
Behold, someone came to him and said, "Good master, what good must I do to have eternal life?"
He said to him, "Why do you call me good? No one is good, except one, that is to say, God. But if you want to enter into life, keep the commandments. »
He said to him, "Which ones?" Jesus said, "You shall not commit murder. You shall not commit adultery. You shall not steal. You shall not bear false witness. »
You shall honor your father and your mother. And you shall love your neighbor as yourself. »
The young man said to him, "I have observed all these things from my youth. What else do I lack? »
Jesus said to him, "If you want to be perfect, go, sell what you have, give it to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; then come, follow me. »
But when the young man heard this, he went away very sad, for he was a man of great possessions.
Jesus said to his disciples, "I tell you for sure, a rich man will find it difficult to enter the kingdom of heaven.
I tell you again, it is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God. »
When the disciples heard this, they were exceedingly astonished and said, "Who can be saved?"
Looking at them, Jesus said, "With men it is impossible, but with God all things are possible."
Peter answered, "Behold, we have left everything and followed you. What will we have? »
Jesus said to them, "Truly I say to you, who have followed me, in the day of regeneration, when the Son of Man shall be seated on the throne of his glory, you shall also sit on twelve thrones, to judge the twelve tribes of Israel.
All those who have left houses, or brothers, or sisters, or a father, or a mother, or a wife, or children, or lands, for my name's sake, shall receive a hundred times, and shall inherit eternal life.
But many will be the last who will be first, and the first who will be the last.
"For the Kingdom of Heaven is like a man, master of a house, who went out early in the morning to hire laborers for his vineyard.
After agreeing with the workmen of a denarius a day, he sent them to his vineyard.
He went out about the third hour, and saw others who were idle in the public square.
He said to them, "Go to the vineyard too, and I will give you what suits you. And they went away.
He went out again about the sixth and ninth hours, and did the same.
About the eleventh hour, he went out and found other idle people. He said to them, "Why do you stay here all day doing nothing?
They replied, "Because no one hired us." He said to them, "You also will go to the vineyard, and you will receive what is right."
When evening came, the owner of the vineyard said to his manager: "Call the workers and give them their wages, from the last to the first.
When those who had been hired about the eleventh hour arrived, they each received a denarius.
When the first arrived, they thought that they would receive more, and they also each received a denarius.
When they had received him, they murmured against the master of the house,
saying, "These have spent only one hour, and you make them equal to us, who have borne the weight of the day and the scorching heat.
"But he answered one of them, 'My friend, I am not hurting you. Have you not agreed with me for a denarius?"
Take what belongs to you, and go away. I want to give to the latter as much as to you.
Is it not permissible for me to do what I want with what belongs to me? Or is your eye evil, because I am good?'
Thus the last will be the first, and the first the last. For many are called, but few are elected. »
As Jesus was going up to Jerusalem, he took the twelve disciples aside, and on the way he said to them:
"Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem, and the Son of Man shall be delivered up to the chief priests and the scribes, who shall condemn him to death,
and will hand him over to the Gentiles to mock him, scourge him, and crucify him; and on the third day he will rise again. »
Then the mother of the sons of Zebedee came to him with her sons, kneeling down and asking him one thing.
He said to him, "What do you want?" She said to him, "Order these, my two sons, to sit, one at your right hand and the other at your left, in your kingdom."
But Jesus answered, "You do not know what you are asking. Are you able to drink the cup that I am about to drink, and to be baptized with the baptism with which I am baptized? They told him, "We can." »
He said to them, "For you shall drink my cup, and you shall be baptized with the baptism with which I am baptized; but to sit at my right hand and on my left, it is not for me to give it, but for him for whom it has been prepared by my Father. »
When the ten heard this, they were indignant against the two brothers.
But Jesus called them and said, "You know that the rulers of the nations rule over them, and that their great ones exercise their authority over them.
It will not be so in your midst; but whoever wants to become great among you will be your servant.
Whoever wants to be first among you will be your slave,
as the Son of Man came, not to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many. »
As they were leaving Jericho, a great crowd followed him.
And behold, two blind men sat by the roadside, hearing that Jesus was passing by, cried out, "Lord, have mercy on us, sons of David!"
The crowd rebuked them, telling them to be silent, but they cried out even louder, "Lord, have mercy on us, sons of David!"
Jesus stopped and called to them, and asked them, "What do you want me to do for you?"
They said to him, "Lord, let our eyes be opened."
Jesus, moved with compassion, touched their eyes; at that very moment their eyes recovered their sight, and they followed him.
When they approached Jerusalem and arrived at Bethsphage, on the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two disciples,
saying to them, "Go to the village in front of you, and you will immediately find a donkey tied up, and a colt with her. Untie them and bring them to me.
If anyone says something to you, you will answer, 'The Lord needs them,' and immediately he will send them. »
All this was done in order that what had been foretold by the prophet might be fulfilled, saying,
"Say to the daughter of Zion, Behold, your King who comes to you, humble, and mounted on an ass, on a colt, the baby of an ass."
The disciples went and did as Jesus had commanded them.
They brought the donkey and the colt, put their clothes on them, and Jesus sat on them.
A very large crowd spread their clothes on the road. Others cut branches from trees and spread them on the road.
The crowd that marched before him, and those who followed him, did not cease to cry out: "Hosanna to the son of David! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the highest heavens! »
When he arrived in Jerusalem, the whole city was agitated, saying, "Who is this?"
The crowds said, "This is the prophet Jesus, from Nazareth to Galilee."
Jesus entered the temple of God, drove out all those who sold and bought in the temple, and overturned the tables of the moneychangers and the seats of those who sold the doves.
He said to them, "It is written, 'My house shall be called a house of prayer, but you have made it a den of thieves.'"
The lame and the blind came to him in the temple, and he healed them.
But the chief priests and scribes, seeing the wonders he was doing, and the children crying in the temple and saying, "Hosanna to the son of David," were indignant,
and said to him, "Do you hear what they say?" Jesus said to them, "Yes. Have you ever read, "Out of the mouths of children and infants have thou shalt forth praise?"
He left them, left the city, and went to Bethany, where he encamped.
In the morning, as he was returning to the city, he was hungry.
Seeing a fig tree by the roadside, he approached it and found only leaves. He said to him, "Let there be no fruit of you forever." Immediately, the fig tree withers.
When the disciples saw this, they were astonished, and said, "How could the fig tree have dried up at once?"
Jesus answered them, "Truly I say to you, if you have faith and do not doubt, not only will you do what was done to the fig tree, but even if you said to this mountain, 'Take yourself and throw yourself into the sea,' it would be done."
Whatever you ask in prayer, believing, you will receive. »
When he had entered the temple, the chief priests and elders of the people came to him while he was teaching, and said, "By what authority do you do these things? Who gave you this authority? »
Jesus answered them, "I will also ask you a question; if you answer it, I will tell you in the same way by what authority I do these things.
John's baptism, where did it come from? Of heaven or men? They reasoned among themselves: "If we say, 'From heaven,' he will ask us, 'Why did you not believe in him?'
But if we say, "Men," we fear the multitude, for all hold John to be a prophet. »
They answered Jesus, "We do not know." He also said to them, "Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.
But what do you think? A man had two sons. He came to the first one and said to him, "My son, go and work in my vineyard today.
He replied, "I don't want to," but he changed his mind afterwards and went.
He came to the second, and said the same thing to him. He replied, "I am going, sir," but he did not go.
Which of the two did his father's will? They said to him, "The first . Jesus said to them, "Truly I say to you, publicans and prostitutes enter the kingdom of God before you."
For John came to you in the way of righteousness, and you did not believe him; but the publicans and prostitutes believed it. When you saw it, you didn't even repent afterwards, in order to believe it.
"Listen to another parable. There was a man, master of the house, who planted a vineyard, surrounded it with a hedge, dug a wine press, built a tower, leased it to farmers and left for another country.
When the fruit season approached, he sent his servants to the farmers to receive his fruit.
The farmers took his servants, beat one, killed another, and stoned another.
He again sent other servants, more numerous than the first, and they treated them in the same way.
Then he sent his son to them, saying, "They will respect my son.
But the peasants, seeing the son, said among themselves, "He is the heir." Come, let us kill him and seize his inheritance.
So they took him and threw him out of the vineyard, and then killed him.
When the owner of the vineyard comes, what will he do to these farmers? »
They said to him, "He will destroy these wretches miserably, and will rent the vineyard to other farmers who will give him the fruit in their season."
Jesus said to them, "Have you never read in the Scriptures, 'The stone which the builders rejected was appointed at the head of the corner. It came from the Lord. It's wonderful in our eyes"?
"Therefore I say to you, the Kingdom of God will be taken away from you and will be given to a nation that produces its fruit.
Whoever falls on this stone will be broken in pieces, but whoever it falls on, it will scatter like dust. »
The chief priests and Pharisees, when they heard his parables, understood that he was speaking of them.
When they sought to seize him, they feared the crowd, because they considered him a prophet.
Jesus answered and spoke to them again in parables, and said:
The kingdom of heaven is like a king who made a wedding for his son.
He sent his servants to call the guests to the wedding, but they would not come.
He sent other servants again, saying, "Say to those who are invited, 'Behold, I have prepared my meal. My cattle and my fat animals are killed, and everything is ready. Come to the wedding feast."
But they laughed at it and went their separate ways, one to his farm, the other to his merchandise;
and the others seized his servants, treated them unworthily, and killed them.
When the king heard this, he became angry, sent his armies, put to death these murderers, and burned their city.
"Then he said to his servants, 'The wedding is ready, but those who were invited were not worthy of it.
Go therefore to the crossroads of the roads, and invite to this wedding all whom you find.
These servants went out into the roads and gathered together all those they found, good and bad. The wedding was filled with guests.
But when the king came in to see the guests, he saw there a man who had no wedding clothes,
and he said to him, "My friend, how did you come here without wedding garments?" He remained silent.
Then the king said to the servants, "Bind his hands and feet, take him away, and cast him into the darkness outside. That's when there will be crying and gnashing of teeth."
For there are many called, but few chosen. »
Then the Pharisees went to consult as to how they could trap him in his speech.
They sent their disciples to him, as well as the Herodians, saying, "Master, we know that you are honest and that you teach the way of God in truth, whoever you teach, for you have no bias for anyone.
So tell us what you think. Is it lawful to pay the tax to Caesar, or not? »
But Jesus, perceiving their wickedness, said, "Why do you tempt me, you hypocrites?
Show me the tax money. They brought him a denarius.
He asked them, "To whom does this image and inscription belong?"
They said to him, "To Caesar." Then he said to them, "Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and to God the things that are God's."
When they heard him, they were astonished, left him and went away.
On that day, some Sadducees (those who say that there is no resurrection) came to him. They questioned him,
saying, "Master," Moses said, "If a man dies without having children, his brother shall marry his wife, and raise up offspring to his brother."
Now there were seven brothers among us. The first married and died, and, having no descendants, he left his wife to his brother.
In the same way, the second, and the third, up to the seventh.
After all of them, the woman died.
At the resurrection, then, whose wife will she be? Because they all got it. »
But Jesus answered them, "You are in error, you do not know the Scriptures, nor the power of God.
For in the resurrection they do not marry or are given in marriage, but they are like the angels of God in heaven.
As for the resurrection of the dead, have you not read what God has said to you, saying:
"I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob"? God is not the God of the dead, but of the living. »
When the crowd heard him, they were astonished at his teaching.
But the Pharisees, when they heard that he had silenced the Sadducees, gathered together.
One of them, a lawyer, asked him a question to test him.
"Master, what is the greatest commandment of the law?"
Jesus said to him, "You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your mind."
This is the first and greatest of the commandments.
A second similar commandment is this: "You shall love your neighbor as yourself."
The whole law and the prophets depend on these two commandments. »
As the Pharisees were gathered, Jesus asked them a question,
saying, "What do you think of Christ? Whose son is he? They said to him, "From David." »
He said to them, "How then does David in the Spirit call him Lord, saying,
"The Lord said to my Lord, sit at my right hand, until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet"?
"If, then, David calls him Lord, how is he his son?"
No one could answer him a word, and no one dared to ask him any more questions from that day on.
Then Jesus, speaking to the crowd and to his disciples,
said: The scribes and Pharisees sit on the seat of Moses.
Whatever they tell you to observe, observe it and do it; but do not do their works, for they say and do not do.
For they bind heavy burdens that are painful to bear, and put them on the shoulders of men; but they themselves do not lift a finger to help them.
But they do all their works to be seen by men. They widen their phylacteries and enlarge the fringes of their clothes,
they love places of honor in festivals, the best seats in synagogues,
greetings in the public squares, and being called by men "Rebbe, Rebbe.
But you are not to be called "Rabbi," for only one is your master, Christ, and you are all brothers.
Do not call any man on earth your father, for there is only one of your Father, who is in heaven.
Do not call yourselves masters, for only one is your master, Christ.
But the one who is greatest among you will be your servant.
Whoever exalts himself will be humbled, and whoever humbles himself will be exalted.
"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you devour the houses of widows, and, to pretend, you make long prayers. That is why you will receive a greater condemnation.
"But woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you close the kingdom of heaven to men; you do not enter yourselves, and you do not allow those who enter to enter.
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you travel through the sea and the land to make one proselyte; and when he becomes so, you make him a son of Gehenna twice as much as you.
"Woe to you, blind guides, who say: 'He who swears by the temple is nothing; but he who swears by the gold of the temple obliges himself'.
Blind fools! For which is greater, gold or the temple that sanctifies gold?
And: "If anyone swears by the altar, he is nothing; but if anyone swears by the gift that is on the altar, he is obliged."
Blind people! For which is greater, the gift or the altar that sanctifies the gift?
Therefore he who swears by the altar swears by it and by all that is on it.
He who swears by the temple, swears by it and by him who has dwelt in it.
He who swears by heaven, swears by the throne of God and by him who sits there.
"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you pay tithes of mint, dill, and cumin, and have neglected the gravest things of the law: justice, mercy, and faith. Now, you should have done these things, and not left others in suspense.
Blind guides, you push the gnat and you swallow the camel!
"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you clean the outside of the cup and the dish, but inside they are full of robbery and iniquity.
Blind Pharisee, first cleanses the inside of the cup and the dish, so that the outside may also become pure.
"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you are like whitewashed tombs, which appear beautiful on the outside, but on the inside are full of the bones of the dead and every kind of impurity.
In the same way, you also appear righteous in the eyes of men on the outside, but on the inside you are full of hypocrisy and iniquity.
"Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you build the tombs of the prophets and decorate the tombs of the righteous,
and you say: "If we had lived in the time of our fathers, we would not have shared with them in the blood of the prophets."
So you bear witness to yourselves that you are the children of those who killed the prophets.
Fill therefore the measure of your fathers.
Serpents, offspring of vipers, how will you escape the judgment of Gehenna?
Therefore behold, I am sending you prophets, sages, and scribes. You will kill and crucify some, you will scourge others in your synagogues and you will persecute them from city to city,
so that all the innocent blood shed on the earth may fall upon you, from the blood of Abel the righteous to the blood of Zechariah son of Barachiah, whom you killed between the sanctuary and the altar.
Verily, I say to you, all these things will happen to this generation.
"Jerusalem, Jerusalem, which kills the prophets and stones those who are sent to it! How often have I wanted to gather your children, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, and you would not!
Behold, your house will be left deserted to you.
For I say to you, you will not see me any more, until you say, "Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord."
Jesus left the temple, and set out on his journey. His disciples approached him to show him the temple buildings.
But he answered them, "You see all these things, don't you? Verily, I say to you, there will not be left here one stone upon another that is not overthrown. »
As he was sitting on the Mount of Olives, the disciples approached him privately, and said, "Tell us, when will this happen? What is the sign of your coming and the end of the world? »
Jesus answered them, "Take care that no one leads you astray.
For many will come in my name, saying, "I am the Christ," and they will lead many astray.
You will hear about wars and rumors of wars. Be careful not to be troubled, for all this must happen, but the end has not yet come.
For a nation will rise up against a nation, and a kingdom against a kingdom; and there will be famines, pestilences, and earthquakes in various places.
But all these things are the beginning of the pains of childbirth.
"Then they will hand you over to oppression and put you to death. You will be hated by all nations for my name's sake.
Then many will stumble, give themselves up to one another, and hate each other.
Many false prophets will arise and lead many people astray.
Because iniquity will multiply, the love of many will grow cold.
But he who endures to the end will be saved.
This Good News of the Kingdom will be preached in all the world, as a witness to all nations, and then the end will come.
"When, therefore, ye shall see the abomination of desolation, of which the prophet Daniel spoke, standing in the holy place,
let those who are in Judea flee into the mountains.
Let not the one who is on the roof go down to remove the things that are in his house.
Let not the one who is in the field come back to take his clothes.
But woe to pregnant women and nursing mothers in those days!
Pray that your escape will not be in winter or on the Sabbath,
for then there will be great sufferings, such as have not been from the beginning of the world until now, no, and never will be.
If those days had not been shortened, no flesh would have been saved. But, because of the elected officials, these days will be shortened.
If someone says to you, "Behold Christ" or "Behold Christ," do not believe him.
For false christs and false prophets will arise, who will do great signs and wonders, in order to lead astray, if possible, even the elect.
"Behold, I told you beforehand.
If, therefore, it is said to you, 'Behold, he is in the desert,' do not go out; or, "Behold, he is in the inner chambers, do not believe him."
For as lightning comes from the east and shows itself even in the west, so will it be with the coming of the Son of man.
Because where the corpse is, that's where the vultures gather.
"But immediately after the sufferings of those days, the sun will be darkened, the moon will give its light no more, the stars will fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens will be shaken;
and then the sign of the Son of Man will appear in heaven. Then all the tribes of the earth will mourn, and they will see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.
He will send his angels with the sound of the trumpet, and they will gather his elect from the four winds, from one end of heaven to the other.
"Now learn this parable of the fig tree: When its branch has become tender and produces its leaves, you know that summer is at hand.
In the same way, you too, when you see all these things, know that he is near, even at the doors.
I tell you with all certainty, this generation will not pass away until all these things are accomplished.
Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will not pass away.
But no one knows that day or hour, not even the angels of heaven, but my Father alone.
What the days of Noah were will be the coming of the Son of man.
For as in the days before the flood, they ate and drank, and married, and gave in marriage, until the day when Noah entered the boat,
and that nothing was known until the flood came and swept them all away, so it will be with the coming of the Son of man.
Then two men will be in a field: one will be taken and the other will be left.
Two women will grind at the mill: one will be taken and the other left.
Watch therefore , for you do not know at what hour your Lord will come.
But know that if the master of the house had known on what watch of the night the thief was coming, he would have kept watch and would not have allowed anyone to enter his house.
Therefore you also must be ready, for at the hour you do not expect, the Son of Man will come.
"Who then is the faithful and prudent servant, whom his master has appointed over his house, to give him his food at the proper time?
Happy is this servant whom his master will find doing it when he comes.
Verily, I say to you, he will establish it over all that he possesses.
But if this evil servant says in his heart, "My master is slow to come,
if he begins to beat his fellow servants, to eat and drink with drunkards,
the master of this servant will come on the day when he does not expect it and the hour when he does not know it,
he will tear him to pieces and give him his share with the hypocrites. This is where there will be crying and gnashing of teeth.
"Then the kingdom of heaven will be like ten virgins who, having taken their lamps, went to meet the bridegroom.
Five of them were foolish, and five were wise.
The fools, when they took their lamps, did not take oil with them,
but the wise took oil from their vessels with their lamps.
While the bridegroom was delaying, they all dozed off and slept.
But at midnight they cried: "Behold! Here is the bridegroom who comes. Go out to meet him!
Then all the virgins got up and prepared their lamps.
The foolish ones said to the wise, "Give us some of your oil, for our lamps are going out."
But the wise men answered, "What if there is not enough for us and for you? Go rather to those who sell, and buy for yourself.
While they were going to buy, the bridegroom arrived; those who were ready entered with him to the wedding feast, and the door was shut.
Then the other virgins came also, saying, "Lord, Lord, open to us."
But he answered, "Truly, I say to you, I do not know you.
Watch therefore , for you know neither the day nor the hour when the Son of Man is to come.
"For it is like a man who, going to another land, called his own servants and entrusted his goods to them.
He gave to one five talents, to another two, to another still one, to each according to his ability. Then he set off.
Immediately the one who had received the five talents went to trade with them, and gained five more talents.
In the same way, he who had received the two talents gained two more.
But he who had received a talent went away, dug in the earth and hid his master's money.
Long after, the master of these servants came and settled his accounts with them.
The one who had received the five talents came and brought five more talents, saying, "Lord, you have given me five talents. Now I have gained five other talents in addition to them'.
His master said to him, "It is good, good and faithful servant. You have been faithful in a few things, I will confide in you many things. Enter into the joy of your master.
"The one who received the two talents came up and said, 'Lord, you have given me two talents. Now I have gained two other talents in addition to them'.
His master said to him, "It is well, good and faithful servant. You have been faithful for few things. I'm going to tell you a lot of things. Enter into the joy of your master.
The one who had received a talent came and said, "Lord, I knew that you are a hard man, who reaps where he has not sown, and who gathers where he has not scattered.
I was afraid, and I went to hide your talent in the earth. Behold, you have what is yours.
"But his master answered him, 'Wicked and slothful servant. You knew that I reap where I have not sown, and that I gather where I have not scattered.
So you should have deposited my money with the bankers, and when I returned, I would have received mine with interest.
Take away the talent from him and give it to him who has the ten talents.
For to him that has, and he shall have abundance, shall be given, but to him that hath not, even that which he has shall be taken away.
Cast the useless servant into the outer darkness, where there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth."
"But when the Son of Man comes in his glory, and all the holy angels with him, then he shall sit on the throne of his glory.
All the nations will be gathered before him, and he will separate them from one another, as a shepherd separates the sheep from the goats.
He will place the sheep on his right hand, but the goats on his left.
Then the King will say to those who are on his right hand: "Come, you blessed of my Father, inherit the Kingdom that was prepared for you from the foundation of the world.
For I was hungry and you gave me something to eat. I was thirsty and you gave me something to drink. I was a stranger and you welcomed me.
I was naked, and you dressed me. I was sick and you visited me. I was in prison and you came to me."
Then the righteous will answer him, "Lord, when did we see you hungry and feed you, or thirsty and give you something to drink?
When did we see you a stranger and welcome you, or naked and clothed you?
When did we see you sick or in prison, and come to you?
The king will answer them, "I tell you the truth, because you did it to one of the least of these my brothers, you did it to me."
Then he will also say to those on his left, "Depart from me, you cursed, into the eternal fire that has been prepared for the devil and his angels;
for I was hungry, and you gave me no food; I was thirsty, and you gave me no drink;
I was a stranger, and you did not take me in; naked, and you have not clothed me; sick, and in prison, and you have not visited me."
"They will also answer, saying, 'Lord, when did we see you hungry, or thirsty, or a stranger, or naked, or sick, or in prison, and did we not help you?'
"Then he will answer them, 'Truly I say to you, because you did not do it to one of the least of these, you did not do it to me.'
These will go to eternal punishment, but the righteous to eternal life. »
After he had finished all these words, Jesus said to his disciples:
"You know that after two days the Passover will come, and that the Son of Man will be delivered up to be crucified."
Then the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders of the people met in the court of the high priest, called Caiaphas.
They held a council to seize Jesus by trickery and put him to death.
But they said, "Not during the festival, lest there be a riot among the people."
As Jesus was in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper,
A woman came to him, holding an alabaster vase containing an ointment of great price, and she sprinkled it on his head while he was at table.
His disciples, seeing this, were indignant and said, "Why this waste?
For this perfume could have been sold at a high price and given to the poor. »
But knowing this, Jesus said to them, "Why are you troubling this woman? She has done a good work for me.
For you always have the poor with you, but you do not always have me.
Indeed, by pouring this perfume on my body, she did it to prepare me for burial.
I tell you truly, wherever this Good News is preached in all the world, what this woman has done will also be spoken of as a memory of herself. »
Then one of the twelve, called Judas Iscariot, went to the chief priests
and said, "What will you give me if I deliver it to you?" So they weighed thirty pieces of silver for him.
From then on, he looked for an opportunity to betray him.
But on the first day of Unleavened Bread, the disciples came to Jesus and said to him, "Where do you want us to prepare the Passover for you?"
He said, "Go to the city to someone's house, and say to him, 'The master said, 'My hour is at hand. I will celebrate the Passover in your house with my disciples. »
The disciples did as Jesus had commanded them, and they prepared for the Passover.
When evening came, he sat down to table with the twelve disciples.
While they were eating, he said, "I tell you for sure, one of you will betray me."
They were exceedingly saddened, and each one began to ask him, "It is not I, is it, Lord?"
He answered, "Whoever has dipped his hand with me in the dish will betray me.
The Son of Man goes as it is written of Him, but woe to the man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would be better for this man if he had not been born. »
Judas, who betrayed him, replied, "It is not I, is it, Rabbi?" He said to her, "You said so."
While they were eating, Jesus took bread, gave thanks for it, and broke it. He gave it to the disciples, saying, "Take, eat; This is my body. »
Then he took the cup, gave thanks, and gave it to them, saying, Drink of it, all of you,
for this is my blood, the blood of the new covenant, which is shed for many, for the remission of sins.
But I say to you, I will not drink of this fruit of the vine from now on, until the day I drink it again with you in my Father's Kingdom. »
After singing a hymn, they went to the Mount of Olives.
Then Jesus said to them, "You will all be offended by me this night, for it is written, 'I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep of the flock will be scattered.'"
But when I am risen, I will go before you to Galilee. »
But Peter answered him, "Even if all fall because of you, I will never fall."
Jesus said to him, "Verily, I say to you, tonight, before the crows, you shall deny me three times."
Peter said to him, "Even if I have to die with you, I will not deny you." All the disciples also said the same thing.
Jesus came with them to a place called Gethsemane, and said to his disciples, "Sit here, while I go there and pray."
He took Peter and the two sons of Zebedee with him, and he began to feel sorrow and great anxiety.
He then said to them, "My soul is exceedingly sorrowful, unto death. Stay here and watch with me. »
He advanced a little, fell on his face, and prayed thus: "My Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass away from me; However, this is not what I want, but what you want. »
And when he came to the disciples, he found them asleep, and said to Peter, "What, you have not been able to watch with me for an hour?"
Watch and pray, so that you do not fall into temptation. The mind is well disposed, but the flesh is weak. »
A second time he went and prayed, saying, "Father, if this cup cannot pass from me without my drinking it, let your desire be fulfilled."
He returned and found them asleep, for their eyes were heavy.
He left them again, went away, and prayed a third time, saying the same words.
Then he approached his disciples and said to them, "Are you still sleeping and resting? Behold, the hour is at hand, and the Son of Man is delivered into the hands of sinners.
Get up, let's go. Behold, he who betrays me is very near. »
While he was still speaking, behold, Judas, one of the twelve, arrived, and with him a great crowd armed with swords and staves, from the chief priests and the elders of the people.
Now the one who betrayed him had given them a sign, saying, "He whom I kiss is he. Enter. »
Immediately he approached Jesus, said, "Hail, Rabbi!" and kissed him.
Jesus said to him, "Friend, why are you here?" Then they came and laid their hands on Jesus, and seized him.
And behold, one of those who were with Jesus stretched out his hand and drew his sword; he struck the servant of the high priest, and cut off his ear.
Then Jesus said to him, "Put your sword back in its place, for all those who take the sword will die by the sword.
Or do you think that I could not ask my Father, and that he would send me even now more than twelve legions of angels?
How would the Scriptures then be fulfilled that this should be so? »
At that hour, Jesus said to the crowd, "Have you gone out like a robber, with swords and staves, to seize me? I sat in the temple every day to teach, and you did not stop me.
But all this happened in order that the scriptures of the prophets might be fulfilled. Then all the disciples left him and fled.
Those who had taken Jesus took him to the high priest Caiaphas, where the scribes and elders were assembled.
But Peter followed him at a distance to the court of the high priest; he entered and sat down with the officers, to see the end.
The chief priests, the elders, and all the council sought false witness against Jesus, in order to put Him to death.
but they found none. They found none. Many false witnesses came forward, but they found none. But at last, two false witnesses presented themselves
and said, "This man said, I can destroy the temple of God, and rebuild it in three days."
The high priest stood up and said to him, "Do you not answer? What are these people who testify against you? »
But Jesus was silent. The high priest answered him, "I adjure you by the living God to tell us if you are the Christ, the Son of God."
Jesus said to him, "You said so. However, I say to you, after this, you will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of power, and coming on the clouds of heaven. »
Then the high priest tore his garments, saying, "He has uttered blasphemy! Why do we need more witnesses? Behold, you have heard his blasphemy.
What do you think? They answered, "He is worthy to die!" »
Then they spat in his face, struck him with their fists, and some slapped him,
saying, "Prophesy to us, Christ! Who struck you? »
Now Peter was sitting outside in the courtyard, and a servant came to him and said, "You also were with Jesus, the Galilean."
But he denied it in front of them all, saying, "I don't know what you're talking about."
As he had gone out to the portico, someone else saw him and said to those who were there, "This man also was with Jesus of Nazareth."
He again denied it with an oath: "I don't know this man."
After a while, those who were there came and said to Peter, "Surely you also are one of them, for your speech makes you known."
Then he began to swear and curse, "I don't know this man!" Immediately, the crowed.
Peter remembered the words that Jesus had spoken to him: "Before the crows, you shall deny me three times." Then he went out and wept bitterly.
As soon as morning came, all the chief priests and the elders of the people held a council against Jesus to put him to death.
They bound him, took him away, and delivered him up to Pontius Pilate, the governor.
Then Judas, who was betraying him, seeing that Jesus was condemned, was remorseful, and brought the thirty pieces of silver back to the chief priests and elders.
saying, "I have sinned in giving up innocent blood." But they said, "What does it matter to us? Take care of it. »
