He threw the silver coins into the sanctuary and went away. Then he went away and hanged himself.
The chief priests took the silver coins and said, "It is not lawful to put them in the treasury, since it is the price of blood."
They held a council, and with them they bought the potter's field to bury the strangers in.
This is why this field has been called "the field of blood" to this day.
Then was fulfilled what had been foretold by Jeremiah the prophet, in these words, "They have taken the thirty pieces of silver, the price of him who had been bought, which some of the children of Israel have prized,
and they gave them for the potter's field, as the Lord commanded me. »
Now Jesus was standing before the governor; and the governor questioned him, saying, "Are you the king of the Jews?" Jesus said to him, "This is what you say."
When he was accused by the chief priests and elders, he made no reply.
Then Pilate said to him, "Do you not hear how many things they testify against you?"
He did not answer him, not even a word, so that the governor was very much astonished.
Now, on the occasion of the festival, the governor was in the habit of releasing to the crowd a prisoner they desired.
They then had a notable prisoner, named Barabbas.
When they were assembled, Pilate said to them, "Whom do you want me to release you? Barabbas, or Jesus who is called the Christ? »
For he knew that it was out of jealousy that they had betrayed him.
As he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent him to say, "Do not meddle with this righteous man, for I have suffered much today in a dream for his sake."
Now the chief priests and elders persuaded the crowd to ask for Barabbas and to destroy Jesus.
But the governor replied, "Which of the two do you want me to release you?" They said, "Barabbas!"
Pilate said to them, "What shall I do to Jesus, who is called Christ?" They all said to him, "Let him be crucified!"
But the governor said, "Why? What harm has he done? But they cried out loudly, saying, "Let him be crucified! »
Then, seeing that nothing was gained, but that on the contrary they were beginning to make a ruckus, Pilate took water and washed his hands in front of the crowd, saying, "I am innocent of the blood of this righteous man. You make sure of it. »
All the people answered, "Let his blood be on us and on our children!"
Then he released Barabbas to them, but he scourged Jesus and handed him over to be crucified.
Then the governor's soldiers took Jesus into the praetorium, and gathered the whole garrison against him.
They stripped him and clothed him in a scarlet robe.
They plaited a crown of thorns and put it on his head, and a reed in his right hand. They knelt before him and mocked him, saying, "Hail, king of the Jews!"
They spat on him, took the reed and beat him on the head.
After mocking him, they took off his cloak, clothed him in his garments, and took him away to crucify him.
When they went out, they found a man from Cyrene named Simon, and they compelled him to walk with them, so that he might carry his cross.
When they came to a place called Golgotha, that is, the place of the skull,
they gave him to drink sour wine mixed with gall. When he had tasted it, he would not drink.
After crucifying him, they divided his clothes among themselves by drawing lots,
and they sat there to look at him.
They put above his head the accusation against him, written: "It is Jesus, the king of the Jews."
And there were two robbers crucified with him, one on his right and the other on his left.
The passers-by blasphemed him, shaking their heads
and saying, "You who destroy the temple and rebuild it in three days, save yourself! If you are the Son of God, come down from the cross! »
In the same way, the chief priests, mocking the scribes, Pharisees, and elders, said:
"He has saved others, but he cannot save himself. If he is the king of Israel, let him come down from the cross now, and we will believe in him.
He trusts in God. May God deliver him now, if he wills, for he has said, "I am the Son of God."
The robbers also, who were crucified with him, threw the same reproach upon him.
Now from the sixth hour there was darkness over the whole land until the ninth hour.
About the ninth hour, Jesus cried out with a loud voice, saying, "Eli, Eli, lima sabachthani?" That is, "My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?"
Some of those who were standing there, when they heard him, said, "This man calls Elijah."
Immediately one of them ran to take a sponge, filled it with vinegar, placed it on a reed and gave it something to drink.
The others said, "Leave him. Let's see if Elijah will come to save him. »
Jesus cried out again with a loud voice, and gave up his spirit.
Behold, the veil of the temple has been torn in two, from top to bottom. The earth shook and the rocks split.
The sepulchres were opened, and many bodies of saints who had fallen asleep were resurrected.
And coming out of the tombs after his resurrection, they entered the holy city and appeared to many people.
Now the centurion and those who were with him and who were watching Jesus, seeing the earthquake and what was happening, were seized with terror and said, "Truly, this was the Son of God!"
There were many women there who were watching from afar, and who had followed Jesus from Galilee, to serve him.
Among them were Mary Magdalene, Mary, mother of James and Joses, and the mother of the sons of Zebedee.
When evening came, there came a rich man from Arimathea, named Joseph, who was also the disciple of Jesus.
This man went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus. Pilate ordered the body to be handed over to him.
Joseph took the body and wrapped it in a clean cloth
and laid him in his new tomb, which he had hewn out of the rock. Then he rolled a large stone against the entrance to the tomb, and went away.
Mary Magdalene was there, with the other Mary, seated in front of the tomb.
The day after the day of preparation, the chief priests and Pharisees assembled to Pilate.
and said, "Lord, we remember what this deceiver, when he was still alive, said, 'After three days I will rise again.'
Command, therefore, that the tomb be placed in safety until the third day, lest his disciples come at night to take him away and say to the people, "He has risen from the dead"; and the last deception will be worse than the first. »
Pilate said to them, "You have a guard. Come on, secure it as much as you can. »
So they went with the guard and secured the tomb, sealing the stone.
After the Sabbath, as dawn began to break on the first day of the week, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary came to see the tomb.
And behold, there was a great earthquake; for an angel of the Lord came down from heaven, and rolled away the stone of the door, and sat down on it.
His appearance was like lightning, and his garment white as snow.
Out of fear of him, the guards trembled and became like dead people.
The angel answered the women, "Do not be afraid, for I know that you are looking for Jesus, who was crucified.
He is not here, for he is risen, as he had said. Come, see the place where the Lord was lying.
Go quickly and say to his disciples, "He has risen from the dead, and behold, he is going before you into Galilee; it is there that you will see him". Here I have told you. »
They quickly departed from the tomb, with fear and great joy, and ran to bring the news to his disciples.
As they were about to announce it to his disciples, behold, Jesus came to meet them, saying, "Rejoice!" They came and took hold of his feet and adored him.
Then Jesus said to them, "Do not be afraid. Go and tell my brothers that they must go to Galilee, and there they will see me. »
As they were leaving, behold, guards entered the city and told the chief priests all that had happened.
After meeting with the elders and deliberating, they gave the soldiers a large sum of money,
saying, "Say that his disciples came by night and carried him off while we were sleeping.
If it comes to the governor's ears, we will persuade him and free you from all worries. »
So they took the money and did as they were told. This proverb spread among the Jews and continues to this day.
The eleven disciples went to Galilee, to the mountain where Jesus had sent them.
When they saw him, they bowed down to him; but some doubted.
Jesus came to them and spoke to them thus: "All authority has been given to me in heaven and on earth.
Go, make disciples of all nations, baptize them in the name of the Father, of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit,
and teach them to observe all that I have commanded you. And behold, I am with you always, until the end of the age. Amen.
The beginning of the Good News of Jesus Christ, the Son of God.
As it is written in the prophets, "Behold, I send my messenger before your face, who will prepare your way before you:
the voice of him crying in the wilderness, Prepare the way of the Lord! Make his paths straight! »
John came to baptize in the wilderness and preach the baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.
All the land of Judea and all the land of Jerusalem came to him. They were baptized by him in the Jordan, confessing their sins.
John was dressed in camel hair and wore a leather belt at his waist. It fed on locusts and wild honey.
He preached, saying: "After me comes him who is more powerful than I, and whose strap I am not worthy to untie from his sandals.
I have baptized you in water, but he will baptize you in the Holy Spirit. »
At that time, Jesus came from Nazareth in Galilee and was baptized by John in the Jordan.
As soon as he rose from the water, he saw the heavens split and the Spirit descend on him like a dove.
A voice came out of heaven: "You are my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased."
Immediately, the Spirit pushed him into the desert.
He stayed there, in the desert, forty days, tempted by Satan. He was with the wild animals, and the angels served him.
After John was taken into custody, Jesus came to Galilee, preaching the Good News of the Kingdom of God,
and saying, "The time is fulfilled, and the Kingdom of God is at hand. Repent, and believe in the Good News. »
As he passed along the Sea of Galilee, he saw Simon and Andrew, Simon's brother, who were casting a net into the sea, for they were fishermen.
Jesus said to them, "Come after me, and I will make you fishers of men."
Immediately they left their nets and followed him.
Going a little way from there, he saw James, son of Zebedee, and John, his brother, who were also in the boat to repair the nets.
Immediately he called them, and they left their father Zebedee in the boat with the hirelings, and followed him.
They went to Capernaum, and immediately on the Sabbath day he went into the synagogue and taught.
They were astonished at his teaching, for he taught them as having authority, and not as the scribes.
Immediately there was found in their synagogue a man possessed by an unclean spirit, who uttered a cry
saying: "Ah! what have we to do with you, Jesus, Nazarene? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are: the Holy One of God! »
Jesus rebuked him, saying, "Be silent, and come out of him!"
The impure spirit, which convulsed him and cried out in a loud voice, came out of him.
They were all amazed, and they asked one another, saying, "What is this?" A new doctrine? For he commands with authority even unclean spirits, and they obey him! »
The news of his coming immediately spread throughout the region of Galilee and its surroundings.
As soon as they came out of the synagogue, they entered the house of Simon and Andrew, with James and John.
Now the mother of Simon's wife was sick with fever, and immediately she was told about it.
He came, took her by the hand and made her stand up. The fever immediately left her, and she served them.
In the evening, at sunset, all the sick and those who were possessed by demons were brought to him.
The whole town was gathered at the gate.
He healed many sick people with various diseases and cast out many demons. He did not allow demons to speak, for they knew him.
Early in the morning, while it was still dark, he got up and went out, and went to a lonely place, where he prayed.
Simon and those who were with him were looking for him.
They found him and said to him, "Everyone is looking for you."
He said to them, "Let us go elsewhere, to the neighboring cities, so that I may preach there also, for that is why I went out."
He went to their synagogues, throughout Galilee, preaching and casting out demons.
A leper approached him, begged him, knelt before him and said, "If you will, you can make me clean."
Moved with compassion, he stretched out his hand, touched him and said: "I want it. Be purified. »
As soon as he had said this, the leprosy immediately withdrew from him and he was made clean.
He gave him a strict warning and sent him away immediately,
saying to him, "See that you do not say anything to anyone, but go and show yourself to the priest and offer for your purification the things that Moses commanded, as a testimony for them."
But he went out, and began to advertise much, and to spread the matter, so that Jesus could no longer enter a city openly, but stood outside, in deserted places. People came to him from everywhere.
A few days after, he again entered Capernaum, and it was learned that he was at home.
Immediately many gathered together, so that there was no more room, not even around the door; and he spoke to them.
Four people came, carrying a paralytic.
As they could not approach him because of the crowd, they removed the roof where he was. After breaking it, they lowered the mat on which the paralytic was lying.
Jesus, seeing their faith, said to the paralytic, "My son, your sins are forgiven you."
But some of the scribes, sitting there, reasoned in their hearts:
"Why does this man utter such blasphemies? Who can forgive sins if not God alone? »
Immediately, Jesus, seeing in his mind that they were reasoning thus in themselves, said to them, "Why do you reason thus in your hearts?
Which is easier, to say to the paralytic, "Your sins are forgiven," or to say to him, "Arise, take up your bed, and walk?"
But that you may know that the Son of Man has power on earth to forgive sins, he said to the paralytic:
I tell you, get up, take your bed and go to your house.
He got up, immediately took the carpet and went out before them all, so that they were all amazed and glorified God, saying, "We have never seen anything like it!"
He went out again to the seashore. The whole crowd came to him, and he taught them.
As he passed, he saw Levi, son of Alphaeus, sitting at the tax office. He said to him, "Follow me." And he got up and followed him.
He was at table in his house, and many publicans and sinners were sitting with Jesus and his disciples, for they were many, and they followed him.
The scribes and Pharisees, seeing that he ate with sinners and publicans, said to his disciples, "Why does he eat and drink with publicans and sinners?"
When Jesus heard this, he said to them, "Those who are healthy do not need a doctor, but those who are sick. I have come not to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance. »
John's disciples and the Pharisees were fasting, and they came to him and asked, "Why do John's disciples and the disciples of the Pharisees fast, but your disciples do not fast?"
Jesus said to them, "Can the bride and groom fast as long as the bridegroom is with them? As long as they have the bridegroom with them, they cannot fast.
But the days will come when the bridegroom will be taken away from them, and then they will fast in that day.
No one sews a piece of unsoaked fabric on an old garment, otherwise the piece will shrink and the new one will come off the old one, and the hole is worse.
No one puts new wine in old wineskins, or the new wine bursts the wineskins, and the wine spills out, and the wineskins are destroyed; but new wine is put in new wineskins. »
He was passing through the wheat fields on the Sabbath, and his disciples began to pluck up the ears.
The Pharisees said to him, "Behold, why do they do what is not lawful on the Sabbath?"
He said to them, "Have you never read what David did when he was in need and hungry, and those who were with him?
How did he enter the house of God at the time when Abiahar, the high priest, ate the shewbread, which it is not lawful to eat, except for the priests, and gave it also to those who were with him? »
He said to them, "The Sabbath was made for man, and not man for the Sabbath.
Therefore the Son of Man is Lord even of the Sabbath. »
He went into the synagogue again, where there was a man whose hand was withered.
They watched him, to know if he was going to heal him on the Sabbath, in order to accuse him.
He said to the man whose hand was withered, "Arise."
He said to them, "Is it lawful on the Sabbath to do good or to do evil? To save a life or to kill? But they remained silent.
After looking at them angrily, saddened by the hardness of their hearts, he said to the man, "Stretch out your hand." He stretched it out, and his hand was made as sound as the other.
The Pharisees went out, and immediately conspired with the Herodians against him, in order to destroy him.
Jesus withdrew to the sea with his disciples. A great crowd followed him, coming from Galilee, from Judea,
of Jerusalem, of Idumea, beyond the Jordan, and of the vicinity of Tyre and Sidon. A great crowd, hearing what great things he was doing, came to him.
He told his disciples to leave a small boat near him, because of the crowd, so that they would not press him.
For he had healed many people, so that all those who had diseases crowded against him to touch him.
The unclean spirits, as soon as they saw him, prostrated themselves before him and cried out, "You are the Son of God!"
He sternly advised them not to make it known.
He went up to the mountain, called to himself those whom he wanted, and they went to him.
He appointed twelve of them, that they should be with him, and that he should send them out to preach
and have the power to heal diseases and cast out demons:
Simon, to whom he gave the name of Peter;
James, son of Zebedee, and John, brother of James, whom he called Boanerges, which means Son of Thunder;
Andrew, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James, son of Alphaeus, Thaddeus, Simon the Zealot;
and Judas Iscariot , who also betrayed him . Then he entered a house.
The crowd gathered again, so that they could not even eat bread.
His friends, when they heard of it, began to seize him, for they said, "He is mad."
The scribes who came down from Jerusalem said, "He has Beelzebub," and "It is by the prince of demons that he casts out demons."
He summoned them together and said to them in parables, "How can Satan drive out Satan?"
If a kingdom is divided against itself, that kingdom cannot subsist.
If a house is divided against itself, this house cannot stand.
If Satan has risen up against himself, and if he is divided, he cannot stand, but he has an end.
But no one can enter the house of the strong man to plunder, unless he first binds the strong man; then he will plunder his house.
"Verily, I say unto you, all the sins of the descendants of man shall be forgiven, including their blasphemies;
but he who blasphemes against the Holy Spirit has never been forgiven, but is subject to eternal condemnation. »
-because they said, "He has an unclean spirit."
His mother and brothers arrived, and, standing outside, they sent for him.
A crowd was sitting around him, and they said to him, "Here is your mother, your brothers, and your sisters looking for you outside."
He said to them, "Who are my mother and my brothers?"
Looking at those who were sitting around him, he said, "Behold my mother and my brothers!
For whoever does the will of God is my brother, my sister, and my mother. »
He again began to teach by the sea. A great crowd had gathered around him, so that he got into a boat on the sea and sat down. The whole crowd was on land, by the sea.
He taught them many things in parables, and said to them in his teaching:
"Listen! Behold, the farmer has gone out to sow.
As he sowed some of the seed fell along the way, and the birds came to devour it.
Others fell on the rocky ground, where there was little earth, and immediately they grew, because they had no depth of earth.
When the sun rose, she was burned; and as it had no root, it withered up.
Others have fallen among the thorns; the thorns grew and choked him, and he gave no fruit.
Others fell into the good soil and bore fruit, growing and increasing. Some produced thirty times, others sixty times, and others a hundred times more. »
He said, "He who has ears to hear, let him hear."
When he was alone, those who surrounded him with the twelve asked him about the parables.
He said to them, "To you has been given the mystery of the kingdom of God; but for those outside, everything happens in parables,
so that, seeing , they do not see, and hearing they do not hear, lest they be converted and their sins be forgiven them. »
He said to them, "Do you not understand this parable? How will you understand all the parables?
The farmer sows the word.
Those who are by the wayside are those where the word is sown; and when they have heard, immediately Satan comes and takes away the word that has been sown in them.
In the same way, it is those who are strewn on the rocks, who, when they have heard the word, immediately receive it with joy.
They have no roots in themselves, but they are ephemeral. When oppression or persecution arises because of speech, they immediately stagger.
Others are those who are sown among thorns. These are those who have heard the word,
but the cares of the present age, the seduction of riches, and the lusts that are creeping in, stifle speech, and render it fruitless.
Those who have been sown in good soil are those who hear the word, receive it, and bear fruit, some thirty times, some sixty times, others a hundred times. »
He said to them, "Shall a lamp be brought to put under a basket or under a bed? Isn't it put on a support?
For there is nothing hidden, except to be known, and there is nothing secret, except to be brought to light.
If anyone has ears to hear, let him hear. »
He said to them, "Take heed of what you hear. With whatever measure you measure, you will be measured, and more will be given to those who hear.
For he who has, more will be given to him; and he who has not, even what he has will be taken away from him. »
He says, "The kingdom of God is like a man who sows seed on the earth,
who sleeps and rises night and day, and whose seed rises and grows without his knowing how.
For the earth bears fruit of itself: first the blade, then the ear, then the whole grain in the ear.
But when the fruit is ripe, he immediately puts in the sickle, for the harvest has come. »
He said, "How are we going to compare the Kingdom of God? Or with what parable shall we illustrate it?
It is like a mustard seed, which, when sown in the ground, although it is inferior to all the seeds that are found on the ground,
but which, when sown, grows and becomes larger than all the grasses, and grows great branches, so that the birds of the air can dwell under its shade. »
It was by many parables of this kind that he addressed them, according as they were able to hear it.
Without a parable, he did not speak to them, but he explained everything privately to his own disciples.
That day, when evening came, he said to them: "Let us go to the other shore."
Leaving the crowd, they took him with them, as he was, in the boat. Other boats were also with him.
A great storm of wind arose, and the waves struck the boat, until it was already filled.
He himself was in the stern, asleep on the cushion; they woke him up and asked him, "Master, does it not matter to you that we are dying?"
He awoke, threatened the wind, and said to the sea, "Peace! Rest assured! The wind ceased, and there was a great calm.
He said to them, "Why are you so afraid? How come you don't have faith? »
They were seized with great fear, and said to one another, "Who is this, that even the wind and the sea obey him?"
They came to the other side of the sea, to the land of the Gadarenes.
As soon as he got out of the boat, a man possessed of an unclean spirit came to meet him outside the tombs.
He dwelt in the sepulchres. No one could bind him anymore, not even with chains,
for he had often been bound with fetters and chains, and the chains had been torn by him, and the fetters broken into pieces. No one had the strength to tame him.
Always, night and day, in the tombs and in the mountains, he uttered cries and slashed himself with stones.
Seeing Jesus from afar, he ran to prostrate himself before him,
and cried out with a loud voice, "What have I to do with you, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beseech thee by God, do not torment me. »
For he said to him, "Come out of this man, you unclean spirit!"
He asked him, "What is your name?" He said to him, "My name is Legion, for there are many of us."
He begged him very much not to send them out of the country.
Now, on the side of the mountain, there was a large herd of pigs grazing.
All the demons begged him, saying, "Send us to the swine, that we may enter into them."
Immediately, Jesus gave them permission. The unclean spirits came out and entered the pigs. The herd of about two thousand people threw themselves from the top of the steep shore into the sea, and they were drowned in the sea.
Those who had fed the pigs fled and told the city and the country. People came to see what had happened.
They came to Jesus, and saw the demoniac sitting, clothed and sane, even the one who had the legion; and they were afraid.
Those who had seen him told them what had happened to him who was possessed by demons, and what concerned the pigs.
They began to beg him to get away from their region.
As he entered the boat, the one who had been possessed by demons begged him to be allowed to be with him.
He did not allow him, but said to him, "Go to your house, to your friends, and tell them of the great things that the Lord has done for you, and how he has had mercy on you."
He went away, and began to proclaim in the Decapolis how great things Jesus had done for him, and everyone was astonished.
When Jesus had crossed the boat again to the other side, a great crowd gathered around him, and he was on the seashore.
And behold, one of the rulers of the synagogue arrived, named Jairus. Seeing him, he threw himself at his feet
and begged him much, saying, "My little girl is at the point of death. Come, I pray you, lay your hands on her, that she may be healed and live. »
He went with him. A great crowd followed him, and pressed against him on all sides.
A woman who had had blood loss for twelve years,
who had suffered much at the hands of many physicians, who had spent all she possessed, and who was not cured, but rather who was getting worse,
having heard of Jesus, came behind him in the crowd and touched his clothes.
For she said, "If I only touch her clothes, I will be healed."
Immediately, the flow of her blood dried up, and she felt in her body that she was cured of her misfortune.
Immediately, Jesus, perceiving in himself that power had gone out of him, turned around in the crowd and asked, "Who has touched my garments?"
His disciples said to him, "You see the crowd pressing against you, and you say, 'Who has touched me?'
He looked around to see the one who had done this.
But the woman, frightened and trembling, knowing what had been done to her, came and threw herself on the ground before him, and told him the whole truth.
He said to her, "My daughter, your faith has healed you. Go in peace, and be cured of your sickness. »
While he was still speaking, people came from the house of the ruler of the synagogue, saying, "Your daughter is dead. Why bother the master again? »
But Jesus, having heard the message spoken, immediately said to the ruler of the synagogue, "Do not be afraid, only believe."
He allowed no one to follow him, except Peter, James, and John, brother of James.
He came to the house of the ruler of the synagogue, and he saw a tumult, weeping, and great lamentation.
When he came in, he said to them, "Why do you make noise and weep? The child is not dead, but he is asleep. »
They laughed at him. But he, having put them all out, took the father of the child, his mother, and those who were with him, and he went in to the place where the child was lying.
Taking the child by the hand, he said to him: "Talitha cumi!", which means, according to the interpretation, "Little girl, I say to you, get up!"
Immediately the young girl got up and walked, for she was twelve years old. They were seized with great astonishment.
He strictly ordered them that no one should know, and ordered that they give him something to eat.
He started from there. He came to his own country, and his disciples followed him.
When the Sabbath came, he began to teach in the synagogue. Many people who heard him were astonished, and said, "Where did this man get these things?" and "What is the wisdom that has been given to this man, that such works should be accomplished by his hands?
Is it not the carpenter, son of Mary and brother of James, Joses, Judah and Simon? Are not his sisters here with us? So they were offended by him.
Jesus said to them, "A prophet is not without honor, except in his own country, among his relatives, and in his house."
There he could do no powerful work, except that he laid his hands on some sick people and healed them.
He was astonished at their incredulity. He went through the villages teaching.
He called the twelve to him, and began to send them two by two; and he gave them authority over the unclean spirits.
He ordered them not to take anything with them for their journey, except a stick only: neither bread, nor wallet, nor money in their purse,
but to wear sandals, and not to put on two tunics.
He said to them, "Where you enter a house, stay there until you come out.
If anyone does not receive you and does not listen to you, shake off the dust that is under your feet, as a testimony against him. Verily, I say to you, on the day of judgment, Sodom and Gomorrah will be more tolerable than that city. »
They went and preached that people repent.
They cast out many demons, and they anointed many sick with oil and healed them.
King Herod heard this, for his name was known, and he said, "John the Baptist has risen from the dead, and therefore these forces are working in him."
But others said, "This is Elijah." Others said, "He is a prophet, or like one of the prophets."
Herod, having heard this, said, "It is John, whom I have beheaded. He rose from the dead. »
For Herod himself had sent to arrest John and had him bound in prison for the sake of Herodias, the wife of Philip, his brother, for he had married her.
For John had said to Herod, "It is not lawful for you to have your brother's wife."
Herodias rose up against him and wanted to kill him, but she could not,
for Herod feared John, knowing that he was a righteous and holy man, and he protected him. When he heard it, he did many things, and he listened to it with pleasure.
An opportune day came when Herod, on his birthday, gave a supper to his nobles, high officials, and rulers of Galilee.
When Herodias' daughter came in and danced, she pleased Herod and those who sat with him. The king said to the maiden, "Ask me what you want, and I will give it to you."
He swore to him, "Whatever you ask of me, I will give you, up to half of my kingdom."
She went out and said to her mother, "What should I ask?" She said, "The head of John the Baptist."
She immediately went in haste to the king and asked him, "I want you to give me the head of John the Baptist on a platter at once."
The king was extremely sorry, but out of consideration for his oaths and for his guests, he would not refuse it.
Immediately the king sent a soldier of his guard and ordered John's head to be brought; he went to behead him in the prison,
brought his head back to a tray and gave it to the young woman; and the young woman gave it to her mother.
When his disciples heard this, they came and took his corpse and laid it in a tomb.
The apostles gathered together to Jesus, and they told him all that they had done and all that they had taught.
He said to them, "Go to a lonely place, and rest for a while." For there was a lot of coming and going, and they didn't even have time to eat.
So they set out in the boat, and went alone to a lonely place.
They saw them going, and many recognized him and ran there on foot from all the cities. They came before them and gathered to him.
Jesus went out and saw a great crowd, and he had pity on them, because they were like sheep without a shepherd; and he began to teach them many things.
As it was late in the day, his disciples came to him and said, "This place is deserted, and it is late in the day.
Send them away, so that they may go into the surrounding countryside and villages to buy bread, for they have nothing to eat. »
But he replied, "You give them something to eat." They asked him, "Are we going to buy two hundred denarii worth of bread and give them something to eat?"
He said to them, "How many loaves have you got? Go and see. When they found out, they said, "Five and two fish." »
He ordered them to sit in groups on the green grass.
They sat down in rows, by hundreds and by fifty.
He took the five loaves and the two fishes; and raising his eyes to heaven, he blessed and broke the loaves, which he gave to his disciples to set before them, and he divided the two fish among all.
They all ate and were satisfied.
They took twelve baskets full of broken pieces and also fish.
Those who had eaten the loaves were five thousand men.
Immediately he put his disciples in the boat and took them to the other shore, to Bethsaida, while he himself sent the crowd away.
After taking leave of them, he went up to the mountain to pray.
When evening came, the boat was in the middle of the sea, and he was alone on land.
Seeing them in anguish to row, for the wind was against them, about the fourth watch of the night, he came to them, walking on the sea; he would have liked to pass near them,
but they, seeing him walking on the sea, thought it was a ghost and cried out;
for all saw him and were troubled. But immediately he spoke to them and said to them, "Courage! This is me! Don't be afraid. »
He got into the boat with them; and the wind ceased, and they were very astonished among themselves, and were astonished at it;
for they did not understand about the loaves, but their hearts were hardened.
After crossing, they landed at Gennesareth and moored on the shore.
As soon as they got out of the boat, the people recognized him,
and ran throughout the region. They began to bring the sick on their mats to the place where they had heard that he was.
Wherever he entered, in the villages, in the towns or in the countryside, they deposited the sick in the public squares and begged him to allow them to touch the fringe of his garment; and all who touched him were healed.
Then the Pharisees and some of the scribes who had come from Jerusalem gathered around him.
Now, seeing some of his disciples eating bread with filthy, that is, unwashed, hands, they found fault.
(For the Pharisees and all the Jews do not eat without washing their hands and forearms, according to the tradition of the ancients.
They do not eat when they return from the market-place, unless they have washed themselves, and there are many other things they have received to keep to it: the washing of cups, jugs, brass vessels, and sofas).
The Pharisees and scribes asked him, "Why do not your disciples walk according to the tradition of the ancients, and eat their bread with unwashed hands?"
He answered them, "Isaiah has indeed prophesied about you, hypocrites, as it is written, 'This people honor me with their lips, but their hearts are far from me.'
They worship me in vain, teaching as doctrines the commandments of men."
"For you lay aside the commandment of God, and cleave to the tradition of men: you wash pitchers and cups, and do many other things like this."
He said to them, "You have done well to reject the commandment of God, in order to keep your tradition.
For Moses said, "Honor your father and mother, and 'Whoever speaks evil of his father or mother be punished with death.'
But you say, "If a man says to his father or mother, 'All that you have been able to receive from me is Corban,' that is, surrendered to God,
"Then you don't allow him to do anything for his father or mother,
thus nullifying the word of God by the tradition you have handed down." You do a lot of things like that. »
He called the whole crowd to himself and said to them, "Listen to me, all of you, and understand.
There is nothing that comes from outside man and enters into him that can defile him; but what comes out of man is what defiles him.
If anyone has ears to hear, let him hear! »
When he had entered a house, far from the crowd, his disciples asked him about the parable.
He said to them, "Are you also without understanding?" Do you not understand that what enters man from without cannot defile him,
because it does not go into his heart, but into his stomach, and then into the latrine, which makes all food pure? »
He answered, "What comes out of man is what defiles man.
For it is from within, from the heart of man, that evil thoughts, adulteries, sexual sins, murders, thefts, etc.,
lusts, wickedness, deceit, lustful desires, evil eye, blasphemy, pride, and folly.
All these evil things come from within and defile man. »
From there he arose and went into the territory of Tyre and Sidon. He entered a house and did not want anyone to know it, but he could not escape vigilance.
For a woman whose little daughter was afflicted with an unclean spirit, having heard of him, came and threw herself at his feet.
This woman was Greek, of Syrophoenician race. She begged him to cast out the demon from his daughter.
But Jesus said to him, "Let the children be satisfied first, for it is not proper to take the children's bread and throw it to the dogs."
But she answered him, "Yes, Lord. Yet, even the dogs under the table eat the children's crumbs. »
He said to him, "For this word, go away. The demon came out of your daughter. »
She went to her house, and found the child lying on the bed, the demon having come out.
He again left the territory of Tyre and Sidon, and went to the Sea of Galilee through the middle of the Decapolis region.
A deaf man who had speech difficulties was brought to him. They begged him to lay his hand on him.
He took him away from the crowd, in private, and put his fingers in his ears; then he spat and touched his tongue.
Raising his eyes to heaven, he sighed and said to him, "Ephphatha!" that is, "Open up!"
Immediately his ears opened, the impediment of his tongue relaxed, and he spoke plainly.
He commanded them not to tell anyone, but the more he commanded them, the more widely they proclaimed it.
They were extremely astonished and said, "He did everything right. He makes the deaf hear and the dumb speak! »
In those days, when there was a very large crowd and they had nothing to eat, Jesus called his disciples and said to them:
"I have pity on the crowd, because they have stayed with me three days and have nothing to eat.
If I send them home on an empty stomach, they will faint on the way, for some of them have made a long journey. »
His disciples answered him, "Where can these men be satisfied with bread here, in a lonely place?"
He asked them, "How many loaves have you got?" They said, "Seven."
He commanded the crowd to sit on the ground, and he took the seven loaves. After giving thanks, he broke them and gave them to his disciples to serve, and they served the multitude.
They also had some small fish. After blessing them, he told them to serve them also.
They ate and were satisfied. They took away seven baskets of the pieces that were left.
Those who had eaten were about four thousand. Then he sent them away.
Immediately he got into the boat with his disciples and arrived in the region of Dalmanutha.
The Pharisees went out and began to question him, seeking from him a sign from heaven and testing him.
He sighed deeply in his mind and said, "Why is this generation looking for a sign? Verily, I say to you, no sign will be given to this generation. »
He left them, and, getting into the boat again, he set out for the other bank.
They had forgotten to take bread, and they had not more than one loaf with them in the boat.
He warned them, saying, "Beware: beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and the leaven of Herod."
They reasoned among themselves, saying, "It is because we have no bread."
Jesus, perceiving this, said to them, "Why do you think it is because you have no bread? Don't you see yet, don't you understand? Is your heart still hardened?
Having eyes, do you not see? You have ears, do you not hear? Don't you remember?
When I broke the five loaves for the five thousand, how many baskets full of pieces did you take away? They said to him, "Twelve." »
"When the seven loaves fed the four thousand, how many baskets full of pieces did you take away?" They told him, "Seven."
He asked them, "Don't you understand yet?"
He arrived at Bethsaida. A blind man was brought to him, and begged to touch him.
He seized the blind man by the hand, and led him out of the village. After spitting on her eyes and laying on her hands, he asked her if he saw anything.
He looked up and said, "I see men, but I see them as walking trees."
Then, again, he put his hands over her eyes. He looked attentively, and, recovered, he saw everyone clearly.
He sent him back to his house, saying, "Do not go into the village or tell anyone in the village."
Jesus went, with his disciples, to the villages of Caesarea Philippi. On the way, he asked his disciples, "Who do they say I am?"
They said to him, "John the Baptist, others say Elijah, but still others, one of the prophets."
He said to them, "But who do you say I am?" Peter replied, "You are the Christ."
He ordered them not to speak of him to anyone.
He began to teach them that the Son of Man was to suffer much, to be rejected by the elders, chief priests, and scribes, to be killed, and to rise again after three days.
He spoke to them openly. Peter took him and began to rebuke him.
But he, turning around and seeing his disciples, rebuked Peter, and said, "Depart from me, Satan! For you have in view, not the things of God, but the things of men. »
He called the crowd with his disciples and said to them, "Whoever wants to come after me, let him deny himself, take up his cross and follow me.
For whoever wants to save his life will lose it; and whoever loses his life for my sake and the Good News will save it.
For what good is it for a man to gain the whole world and lose his life?
For what will man give in exchange for his life?
For whoever is ashamed of me and of my words in this adulterous and sinful generation, the Son of Man also will be ashamed of him when he comes in the glory of his Father with the holy angels. »
He said to them, "Verily, I say to you, there are some here who will not taste death until they have seen the Kingdom of God come with power."
Six days after, Jesus took Peter, James, and John with him, and brought them up to a high mountain, apart, and he was changed into another form before them.
His garments became sparkling, of extreme whiteness, like snow, such as no launderer on earth can whiten them.
Elijah and Moses appeared to them, and they conversed with Jesus.
Peter answered Jesus, "Rabbi, it is good for us to be here. Let us make three tents: one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah. »
Indeed, he did not know what to say, because they were very afraid.
A cloud came to cover them with his shadow, and a voice came out of the cloud: "This is my beloved Son. Listen. »
Suddenly, looking around them, they saw no one with them, except Jesus alone.
As they came down from the mountain, he commanded them not to tell anyone what they had seen, until the Son of Man had risen from the dead.
They kept this word to themselves, wondering what this "resurrection of the dead" meant.
They questioned him, saying, "Why do the scribes say that Elijah must come first?"
He said to them, "Elijah comes first, and he restores all things. How is it written of the Son of Man that he is to suffer much and be despised?
But I tell you that Elijah came, and that they also did to him as they willed, as it is written of him. »
When he came to the disciples, he saw a great crowd around them, and scribes questioning them.
Immediately, the whole crowd, on seeing him, was very much astonished, and running to him, they saluted him.
He asked the scribes, "What do you ask of them?"
A man of the crowd answered, "Master, I have brought you my son, who has a dumb spirit;
and wherever he seizes him, he throws him to the ground; his mouth is full of foam, grinds his teeth and becomes rigid. I asked your disciples to cast him out, and they couldn't. »
He answered him, "Unbelieving generation, how long shall I be with you? How much longer shall I bear with you? Bring him to me. »
They brought him to him, and when he saw him, the spirit immediately seized him and he fell to the ground, wallowing and foaming at the mouth.
He asked his father, "How long has this been happening to him?" He said, "From childhood.
Often she threw it both into the fire and into the water to destroy it. But if you can do something, have mercy on us and help us. »
Jesus said to him, "If you can believe, all things are possible to him who believes."
Immediately the father of the child cried out, crying: "I believe . Help my disbelief! »
Seeing that a crowd was running, Jesus threatened the unclean spirit, saying to him, "Dumb and deaf spirit, I command you, come out of him, and never enter him again!"
After screaming and subjecting him to strong convulsions, she came out of him. The child became like a dead man, till most of them said, "He is dead."
But Jesus, having taken him by the hand, raised him up, and he arose.
When he entered the house, his disciples asked him privately, "Why couldn't we drive her out?"
He said to them, "This kind can only come out by prayer and fasting."
They set out from there and passed through Galilee. He didn't want us to know,
for he taught his disciples, and said to them, "The Son of Man is delivered into the hands of men, and they will kill him; and when he has been killed, on the third day he will rise again. »
But they did not understand this word, and they were afraid to question him.
He arrived at Capernaum. When he was in the house, he asked them, "What were you discussing among yourselves on the way?"
But they were silent, for they had quarrelled on the way about who was the greatest.
He sat down, called the twelve, and said to them, "If anyone wants to be first, let him be last of all and servant of all."
He took a little child and placed him in the midst of them. Taking him in his arms, he said to them:
"Whoever receives such a little child in my name receives me; and whoever receives me does not receive me, but receives him who sent me. »
John said to him, "Master, we have seen someone who does not follow us, who casts out demons in your name; and we forbade him, because he does not follow us. »
But Jesus said, "Do not hinder him, for there is no one who does a mighty work in my name and who can quickly speak evil of me.
For whoever is not against us is on our side.
For whoever gives you a cup of water to drink in my name, because you are of Christ, I tell you with all certainty, he will not lose his reward in any way.
Whoever causes one of these little ones who believe in me to stumble, it would be better for him to be thrown into the sea, with a millstone hanging from his neck.
If your hand causes you to stumble, cut it off. It is better for you to enter the mutilated life, than to go with your two hands into hell, into the unquenchable fire,
If your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off. It is better for you to enter life with a limp, than to have both feet thrown into hell, into the fire that is not extinguished,
If your eye causes you to stumble, throw it out. It is better for you to enter the kingdom of God with one eye, than to have two eyes to be cast into the hell of fire,
"where their worm does not die and where the fire is not extinguished".
For every one shall be salted by fire, and every sacrifice shall be seasoned with salt.
Salt is good, but if the salt has lost its flavor, what will you season it with? Have salt within yourselves, and be at peace with one another. »
He arose from there and came into the territory of Judea and beyond the Jordan. Crowds gathered again around him. As he usually did, he taught them again.
Some Pharisees came to put him to the test, and asked him, "Is it lawful for a man to divorce his wife?"
He answered, "What did Moses command you?"
They said, "Moses allowed a deed of divorce to be written and divorced from her."
But Jesus said to them, "It is because of your hardness of heart that he has written this commandment to you.
But from the beginning of creation, God made them male and female.
Therefore a man shall leave his father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife,
and the two will become one flesh, so that they will no longer be two, but one flesh.
What God has therefore joined together, let not man separate. »
In the house, his disciples questioned him again on the same question.
He said to them, "Whoever divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery against her.
If a woman herself divorces her husband and marries another, she commits adultery. »
Little children were brought to him to be touched, but the disciples rebuked those who brought them.
But when Jesus saw this, he was indignant and said to them, "Let the little children come to me! Do not hinder them, for the Kingdom of God belongs to those who are like them.
Verily, I say to you, whoever does not receive the Kingdom of God as a little child will not enter it. »
He took them in his arms and blessed them by laying his hands on them.
As he was going out of the way, someone ran to him, knelt before him, and asked him, "Good master, what must I do to inherit eternal life?"
Jesus said to him, "Why do you call me good? No one is good, except one: God.
You know the commandments: Do not commit murder, do not commit adultery, do not steal, do not bear false witness, do not deceive, honor your father and mother. »
He said to him, "Master, I have observed all these things from my youth."
Jesus, looking at him, loved him and said to him, "You lack one thing. Go, sell all you have and give it to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; then come, follow me, taking up the cross. »
But at these words his face fell and he went away sad, for he was a man of great possessions.
Jesus looked around and said to his disciples, "How difficult it is for those who have riches to enter the Kingdom of God!"
The disciples were amazed at his words. But Jesus spoke again: "Children, how difficult it is for those who trust in riches to enter the Kingdom of God!
It is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God. »
They were extremely astonished and said to him, "Then who can be saved?"
Jesus, looking at them, said, "With men it is impossible, but not with God, for all things are possible with God."
Peter began to say to him, "Behold, we have left everything and followed you."
Jesus said, "Verily I say to you, there is no one who, for my sake and for the sake of the Good News, has left his house, his brothers, his sisters, his father, his mother, his wife, his children, or his land;
but he will receive a hundred times more now, in this time: houses, brothers, sisters, mothers, children and lands, with persecutions; and in the age to come, eternal life.
But many of the first will be the last, and the last the first. »
They were on their way, going up to Jerusalem; Jesus passed before them, and they were astonished; those who followed were afraid. He took the twelve again, and began to tell them the things that were about to happen to him.
"Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem. The Son of Man will be delivered up to the high priests and scribes. They will condemn him to death, and deliver him to the pagans.
They will mock him, spit on him, scourge him and put him to death. On the third day, he will rise again. »
James and John, the sons of Zebedee, came to him and said, "Master, we want you to do for us whatever we ask."
He said to them, "What do you want me to do for you?"
They said to him, "Grant that we may sit, one on your right hand, the other on your left, in your glory."
But Jesus said to them, "You do not know what you are asking for. Are you able to drink the cup that I drink, and to be baptized with the baptism with which I am baptized? »
They replied, "We can." Jesus said to them, "For you shall drink the cup that I drink, and you shall be baptized with the baptism with which I am baptized;
but it is not for me to sit on my right hand and on my left, but for Him for whom it has been prepared. »
When the ten heard this, they began to be indignant against James and John.
Jesus summoned them and said to them, "You know that those who are recognized as the rulers of the nations tyrannize over them, and that their great ones exercise their authority over them.
But it will not be so among you: whoever wants to become great among you will be your servant.
Whoever wants to become the first among you will be the servant of all.
For the Son of Man also came, not to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many. »
They arrived at Jericho. As he was coming out of Jericho with his disciples and a great crowd, Bartimaeus, son of Timaeus, a blind beggar, was sitting by the wayside.
When he heard that it was Jesus the Nazarene, he began to cry out and say, "Jesus, son of David, have mercy on me!"
Many rebuked him, so that he would be silent, but he cried out even louder: "You, son of David, have mercy on me!"
Jesus stopped and said, "Call him." They called the blind man and said to him, "Courage! Stand up. He's calling you! »
He threw off his cloak, jumped up and came to Jesus.
Jesus asked him, "What do you want me to do for you?" The blind man said to him, "Rabboni, let me see again."
Jesus said to him, "Go away. Your faith has healed you. Immediately he received his sight and followed Jesus on the way.
When they approached Jerusalem, Bethsphage, and Bethany, to the Mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples
and said to them, "Go to the village in front of you. As soon as you have entered it, you will find a young donkey tied up, on which no one has sat. Untie it and bring it in.
If someone asks you, "Why are you doing this?" say, "The Lord needs him; and immediately he will send him back here. »
They went away, and found a young donkey tied to the door, outside, in the middle of the street, and they untied it.
Some of those who were there asked them, "What are you doing when you untie the young donkey?"
They answered them exactly as Jesus had said, and they let them go.
They brought the young donkey to Jesus, threw their clothes into it, and Jesus sat on it.
Many hung their clothes on the road, and others cut branches of trees and scattered them on the road.
Those who preceded and those who followed shouted, "Hosanna! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord!
Blessed be the kingdom of our father David, who comes in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the highest heavens! »
Jesus entered the temple of Jerusalem. After looking at everything, when evening came, he went to Bethany with the twelve.
The next day, when they left Bethany, he was hungry.
Seeing from a distance a fig tree that had leaves, he approached to see if he could not find something there. When he reached it, he found only leaves, for it was not the season for figs.
Jesus said to him, "Let no one ever eat any more of the fruit of you!" and his disciples heard him.
They arrived in Jerusalem. Jesus went into the temple and began to throw out those who were selling and those who were buying in the temple; he overturned the tables of the moneychangers and the seats of those who sold doves.
He did not allow anyone to carry a vessel into the temple.
He taught them, saying, "Is it not written, 'My house shall be called a house of prayer for all nations?' But you have turned it into a den of thieves! »
The chief priests and the scribes heard him, and they sought how to destroy him. For they feared him, because the whole crowd was astonished at his teaching.
When evening came, he left the city.
As they passed by in the morning, they saw the fig tree dried up to the roots.
Peter, remembering, said to him, "Rabbi, look! The fig tree that you cursed has dried up. »
Jesus answered them, "Have faith in God.
For I say to you verily, whoever says to this mountain, "Take it away and cast it into the sea," and will not doubt in his heart, but will believe that what he says will come to pass, will obtain what he will say.
Therefore I say to you, that whatever you pray and ask for, believe that you have received it, and you shall have it.
Whenever you are in prayer, forgive, if you have anything against anyone, so that your Father, who is in heaven, will also forgive you your transgressions.
But if you do not forgive, your Father who is in heaven will not forgive your transgressions either. »
They returned to Jerusalem. As he walked through the temple, the chief priests, scribes, and elders came to him.
They began to say to him, "By what authority do you do these things? Or who gave you the authority to do these things? »
Jesus said to them, "I am going to ask you a question. Answer me, and I will tell you by what authority I do these things.
Did John's baptism come from heaven or from men? Answer me. »
They reasoned among themselves: "If we say, 'From heaven,' he will say, 'Why did you not believe in him?'
If we say, "Men," they feared the people, for all held John to be a true prophet.
They answered Jesus, "We do not know." Jesus said to them, "Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things."
He began to speak to them in parables. "A man planted a vineyard, surrounded it with a hedge, dug a pit for the winepress, built a tower, rented it to a farmer, and went to another country.
When the time came, he sent a servant to the farmer to ask him for his share of the fruit of the vine.
They took him, beat him, and sent him away empty.
He sent another servant to them again; they threw stones at him, wounded him on the head, and sent him away shamefully.
He sent yet another, and they killed him, and many others, beating some and killing others.
He had a beloved son left, whom he sent last, saying, "They will respect my son."
But the peasants said among themselves, "He is the heir." Come, let us kill him, and the inheritance will be ours.
They took him, killed him, and drove him out of the vineyard.
What will the owner of the vineyard do? He will come and destroy the tenants, and he will give the vineyard to others.
Haven't you even read this scripture? "The stone that the builders rejected was appointed to the head of the corner.
It comes from the Lord. It's wonderful in our eyes"?
They sought to seize him, but they feared the crowd, for they knew that he had spoken the parable against them. They left him and went away.
They sent some of the Pharisees and Herodians to him to ensnare him with words.
When they arrived, they asked him this question: "Master, we know that you are honest and that you bow to no one; for you have no bias for anyone, but you truly teach the way of God. Is it lawful to pay the tax to Caesar, or not?
Should we give, or not give? But he, knowing their hypocrisy, said to them, "Why do you try me? Bring me a denarius, that I may see it. »
They brought it. He said to them, "To whom does this image and inscription belong?" They said to him, "It's Caesar's."
Jesus answered them, "Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and to God the things that are God's." They were very amazed by him.
Some Sadducees, who say that there is no resurrection, came to him. They questioned him, saying:
"Master, Moses wrote to us: 'If a man's brother dies and leaves a woman behind, leaving no children, let his brother take his wife and beget offspring for his brother.'
There were seven brothers. The first took a wife, and died without leaving any descendants.
The second took it, and died, leaving no child behind him. The third did the same;
and the other seven took it and left no children. The last of all women also died.
At the resurrection, when they rise, whose wife will she be? For the seven had her for their wife. »
Jesus answered them, "Is it not because you are in error, knowing neither the Scriptures nor the power of God?
For when they rise from the dead, they will not marry or be given in marriage, but they will be like angels in heaven.
But as for the resurrection of the dead, did you not read in the book of Moses, concerning the bush, how God spoke to him, saying, "I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob"?
He is not the God of the dead, but of the living. You are therefore seriously mistaken. »
One of the scribes, who heard them discussing together, knowing that he had answered them well, asked him, "What is the greatest of all the commandments?"
Jesus answered, "The greatest is, Hear, O Israel, the Lord our God, the Lord is one.
You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, with all your mind, and with all your strength.' This is the first commandment.
The second is thus conceived: "You shall love your neighbor as yourself." There is no other commandment greater than these. »
The scribe said to him, "Truly, master, you have said that he is one and that there is none other than him;
and to love Him with all one's heart, with all one's mind, with all one's soul and with all one's strength, and to love one's neighbor as oneself, is more important than all burnt offerings and sacrifices. »
Seeing that he answered wisely, Jesus said to him, "You are not far from the Kingdom of God." After that, no one dared to ask him any more questions.
Jesus answered, as he was teaching in the temple, "How is it that the scribes say that Christ is the son of David?"
For David himself said in the Holy Spirit, The Lord said to my Lord, "Sit at my right hand, until I make your enemies the footstool of your feet."
That is why David himself calls him Lord, how could he be his son? The common people listened to him with pleasure.
In his teaching, he said to them: "Beware of the scribes, who love to walk about in long robes, to be greeted in the public squares,
to have the best seats in the synagogues and the best seats in the festivals,
those who devour the houses of widows, and who, to pretend, make long prayers. These will receive a greater condemnation. »
Jesus sat down in front of the treasury and saw how the crowd was throwing money into the treasury. Many rich people threw away a lot of it.
A poor widow came, and she threw two small pieces of brass, which are equivalent to a piece of quadrans.
He called his disciples and said to them, "Truly I say to you, this poor widow has given more than all those who give to the treasury,
for all have given of their superfluity, but she, of her poverty, has given all that she had to live on. »
As he was leaving the temple, one of his disciples said to him, "Master, see what kind of stones and what kinds of buildings!"
Jesus said to him, "Do you see these great buildings? There will not remain here stone upon stone, which is not overthrown. »
As he sat on the Mount of Olives, opposite the temple, Peter, James, John, and Andrew asked him privately:
"Tell us, when will this happen? What is the sign that all these things are going to come to pass? »
Jesus answered and began to say to them, "Take care that no one leads you astray.
For many will come in my name, saying, "It is I," and they will lead many people astray.
"When you hear of wars and rumors of wars, do not be disturbed. For it must happen, but the end has not yet come.
For a nation will rise up against a nation, and a kingdom against a kingdom. There will be earthquakes in various places. There will be famines and unrest. These things are the beginning of birth pains.
"But take heed of yourselves, for they will give you up to the councils. You will be beaten in the synagogues. You shall stand before rulers and kings for my sake, to bear witness to them.
First of all, the Good News must be preached to all nations.
When you are taken away and handed over, do not worry beforehand and do not premeditate what you are going to say, but say what will be given to you at the same time. For it is not you who speak, but the Holy Spirit.
"The brother shall deliver his brother to death, and the father his child. Children will rise up against the parents and put them to death.
You will be hated by all because of my name, but he who endures to the end will be saved.
"But when ye shall see the abomination of desolation, of which the prophet Daniel spoke, standing where it ought not to be" (let the reader understand), "let them that are in Judea flee into the mountains,
and let not the one who is on the roof go down and enter to take anything from his house.
Let not the one who is in the field come back to take his cloak.
But woe to those who are pregnant and those who are breastfeeding in those days!
Pray that your escape does not occur in winter.
For in those days there will be such oppression as there has not been since the beginning of God's creation until now, and never will be.
If the Lord had not shortened the days, no flesh would have been saved; but, because of the elect whom he has chosen, he has shortened the days.
If, therefore, anyone says to you, "Behold the Christ," or "Behold, behold," do not believe him.
For false christs and false prophets shall arise, who shall do signs and wonders, in order to lead astray, if possible, even the elect.
But you, watch. "Behold, I have told you everything beforehand.
But in those days, after this oppression, the sun will be darkened, the moon will no longer give its light,
the stars will fall from heaven, and the powers that are in the heavens will be shaken.
Then they will see the Son of Man coming in clouds with great power and glory.
Then he will send his angels, and he will gather his elect from the four winds, from the ends of the earth to the ends of heaven.
"Now learn this parable of the fig tree. When the twig has become tender and is producing its leaves, you know that summer is at hand;
In the same way, you too, when you see these things happening, know that it is near, at the gates.
I tell you with all certainty, this generation will not pass until all these things happen.
Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will not pass away.
But on that day and that hour no one knows, neither the angels in heaven, nor the Son, but the Father alone.
Watch, be vigilant and pray, for you do not know when the time will come.
"It is as if a man were going to another country, leaving his house, giving orders to his servants and to each his work, and ordering the doorkeeper to keep watch.
Watch then, for you do not know when the master of the house will come, either in the evening, or at midnight, or at the crowing of the, or in the morning,
lest when he comes suddenly, he should find you asleep.
What I say to you, I say to all: Watch! »
Two days had passed before the Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread. The chief priests and scribes were looking for ways to get hold of him by trickery and put him to death.
For they said, "Not during the festival, for there might be a riot among the people."
While he was at Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper, and was at table, a woman came, holding an alabaster vessel containing an ointment of pure spikenard, very expensive. She broke the vase and poured some on the leper's head.
But some of them were indignant among themselves, saying, "Why has this perfume been wasted?
For it could have been sold for more than three hundred denarii and given to the poor. So they grumble against her.
But Jesus said, "Leave her alone. Why bother him? She did a good deed for me.
For you always have the poor with you, and when you will, you can do good to them; but you will not always have me.
She did what she could. She anointed my body in advance to bury it.
I tell you in truth, wherever this Good News is preached in the whole world, people will also talk about what this woman did, in memory of her. »
Judas Iscariot, who was one of the twelve, went to the chief priests to deliver him up to them.
When they heard of this, they rejoiced, and promised to give him money. He was looking for how he could deliver it conveniently.
On the first day of the Unleavened Bread, when the Passover is sacrificed, his disciples asked him, "Where do you want us to go to prepare for you to eat the Passover?"
He sent two of his disciples and said to them, "Go to the city, and there a man carrying a pitcher of water will meet you. Follow
and where he enters, say to the householder, "The master said, Where is the guest room, where I can eat the Passover with my disciples?"
He will himself show you a large upper room furnished and ready. Get ready to welcome us there. »
His disciples went out and entered the city; they found things as he had told them, and they prepared for the Passover.
When evening came, he arrived with the twelve.
As they sat and were eating, Jesus said, "I say to you for sure, one of you will betray me, he who eats with me."
They began to be sad and to ask him, one after the other, "Is it not I?" And another said, "It is not I, is it?"
He answered them, "It is one of the twelve, the one who dips with me in the dish.
For the Son of Man goes as it is written of him, but woe to the man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would be better for this man if he had not been born. »
While they were eating, Jesus took bread; and, after blessing it, he broke it and gave it to them, saying, "Take, eat. This is my body. »
He took the cup, and, after giving thanks, he gave it to them. They all drank it.
He said to them, "This is my blood, the blood of the new covenant, which is shed for many.
Verily I say to you, I will not drink of the fruit of the vine again until the day I drink it again in the Kingdom of God. »
After singing a hymn, they went to the Mount of Olives.
Jesus said to them, "You will all be scandalized by me this night, for it is written, 'I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered.'"
However, when I am resurrected, I will go before you to Galilee. »
But Peter said to him, "Although all are offended, I will not be."
Jesus said to him, "I tell you with certainty, this very day, this night, before the crows twice, you shall deny me three times."
But he spoke all the more: "If I must die with you, I will not deny you." They all said the same thing.
They came to a place called Gethsemane. He said to his disciples, "Sit here, while I pray."
He took Peter, James, and John with him, and began to be deeply troubled and afflicted.
He said to them, "My soul is exceedingly sorrowful, even unto death. Stay here and watch. »
He advanced a little, threw himself on the ground, and prayed that, if it were possible, the hour would pass away from him.
He said, "Abba, Father, all things are possible for you. I beg you, take this cup away from me. However, this is not what I desire, but what you desire. »
He came and found them asleep, and he said to Peter, "Simon, are you asleep? Couldn't you stay up for an hour?
Watch and pray, so that you do not fall into temptation. The mind is well disposed, but the flesh is weak. »
He went away again and prayed, saying the same words.
He came again and found them asleep, for their eyes were very heavy, and they did not know what to answer him.
He returned for the third time and said to them, "Sleep now, and rest. That's enough. The time has come. Behold, the Son of Man is delivered into the hands of sinners.
Stand up! Let's go. Behold, he who betrays me is very near. »
Immediately, while he was still speaking, Judas, one of the twelve, arrived, accompanied by a crowd armed with swords and staves, composed of the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders.
Now the one who betrayed him had given them a sign, saying, "He whom I am going to kiss is he. Seize him, and lead him to safety. »
As soon as he arrived, he came up to him and said, "Rabbi! Rabbi! and kissed him.
They laid their hands on him and seized him.
But one of those who were there, drawing his sword, struck the servant of the high priest and cut off his ear.
Jesus answered them, "Did you go out like a robber with swords and sticks to seize me?
I was with you every day in the temple, teaching, and you did not stop me. But it is in order that the Scriptures may be fulfilled. »
They all left him, and fled.
A young man followed him, having thrown a linen cloth around him over his naked body. The young men seized him,
but he left the shroud and fled naked before them.
They took Jesus to the high priest. All the chief priests, the elders, and the scribes met with him.
Peter had followed him at a distance, until he had entered the court of the high priest. He sat with the officers, and warmed himself by the light of the fire.
The chief priests and the whole council were looking for witnesses against Jesus to put him to death, but they found none.
For many bore false witness against him, and their testimonies did not agree with one another.
Some of them arose and gave false testimony against him, saying:
"We have heard him say, 'I will destroy this temple made with hands, and in three days I will build another made with hands.'"
Even so, their testimony did not agree.
The high priest stood up in the middle and asked Jesus, "Have you no answer? What are these people who testify against you? »
But he was silent and said nothing. The high priest asked him again, "Are you the Christ, the Son of the Blessed?"
Jesus says, "I am. You will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of power, and coming with the clouds of heaven. »
The high priest tore his garments and said, "What more need do we have of witnesses?
You have heard the blasphemy! What do you think? They all condemned him to be worthy of death.
Some began to spit on him, to cover his face, to punch him, and to say to him, "Prophesy!" The officers struck him with the palms of their hands.
As Peter was in the courtyard below, one of the servants of the high priest came,
and seeing Peter warming himself, she looked at him and said, "You were also with the Nazarene, Jesus!"
But he denied it, saying, "I do not know or understand what you say." He went out on the porch, and the crowed.
The maid saw him and again began to say to those who were there, "It is one of them."
But he denied it again. After a while, those who were there said to Peter, "You are truly one of them, for you are a Galilean, and your language shows it."
But he began to curse and swear, "I don't know that man you are talking about!"
The rooster crowed. Peter remembered the words Jesus had spoken to him: "Before the crows twice, you shall deny me three times." When he thought of this, he cried.
In the morning, the chief priests, with the elders, the scribes, and all the Sanhedrin, conferred, bound Jesus, took him away, and delivered him up to Pilate.
Pilate asked him, "Are you the king of the Jews?" He replied, "That's what you say."
The chief priests accused him of many things.
Pilate asked him again, "Do you not answer? See how many things they testify against you! »
But Jesus answered no more, which astonished Pilate.
Now, on the occasion of the feast, he used to release a prisoner from them, the one they asked him for.
There was a man named Barabbas, connected with his companions in the insurrection, men who, in the insurrection, had committed murder.
The crowd, uttering loud cries, began to ask him to do as he had always done for them.
Pilate answered them, "Do you want me to release the king of the Jews to you?"
For he knew that it was out of envy that the chief priests had betrayed him.
But the chief priests stirred up the crowd, so that he would release Barabbas to them instead.
Pilate asked them again, "What shall I do to him whom you call the king of the Jews?"
They cried out again, "Crucify him!"
Pilate said to them, "Why, what evil has he done?" But they cried out loudly, "Crucify him!"
Pilate, wishing to please the crowd, released Barabbas to them, and handed over Jesus, after having caused him to be scourged, to be crucified.
The soldiers took him into the courtyard, which is the praetorium, and they summoned the whole cohort.
They clothed him with purple, and, weaving a crown of thorns, they laid it on him.
They began to salute him: "Hail, King of the Jews!"
They struck his head with a reed, spat on him, and, bending their knees, paid homage to him.
After mocking him, they took off his purple mantle and clothed him in his own garments. Then they led him outside to crucify him.
They compelled a passer-by, Simon of Cyrene, father of Alexander and Rufus, to go with them, that he might carry his cross.
They led him to the place called Golgotha, which is, according to the interpretation, "the place of the skull."
They offered him wine mixed with myrrh to drink, but he did not take it.
After crucifying him, they divided his clothes among themselves, drawing lots for each one to take.
It was the third hour when they crucified him.
The inscription of his accusation was written on him: "THE KING OF THE JEWS."
They crucified with him two robbers, one on his right and the other on his left.
Thus is fulfilled the Scripture, which says, "He was numbered among the transgressors."
The passers-by blasphemed him, shaking their heads and saying: "Ha! you who destroy the temple and rebuild it in three days,
save yourself, and come down from the cross! »
In the same way, the chief priests, mocking each other and the scribes, said, "He has saved others. He cannot save himself.
Let Christ, the King of Israel, come down from the cross now, that we may see Him and believe Him. Those who were crucified with him also insulted him.
When the sixth hour arrived, there was darkness over all the earth until the ninth hour.
At the ninth hour, Jesus cried out in a loud voice, "Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani?" which is the same as saying, "My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?"
Some of those who were there, when they heard him, said, "Behold, he is calling Elijah."
Someone ran to fill a sponge with vinegar, put it on a reed and gave it to him to drink, saying, "Leave him. Let's see if Elijah will come to bring him down. »
Jesus uttered a loud cry, and gave up his spirit.
The veil of the temple was torn in two, from top to bottom.
The centurion, who stood opposite him, seeing that he had uttered such a cry and breathed his last, said, "Truly, this man was the Son of God!"
There were also women who looked on from afar, among them Mary Magdalene, Mary, mother of James the Less and Joses, and Salome,
who, when he was in Galilee, followed him and served him, and many other women who went up with him to Jerusalem.
When evening came, as it was the day of preparation, that is, the eve of the Sabbath,
Joseph of Arimathea, a prominent member of the council, who was also seeking the kingdom of God himself, arrived. He boldly went to Pilate, and asked for the body of Jesus.
