Pilate was surprised to learn that he was already dead; and, summoning the centurion, he asked him if he had been dead for a long time.
The centurion having answered him, he gave the body to Joseph.
He bought a linen cloth, lowered the body, rolled it up in the linen cloth and placed it in a tomb hewn in the rock. He rolled a stone against the door of the tomb.
Mary Magdalene and Mary, mother of Joses, saw where he was lying.
When the Sabbath was over, Mary Magdalene, Mary, the mother of James, and Salome bought spices to come and anoint him.
On the first day of the week, very early, they went to the sepulchre at sunrise.
They said to one another, "Who will roll away for us the stone of the entrance to the sepulchre?"
for it was very large. Looking up, they saw that the stone had been rolled back.
On entering the tomb, they saw a young man seated on the right, dressed in a white robe; and they were astonished.
He said to them, "Do not be surprised. You are looking for Jesus, the Nazarene, who was crucified. He is risen! He's not here. Look at the place where they deposited it!
But go and say to his disciples and to Peter, "He is going before you into Galilee. There, you will see him, as he told you. »
They went out and fled from the tomb, for trembling and stupor had seized them. They said nothing to anyone, for they were afraid.
Now, having risen early in the morning, on the first day of the week, he appeared first to Mary Magdalene, from whom he had cast out seven demons.
She went and told those who had been with him, while they were grieving and weeping.
When they heard that he was alive and that she had seen him, they did not believe.
After this, it was revealed in another form to two of them, while they were walking, going into the country.
They went away and told the others. Nor did they believe them.
Then he was revealed to the eleven themselves, while they were at table, and he reproached them for their unbelief and hardness of heart, because they did not believe those who had seen him after his resurrection.
He said to them, "Go into all the world and preach the Good News to all creation.
Whoever believes and is baptized will be saved, but whoever does not believe will be condemned.
These are the signs that will follow those who believe: in my name they will cast out demons; they will speak new languages;
they will seize snakes; if they drink anything deadly, it will do them no harm; they will lay their hands on the sick, and they will heal. »
And so, the Lord, after speaking to them, was received into heaven and sat down at the right hand of God.
They went out and preached everywhere, the Lord working with them and confirming the word by the signs that followed. Amen.
Since many have undertaken to put in order the narrative of the events that have taken place among us,
As those who from the beginning have been eyewitnesses and servants of the word,
it seemed good to me, having from the beginning followed exactly the course of all things, to write to you in order, very excellent Theophilus,
so that you may know for certain the things in which you have been taught.
There was, in the time of Herod, king of Judea, a priest named Zechariah, of the priestly division of Abijah. He had a wife among the daughters of Aaron, and her name was Elizabeth.
They were both righteous before God, walking blameless in all the commandments and ordinances of the Lord.
But they had no children, for Elizabeth was barren, and they were both advanced in years.
Now, while he was exercising the office of priest before God according to the order of his division,
according to the custom of the office of priest, his lot was to enter the temple of the Lord and burn incense there.
All the multitude of the people prayed outside at the hour of incense.
An angel of the Lord appeared to him, standing to the right of the altar of incense.
Zechariah was troubled when he saw him, and fear seized him.
But the angel said to him, "Do not be afraid, Zechariah, for your request has been granted. Your wife, Elizabeth, will bear you a son, and you will call his name John.
You will have joy and gladness, and many will rejoice at his birth.
For he shall be great in the sight of the Lord, and he shall not drink wine or strong drink. He will be filled with the Holy Spirit, from his mother's womb.
He will bring many of the children of Israel back to the LORD, their God.
He will go before him with the spirit and power of Elijah, to turn the hearts of the fathers to the children, and the disobedient to the wisdom of the righteous, to prepare a people for the Lord. »
Zechariah said to the angel, "How can I be sure? For I am an old man, and my wife is well advanced in years. »
The angel answered him, "I am Gabriel, who stands in the presence of God. I have been sent to speak to you and tell you this good news.
Behold, you will be silent, and you will not be able to speak until the day when these things come to pass, because you have not believed my words, which will be fulfilled in their time. »
The people were waiting for Zechariah and were astonished that he was slow to enter the temple.
When he went out, he could not speak to them. They understood that he had seen a vision in the temple. He continued to make signs to them, and he remained silent.
When the days of his service were fulfilled, he went to his house.
After these days, Elizabeth, his wife, became pregnant, and she hid herself for five months, saying:
"This is how the Lord made me in the days that he looked upon me, to take away my reproach among men."
In the sixth month, the angel Gabriel was sent by God to a city in Galilee, called Nazareth,
with a virgin promised in marriage to a man named Joseph, of the house of David. The virgin's name was Mary.
After entering, the angel said to him, "Rejoice, you who are so favored! The Lord is with you. Blessed are you among all women! »
But when she saw him, she was very troubled by these words, and she reflected on how she could be greeted.
The angel said to her, "Do not be afraid, Mary, for you have found favor with God.
Behold, thou shalt conceive in thy womb, and thou shalt give birth to a son, and thou shalt call his name Jesus.
He will be great and will be called the Son of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his father David,
and he will reign over the house of Jacob forever. There will be no end to his reign. »
Mary said to the angel, "How can this be, since I am a virgin?"
The angel answered him, "The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. Therefore also the holy one who is born of you will be called the Son of God.
Behold, Elizabeth, your kinswoman, has conceived a son in her old age, and this is the sixth month of her who was called barren.
For nothing that is said by God is impossible. »
Mary said, "Behold, the handmaid of the Lord; let it be done to me according to your word. Then the angel walked away from her.
In those days Mary got up and went in haste to the mountain, to a city of Judah,
she entered the house of Zechariah and greeted Elizabeth.
When Elizabeth heard Mary's greeting, the child leaped in her womb, and Elizabeth was filled with the Holy Spirit.
She cried out in a loud voice and said, "Blessed are you among women, and blessed is the fruit of your womb!
Why am I so favored, that the mother of my Lord should come to me?
For behold, when the voice of your greeting reached my ears, the baby leaped for joy into my womb!
Blessed is she who believes, for the things that have been spoken to her from the Lord will be fulfilled. »
Mary said, "My soul magnifies the Lord.
My spirit rejoiced in God my Saviour,
for he has looked upon the humble condition of his servant. For from now on, all generations will call me blessed.
For he who is mighty has done great things for me. Holy is his name.
His mercy extends from generation to generation on those who fear him.
He showed strength with his arm. He has scattered the proud in the imagination of their hearts.
He has caused princes to fall from their thrones, and has exalted the humble.
He has filled the hungry with good things. He sent the rich back empty.
He helped Israel, his servant, to remember mercy,
as he spoke to our fathers, to Abraham and to his descendants forever. »
Mary stayed with her for about three months, and then she returned to her house.
The time for Elizabeth to give birth was fulfilled, and she gave birth to a son.
Her neighbors and relatives heard that the Lord had magnified His mercy toward her, and they rejoiced with her.
On the eighth day they came to circumcise the child, and they wanted to call him Zacharias, after his father.
His mother replied, "No, but he will be called John."
They said to him, "There is no one among your relatives who is called by that name."
They made signs to his father, to know what he wanted to be called.
He asked for a tablet and wrote, "His name is John." They were all amazed.
Immediately his mouth was opened and his tongue was loosed, and he spoke blessing God.
Fear took hold of all the inhabitants of the neighborhood, and all these words were spoken throughout the mountain of Judea.
All those who heard them fixed them in their hearts, saying, "What will this child be?" The hand of the Lord was with him.
His father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit, and he prophesied, saying,
"Blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel, for he has visited and redeemed his people;
and he raised up for us a horn of salvation in the house of his servant David.
(as he said through the mouth of his holy prophets who have existed since time immemorial),
the salvation of our enemies and from the hand of all those who hate us;
to show mercy to our fathers, to remember his holy covenant,
the oath he made to Abraham our father,
to grant us that, delivered from the hand of our enemies, must serve him without fear,
in holiness and righteousness before Him all the days of our lives.
And you, my child, will be called a prophet of the Most High; for you will go before the face of the Lord to prepare his ways,
to give knowledge of salvation to his people through the remission of their sins,
because of the tender mercy of our God, by whom the dawn from above will visit us,
to enlighten those who sit in darkness and the shadow of death; to guide our feet on the path of peace. »
The child grew up and became strong in spirit, and he was in the wilderness until the day of his public appearance in Israel.
At that time, a decree of Caesar Augustus provided for the inscription of the whole world.
This was the first inscription made when Quirinius was governor of Syria.
They all went to register, each in his own city.
Joseph also went up from Galilee, from the city of Nazareth, in Judea, to the city of David, called Bethlehem, because he was of the house and family of David,
to register with Mary, promised to marry him, being pregnant.
While they were there, the day had come for her to give birth.
She gave birth to her firstborn son. She wrapped him in strips of cloth and laid him in a manger, for there was no room for them in the inn.
In the same country there were shepherds who stayed in the fields and watched over their flocks by night.
And behold, an angel of the Lord stood by them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified.
The angel said to them, "Do not be afraid, for behold, I bring you good news, great joy, which will be shared by all the people.
For a Saviour is born to you this day in the city of David, who is Christ the Lord.
Here is the sign that is given to you: you will find a baby wrapped in strips of cloth, lying in a manger. »
Suddenly, there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host who praised God and said,
"Glory to God in the highest, on earth peace, good will towards men".
When the angels departed from them in heaven, the shepherds said to one another, "Let us go to Bethlehem, and see what has happened, what the Lord has made known to us."
They came in haste and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby was lying in the manger.
As soon as they saw him, they published widely the word that had been spoken to them about this child.
All who heard him were astonished at what the shepherds had said to them.
But Mary kept all these words, meditating on them in her heart.
The shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all that they had heard and seen, according to what had been announced to them.
When eight days were completed for the circumcision of the child, he was given the name of Jesus, which had been given by the angel before he was conceived in his mother's womb.
When the days of their purification according to the law of Moses were fulfilled, they brought him up to Jerusalem to present him to the Lord
(according to what is written in the law of the Lord: "Every male who opens the bowels shall be called holy to the Lord")
and to offer a sacrifice according to what is said in the law of the Lord: "A pair of turtledoves or two young pigeons."
Behold, there was a man in Jerusalem whose name was Simeon. This man was righteous and pious, he sought the consolation of Israel, and the Holy Spirit was upon him.
It had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit that he was not to see death until he had seen the Christ of the Lord.
He entered the temple by the Spirit. When the parents brought the child Jesus, to act towards him according to the custom of the law,
he received him in his arms, blessed God and said,
"Now thou shalt set thy servant free, O Master, according to thy word, in peace;
for my eyes have seen your salvation,
which you have prepared before the face of all peoples;
a light for revelation to the nations, and the glory of your people Israel. »
Joseph and his mother were astonished at the things that were said about him.
Simeon blessed them, and he said to Mary his mother, "Behold, this child is destined for the fall and rise of many in Israel, and for a sign to be proclaimed.
Yes, a sword will pierce your soul, so that the thoughts of many hearts may be revealed. »
There was a certain Anna, prophetess, daughter of Phanuel, of the tribe of Asher (she was of an advanced age, having lived seven years with a husband since her virginity,
and she had been a widow for about eighty-four years), who did not depart from the temple, prostrating herself night and day with fasts and supplications.
She went up that very hour, gave thanks to the Lord and spoke of him to all those who were waiting for redemption in Jerusalem.
When they had done all that was in accordance with the law of the Lord, they returned to Galilee, to their city, Nazareth.
The child grew and became strong in spirit, he was filled with wisdom, and the grace of God was upon him.
His parents went to Jerusalem every year for the feast of Passover.
When he was twelve years old, they went up to Jerusalem according to the custom of the festival;
and when they had fulfilled the days, as they were returning, the child Jesus remained behind in Jerusalem. Joseph and his mother did not know this,
but, supposing that he was in the company, they went a day's journey; and they sought him among their relatives and acquaintances.
Not finding him, they returned to Jerusalem to look for him.
Three days later, they found him in the temple, sitting in the midst of the masters, listening to them and questioning them.
All who heard him were amazed at his intelligence and his answers.
When they saw him, they were astonished, and his mother said to him, "My son, why have you treated us like this? Behold, your father and I, we were looking for you impatiently. »
He said to them, "Why did you seek me? Did you not know that I must be in my Father's house? »
They did not understand the word he was addressing to them.
And he went down with them and came to Nazareth. He was subject to them, and his mother kept all these words in her heart.
And Jesus grew in wisdom and stature, and in favor with God and men.
In the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, Pontius Pilate being governor of Judea, Herod tetrarch of Galilee, his brother Philip tetrarch of the region of Ituraea and Trachonitis, and Lysanias tetrarch of Abilene,
during the high priesthood of Anna and Caiaphas, the word of God was addressed to John, son of Zechariah, in the wilderness.
He went throughout the Jordan region, preaching the baptism of repentance for the remission of sins.
As it is written in the book of the words of the prophet Isaiah, "The voice of one crying in the wilderness, Prepare the way of the Lord. Make your paths straight.
Every valley will be filled. Every mountain and hill will be made low. The crooked will become straight, and the difficult paths will be smoothed out.
All flesh will see the salvation of God.'
So he said to the crowd that was going out to be baptized by him, "O races of vipers, who warned you to flee from the wrath to come?
Therefore produce fruit worthy of repentance, and do not begin to say among yourselves, "We have Abraham for our father"; for I tell you that God can raise up children for Abraham from these stones!
Now also, the axe is at the root of the trees. Every tree that does not produce good fruit is therefore cut down and thrown into the fire. »
The crowds asked him, "What should we do?"
He replied, "Let him who has two tunics give to him who has none. Let him who has something to eat do the same. »
Tax-collectors also came to be baptized, and they said to him, "Master, what shall we do?"
He said to them, "Do not collect more than is assigned to you."
The soldiers also questioned him, saying, "And we? What should we do? He said to them, "Extort no one by violence, and accuse no one wrongly." Be content with your salary. »
As the people were waiting, and all reasoned in their hearts about John, to know if he was the Christ,
John answered them all, "I baptize you with water, but he comes, mightier than I, whose sandal strap I am not worthy to untie. He will baptize you in the Holy Spirit and in fire.
His van is in his hand; he will clean his threshing floor and gather the wheat in his barn, but he will burn the tares in an unquenchable fire. »
Then, with many other exhortations, he would preach the good news to the people.
But Herod the tetrarch, having been rebuked by him on account of Herodias, his brother's wife, and of all the evil deeds he had committed,
added to all these things that he shut up John in prison.
Now when all the people were baptized, Jesus also had been baptized and he was praying. The sky opened,
and the Holy Spirit descended upon him in a corporeal form, like a dove; and a voice came out of heaven, saying, "You are my beloved Son. In you I have put all my affection. »
Jesus himself, when he began to teach, was about thirty years old; he was the son (as was supposed) of Joseph, son of Eli,
son of Matthat, son of Levi, son of Melchi, son of Jannai, son of Joseph,
son of Mattathiah, son of Amos, son of Nahum, son of Esli, son of Naggai,
son of Maath, son of Matathiah, son of Semein, son of Joseph, son of Judah,
son of Joanan, son of Rhesa, son of Zerubbabel, son of Shealtiel, son of Neri,
son of Melchi , son of Addi , son of Cosam , son of Elmodam , son of Er ,
son of Jose, son of Eliezer, son of Jorim, son of Matthat, son of Levi,
son of Simeon, son of Judah, son of Joseph, son of Jonan, son of Eliakim,
the son of Meleah, the son of Menan, the son of Mattatha, the son of Nathan, the son of David,
the son of Jesse, the son of Obed, the son of Boaz, the son of Salmon, the son of Nahshon,
the son of Amminadab , the son of Aram , the son of Hezron , the son of Perez , the son of Judah ,
the son of Jacob, the son of Isaac, the son of Abraham, the son of Terah, the son of Nahor,
son of Serug, son of Reu, son of Peleg, son of Eber, son of Shelah,
son of Cainan , son of Arphaxad , son of Shem , son of Noah , son of Lamech ,
son of Methuselah, son of Enoch, son of Jared, son of Mahalaleel, son of Cainan,
son of Enos, son of Seth, son of Adam, son of God.
Jesus, filled with the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan and was led by the Spirit into the wilderness
for forty days, to be tempted by the devil. He ate nothing during those days. Then, when they were finished, he was hungry.
The devil said to him, "If you are the Son of God, command this stone to become bread."
Jesus answered him, "It is written, 'Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word of God.'"
The devil, leading him to a high mountain, showed him in an instant all the kingdoms of the world.
The devil said to him, "I will give you all this authority and their glory, for they have been given to me, and I give them to whomever I will.
So if you bow down to me, all this will be yours. »
Jesus answered him, "Go behind me, Satan! For it is written, "You shall worship the Lord your God, and serve no one but him."
He led him to Jerusalem, placed him on the pinnacle of the temple, and said to him, "If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down from here,
for it is written, He will put His angels at your head, to protect you.
and on their hands they shall carry thee, lest thou strike thy foot against a stone. »
Jesus answered and said to him, "It has been said, 'You shall not tempt the Lord your God.'"
When the devil had finished all the temptations, he departed from him until another time.
Jesus returned to Galilee in the power of the Spirit, and the news of his coming spread throughout the surrounding region.
He taught in their synagogues, and was glorified by all.
He went to Nazareth, where he had been brought up. He entered, according to his custom, into the synagogue on the Sabbath, and rose to read.
He was given the book of the prophet Isaiah. He opened the book, and found the place where it was written,
"The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, for he has anointed me to preach the good news to the poor. He has sent me to heal the brokenhearted, to proclaim the liberation of the captives, the recovery of sight for the blind, to deliver the crushed,
and to proclaim the acceptable year of the Lord. »
He closed the book, handed it back to the keeper and sat down. The eyes of all who were in the synagogue were fixed on him.
He began to say to them, "This Scripture has been fulfilled for you today."
All testified to him and were astonished at the gracious words that came from his lips; and they said, "Is not this the son of Joseph?"
He said to them: "You will no doubt say to me this proverb: 'Doctor, heal yourself! All that we heard done in Capernaum, do it also here, in your native city. »
He answered, "Verily, I say to you, no prophet is accepted in his native city.
But verily, I say to you, there were many widows in Israel in the days of Elijah, when heaven was closed for three years and six months, and a great famine came upon the whole land.
Elijah was not sent to any of them, except to Zarephath in the land of Sidon, to a woman who was a widow.
There were many lepers in Israel in the time of the prophet Elisha, and none of them was cleansed except Naaman, the Syrian. »
They were all filled with fury in the synagogue when they heard these things.
They got up, threw him out of the city, and led him to the top of the hill on which their city was built, in order to throw him from the top of the cliff.
But he, passing through the midst of them, went away.
He went down to Capernaum, a city in Galilee. He taught them on the Sabbath,
and they were astonished at his teaching, for his word had authority.
There was in the synagogue a man possessed by the spirit of an unclean demon. He uttered a loud cry,
saying: "Ah! what have we to do with you, Jesus of Nazareth? Have you come to destroy us? I know who you are: the Holy One of God! »
Jesus rebuked him, saying, "Be silent and come out of him!" When the devil had cast him into the midst of them, he came out of him, without having done him any harm.
Stupor seized all, and they spoke together with one another, saying, "What is this word? For it is with authority and power that he commands the unclean spirits, and they go out! »
The news of his coming spread to all the places in the surrounding region.
He got up from the synagogue and went into Simon's house. Simon's mother-in-law was stricken with a high fever, and they begged him to help her.
He stood over her and threatened the fever, which left her. Immediately, she got up and served them.
At sunset, all those who had sick people suffering from various diseases brought them to him; he laid his hands on each of them and healed them.
Demons also came out of many, crying out and saying, "You are the Christ, the Son of God!" Rebuking them, he did not allow them to speak, for they knew that he was the Christ.
When the day came, he set out and went to an uninhabited place. The crowd sought him, approached him and held him back, so that he would not depart from them.
But he said to them, "I must also preach the good news of the Kingdom of God in the other cities. That's why I was sent. »
He preached in the synagogues of Galilee.
As the crowd pressed him and listened to the word of God, he stood by the shore of the lake of Gennesareth.
He saw two boats on the shore of the lake, but the fishermen had come out and were washing their nets.
He got into one of the boats, which was Simon's, and asked him to get a little away from the land. He sat down and taught the crowd from the boat.
When he had finished speaking, he said to Simon, "Go into the deep water and cast your nets for fishing."
Simon answered him, "Master, we have worked all night and we have taken nothing; but at your word, I will cast the net. »
When they had done this, they caught a great quantity of fish, and their net broke.
They made a sign to their companions in the other boat to come and help them. They came and filled the two boats, so that they began to sink.
Simon Peter, seeing this, fell at Jesus' knees, saying, "Lord, depart from me, for I am a sinful man."
For he was astonished, as were all those who were with him, at the catch of fish they had made;
as well as James and John, sons of Zebedee, who were associated with Simon. Jesus said to Simon, "Do not be afraid. From now on, you will catch people alive. »
When they had brought their boats ashore, they left everything, and followed him.
As he was in one of the cities, there was a man suffering from leprosy. When he saw Jesus, he fell on his face and begged him, saying, "Lord, if you will, you can make me clean."
He stretched out his hand and touched him, saying, "I will. Be purified. Immediately, leprosy left him.
He commanded him not to tell anyone: "But go, show yourself to the priest, and offer for your purification what Moses commanded, as a witness for them."
But the news of his coming spread more and more, and great crowds gathered to hear him and to be healed by him of their infirmities.
But he withdrew into the wilderness and prayed.
One of those days, he was teaching. There were sitting Pharisees and doctors of the law from all the villages of Galilee, Judea, and Jerusalem. The Lord's power was with him to heal them.
Behold, some men were bringing a paralytic on a cot, and they were trying to bring him in to lay him before Jesus.
Not finding a way to get him in because of the crowd, they went up to the roof of the house and made him go down through the tiles, with his bed, to the middle, before Jesus.
Seeing their faith, Jesus said to him, "Man, your sins are forgiven you."
The scribes and Pharisees began to reason, saying, "Who is this who utters blasphemies? Who can forgive sins if not God alone? »
But Jesus, perceiving their thoughts, answered them, "Why do you reason thus in your hearts?
Which is easier to say, "Your sins are forgiven you," or to say, "Arise and walk"?
But that you may know that the Son of Man has power on earth to forgive sins, he said to the paralyzed, "I say to you, get up, take up your bed, and go to your house."
Immediately he arose in their presence, took what he had laid down, and went to his house, glorifying God.
Amazement took hold of all, and they glorified God. They were filled with fear, and said, "We have seen strange things today."
After this, he went out and saw a publican, named Levi, sitting in the tax office, and he said to him, "Follow me!"
He left everything, got up and followed him.
Levi made a great feast for him in his house. There was a great crowd of tax collectors and other people who were lying with them.
The scribes and Pharisees murmured against his disciples, saying, "Why do you eat and drink with publicans and sinners?"
Jesus answered them, "Those who are healthy do not need a doctor, but those who are sick do.
I have not come to call the righteous, but sinners, to repentance. »
They said to him, "Why do John's disciples often fast and pray, as do the disciples of the Pharisees, but yours eat and drink?"
He said to them, "Can you make the friends of the bridegroom fast while the bridegroom is with them?
But the days will come when the bridegroom will be taken from them. Then they will fast in those days. »
He also told them a parable. "No one puts a piece of a new garment on an old garment, or he will tear the new, and the piece of the new will not match the old.
No one will put new wine in old wineskins, otherwise the new wine will burst the wineskins, it will spill out, and the wineskins will be destroyed.
But new wine must be put in fresh wineskins, and both can be preserved.
No man who has drunk old wine immediately desires new wine, for he says, "The old is better." »
Now, on the second Sabbath after the first, he went through the wheat fields. His disciples plucked the ears of corn and ate by rubbing them in their hands.
But some of the Pharisees said to them, "Why do you do what it is not lawful to do on the Sabbath?"
Jesus answered and said to them, "Have you not read what David did when he and those who were with him were hungry?
how he entered the house of God, took and ate the shewbread, and gave it also to those who were with him, which it is not lawful to eat, except for the priests alone? »
He answered them, "The Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath."
On another Sabbath, he entered the synagogue and taught. There was a man there, whose right hand was withered.
The scribes and Pharisees watched him, to see if he would do a healing on the Sabbath, in order to find an accusation against him.
But Jesus knew their thoughts, and he said to the man with the withered hand, "Arise and stand in the middle." He got up and stood up.
Then Jesus said to them, "I will ask you a question: Is it lawful on the Sabbath to do good or to do evil? To save a life, or to kill? »
He looked at them all, and said to the man, "Stretch out your hand." He did so, and his hand was made as sound as the other.
But they were filled with rage, and they talked among themselves about what they could do to Jesus.
In those days he went to the mountain to pray, and he spent the whole night praying to God.
When the day came, he called his disciples, and chose twelve of them, whom he also called apostles:
Simon, whom he also called Peter; André, his brother; Jacob; John; Philippe; Barthélemy;
Matthew; Thomas; James, son of Alphaeus; Simon, called the Zealot;
Judas, son of James; and Judas Iscariot , who also became a traitor .
He went down with them and stood on level ground, in company with a crowd of his disciples and a great number of people from all Judea, from Jerusalem and from the sea coast of Tyre and Sidon, who came to hear him and to be healed of their diseases,
as well as of those who were tormented by unclean spirits; and they were healed.
The whole crowd tried to touch him, for a force came out of him and healed them all.
He lifted up his eyes to his disciples, and said, "Blessed are you who are poor, for the kingdom of God is yours.
Blessed are those who are hungry now, for you will be fulfilled. Blessed are you who are weeping now, for you will laugh.
Blessed are you when men hate you, when they exclude you and mock you, and cast your name to pasture for the Son of Man's sake.
Rejoice in that day and rejoice, for behold, your reward is great in heaven, for their fathers did the same to the prophets.
"But woe to you who are rich! For you have received your consolation.
Woe to you, who are now satisfied, for you will be hungry. Woe to you who laugh now, for you will mourn and weep.
Woe to men, when men speak well of you, for their fathers did the same thing to the false prophets.
"But I say to you, who listen to me, love your enemies, do good to those who hate you,
bless those who curse you, and pray for those who mistreat you.
To the one who strikes you on the cheek, present the other also; and to him who takes your cloak from you, do not also refuse your tunic.
Give to whoever asks you, and do not ask him who deprives you of your goods to give them back to you.
"As you want people to do to you, do the exact same thing to them.
"If you love those who love you, how does that honor you? For even sinners love those who love them.
If you do good to those who do you good, what honor does it do you? For even sinners do the same.
If you lend to those you hope to receive, what merit do you have? Sinners themselves lend to sinners, to receive as much in return.
But love your enemies, do good, lend without expecting anything in return, and your reward will be great, and you will be the children of the Most High, for he is good to the ungrateful and the wicked.
"Be merciful, therefore, as your Father is also merciful.
Do not judge, and you will not be judged. Do not condemn, and you will not be condemned. Free yourself, and you will be free.
"Give, and it will be given to you: you will be given a good measure, packed, shaken and overflowing. For it is with the same measure that you measure that you will be measured. »
He addressed them a parable. "Can a blind man guide a blind man? Will they not both fall into a pit?
A disciple is not above his master, but each one, when he is well formed, will be like his master.
Why do you see the speck in your brother's eye, but do you not consider the beam in your own eye?
Or how can you say to your brother, "My brother, let me remove the speck that is in your eye," when you yourself do not see the beam that is in your eye? Hypocrite! First remove the beam from your eye, and then you will be able to see clearly to remove the speck that is in your brother's eye.
"For there is no good tree that produces rotten fruit, nor a rotten tree that produces good fruit.
For each tree is recognized by its fruit. For figs are not gathered from thorns, nor grapes from a thorn bush.
The good man draws from the good treasury of his heart what is good, and the evil man draws from the evil treasure of his heart what is evil, for it is from the abundance of the heart that the mouth speaks.
Why do you call me, "Lord, Lord," and do not do what I say?
Whoever comes to me, hears my words and does them, I will show you to whom he is like.
He is like a man who builds a house, who has dug and deepened, and who has laid the foundation on the rock. When there was a flood, the torrent rushed against this house and could not shake it, because it was founded on the rock.
But he who hears and does not do is like a man who built a house on the earth without foundation, against which the torrent broke, and immediately it fell; and the ruin of this house was great. »
When he had finished speaking in the ear of the people, he entered Capernaum.
The servant of a centurion, who was dear to him, was sick and on the point of death.
When he heard of Jesus, he sent him elders of the Jews, begging him to come and save his servant.
When they came to Jesus, they begged him earnestly, saying, "It is worthy that you should do this for him,
for he loves our nation, and it is for us that he has built our synagogue. »
Jesus went with them. As he was not far from home, the centurion sent him some friends to say, "Lord, do not worry yourself, for I am not worthy that you should come under my roof.
That is why I did not even think myself worthy to come and see you; but speak the word, and my servant will be healed.
For I too am a man under authority, having soldiers under my command. I said to one, "Go," and he goes; to another, "Come," and he comes; to my servant, 'Do this,' and he does it."
When Jesus heard these things, he was astonished at him, and then he turned around and said to the crowd that followed him, "I say to you, I have not found so great faith, not even in Israel."
Those who had been sent, having returned home, found that the servant who had been sick was healed.
Soon after, he went to a city called Nain. Several of his disciples, as well as a great crowd, accompanied him.
As he approached the gate of the city, behold, a dead man was carried away, the only son of his mother, who was a widow. Many people from the city were with her.
The Lord, when he saw her, took pity on her and said to her, "Do not weep."
He approached and touched the coffin, and the pallbearers stopped. He said, "Young man, I say to you, arise!"
The one who was dead stood up and began to speak. Then he entrusted him to his mother.
All were seized with fear and glorified God, saying, "A great prophet has arisen among us" and "God has visited his people."
This news spread about him throughout Judea and the surrounding region.
John's disciples told him all these things.
John, having called two of his disciples to him, sent them to Jesus, saying, "Are you the one who is coming, or must we seek another?"
The men came to him and said, "John the Baptist has sent us to you, saying, 'Are you the one who is coming, or are we to look for another?'
In that hour he healed many diseases, plagues, and evil spirits, and restored sight to many blind men.
Jesus answered them, "Go and tell John what you have seen and heard: that the blind may receive their sight, that the lame may walk, that the lepers may be cleansed, that the deaf may hear, that the dead may be raised, and that the good news be preached to the poor.
Happy is he who finds in me no occasion to fall! »
When John's messengers had gone, he began to say to the crowd about John, "What have you gone to see in the wilderness? A reed shaken by the wind?
But what did you go to see? A man dressed in a soft garment? Behold, those who are magnificently dressed and live in delicacy are in the courts of kings.
But you, what did you go to see? A prophet? Yes, I tell you, and much more than a prophet.
It is he of whom it is written, Behold, I send my messenger before you, who will prepare your way before you.
"For I say unto you, among those born of women there is no greater prophet than John the Baptizer; and he who is the least in the kingdom of God is greater than he. »
When all the people and publicans heard this, they declared that God is righteous, having been baptized by the baptism of John.
But the Pharisees and the jurists rejected the counsel of God, not having themselves been baptized by him.
So what should I compare the people of this generation to? What do they look like?
They are like children sitting in the market place, calling out to each other, saying, 'We whistled for you, and you did not dance. We lamented, and you did not weep.
For John the Baptist did not come to eat bread or drink wine, and you say, "He has a demon."
The Son of Man came eating and drinking, and you say, "Behold a glutton and a drunkard, the friend of publicans and sinners."
Wisdom is justified by all its children. »
One of the Pharisees invited him to eat with him. He went into the house of the Pharisee and sat down to table.
And behold, a woman of the city, who was a sinner, knowing that he was lying in the house of the Pharisee, brought an alabaster vessel filled with incense.
Standing behind at her feet weeping, she began to wet her feet with her tears, wiped them with the hair of her head, kissed her feet, and anointed them with the ointment.
The Pharisee who had invited him, seeing this, said to himself, "This man, if he were a prophet, would have understood who and what kind of woman it is who touches him, that she is a sinner."
Jesus answered him, "Simon, I have something to say to you." He said, "Master, speak."
"A certain lender had two debtors. One owed five hundred denarii, and the other fifty.
As they could not pay, he forgave them both. Which of them will love him the most? »
Simon answered, "The one, I suppose, whom he has forgiven the most." He said to him, "You have judged rightly."
Turning to the woman, he said to Simon, "Do you see this woman? I entered your house, and you did not give me water for my feet, but she wet my feet with her tears, and wiped them with the hair of her head.
You didn't give me a kiss, but she, since I entered, hasn't stopped kissing my feet.
You have not anointed my head with oil, but she has anointed my feet with perfume.
Therefore I tell you that her sins, which are many, are forgiven, for she loved much. But he who is forgiven little, loves little. »
He said to him, "Your sins are forgiven."
Those who were at table with him began to say to themselves, "Who is this, who forgives even sins?"
He said to the woman, "Your faith has saved you. Go in peace. »
Soon after, he traveled through the towns and villages, preaching and bringing the good news of the Kingdom of God. He had with him the twelve,
and some women who had been healed of evil spirits and infirmities: Mary, called Magdalene, from whom seven demons had issued,
Jeanne, wife of Chuzas, steward of Herod, Susanna, and several others who served them with their property.
When a great crowd was assembled, and people from all the cities came to him, he spoke in a parable:
"The farmer went out to sow his seed. As he sowed , some of the seed fell along the way; it was trampled on, and the birds of the air devoured it.
Another part of the seed fell on the rock; no sooner had it grown than it dried up, for lack of moisture.
Another fell in the midst of thorns; the thorns grew with her and choked her.
Another fell into good soil; it has grown and given a hundred times more fruit. Saying this, he cried out, "He who has ears to hear, let him hear." »
Then his disciples asked him, "What does this parable mean?"
He said, "It has been given to you to know the mysteries of the kingdom of God, but to others it has been given in parables, so that when they see they do not see and when they hear they do not understand.
"This is the parable: The seed is the word of God.
Those who are on the way are those who hear; then the devil comes and takes away the word from their hearts, so that they do not believe and are not saved.
Those who are on the rock are those who, when they hear, receive the word with joy; but these have no root. They believe for a time, then fall at the moment of temptation.
Those who have fallen among thorns are those who have heard the word, but who, as they go on their way, are choked by the cares, riches, and pleasures of life, and they do not bear fruit when ripe.
Those who are in good soil are those who, with an honest and good heart, having heard the word, hold fast to it and bear fruit with perseverance.
No one, after lighting a lamp, covers it with a container or puts it under a bed; but he puts it on a stand, so that those who enter may see the light.
For there is nothing hidden that should not be revealed, nor secret that should not be known and brought to light.
Be careful, therefore, in the manner in which you hear. For he who has, it will be given to him; and he who has not, even what he thinks he has will be taken away from him. »
His mother and brothers came to see him, but they could not approach him because of the crowd.
Some people said to him, "Your mother and brothers are outside, they want to see you."
But he answered them, "My mother and my brothers are the ones who hear the word of God and do it."
One of these days he and his disciples got into a boat and said to them, "Let us go to the other side of the lake." So they got into the water.
But as they sailed, he fell asleep. A windstorm hit the lake, and they took a dangerous amount of water.
They came up to him and woke him up, saying, "Master, Master, we are dying." He awoke and threatened the wind and the raging of the water; then they ceased, and calm returned.
He said to them, "Where is your faith?" They were frightened, and were astonished, and said to one another, "Who is this, that he should command even the winds and the waters, and that they should obey him?"
They then came to the country of the Gadarenes, which is opposite Galilee.
When Jesus dismounted, a man from the city who had had demons for a long time came to meet him. He wore no clothes, and did not dwell in a house, but in tombs.
When he saw Jesus, he cried out, prostrated himself before him, and said in a loud voice, "What have I to do with you, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beg you, don't torment me! »
For Jesus commanded the unclean spirit to come out of this man. For the unclean spirit had often taken possession of this man. He was kept under guard and bound with chains and fetters. By breaking the bonds, he was driven by the demon into the desert.
Jesus asked him, "What is your name?" He said, "Legion," for many demons had entered into him.
They begged him not to order them to go into the abyss.
Now there was a herd of many pigs grazing on the mountain, and they begged him to allow them to enter them. And he allowed them to do so.
The demons came out of the man and entered the pigs, and the herd rushed from the top of the steep shore into the lake and was drowned.
When those who fed them saw what had happened, they fled and told it in the city and in the countryside.
People came out to see what had happened. They approached Jesus and found the man from whom the demons had come, sitting at Jesus' feet, clothed and sane; and they were afraid.
Those who had seen this told them how the one who had been possessed by demons had been healed.
All the inhabitants of the surrounding country, the Gadarenes, begged him to get away from them, for they were very afraid. Then he got into the boat and returned.
The man from whom the demons had come begged him to accompany him, but Jesus sent him away, saying:
"Return to your house, and declare the great things that God has done for you." He went away, proclaiming throughout the city the great things that Jesus had done for him.
When Jesus returned, the crowd welcomed him, for all were waiting for him.
Behold, a man named Jairus arrives. He was a ruler of the synagogue. He threw himself at Jesus' feet and begged him to enter his house,
for he had an only daughter, about twelve years old, and she was dying. But, as he was leaving, the crowd pressed against him.
A woman who had had a flow of blood for twelve years, who had spent all her money on doctors and who could not be cured by any of them,
came behind him and touched the fringe of his cloak. Immediately, the flow of his blood stopped.
Jesus said, "Who has touched me?" When all denied it, Peter and those who were with him said, "Master, the crowd is pressing and pushing you, and you say, 'Who has touched me?'
But Jesus said, "Someone has touched me, for I saw that power had gone out of me."
The woman, seeing that she was not hidden, came trembling; and, throwing herself on the ground before him, she told him, in the presence of everyone, the reason why she had touched him, and how she had been healed immediately.
He said to her, "My daughter, rejoice. Your faith has healed you. Go in peace. »
While he was still speaking, someone from the house of the ruler of the synagogue came to him and said, "Your daughter is dead. Do not disturb the master. »
But Jesus, hearing him, answered him, "Do not be afraid. Only believe, and she will be healed. »
When he arrived at the house, he let no one in, except Peter, John, James, the father of the child and his mother.
Everyone was crying and crying for her. But he said, "Don't cry. She is not dead, but she is asleep. »
They laughed at him, knowing that she was dead.
But he brought them all out, and, taking her by the hand, he called to her, saying, "Child, arise!"
Her mind returned, and she immediately got up. He ordered that he be given something to eat.
His parents were stunned, but he ordered them not to tell anyone anything about what had happened.
He summoned the twelve and gave them power to overcome all demons and heal diseases.
He sent them to preach the Kingdom of God and heal the sick.
He said to them, "Take nothing for your journey: neither stick, nor wallet, nor bread, nor money. Do not have two tunics each.
In whatever house you enter, stay there, and leave it.
All those who do not receive you, when you leave this city, shake off even the dust from your feet, as a witness against them. »
They set out and went through the villages, preaching the Good News and healing everywhere.
Herod the tetrarch heard all that he had done, and he was greatly troubled, because some said that John had risen from the dead.
others that Elijah had appeared, and still others that one of the ancient prophets had risen.
Herod said, "I have beheaded John, but who is this of whom I hear so much?" He tried to see him.
The apostles, on their return, told him what they had done. He took them and withdrew to a lonely place, to a city called Bethsaida.
But the crowd, perceiving this, followed him. He welcomed them, spoke to them of the Kingdom of God, and healed those who needed to be healed.
The day was beginning to fall; the twelve came and said to him, "Send the crowd away, that they may go to the villages and farms round about, and that they may lodge and get food, for we are here in a lonely place."
But he said to them, "You give them something to eat." They said, "We have no more than five loaves and two fish, unless we go and buy food for all these people."
For they were about five thousand men. He said to his disciples, "Have them sit in groups of about fifty each."
They did so, and made them all sit down.
He took the five loaves and the two fishes, and, raising his eyes to heaven, blessed them, broke them, and gave them to the disciples to present to the crowd.
They ate and were all satisfied. They picked up the twelve baskets of pieces that were left.
As he was praying alone, the disciples were near him, and he asked them, "Who do the crowds say that I am?"
They answered, "John the Baptizer, but others say, Elijah, and still others, that one of the ancient prophets has risen."
He said to them, "But who do you say I am?" Peter answered, "The Christ of God."
But he warned them and commanded them not to tell anyone,
saying, "The Son of Man must suffer much, and be rejected by the elders, the chief priests, and the scribes, and be killed, and rise again on the third day."
He said to all, "If anyone wants to come after me, let him deny himself, take up his cross, and follow me.
For whoever wants to save his life will lose it, but whoever loses his life for my sake will save it.
For what good does it profit a man to gain the whole world, if he loses or denies himself?
For whoever is ashamed of me and of my words, the Son of Man will be ashamed of him, when he comes in his glory, and in the glory of the Father and of the holy angels.
But I tell you the truth: among those who stand here, there are some who will not taste death until they have seen the Kingdom of God. »
About eight days after these words, he took Peter, John, and James with him, and went up to the mountain to pray.
As he prayed, the aspect of his face changed, and his garments became white and dazzling.
And behold, two men were conversing with him, who were Moses and Elijah,
who appeared in glory and spoke of his departure, which he was about to accomplish in Jerusalem.
Now Peter and those who were with him were overcome with sleep; but, when they were fully awakened, they saw his glory and the two men who were standing with him.
As they parted from him, Peter said to Jesus, "Master, it is good for us to be here. Let us make three tents: one for you, one for Moses, and one for Elijah," without knowing what he was saying.
As he said this, a cloud came over them, and they were afraid when they entered the cloud.
A voice came out of the cloud, saying, "This is my beloved Son. Listen! »
When the voice was heard, Jesus was found alone. They were silent, and told no one at that time what they had seen.
The next day, when they came down from the mountain, a great crowd came to meet him.
And behold, a man of the crowd cried out, "Master, I beg you to look at my son, for he is my only child.
Behold, a spirit seizes him, he suddenly cries out, convulses him to the point of foaming at him, and as soon as he leaves him, he bruises him gravely.
I begged your disciples to cast him out, and they could not. »
Jesus answered, "Unbelieving and perverse generation, how long shall I be with you and bear with you? Bring your son here. »
As he was still approaching, the demon threw him to the ground and convulsed him violently. But Jesus threatened the unclean spirit, healed the boy, and returned him to his father.
They were all amazed at the majesty of God. When all marveled at all the things Jesus did, he said to his disciples:
"Let these words penetrate your ears, for the Son of Man will be delivered into the hands of men."
But they did not understand this word. It was hidden from them, so that they would not perceive it, and they were afraid to question him about this word.
A dispute arose among them as to which of them was the greatest.
Jesus, knowing the reasoning of their hearts, took a little child, placed him by his side,
and said to them, "Whoever receives this little child in my name receives me. And he who receives me receives him who sent me. For he who is the least of you all, he will be great. »
John answered, "Master, we have seen someone who casts out demons in your name, and we have forbidden him to do so, because he does not follow us."
Jesus said to him, "Do not hinder him, for he who is not against us is for us."
As the days when he was to be carried off were at hand, he prepared to go to Jerusalem
and sent messengers before him. They went and entered a village of the Samaritans, in order to prepare to receive him.
They did not receive him, because he traveled with his face turned towards Jerusalem.
When his disciples, James and John, saw this, they said, "Lord, do you want us to command fire to come down from heaven and destroy them, as Elijah did?"
But he turned around and rebuked them, "You don't know what spirit you are of.
For the Son of Man did not come to destroy the lives of men, but to save them. They went to another village.
As they went on their way, a man said to him, "I will follow you wherever you go, Lord."
Jesus said to him, "The foxes have holes and the birds of the air have nests, but the Son of Man has nowhere to lay his head."
He said to another, "Follow me!" But he said, "Lord, let me go and bury my father first."
But Jesus said to him, "Let the dead bury their own dead, but you go and proclaim the Kingdom of God."
Another also said, "I want to follow you, Lord, but first let me say goodbye to those who are with me."
But Jesus said to him, "No one, having put his hand to the plough and looking back, is fit for the Kingdom of God."
Now after these things the Lord appointed seventy others, and sent them two by two before him to all the cities and places where he was about to come.
Then he said to them, "The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few. Pray therefore to the Lord of the harvest, that he may send laborers into his harvest.
Go this way. Behold, I send you out as lambs in the midst of wolves.
Do not wear purses, purses, or sandals. Do not greet anyone on the way.
In whatever house you enter, say first, "Peace be with this house."
If there is a son of peace there, your peace will rest on him; if not, it will come back to you.
Stay in this same house, eat and drink what is given you, for the worker deserves his wages. Don't go from house to house.
In whatever city you enter and where you are received, eat what is presented to you.
Heal the sick who are there and say to them: "The Kingdom of God has drawn near to you."
But in whatever city you enter, and where you are not received, go out into its streets and say:
"We wipe against you the dust of your city that has clung to us. But know that the Kingdom of God has drawn near to you."
I tell you, on that day it will be more bearable for Sodom than for this city.
"Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the miracles that were done among you had been done at Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting on sackcloth and ashes.
But, in judgment, Tyre and Sidon will be more tolerable than you.
You, Capernaum, who are lifted up to heaven, will be humbled to hell.
Whoever hears you hears me, and whoever rejects you rejects me. He who rejects me rejects the one who sent me. »
The seventy returned with joy, saying, "Lord, even the demons are subject to us in your name!"
He said to them, "I saw Satan fall from heaven like lightning.
Behold, I give you power to walk on serpents and scorpions, and on all the power of the enemy. Nothing can hurt you.
However, do not rejoice that the spirits are subject to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven. »
At that same hour, Jesus rejoiced in the Holy Spirit and said, "I thank you, O Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that you have hidden these things from the wise and understanding, and have revealed them to little children. Yes, Father, for thus he has been pleasing in your sight. »
Turning to the disciples, he said, "All things have been given to me by my Father. No one knows who the Son is, if not the Father, and who the Father is, if not the Son, and the one to whom the Son wishes to reveal him. »
Turning to the disciples, he said to them privately, "Blessed are the eyes that see the things you see,
for I tell you that many prophets and kings have desired to see the things which you see, and have not seen them, and have not heard the things which you hear, and have not heard them. »
Behold, a doctor of the law arose and tested him, saying, "Master, what must I do to inherit eternal life?"
He said to him, "What is written in the law? How do you read it? »
He answered, "You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, with all your strength, and with all your mind, and your neighbor as yourself."
He said to him, "You answered well. Do this, and you will live. »
But he, wishing to justify himself, asked Jesus, "Who is my neighbor?"
Jesus answered, "A man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho. He fell into the midst of brigands who stripped him, beat him, and then went away, leaving him half dead.
By chance, a priest was coming down there. He saw it and went to the other side.
In the same way, a Levite, who had arrived at this place and had seen it, passed over to the other side.
But a Samaritan, who was on a journey, came to where he was. When he saw him, he was moved with compassion,
approached him, dressed his wounds, and poured out oil and wine. He put him on board his own beast, took him to an inn, and took care of him.
The next day, as he was leaving, he took two denarii, gave them to the host, and said to him, "Take care of him. Whatever you spend beyond that, I will give you back when I return."
Now, which of these three do you think is the neighbor of him who fell in the midst of the robbers? »
He said, "He that had mercy on him." Then Jesus said to him, "Go and do the same."
As they continued their way, he entered a village, and a woman, named Martha, received him in her house.
She had a sister, named Mary, who also sat at Jesus' feet and listened to His word.
But Martha, distracted by the service, came to Jesus and said to him, "Lord, do you not care that my sister left me alone to serve? Ask him to help me. »
Jesus answered her, "Martha, Martha, you are worried and troubled by many things,
but only one thing is necessary. Mary has chosen the good part, which will not be taken away from her. »
When he was finishing his prayers in a certain place, one of his disciples said to him, "Lord, teach us to pray, as John also taught his disciples."
He said to them, "When you pray, say, 'Our Father who is in heaven, let your name be kept holy. Thy kingdom come. Thy will be done on earth, as it is in heaven.
Give us day after day our daily bread.
Forgive us our sins, for we also forgive all those who are indebted to us. Do not subject us to temptation, but deliver us from the evil one. »
He said to them, "Which of you, if he goes to a friend at midnight and says to him, 'Friend, lend me three loaves,
for a friend of mine came to see me on his return from a journey, and I have nothing to present to him,
and the one inside will answer, "Do not disturb me. The door is now closed, and my children are lying with me. I can't stand up and give it to you"?
I tell you, even if he will not get up to give it to her because he is her friend, he will get up, because of her obstinacy, and give her as much as he needs.
"I say to you, keep asking, and it will be given to you. Always search, and you will find . Keep knocking, and it will be opened to you.
For whoever asks receives . He who seeks finds . To the one who knocks, we open it.
"Which of you, fathers, if his son asks for bread, will give him a stone? Or if he asks for a fish, will he not give him a serpent instead of a fish?
Or if he asks for an egg, he won't give him a scorpion, right?
If, then, you, who are evil, know how to give good things to your children, how much more will your heavenly Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him. »
He was casting out a demon, and this man was dumb. When the demon had come out, the dumb man spoke, and the crowd was astonished.
But some of them said, "He casts out demons by Beelzebub, the prince of demons."
Others, testing him, expected him to be a sign from heaven.
But he, knowing their thoughts, said to them, "Every kingdom divided against itself is devastated. A house divided against itself falls.
If Satan also is divided against himself, how will his kingdom stand? For you say that it is by Beelzebub that I cast out demons.
But if it is by Beelzebub that I cast out demons, by whom do your children cast them out? That is why they will be your judges.
But if it is by the finger of God that I cast out demons, it is because the Kingdom of God has come to you.
"When a strong, well-armed man guards his own home, his property is safe.
But when someone stronger attacks him and defeats him, he takes away all the armor in which he trusted, and divides his booty.
"Whoever is not with me is against me. He who does not assemble with me scatters.
The impure spirit, when it has gone out of man, passes through arid places, seeking rest; and finding none, he said, "I will return to my house from which I came.
When he returns, he finds it swept and put away.
Then he goes and takes seven other spirits worse than himself, and they enter and dwell there. This man's last state becomes worse than the first. »
As he spoke thus, a woman of the crowd raised her voice and said to him, "Blessed is the womb that bore you and the breasts that suckled you!"
But he says, "On the contrary, blessed are those who hear the word of God and keep it."
As the crowds gathered around him, he began to say, "This generation is bad. She is looking for a sign. He will be given no other sign than the sign of Jonah the prophet.
For as Jonah was a sign to the Ninevites, so the Son of Man will be a sign to this generation.
The queen of the south will rise up in the tribunal with the men of this generation and condemn them, for she has come from the ends of the earth to hear the wisdom of Solomon; and behold, there is here a greater man than Solomon.
The men of Nineveh will stand up in judgment with the men of this generation and condemn it, for they have repented at Jonah's preaching; and behold, a greater than Jonah is here.
"No one, after lighting a lamp, puts it in a cellar or under a basket, but on a stand, so that those who enter may see the light.
The lamp of the body is the eye. Wherefore, when thy eye is good, thy whole body is also full of light; but when it is bad, your body is also full of darkness.
See, then, if the light that is in you is not darkness.
If, therefore, your whole body is full of light, having no dark part, it will be entirely full of light, as when the lamp, by its brightness, illuminates you. »
As he spoke, a Pharisee asked him to dine with him. He entered and sat down to table.
When the Pharisee saw him, he was surprised that he had not first washed himself before dinner.
The Lord said to him, "You Pharisees clean the outside of the cup and the dish, but your inside is full of robbery and wickedness.
Fools, did not he who made the outside also make the inside?
But give to the needy what is within, and behold, all things will be pure for you.
But woe to you, Pharisees! For you pay tithes of mint, of the street, and of all herbs, but you disregard the justice and love of God. You should have done both of these things, and not left the other in abeyance.
Woe to you, Pharisees! Because you love the best seats in synagogues and greetings in market places.
Woe to you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! For you are like hidden graves, and the men who walk on them do not know it. »
One of the lawyers replied: "Master, by saying this, you are insulting us too."
He said: "Woe to you too, lawyers! For you burden men with burdens that are difficult to bear, and you yourselves lift not a finger to help bear these burdens.
Woe to you! For you build the tombs of the prophets, whom your fathers slain.
In this way you bear witness and consent to the works of your fathers. For they have killed them, and you are building their tombs.
Therefore the wisdom of God has said, "I will send them prophets and apostles, and they will kill and persecute some of them,
that the blood of all the prophets, which was shed from the foundation of the world, may be required of this generation,
from the blood of Abel to the blood of Zechariah, who perished between the altar and the sanctuary." Yes, I tell you, it will be demanded of this generation.
Woe to you, lawyers! For you have taken away the key to knowledge. You did not enter yourselves, and those who did enter you prevented them. »
When he said this to them, the scribes and Pharisees began to be terribly angry, and to draw many things from him.
lying in wait for him and trying to catch him in something he could say, in order to accuse him.
Meanwhile, when a crowd of many thousands had gathered together, to the point of trampling on one another, he began to say to his disciples, first of all, "Beware of the leaven of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy.
But there is nothing hidden that is not revealed, nor concealed that is not known.
Therefore all that you have said in darkness will be heard in the light. What you have said in your ear in the inner chambers will be proclaimed on the rooftops.
"I say to you, my friends, do not fear those who kill the body and who, after that, have nothing more to do.
But I will warn you who you should be afraid of. Fear him who, after having killed, has the power to throw into hell. Yes, I tell you, fear it.
"Aren't five sparrows sold for two pieces of assaria? None of them is forgotten by God.
But all the hairs on your head are counted. So don't be afraid. You are more valuable than many sparrows.
"I say to you, whoever confesses me before men, the Son of Man will also confess him before the angels of God;
but he who denies me before men will be denied before the angels of God.
Whoever speaks a word against the Son of Man will be forgiven, but those who blaspheme against the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven.
When you are brought before the synagogues, the magistrates and the authorities, do not worry about what you will answer or say;
for the Holy Spirit will teach you at this very hour what you must say. »
A man of the crowd said to him, "Master, tell my brother to share the inheritance with me."
But he said to him, "Man, who has made me judge or arbiter over you?"
He said to them, "Beware! Beware of covetousness, for a man's life does not consist in the abundance of things he possesses. »
He addressed them a parable, saying: "The land of a rich man produced in abundance.
He reasoned to himself, saying, "What am I going to do, for I have no room to store my crops?"
He replied, "This is what I am going to do. I will demolish my barns, I will build larger ones, and I will store all my grain and my goods in them.
I will say to my soul: "Soul, you have many possessions accumulated for many years. Take your ease, eat, drink, and be merry. »'
But God said to him: "Fool, this evening, your soul is being asked for. The things you have prepared, to whom will they belong?
It is the same with him who lays up treasure for himself, and is not rich in the sight of God. »
He said to his disciples, "Therefore I say to you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat, nor about your body, what you will wear.
Life is more than food, and the body more than clothing.
Consider the crows: they do not sow, they do not reap, they have neither barns nor stables, and God feeds them. How much more precious you are than birds!
Which of you, by worrying, can add a cubit to his size?
If, then, you are not able to do the least things, why do you worry about the rest?
Consider the lilies, how they grow. I tell you, Solomon himself, in all his glory, was not clothed like one of them.
But if this is how God dresses the grass of the field, which exists today and tomorrow will be thrown into the oven, how much more will he clothe you, people of little faith?
"Do not seek what you will eat or drink, and do not worry.
For the nations of the world seek all these things, but your Father knows that you need them.
Seek the kingdom of God, and all these things will be given to you as well.
"Do not fear, little flock, for it is your Father's good pleasure to give you the Kingdom.
Sell what you have and donate to the needy. Make for yourselves purses that do not grow old, an unalterable treasure in the heavens, where no thief approaches and where no moth destroys.
For where your treasure is, there will your heart also be.
"Let your waist be clothed and your lamps lighted.
Be like men who watch for their master when they return from the wedding, so that when he comes knocking, they will open it for him at once.
Happy are those servants whom the master will find watching when he comes. I tell you for sure, he will dress himself, make them lie down and come and serve them.
They will be blessed if he comes on the second or third watch and finds them so.
But know that if the master of the house had known at what time the thief was coming, he would have kept watch and would not have allowed anyone to enter his house.
Therefore you also must be ready, for the Son of Man is coming at an hour when you are not expecting him. »
Peter said to him, "Lord, are you telling this parable to us, or to everyone?"
The Lord said, "Who then is the faithful and discreet steward whom his master shall appoint over his house, to give him his share of food at the proper time?
Happy is this servant whom his master will find doing this when he comes.
Truly I say to you, he will establish it over all that he possesses.
But if that servant says in his heart, "My master is slow to come," and begins to beat the servants and maidservants, to eat, to drink, and to get drunk,
The master of this servant will come on the day when he does not expect him, and at the hour he does not know, he will cut him in two and put his share with the infidels.
The servant who knew the will of his master and did not prepare and did not do what he wanted, will be beaten with many blows;
but he who did not know, and who has done things worthy of blows, will be beaten with few blows. Of him to whom much has been given, much will be asked; and of him to whom much has been entrusted, more will be asked.
"I have come to cast fire on the earth. I would like it to be already on.
But I have a baptism to receive, and how I grieve until it is accomplished!
Do you think that I have come to give peace on earth? I tell you, no, but rather division.
For henceforth, in the same house, there will be five people divided, three against two, and two against three.
They will be divided, father against son, and son against father; mother against daughter, and daughter against her mother; mother-in-law against her daughter-in-law, and daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law. »
He also said to the crowd, "When you see a cloud rising in the west, you immediately say, 'There is going to be a shower,' and it happens.
When a south wind blows, you say, "There will be scorching heat," and it happens.
Hypocrites! You know how to interpret the aspect of the earth and the sky, but how is it that you do not interpret this time?
"Why don't you judge for yourselves what is right?
For when you go with your adversary before the magistrate, strive on the way to free yourself from him, lest he drag you before the judge, the judge deliver you up to the officer, and the officer throw you into prison.
I tell you, you will not get out of there until you have paid every penny. »
Some of them, who were present at the same time, told him of the Galileans, whose blood Pilate had mixed with their sacrifices.
Jesus answered them, "Do you think that these Galileans were greater sinners than all the other Galileans, because they suffered such things?
I tell you, no; but if you do not repent, you will all perish in the same way.
Or do you think that those eighteen people on whom the tower of Siloam fell and killed them, were they worse sinners than all the inhabitants of Jerusalem?
I tell you, no, but if you do not repent, you will all perish in the same way. »
He tells this parable. "A man had planted a fig tree in his vineyard. He came to look for fruit on this fig tree and found none.
He said to the husbandman, "I have been coming to look for fruit on this fig tree for three years and I have not found any. Cut it down!
He replied, "Lord, leave him alone again this year, until I dig around him and fertilize him.
If it bears fruit, so much the better; if not, after that, you can cut it off. »
He was teaching in one of the synagogues on the Sabbath.
And behold, there was a woman who had had a spirit of infirmity for eighteen years. She was bent over and could not straighten herself in any way.
Jesus, having seen her, called to her and said to her, "Woman, you are freed from your infirmity."
He laid his hands on her, and immediately she stood up and glorified God.
The ruler of the synagogue, indignant that Jesus had done healings on the Sabbath, said to the crowd, "There are six days on which one must work. Come on those days to be healed, and not on the Sabbath! » .
The Lord answered him, "Hypocrites! Does not each of you free his ox or donkey from the stable on the Sabbath and lead it to the water?
Is not this woman, daughter of Abraham, whom Satan bound for eighteen long years, to be freed from this bondage on the Sabbath? » .
As he said these things, all his opponents were disappointed, and the whole crowd rejoiced at all the glorious things he had done.
He said, "What does the Kingdom of God look like? To what shall I compare it?
It is like a mustard seed that a man has taken and put in his garden. It has grown and has become a great tree, and the birds of the air live in its branches. »
He also said, "To what shall I compare the kingdom of God?
It is like leaven, which a woman has taken and hidden in three measures of flour, until all is leavened. »
He passed through towns and villages, taught, and went to Jerusalem.
Someone said to him, "Lord, are there few who are saved?" He said to them:
"Strive to enter by the narrow gate; for many, I tell you, will seek to enter and will not be able to do so.
When the householder has risen and closed the door, and you have gone outside and knocked at the door, saying, "Lord, Lord, open to us," he will answer you, "I do not know you, and I do not know where you come from."
Then you will begin to say, "We have eaten and drunk in your presence, and you have taught in our streets."
And he will say: "I tell you, I do not know where you are from. Depart from me, all you workers of iniquity."
There will be weeping and gnashing of teeth when you see Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and all the prophets in the kingdom of God, and yourselves cast out.
They will come from the east, from the west, from the north and from the south, and they will sit in the kingdom of God.
Behold, there are the last who will be the first, and there are the first who will be the last. »
That same day the Pharisees came and said to him, "Come out of here and go away, for Herod wants to kill you."
He said to them, "Go and tell this fox, 'Behold, I cast out demons and I do healings today and tomorrow, and on the third day I complete my mission.
Nevertheless, I must continue my journey today, tomorrow and the day after tomorrow, for it is not possible for a prophet to perish outside Jerusalem.
"Jerusalem, Jerusalem, you who kill the prophets and stone those who are sent to her! How often have I wanted to gather your children, as a hen gathers her brood under her wings, and you have refused!
Behold, your house will be left deserted to you. I tell you, you will not see me until you say, "Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord."
As he entered the house of one of the chief Pharisees on the Sabbath to eat bread, they observed him.
And behold, a man suffering from dropsy was in front of him.
Jesus, speaking to the jurists and Pharisees, said, "Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath?"
But they were silent. He took him, cured him, and let him go.
He answered them, "Which of you, if his son or ox fell into a well, would not immediately pull him out on the Sabbath?"
They could not answer him on these things.
He addressed a parable to the guests, noticing that they chose the best seats, and he said to them:
"When someone invites you to a wedding, do not sit in the best place, for it may be that someone more honorable than you is invited by him,
and let the one who invited you both come and say, "Make room for this person." Then you would start, with shame, to take the lowest place.
But when you are invited, go and sit in the lowest place, so that the one who invited you will come and say to you, "My friend, go up higher." Then you will be honored in the presence of all those who are at the table with you.
For whoever exalts himself will be humbled, and whoever humbles himself will be exalted. »
He also said to the one who had invited him, "When you prepare a dinner or a supper, do not call your friends, nor your brothers, nor your relatives, nor rich neighbors, for they may also reciprocate and pay you.
But when you make a feast, ask the poor, the crippled, the lame, or the blind;
And you will be blessed, because they do not have the means to reimburse you. For you will be repaid at the resurrection of the righteous. »
When one of those who were at table with him heard these things, he said to him, "Blessed is he who makes a feast in the kingdom of God!"
But he said to him, "A man has made a great supper, and he has invited many people.
At mealtime, he sent his servant to say to the guests, "Come, for everything is ready now.
All of them, as one man, began to apologize. The first said to him, "I have bought a field, and I must go and see it. I apologize for me.
