Another said, "I have bought five pairs of oxen, and I must go and try them. I apologize for me.
Another said, "I married a woman, so I can't come.
"And this servant came, and told his master these things. The householder, angry, said to his servant, "Go quickly through the streets and alleys of the city, and bring the poor, the crippled, the blind, and the lame.
"The servant said, 'Lord, it is done as you have commanded, and there is still room.'
The master said to the servant, "Go to the roads and hedges, and force them to come in, so that my house may be filled.
For I tell you that none of these men who have been invited will taste my supper.'
Now a great crowd went with him. He turned to them and said:
"If anyone comes to me and does not disregard his father, mother, wife, children, brothers and sisters, and even his own life, he cannot be my disciple.
Whoever does not carry his own cross and follow me, cannot be my disciple.
For which of you, if he wishes to build a tower, does not first sit down to calculate the cost of it, in order to see if he has enough to complete it?
Or, when he has laid the foundation and cannot finish, all who see him begin to laugh at him,
saying, "This man began to build and could not finish."
Or what king, when he goes to meet another king in a war, does not first sit down to see if he is able, with ten thousand men, to meet him who comes against him with twenty thousand men?
Or, while the other is still far away, he sends an emissary and asks for peace conditions.
Therefore, the one among you who does not renounce all that he possesses cannot be my disciple.
"Salt is good, but if the salt becomes flat and tasteless, what do you season it with?
It is not good for the land or for the dung heap. We throw him out. Let him who has ears to hear, hear. »
Now all publicans and sinners came to him to hear him.
The Pharisees and scribes murmured, saying, "This man welcomes sinners and eats with them."
He told them this parable:
"Which of you, if he had a hundred sheep and lost one, would not leave the ninety-nine others in the wilderness to run after the one that is lost, until he finds it?
When he has found it, he carries it on his shoulders rejoicing.
When he returned home, he called his friends and neighbors, saying to them, "Rejoice with me, for I have found my sheep that was lost!"
I say unto you, likewise, there shall be more joy in heaven for one sinner who repents, than for ninety-nine righteous people who have no need of repentance.
"Or what woman, if she had ten drachmas, if she lost one, would not light a lamp, sweep the house, and search diligently until she found it?
When she has found it, she summons her friends and neighbors saying: "Rejoice with me, for I have found the drachma I had lost!"
In the same way, I say to you, there is joy in the presence of the angels of God over one sinner who repents. »
He said, "A man had two sons.
The youngest said to his father: "Father, give me my share of your property." So he divided his livelihood between them.
A few days after, the younger son collected all these and went to a distant country. There he squandered his possessions by living in debauchery.
When he had spent everything, a great famine came upon that country, and he began to be in need.
He went to attach himself to one of the citizens of that country, who sent him to his fields to feed the pigs.
He wanted to fill his belly with the pods that the pigs ate, but no one gave him any.
When he came to himself, he said, "How many of my father's hirelings have bread in abundance, and I am dying of hunger!
I will get up and go to my father, and I will say to him, "Father, I have sinned against heaven and in your sight.
I am no longer worthy to be called your son. Make me one of your hirelings. »''
"He got up and went to his father. But, as he was still far away, his father saw him and was moved with compassion; he ran, threw himself on his neck and kissed him.
The son said to him, "Father, I have sinned against heaven and in your eyes. I am no longer worthy to be called your son."
"But the father said to his servants, 'Bring the most beautiful robe and put it on him. Put a ring on his hand and sandals on his feet.
Bring the fattened calf, kill it, let us eat and celebrate;
for this one, my son, was dead and he lives again. He was lost and he is found. And they began to celebrate.
"Now, his eldest son was in the fields. As he approached the house, he heard music and dancing.
He called one of the servants and asked him what was going on.
He said to him, "Your brother has arrived, and your father has killed the fattened calf, for he has received it safe and sound.
But he became angry and would not enter. Then his father went out and begged him.
But he replied to his father, "I have served you for so many years and I have never disobeyed one of your commandments, but you have never given me a goat so that I can celebrate with my friends.
But when your son arrived, he who devoured your life with prostitutes, you killed the fatted calf for him.
He said to him, "My son, you are always with me, and all that is mine is yours.
But it was fitting to celebrate and rejoice, for this one, your brother, was dead, and he rose again. He was lost, and he is found. »
He also said to his disciples, "There was a rich man who had a manager. He was reproached that this man was wasting his property.
He called to him and said, "What do I hear about you? Give an account of your management, because you can no longer be a manager.
"The manager said to himself, 'What am I going to do, since my lord is taking away the position of manager from me? I don't have the strength to dig deeper. I am ashamed to beg.
I know what I will do, so that, when I am relieved of my duties, I will be received in his house.
Calling each of his master's debtors, he said to the first, "How much do you owe to my master?"
He replied, "A hundred batos of oil." He said to him: "Take your ticket, sit down quickly and write fifty".
He then said to another, "How much do you owe? He replied, "A hundred corns of wheat." He said to him, "Take your note, and write eighty.
"His lord congratulated the dishonest manager because he had acted wisely, for the children of this world are, in their own generation, wiser than the children of light.
I say to you, make friends by means of an iniquitous mammon, so that when you fail, they may receive you into the eternal tents.
He who is faithful in a few things is also faithful in many. He who is dishonest for a few things is also dishonest for many.
If, then, you have not been faithful in unrighteous riches, who will entrust you with true riches?
If you have not been faithful in what belongs to others, who will give you what belongs to you?
No servant can serve two masters, for either he will hate one and love the other, or he will cling to one and despise the other. You cannot serve God and mammon. »
The Pharisees, who loved money, also heard all these things, and they mocked him.
He said to them, "You are the ones who justify yourselves in the eyes of men, but God knows your hearts. For that which is exalted among men is an abomination in the sight of God.
"The law and the prophets went as far as John. From then on, the Good News of the Kingdom of God is preached, and everyone enters it by force.
But it is easier for heaven and earth to pass away than to make a little stroke of the pen fall from the law.
"Whoever divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery. Whoever marries a divorced woman commits adultery.
There was a rich man there, dressed in purple and fine linen, and living every day in luxury.
A beggar, named Lazarus, was led to his door, covered with sores,
and desirous of feeding on the crumbs that fell from the rich man's table. And even the dogs came to lick his wounds.
The beggar died, and he was carried away by the angels into the bosom of Abraham. The rich man also died and was buried.
In Hades he lifted up his eyes, being a prey to torments, and he saw Abraham in the distance, and Lazarus in his bosom.
He cried out, "Father Abraham, have mercy on me, and send Lazarus, that he may dip the tip of his finger in the water and cool my tongue. For I am prey to anguish in this flame.
"But Abraham said, 'My son, remember that you received your good things while you were alive, and Lazarus in the same way received bad things. But now he is comforted and you are in anguish.
In addition to all this, between us and you, a great gap is fixed, so that those who want to pass from here to you cannot do so, and no one can pass from there to us."
He said, "I ask you, then, father, to send him to my father's house.
for I have five brothers - that he may bear witness to them and that they too may not go to this place of torment."
"But Abraham said to him, 'They have Moses and the prophets. Let them listen to them.
"He answered, 'No, father Abraham, but if anyone comes to them from the dead, they will repent.'
"He said to him, 'If they do not listen to Moses and the prophets, neither will they be convinced if anyone rises from the dead.'
He said to the disciples, "It is impossible that there should be no opportunities for sinning, but woe to him through whom they come!
It would be better for him to have a millstone hung around his neck and thrown into the sea, rather than to make one of these little ones stumble.
Beware. If your brother sins against you, rebuke him. If he repents, forgive him.
If he has sinned against you seven times in a day, and seven times he returns, saying, "I repent," you shall forgive him. »
The apostles said to the Lord, "Increase our faith."
The Lord said, "If you had faith like a mustard seed, you would say to that sycamore tree, 'Uproot yourself and plant yourself in the sea,' and it would obey you.
But who among you, having a servant who ploughs or herds sheep, will say to him, when he returns from the field, "Come and sit down at the table at once"?
Will he not rather say to him: "Prepare my meal, dress properly, and serve me while I eat and drink. Then you will eat and drink"?
Does he thank this servant because he did as he was commanded? I don't think so.
In the same way, you also, when you have done all that has been commanded you, say, "We are unworthy servants. We have done our duty. »
As he was on his way to Jerusalem, he passed through the borders of Samaria and Galilee.
As he entered a village, ten leper men, who were standing aside, came to meet him.
They lifted up their voices and said, "Jesus, Master, have mercy on us!"
When he saw them, he said to them, "Go and show yourselves to the priests." As they went, they were cleansed.
One of them, seeing that he was healed, retraced his steps, glorifying God with a loud voice.
He fell on his face at the feet of Jesus and gave thanks to him; he was a Samaritan.
Jesus answered, "Have not the ten been cleansed? But where are the other nine?
Have not others been found who have returned to give glory to God, except this stranger? »
Then he said to him, "Get up and go away. Your faith has healed you. »
When the Pharisees asked him when the kingdom of God would come, he replied, "The kingdom of God does not come as an observer;
neither will we say, "Look here!" or "Look there!" for behold, the Kingdom of God is within you. »
He said to the disciples, "The days will come when you will desire to see one of the days of the Son of man, and you will not see it.
You will be told: "Look here!" or "Look there!" Do not walk away or follow them,
for as lightning, when it starts from one part of heaven, shines to another part of heaven, so it will be with the Son of Man in his day.
But first he must suffer a lot and be rejected by this generation.
As it was in the days of Noah, so will it be in the days of the Son of Man.
They ate, they drank, they married, and they were betrothed until the day Noah got into the boat, and the flood came and destroyed them all.
It was the same in the days of Lot: they ate, they drank, they bought, they sold, they planted, they built;
but on the day that Lot came out of Sodom, there fell from heaven a rain of fire and brimstone, which destroyed them all.
So it will be on the day when the Son of Man is revealed.
On that day, whoever is on the roof and has his goods in the house, let him not come down to take them away. In the same way, let not whoever is in the field turn back.
Remember Lot's wife!
He who seeks to save his life loses it, but he who loses his life preserves it.
I tell you, on that night, there will be two people in the same bed. One will be taken and the other left.
There will be two people grinding grain together. One will be taken and the other left."
And they, answering, asked him, "Where, Lord?" He said to them, "Where the body is, there also the vultures will be gathered."
He also told them, in a parable, that they should always pray and not be discouraged,
saying, "There was a judge in a certain city who did not fear God and did not respect men.
There was a widow in that city who often came to him and said, "Defend me against my adversary."
He would not for some time; but then he said to himself, 'Although I do not fear God and do not respect man,
however, because this widow is bothering me, I will defend her, or else she will tire me out by her continual coming.'
The Lord said, "Listen to what the unrighteous judge says.
Will not God take vengeance on his elect who cry out to him day and night, and yet show patience with them?
I tell you that he will soon avenge them. However, when the Son of Man comes, will he find faith on earth? »
He also told this parable to some who were convinced of their own righteousness and despised all others:
Two men went up to the temple to pray, one a Pharisee, the other a publican.
The Pharisee stood and prayed alone thus: God, I thank you that I am not like the rest of men, extortionists, unjust, adulterers, nor even like this publican.
I fast twice a week. I give tithes of all that I receive.'
But the publican, who stood aside, did not even raise his eyes to heaven, but beat his breast, saying, "God, have mercy on me, who am a sinner.
I tell you, this one went down to his house justified rather than the other; for whoever exalts himself will be humbled, but he who humbles himself will be exalted. »
They also brought their babies to him, so that he could touch them. But the disciples, seeing this, rebuked them.
Jesus called them and said, "Let the little children come to me and do not hinder them, for the Kingdom of God belongs to those who are like them.
Verily, I say to you, whoever does not receive the Kingdom of God as a little child, will not enter it. »
A certain chief asked him, "Good master, what must I do to inherit eternal life?"
Jesus asked him, "Why do you call me good? No one is good, except one: God.
You know the commandments: "Do not commit adultery", "Do not commit murder", "Do not steal", "Do not bear false witness", "Honor your father and mother".
He replied, "I have observed all these things since my youth."
When Jesus heard this, he said to him, "You still lack one thing. Sell everything you have and distribute it to the poor. Then you will have treasure in heaven; then come, follow me. »
But when he heard these things, he became very sad, for he was very rich.
Jesus, seeing that he was very sad, said, "How difficult it is for those who have riches to enter the kingdom of God!
For it is easier for a camel to enter through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter the Kingdom of God. »
Those who heard him said, "Then who can be saved?"
But he said, "What is impossible to men is possible to God."
Peter said, "Look, we have left everything and followed you."
He said to them, "Verily, I say to you, there is no one who has left his house, or his wife, or his brothers, or his parents, or his children, for the sake of the kingdom of God,
who does not receive eternal life many times in this time and in the world to come. »
He took the twelve aside and said to them, "Behold, we are going up to Jerusalem, and all that is written by the prophets concerning the Son of Man will be fulfilled.
For he will be handed over to the Gentiles, he will be mocked, he will be insulted, he will be spat on.
He will be scourged and put to death. On the third day, he will rise again. »
They didn't understand anything about these things. This word was hidden from them, and they did not understand the things that were said.
As he approached Jericho, a blind man sat by the side of the road begging.
Hearing a crowd passing by, he asked what it meant.
He was told that Jesus of Nazareth was passing by.
He cried out, "Jesus, son of David, have mercy on me!"
Those who led the way rebuked him to be silent; but he cried out even louder, "Son of David, have mercy on me!"
When Jesus stopped, he ordered him to be brought to Himself. Approaching, he asked him:
"What do you want me to do?" He said, "Lord, that I may see again."
Jesus said to him, "Receive your sight. Your faith has healed you. »
Immediately he received his sight and followed him, glorifying God. All the people, when they saw him, praised God.
He entered and passed through Jericho.
There was a man named Zacchaeus. He was a great tax collector, and he was rich.
He sought to see who Jesus was, but he could not because of the crowd, for he was of small stature.
So he ran ahead and climbed a sycamore tree to see him, for he was going to pass that way.
When Jesus arrived at this place, he looked up and saw him, and he said to him, "Zacchaeus, hurry down, for today I must stay with you."
He hastened, alighted, and received him with joy.
When they saw him, they all murmured, saying, "He has come in to lodge with a man who is a sinner."
Zacchaeus, standing, said to the Lord, "Behold, Lord, half of my possessions I give to the poor. If I have unjustly demanded something from someone, I give him back four times more. »
Jesus said to him, "Today salvation has come to this house, for he also is the son of Abraham.
For the Son of Man came to seek and save what was lost. »
When they heard these things, he went on and told a parable, because he was near Jerusalem, and they supposed that the kingdom of God was going to be revealed immediately.
So he said, "A certain nobleman went to a distant country to receive a kingdom and to return.
He called ten of his servants, gave them ten pieces of mina, and said to them, "Mind your own business until I come.
But his fellow citizens hated him and sent an emissary after him, saying, 'We do not want this man to rule over us.'
"When he returned, after receiving the kingdom, he commanded that these servants, to whom he had given the money, should be called to him, that he might know what they had gained by doing business.
The first one came before him and said, "Lord, your mina has made ten more minas.
He said to him, "It is good, good servant. Because you have been found faithful with very little, you will have authority over ten cities.
"The second came, saying, 'Your mina, Lord, has made five minas.'
He said to him, "And you will be the ruler of five cities."
Another came, saying, "Lord, here is your mina, which I have kept in a handkerchief,
for I feared you, because you are a demanding man. You gather what you have not laid down, and you reap what you have not sown.
He said to him, "With your own mouth I will judge you, wicked servant! You knew that I am a demanding man, taking what I have not laid down and reaping what I have not sown.
So, why didn't you deposit my money in the bank, so that when I return, I get an interest on it?
He said to those who were standing there, "Take away the mina from him and give it to the one who has the ten minas.
They said to him, "Lord, he has ten minas!
For, I say to you, to whoever has anything, more will be given; but from him who has nothing, even what he has will be taken away.
But bring here those of my enemies who did not want me to reign over them, and kill them before me. »
Having said these things, he set out on his way, going up to Jerusalem.
When he approached Bethsphage and Bethany, on the mountain called the Mount of Olives, he sent two of his disciples,
saying, "Go to the other side of the village, where you will find, on entering, a colt tied, on which no one has ever sat. Untie it and bring it in.
If someone asks you, "Why are you untying him?" say to him, "The Lord needs him."
Those who had been sent went away and found things exactly as he had said them.
As they were untying the colt, its owners said to them, "Why are you untying the colt?"
They answered, "The Lord needs it."
Then they brought him to Jesus. They threw their cloaks over the colt, and made Jesus sit on it.
While he was going, they spread their cloaks on the road.
As he approached the descent of the Mount of Olives, the whole multitude of the disciples began to rejoice and to praise God aloud for all the wonders they had seen.
saying, "Blessed be the King who comes in the name of the Lord!" Peace in heaven, and glory in the highest! »
Some of the Pharisees of the crowd said to him, "Master, rebuke your disciples!"
He answered them, "I tell you, if they were silent, the stones would cry out."
When he came near, he saw the city and wept over it,
saying, "If you had known today the things that belong to your peace! But now they are hidden from your eyes.
For the days will come upon you when your enemies will set up a barricade against you, surround you, and enclose you on all sides,
and will throw you to the ground, you and your children who are in you. They will not leave one stone in you on top of the other, because you have not known the moment of your punishment. »
He entered the temple and began to drive out those who were buying and selling there,
saying to them, "It is written, 'My house is a house of prayer, but you have made it a 'den of thieves.'"
He taught every day in the temple, but the chief priests, the scribes, and the chief men of the people sought to destroy him.
They could not find what they could do, for all the people were attached to his every word.
One of these days, as he was teaching the people in the temple and preaching the Good News, the priests and scribes came to him with the elders.
They asked him, "Tell us, by what authority do you do these things? Or who gives you this authority? »
He replied, "I will also ask you a question. Tell me:
Was John's baptism from heaven, or from men? »
They reasoned thus: "If we say, 'From heaven,' he will say, 'Why did you not believe him?'"
But if we say, "Men," all the people will stone us, for they are persuaded that John was a prophet. »
They replied that they did not know where it came from.
Jesus said to them, "Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things."
He began to tell this parable to the people: A man planted a vineyard, rented it to farmers, and went on a long stay in another country.
At the proper time, he sent a servant to the tenants to collect his share of the fruit of the vine. But the peasants beat him and sent him away empty.
He sent another servant, who was also beaten and ill-treated, and who was sent away empty.
He sent a third again; they wounded him also and threw him out.
The owner of the vineyard said, "What shall I do? I will send my beloved son. Maybe when they see him, they will respect him.
"But when the peasants saw him, they reasoned among themselves, saying, 'He is the heir. Come, let us kill him, so that the inheritance may come back to us.
Then they threw him out of the vineyard and killed him. What will the master of the vineyard do to them?
He will come and destroy these peasants, and he will give the vineyard to others. When they heard this, they said, "May it never be! »
But he looked at them and said, "Then what is the meaning of what is written, 'The stone which the builders rejected was made the chief cornerstone?'
All who fall on this stone will be broken in pieces, but it will reduce to dust the one on whom it falls. »
The chief priests and the scribes were trying to lay their hands on him at that very hour, but they feared the people, for they knew that he had spoken this parable against them.
They watched him and sent spies, who pretended to be righteous, in order to trap him in one of his words, to deliver him to the power and authority of the governor.
They asked him this question: "Master, we know that you say and teach what is right, that you have no bias for anyone, and that you truly teach the way of God.
Are we allowed to pay taxes to Caesar or not? »
But, realizing their cunning, he said to them: "Why do you try me?
Show me a denarius. To whom does the image and the inscription it bears belong? They answered, "Caesar's." »
He said to them, "Render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and to God the things that are God's."
They did not succeed in trapping him in his words before the people. They were surprised by his answer and were silent.
Some of the Sadducees came to him, those who deny the existence of the resurrection.
They asked him: "Master, Moses wrote to us that if a man's brother dies having a wife and is childless, his brother should take the wife and raise children for his brother.
So there were seven brothers. The first took a wife, and died childless.
The second took her as his wife, and he died childless.
The third took it, and the other seven left no children and died.
After this, the woman also died.
Wherefore, at the resurrection, shall she be the wife of her? For the seven had her for their wife. »
Jesus said to them, "The children of this world marry and are given in marriage.
But those who are deemed worthy to reach this world and the resurrection of the dead do not marry or are given in marriage.
For they can no longer die, since they are like angels and are children of God, being children of the resurrection.
But that the dead rise, Moses himself showed at the bush, when he called the Lord "God of Abraham, God of Isaac, and God of Jacob."
Now he is not the God of the dead, but of the living, for all are alive to him. »
Some of the scribes replied, "Master, you speak well."
They did not dare to ask him any further questions.
He said to them, "Why is it said that Christ is the son of David?
David himself says in the book of Psalms, The Lord said to my Lord, "Sit at my right hand,
"David calls him Lord, how is he his son?"
In the presence of all the people, he said to his disciples:
"Beware of those scribes who love to walk about in long robes, and who love greetings in the marketplaces, the best seats in the synagogues, and the best places in the festivals;
who devour the houses of widows, and who, for a pretext, make long prayers. These will receive a greater condemnation. »
He looked up and saw the rich putting their gifts into the treasury.
He saw a poor widow throwing two small pieces of brass.
He said, "Verily I say to you, this poor widow has put more than all of them,
for all these have given gifts to God of their superfluity, but she, from her poverty, has put all she had to live. »
As some were talking about the temple and how it was decorated with beautiful stones and gifts, he said:
"As for these things which you see, the days will come when there will not be one stone left here upon another that is not overturned."
They asked him, "Master, when will these things happen? What is the sign that these things are going to happen? »
He said, "Take heed that you do not let yourselves be led astray, for many will come in my name, saying, 'It is I,' and 'The time is at hand.' So don't follow them.
When you hear of wars and troubles, do not be terrified, for these things must happen first, but the end will not come immediately. »
Then he said to them, "A nation will rise up against a nation, and a kingdom against a kingdom.
There will be great earthquakes, famines, and pestilences in various places. There will be terrors and great signs from heaven.
But before all this, they will lay hands on you, persecute you, deliver you up to synagogues and prisons, bring you before kings and governors, for my name's sake.
The result will be a testimony for you.
So get it into your head not to think in advance about how to respond,
for I will give you a mouth and wisdom that all your adversaries will not be able to resist or contradict.
You will be delivered even by your parents, brothers, relatives and friends. They will have some of you put to death.
You will be hated by all men for my name's sake.
And not a hair of your head will perish.
"It is by your endurance that you will earn your living.
"But when you see Jerusalem surrounded by armies, know that its desolation is at hand.
So let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains. Let those who are in the midst of it go. Let those who are in the countryside not enter it.
For these are days of vengeance, that all that is written may be fulfilled.
Woe to pregnant women and those who are breastfeeding in those days! For there will be great distress in the land and great anger for this people.
They will fall under the edge of the sword, and they will be taken captive to all the nations. Jerusalem will be trodden under foot by the Gentiles, until the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled.
There will be signs in the sun, moon, and stars; and on earth, the anguish of the nations, in perplexity because of the roaring of the sea and the waves;
men will be seized with fear and expectation of the things that are going to happen to the world, for the powers of heaven will be shaken.
Then they will see the Son of Man coming on a cloud with power and great glory.
But when these things begin to happen, look up and lift up your heads, for your redemption is near. »
He told them a parable. "Look at the fig tree and all the trees.
When they are already budding, you see it and you know for yourself that summer is already near.
In the same way, you too, when you see these things happening, you know that the Kingdom of God is at hand.
Truly, I say to you, this generation will not pass away until all is accomplished.
Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will not pass away.
"Take heed, then, that your hearts do not weigh down under the weight of the pleasures of the feast, of the drunkenness and cares of the present life, and that this day does not come upon you unexpectedly.
For he will come as a snare for all those who dwell on the face of the whole earth.
Watch therefore continually, praying that you may be counted worthy to escape all these things that will happen, and to present yourselves before the Son of man. »
Every day Jesus taught in the temple, and every evening he went out and spent the night on the mountain called Mount Olivet.
All the people came early in the morning to him in the temple to listen to him.
Now the feast of unleavened bread, which is called the Passover, was approaching.
The chief priests and scribes were looking for how they could put him to death, for they feared the people.
Satan entered into Judas, also called Iscariot, who was numbered among the twelve.
He went away, and conversed with the chief priests and military commanders as to how he could deliver him up to them.
They were happy, and agreed to give him money.
He consented to this, and sought an opportunity to deliver him up to them in the absence of the crowd.
The day of unleavened bread arrived, when the Passover was to be sacrificed.
Jesus sent Peter and John, saying, "Go and prepare the Passover for us, that we may eat it."
They said to him, "Where do you want us to prepare?"
He said to them, "Behold, when you have entered the city, a man carrying a jug of water will come to meet you. Follow him into the house where he will enter.
Say to the master of the house, "The master says to you, 'Where is the guest room where I can eat the Passover with my disciples?'
He will show you a large furnished upper room. Make your preparations there. »
They went out, found things as Jesus had told them, and they prepared for the Passover.
When the hour came, he sat down with the twelve apostles.
He said to them, "I have long desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer,
for, I say to you, I will not eat of it until it is fulfilled in the kingdom of God. »
He received a cup, and, after giving thanks, he said, "Take this and divide it among yourselves,
for I say to you, I will not drink of the fruit of the vine at all, until the kingdom of God is accomplished. »
He took bread, and, after giving thanks, he broke it and gave it to them, saying, "This is my body, which is given for you. Do this in memory of me. »
In the same way, after the meal, he took the cup, saying, "This cup is the new covenant in my blood, which is poured out for you.
But behold, the hand of him who betrays me is with me on the table.
The Son of Man is indeed departing, as he has been decided, but woe to the man by whom he is betrayed! »
They began to wonder among themselves which of them was the one who would do this thing.
A dispute also arose between them, as to which of them was considered the greatest.
He said to them, "The kings of the nations rule over them, and those who have authority over them are called 'benefactors.'
But it is not the same for you. On the contrary, let him who is the greatest among you become like the youngest, and the one who governs, like the one who serves.
For who is greater, the one who sits at the table, or the one who serves? Isn't it the one who sits at the table? But I am in your midst as one who serves.
"But you are the ones who have persevered with me in my trials.
I give you a kingdom, as my Father has conferred on me,
so that you may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom. You will sit on thrones, and you will judge the twelve tribes of Israel. »
The Lord said, "Simon, Simon, behold, Satan has asked to have you all, that he may sift you like wheat,
but I have prayed for you, that your faith may not fail. You, when you have turned around, strengthen your brothers. »
He said to him: "Lord, I am ready to go with you to prison and to death!"
He said, "I tell you, Peter, the will not crow today until you have denied three times that you know me."
He said to them, "When I sent you without purse, without bag, and without sandals, did you lack anything?" They said, "Nothing."
Then he said to them, "Now, if anyone has a purse, let him take it, and a sack. If anyone has none, let him sell his cloak and buy a sword.
For I say to you, it is still necessary that what is written in me should be fulfilled, "He was numbered among the transgressors." For what concerns me is fulfilled. »
They said, "Lord, here are two swords." He told them, "Enough is enough."
He went out and went, according to his custom, to the Mount of Olives. His disciples also followed him.
When he arrived at that place, he said to them, "Pray that you may not enter into temptation."
He withdrew from them about a stone's throw away, and, having knelt down, he prayed,
saying, "Father, if you will, remove this cup from me. However, let it not be my will that is done, but yours. »
An angel from heaven appeared to him, and strengthened him.
Being in agony, he prayed more ardently. His sweat became like large drops of blood falling on the ground.
Having risen after praying, he came to the disciples and found them asleep because of sadness,
and he said to them, "Why do you sleep? Stand up and pray that you do not enter into temptation. »
While he was still speaking, a crowd appeared. He who was called Judas, one of the twelve, was at their head. He approached Jesus to kiss him.
But Jesus said to him, "Judas, is it by a kiss that you betray the Son of man?"
Those who were around him, seeing what was about to happen, said to him, "Lord, shall we strike with the sword?"
A number of them struck the servant of the high priest, and cut off his right ear.
But Jesus answered, "Let me at least do this." He touched his ear and healed him.
Jesus said to the chief priests, the temple rulers, and the elders, who had come against him, "You went out as against a robber, with swords and staves?
When I was with you every day in the temple, you did not lay a hand on me. But this is your hour, and the power of darkness. »
They seized him, took him away, and conducted him to the house of the high priest. But Pierre followed at a distance.
When they had lit a fire in the middle of the courtyard and sat down together, Peter sat down in the midst of them.
A servant saw him as he was sitting in the light, and, looking at him attentively, she said, "This man also was with him."
He denied Jesus, saying, "Woman, I do not know Him."
A little later, someone else saw him and said, "You too are one of them!" But Peter answered, "I am not a man."
After about an hour had passed, another confidently said, "Verily, this man also was with him, for he is a Galilean."
But Peter said, "Boy, I don't know what you're talking about!" Immediately, while he was still speaking, a crowed.
The Lord turned around and looked at Peter. Peter then remembered the word of the Lord, who had said to him, "Before the crows, you shall deny me three times."
He went out, and wept bitterly.
The men who held Jesus mocked him and beat him.
Having blindfolded him, they struck him in the face and asked him, "Prophesy! Who is it that struck you? »
They said many other things against him, insulting him.
As soon as the day came, the assembly of the elders of the people assembled, the chief priests and the scribes, and they took him into their council, saying:
"If you are the Christ, tell us." But he said to them, "If I tell you, you will not believe,
and if I ask you, you will not answer me and let me go.
From now on, the Son of Man will sit at the right hand of the power of God. »
They all said, "Are you the Son of God?" He said to them, "You say so, because I am."
They said, "Why should we need another testimony? For we ourselves have heard from his own lips! »
The whole company got up and brought him before Pilate.
They began to accuse him, saying, "We have found this man who perverts the nation, who forbids Caesar to pay taxes, and who says that he himself is Christ, a king."
Pilate asked him, "Are you the king of the Jews?" He replied, "That's what you say."
Pilate said to the chief priests and the crowd, "I find no reason to accuse this man."
But they insisted, saying, "He stirs up the people, teaching in all Judea, from Galilee to hither."
But Pilate, having heard of Galilee, asked if this man was a Galilean.
When he heard that he was under Herod's jurisdiction, he sent him to Herod, who was also in Jerusalem at that time.
When Herod saw Jesus, he had great joy, for he had long desired to see him, having heard many things said about him. He hoped to see some miracle accomplished by him.
He questioned him with many words, but he did not answer.
The chief priests and the scribes, standing, accused him vehemently.
Herod and his soldiers humiliated him and mocked him. After they had clothed him in luxurious garments, they sent him back to Pilate.
On that day Herod and Pilate became friends, for they had previously been enemies of each other.
Pilate summoned the chief priests, the magistrates, and the people,
and said to them, "You have brought this man to me as a man who perverts the people; Now, after examining it before you, I have found no reason to accuse this man about the things of which you accuse him.
Neither did Herod, for I sent you to him, and behold, he did nothing worthy of death.
So I will chastise him and release him. »
However, he was to release a prisoner to them on the occasion of the feast.
But they all cried out together, "Let go of this man! Release us Barabbas,
who had been thrown into prison for a revolt in the city and for murder. »
Then Pilate spoke to them again, wanting to release Jesus,
but they cried out, "Crucified! Crucify him! »
He said to them for the third time: "Why? What harm has this man done? I have not found in him any capital crime. So I will chastise him and release him. »
But they insisted aloud, demanding that he be crucified. Their voices and those of the chief priests prevailed.
Pilate decreed that whatever they asked for should be done.
He released the one who had been thrown into prison for insurrection and murder, the one they demanded, but he delivered Jesus to their will.
After taking him away, they seized a certain Simon of Cyrene who had come from the country and put the cross on him to carry it after Jesus.
A great crowd of the people followed him, including women who also wept and lamented him.
But Jesus, turning to them, said, "Daughters of Jerusalem, do not weep for me, but weep for yourselves and for your children.
For the days are coming when they will say: Blessed are the barren, the wombs that have not given birth, the breasts that have not suckled!
Then they will begin to say to the mountains, "Fall upon us," and to the hills, "Cover us."
For if they do these things in the green tree, what will be done in the dry tree?
There were also others, two malefactors, led with him to be put to death.
When they arrived at the place called "Skull", they crucified him there with the evildoers, one on the right and the other on the left.
Jesus said, "Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do." They divided his clothes by drawing lots.
The people were there, watching. The chiefs who were with them also mocked him, saying, "He saved others. Let him save himself, if this is the Christ of God, his chosen one! »
The soldiers also mocked him, approaching him and offering him vinegar,
and saying, "If you are the king of the Jews, save yourself!"
An inscription was also placed above him in Greek, Latin and Hebrew letters: "HE IS THE KING OF THE JEWS".
One of the criminals who had been hanged insulted him, saying, "If you are the Christ, save yourself and us."
But the other, speaking up, rebuked him and said, "You do not even fear God, since you are under the same condemnation?
For we are just, for we receive the reward of our deeds; but this man has done nothing wrong. »
He said to Jesus, "Lord, remember me when you come into your kingdom."
Jesus said to him, "Verily I say to you, today you will be with me in paradise."
It was about the sixth hour, and darkness spread over the whole country until the ninth hour.
The sun grew darker, and the veil of the temple was torn in two.
Jesus, uttering a loud cry, said, "Father, into your hands I commend my spirit." Having said this, he breathed his last.
The centurion, seeing what had happened, glorified God, saying, "Certainly, he was a righteous man."
The whole crowd that had gathered to see this, seeing what had happened, returned home beating their breasts.
All the people of his acquaintance and the women who had followed him from Galilee stood at a distance, observing these things.
Behold, there was a man named Joseph, a member of the Sanhedrin, a good and righteous man
(he had not consented to their counsels and actions), a native of Arimathea, a city of the Jews, who was also waiting for the kingdom of God.
This man went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.
He lowered it, wrapped it in a shroud, and laid it in a tomb hewn in stone, where no one had ever been laid.
It was the day of Preparation, and the Sabbath was approaching.
The women of Galilee who had come with him followed, and saw the tomb and the manner in which his body had been laid down.
They returned and prepared spices and ointments. On the Sabbath they rested, according to the commandment.
On the first day of the week, at dawn, they went to the tomb with other people, bringing the spices they had prepared.
They found the stone rolled up in front of the tomb.
They went in, and did not find the body of the Lord Jesus.
As they were very perplexed on this subject, behold, two men stood near them, dressed in dazzling garments.
Seized with terror, they prostrated themselves with their faces to the ground. Men said to them, "Why do you seek the living among the dead?
He is not here, but he is risen. Remember what he said to you, when he was still in Galilee,
namely, that the Son of Man is to be delivered into the hands of sinful men, to be crucified, and to rise again on the third day. »
They remembered his words,
returned from the tomb, and related all these things to the eleven and to all the others.
They were Mary Magdalene, Joanna and Mary, mother of James. The other women who were with them related these things to the apostles.
These words seemed to them foolish, and they did not believe them.
But Peter got up and ran to the tomb. He bent down and looked in; he saw the strips of linen spread out by themselves, and he went home, wondering what had happened.
Behold, on the same day, two of them went to a village called Emmaus, situated sixty stadia from Jerusalem.
They talked among themselves about all these things that had happened.
As they were discussing and questioning each other, Jesus himself drew near and walked with them.
But their eyes were prevented from recognizing him.
He said to them, "What are you talking about as you walk, and are you sad?"
One of them, named Cleopas, answered him, "Are you the only stranger in Jerusalem who does not know what has happened there these days?"
He said to them, "What things?" They said to him, "Concerning Jesus the Nazarene, who was a prophet mighty in deed and word before God and before all the people,
and how the chief priests and our leaders delivered him up to be condemned to death and crucified him.
But we hoped that he would be the one who would buy Israel. Yes, and on top of all that, it's now been the third day since these things happened.
Moreover, some of the women of our company astonished us, having arrived early at the tomb;
and not having found his body, they came to say that they too had seen a vision of angels, who said that he was alive.
Some of us went to the tomb and found him as the women had said, but they did not see him. »
He said to them, "Foolish people, and slow of heart to believe all that the prophets have foretold!
Must not Christ have suffered these things and entered into his glory? »
Starting from Moses and all the prophets, he explained to them in all the Scriptures what concerned him.
They approached the village where they were going, and he pretended to go further.
They urged him, saying, "Stay with us, for evening has just fallen, and the day is almost over." He went in to stay with them.
After sitting down to table with them, he took the bread and gave thanks. He broke it and gave it to them.
Their eyes were opened, and they recognized him; then he disappeared from their sight.
They said to one another, "Did not our hearts burn within us while he spoke to us on the way and opened the Scriptures to us?"
They got up that very hour, returned to Jerusalem, and found the eleven assembled, and those who were with them,
saying, "The Lord is truly risen, and has appeared to Simon."
They related what had happened on the way, and how they had recognized him by the breaking of the bread.
As they said this, Jesus himself stood in their midst and said to them, "Peace be with you."
But they were terrified and filled with fear, and they supposed that they had seen a spirit.
He said to them, "Why are you troubled? Why do doubts arise in your hearts?
See my hands and my feet, that it is really me. Touch me and see, for a spirit has no flesh and bones, as you see that I have. »
When he had said this, he showed them his hands and feet.
As they did not yet believe in joy and were astonished, he said to them, "Have you anything here to eat?"
They gave him a piece of grilled fish and honeycomb.
He took them, and ate in their presence.
He said to them, "This is what I told you when I was still with you, that all that is written about me in the law of Moses, in the prophets, and in the psalms must be fulfilled."
Then he opened their minds, that they might understand the Scriptures.
He said to them, "Thus it is written, and so it was necessary that Christ should suffer and rise from the dead on the third day,
and that repentance and forgiveness of sins should be preached in his name to all nations, beginning with Jerusalem.
You are witnesses of these things.
Behold, I am sending upon you the promise of my Father. But wait in the city of Jerusalem until you are clothed with power from on high. »
He led them as far as Bethany, and then raising his hands he blessed them.
While he was blessing them, he withdrew from them and was taken up to heaven.
They bowed down to him and returned to Jerusalem with great joy,
and they were continually in the temple, praising and blessing God. Amen.
In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.
The same was in the beginning with God.
All things were made by her. Without it, nothing has been done of what has been done.
In him was life, and life was the light of men.
The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not conquered it.
There came a man sent from God, whose name was John.
He came as a witness, to bear witness to the light, that all might believe through him.
He was not the light, but he was sent to bear witness to the light.
The true light, which enlightens everyone, came into the world.
He was in the world, and the world was made by him, and the world did not recognize him.
He came to his own, and his own did not receive him.
But to all who received him, he gave the right to become children of God, to those who believe in his name,
who are born, not of the blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God.
The Word became flesh and lived among us. We have seen his glory, a glory like that of the only begotten Son of the Father, full of grace and truth.
John testified of him. He cried out, "He of whom I said, 'He who comes after me has surpassed me, for he was before me.'"
From his fullness, we have all received grace upon grace.
For the law was given by Moses. Grace and truth have been realized by Jesus Christ.
At no time has anyone seen God. The only-begotten Son, who is in the bosom of the Father, has declared it.
This is the testimony of John, when the Jews sent priests and Levites from Jerusalem to ask him, "Who are you?"
He declared, and did not deny, but he declared, "I am not the Christ."
They asked him, "Who? Are you Elijah? He said, "I'm not." "You are the prophet?" He replied, "No." »
So they said to him, "Who are you? Give us an answer to report to those who sent us. What do you say about yourself? »
He says, "I am the voice of him crying in the wilderness, 'Make straight the way of the Lord,' as the prophet Isaiah said."
Those who had been sent were Pharisees.
They asked him, "Why do you baptize, if you are neither the Christ, nor Elijah, nor the prophet?"
John answered them, "I baptize in water, but there is someone among you whom you do not know.
It is he who comes after me, who is preferred to me, and whose strap I am not worthy to untie. »
These things were happening at Bethany, on the other side of the Jordan, where John was baptizing.
The next day he saw Jesus coming to him, and he said, "Behold, the Lamb of God, who takes away the sin of the world!
It is he of whom I have said: "After me comes a man who is preferred to me, for he was before me.
I did not know him, but that is why I came to baptize in water, that he might be revealed to Israel. »
John testified: "I saw the Spirit descend from heaven like a dove, and he remained upon him.
I did not recognize him, but the one who sent me to baptize in water said to me: "The one on whom you will see the Spirit descend and remain is the one who baptizes in the Holy Spirit.
I have seen and testified that he is the Son of God. »
The next day, John was still standing with two of his disciples,
and, looking at Jesus who was walking, he said, "Behold the Lamb of God."
The two disciples heard him speak, and they followed Jesus.
Jesus turned round, saw them following him, and said to them, "What are you looking for?" They said to him, "Rabbi," "Where do you live?"
He said to them, "Come and see." They came and saw where he was, and they stayed with him that day. It was about the tenth hour.
One of those who had heard John and followed him was Andrew, brother of Simon Peter.
He first found his own brother, Simon, and said to him, "We have found the Messiah!" (that is, according to the interpretation, Christ).
He brought him to Jesus. Jesus looked at him and said, "You are Simon, son of Jonah. You will be called Cephas" (which is, by interpretation, Peter).
The next day, determined to go to Galilee, he found Philip. Jesus said to him, "Follow me."
Now Philip was of Bethsaida, the city of Andrew and Peter.
Philip, having found Nathanael, said to him, "We have found him of whom Moses in the law and also the prophets spoke: Jesus of Nazareth, son of Joseph."
Nathanael said to him, "Can anything good come out of Nazareth?" Philip said to him, "Come and see."
Jesus, seeing Nathanael approaching him, said of him, "This is truly an Israelite in whom there is no deceit!"
Nathanael said to him, "How do you know me?" Jesus answered him, "Before Philip called you, when you were under the fig tree, I saw you."
Nathanael replied, "Rabbi, you are the Son of God! You are the King of Israel! »
Jesus answered him, "Because I said to you, 'I saw you under the fig tree,' do you believe? You'll see bigger things than these! »
He said to him, "Most assuredly, I say to you all, you will see heaven opened from now on, and the angels of God ascending and descending on the Son of man."
On the third day there was a wedding at Cana of Galilee. The mother of Jesus was there.
Jesus was also invited, with his disciples, to the wedding.
When the wine ran out, Jesus' mother said to him, "They have no wine."
Jesus said to her, "Woman, what does this have to do with you and me? My time has not yet come. »
His mother said to the servants, "Whatever he tells you, do it."
Now, he| there were six stone vessels of water, placed according to the method of purification of the Jews, and each containing two or three meters.
Jesus said to them, "Fill the vessels with water." So they filled them to the brim.
He said to them, "Now draw a little water, and carry it to the master of the festival." So they took it.
When the master of the meal had tasted the water that had become wine and did not know where it came from (but the servants who had drawn the water knew), the master of the meal called the bridegroom
and said to him, "Let each one serve the good wine first, and then, when the guests have drunk, the less good. You, you have kept the good wine until now! »
This beginning of his miracles Jesus accomplished at Cana of Galilee, and he revealed his glory; and his disciples believed in him.
After this, he went down to Capernaum, he, his mother, his brothers, and his disciples, and they stayed there a few days.
The Passover of the Jews was at hand, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
He found in the temple those who sold oxen, sheep, and doves, and the money-changers seated.
He made a whip of ropes and drove them all out of the temple, both the sheep and the oxen; he threw the money of the moneychangers and overturned their tables.
To those who sold the doves, he said, "Take these things away from here! Do not make my Father's house a marketplace! »
His disciples remembered that it was written, "Zeal for your house will devour me."
So the Jews answered him, "What sign do you show us, since you do these things?"
Jesus answered them, "Destroy this temple, and in three days I will raise it up."
So the Jews said, "It took forty-six years to build this temple! Will you raise it up in three days? »
But he spoke of the temple of his body.
So when he was raised from the dead, his disciples remembered that he had said this, and they believed the Scripture and the word that Jesus had spoken.
Now, when he was in Jerusalem, at the Passover, during the feast, many believed in his name, observing the miracles he performed.
But Jesus did not confide in them, because he knew everyone,
and that he had no need of anyone to bear witness about man, for he himself knew what was in man.
There was a man of the Pharisees, named Nicodemus, chief of the Jews.
He came to Jesus by night and said to him, "Rabbi, we know that you are a teacher from God; for no one can do these signs that you make, unless God is with him. »
Jesus answered him, "Verily, I say to you, unless anyone is born again, he cannot see the Kingdom of God."
Nicodemus said to him, "How can a man be born when he is old? Can he enter his mother's womb a second time and be born? »
Jesus answered, "Truly I say to you, unless a man is born of water and of the Spirit, he cannot enter the kingdom of God."
That which is born of the flesh is flesh. He who is born of the Spirit is spirit.
Do not be surprised that I said to you, "You must be born again."
The wind blows where it wills, and you hear its sound; but you do not know whence he comes or whither he goes. So it is with everyone who is born of the Spirit. »
Nicodemus replied, "How can these things be?"
Jesus answered him, "Are you the teacher of Israel, and do you not understand these things?
Verily I say to you, we speak what we know, and we bear witness of what we have seen, and you do not receive our testimony.
If I have told you earthly things and you do not believe, how will you believe if I tell you heavenly things?
No one has ascended into heaven except the one who came down from heaven, the Son of man, who is in heaven.
As Moses lifted up the serpent in the wilderness, so must the Son of Man be lifted up,
so that whoever believes in him may not perish, but have eternal life.
For God so loved the world that he gave his only begotten Son, that whoever believes in him should not perish, but have eternal life.
For God did not send his Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through him.
Whoever believes in him is not judged. He who does not believe is already judged, because he has not believed in the name of the only-begotten Son of God.
This is the judgment: light came into the world, and men preferred darkness to light, because their works were evil.
For whoever does evil hates the light and does not come to the light, lest his works be revealed.
But he who practices the truth comes to the light, that his works may be revealed, and that they may be done in God. »
After these things, Jesus came with his disciples to the land of Judea. He stayed there with them, and baptized.
John also baptized at Enon, near Salim, because there was a lot of water there. They came and were baptized;
for John had not yet been thrown into prison.
John's disciples then had a dispute with some Jews about the purification.
They came to John and said to him, "Rabbi, the one who was with you beyond the Jordan, and to whom you have borne witness, behold, he baptizes, and all the world come to him."
John answered, "A man cannot receive anything unless it has been given to him from heaven."
You yourselves bear witness that I said, "I am not the Christ," but "I was sent before him."
He who has the bride is the husband; but the friend of the bridegroom, who stands and listens to him, rejoices greatly because of the voice of the bridegroom. That is why my joy is complete.
It has to increase, but I have to decrease.
"He who comes from above is above all. He who comes from the earth belongs to the earth and speaks of the earth. He who comes from heaven is above all.
What he has seen and heard he testifies, and no one receives his testimony.
The one who received his testimony has stamped with his seal that God is true.
For he whom God has sent speaks the words of God, for God gives the Spirit without measure.
The Father loves the Son, and he has placed all things in his hands.
He who believes in the Son has eternal life, but he who disobeys the Son will not see life, but the wrath of God remains upon him. »
The Lord, knowing that the Pharisees had learned that Jesus was making and baptizing more disciples than John
(although Jesus himself did not baptize, but his disciples),
left Judea and went to Galilee.
He had to pass through Samaria.
So he came to a city in Samaria called Sychar, near the parcel of land that Jacob had given to his son Joseph.
Jacob's well was there. Jesus, tired from his journey, sat down by the well. It was about the sixth hour.
A woman from Samaria came to draw water. Jesus said to him, "Give me something to drink."
For his disciples had gone to the city to buy provisions.
So the Samaritan woman said to him, "How is it that you, who are a Jew, ask me, a Samaritan woman, for a drink?" (For the Jews have nothing to do with the Samaritans).
Jesus answered him, "If you knew what the gift of God is, and who it is that says to you, 'Give me something to drink,' you would have asked him, and he would have given you living water."
The woman said to him, "Sir, you have nothing to draw from, and the well is deep. Where are you going to get this living water?
Are you greater than our father Jacob, who gave us the well and drank from it himself, and his children and his cattle? »
Jesus answered him, "Whoever drinks of this water will thirst again,
but whoever drinks of the water that I will give him will never thirst again; the water that I will give him will become in him a fountain of water springing up to eternal life. »
The woman said to him, "Lord, give me this water, so that I may not thirst and come hither to draw."
Jesus said to her, "Go, call your husband, and come hither."
The woman replied, "I have no husband." Jesus said to her, "You have said, 'I have no husband.'
for you have had five husbands, and the one you have now is not your husband. You have said it in truth. »
The woman said to him, "Sir, I see that you are a prophet.
Our fathers prostrated themselves on this mountain, and you Jews say that the place to prostrate oneself is in Jerusalem. »
Jesus said to her, "Woman, believe me, the hour is coming when you will not worship the Father on this mountain or in Jerusalem.
You worship what you don't know. We worship what we know, for salvation comes from the Jews.
But the hour is coming, and it is now, when true worshippers will worship the Father in spirit and in truth, for the Father seeks such worshippers.
God is spirit, and those who worship him must worship in spirit and in truth. »
The woman said to him, "I know that the Messiah is coming, the one called Christ. When he comes, he will announce all things to us. »
Jesus said to him, "It is I who speak to you."
Immediately his disciples arrived. They were astonished that he was talking to a woman; yet no one said, "What are you looking for?" or "Why are you talking to her?"
So the woman left her water pot, went into the city and said to the people:
"Come and see a man who told me everything I did. Is this Christ? »
They went out of the city, and approached him.
Meanwhile, the disciples pressed him, saying, "Rabbi, eat."
But he said to them, "I have a meal to eat that you don't know."
So the disciples said to one another, "Has anyone brought him anything to eat?"
Jesus said to them, "My food is to do the will of him who sent me and to do his work.
Don't you say, "There are still four months before the harvest? Behold, I say to you, lift up your eyes and look at the fields: they are already white for the harvest.
The one who reaps receives a reward and reaps fruit for eternal life, so that the one who sows and the one who reaps may rejoice together.
For this saying is true: "One sows, the other reaps".
I have sent you to reap what you have not worked. Others have worked, and you have participated in their work. »
Many of the Samaritans of that city believed in him, because of the word of the woman, who testified, "He has told me all that I have done." »
So the Samaritans came to him and begged him to stay with them. He stayed there two days.
Many others believed because of his word.
They said to the woman, "Now we believe, not because of what you have said, but because we have heard it ourselves, and we know that it is truly Christ, the Savior of the world."
After these two days, he left thence and went to Galilee.
For Jesus himself testified that a prophet has no honor in his own country.
When he arrived in Galilee, the Galileans received him, after seeing all that he was doing in Jerusalem during the festival, for they also went to the festival.
So Jesus returned to Cana of Galilee, where he changed water into wine. There was a gentleman at Capernaum whose son was ill.
When he heard that Jesus had gone from Judea to Galilee, he went to him and begged him to come down and heal his son, for he was at the point of death.
Jesus then said to him, "Unless you see signs and wonders, you will not believe in any way."
The nobleman said to him, "Sir, come down before my child dies."
Jesus said to him, "Go away. Your son is alive. The man believed the word that Jesus had spoken to him, and he went away.
As he was descending, his servants came to meet him and said, "Your child lives!"
So he inquired of them what time he began to get better. So they said to him, "Yesterday, at the seventh hour, the fever left him."
The father knew, then, that it was at that hour that Jesus had said to him, "Your son lives." He believed, as well as all his house.
Here again is the second sign that Jesus made, after he had passed from Judea into Galilee.
After these things, there was a feast of the Jews, and Jesus went up to Jerusalem.
Now there is in Jerusalem, near the sheep's gate, a pool called in Hebrew "Bethesda," and with five porticoes.
A great crowd of the sick, the blind, the lame or the paralytic were lying there, waiting for the water to start moving.
There was a man there who had been ill for thirty-eight years.
Jesus, when he saw him lying there, and knowing that he had been sick for a long time, asked him, "Do you want to be healed?"
The sick man replied, "Lord, I have no one to put me in the pool when the water is agitated, but while I am coming, another comes down before me."
Jesus said to him, "Get up, take up your mat, and walk."
Immediately, the man was healed, he took up his carpet again and walked. Now, that day was a Sabbath.
So the Jews said to the one who had been healed, "It is the Sabbath. It is not permissible for you to carry the carpet. »
He replied, "The One who healed me said to me, 'Take up your carpet and walk.'"
Then they asked him, "Who is the man who said to you, 'Take your carpet and walk?'"
But the one who had been healed did not know who it was, for Jesus had withdrawn, a crowd being in the place.
After this, Jesus found him in the temple and said to him, "Behold, you are healed. Sin no more, so that nothing worse may happen to you. »
The man went away, and told the Jews that it was Jesus who had healed him.
Therefore the Jews persecuted Jesus and sought to put him to death, because he did these things on the Sabbath.
But Jesus answered them, "My Father is still working, and I am also working."
Therefore the Jews sought all the more to put him to death, because he not only violated the Sabbath, but also called God his own Father, thus making himself equal to God.
Jesus answered them, "Truly, I say to you, the Son can do nothing of himself, except what he sees the Father doing. For all that the Son does, so does the Son.
For the Father has affection for the Son, and he shows him all that he himself does. He will show him works greater than these, so that you may be astonished.
For as the Father raises the dead and gives them life, so the Son also gives life to whomever he wills.
For the Father judges no one, but has committed all judgment to the Son,
so that all may honor the Son, as they honor the Father. He who does not honor the Son does not honor the Father who sent him.
Verily I say to you, he who heareth my word and believes in him who sent me hath eternal life, and he does not come to judgment, but has passed from death to life.
Verily I say to you, the hour is coming, and it has already come, when the dead shall hear the voice of the Son of God, and those who have heard it shall live.
For as the Father has life in himself, so he gave the Son to have life also in himself.
He also gave him the power to judge, because he is the son of man.
Do not be surprised at this, for the hour is coming when all who are in the tombs will hear his voice
and those who have done good for the resurrection of life, and those who have done evil for the resurrection of judgment, will come forth.
I can't do anything on my own. As I hear, I judge; and my judgment is just, because I seek not my own will, but the will of my Father who sent me.
"If I testify of myself, my testimony is not valid.
It is another who testifies to me. I know that the testimony he gives of me is true.
You sent to John, and he bore witness to the truth.
But the testimony I receive does not come from a man. However, I say these things so that you may be saved.
He was the burning and shining lamp, and you were pleased to rejoice for a time in his light.
But the testimony I give is greater than that of John; for the works which the Father has given me to do, the very works which I do, bear witness to me, that the Father has sent me.
The Father himself, who sent me, has borne witness of me. You have never heard his voice, nor seen his face.
You do not have his word living in you, because you do not believe in him whom he has sent.
You search the Scriptures, because you think you have eternal life in them; they are the ones who bear witness to me.
But you do not want to come to me, to have life.
I receive no glory from men.
But I know you, and I know that you do not have the love of God in you.
I have come in the name of my Father, and you do not receive me. If another comes in his own name, you will receive him.
How can you believe, you who receive the glory of one another, and you who do not seek the glory that comes from the one God?
"Do not think that I will accuse you before the Father. There is one who accuses you, even Moses, in whom you have placed your hope.
For if you believed Moses, you would believe me, for he wrote about me.
But if you do not believe his writings, how will you believe my words? »
After this, Jesus went to the other side of the Sea of Galilee, which is also called the Sea of Galilee.
A great crowd followed him, because they saw the miracles he performed on the sick.
Jesus went up to the mountain, where he sat down with his disciples.
Now, the Passover, the feast of the Jews, was at hand.
Jesus, looking up and seeing that a great crowd was coming to him, said to Philip, "Where shall we buy loaves of bread that they may eat?"
He said this to test it, for he himself knew what he would do.
Philip replied, "Two hundred denarii of bread is not enough for them, so that each one may receive a little."
One of his disciples, Andrew, brother of Simon Peter, said to him:
"There is a boy here who has five barley loaves and two fish, but what is it, among many others?"
Jesus said, "Make the people sit down." Now, there was a lot of grass in this place. So the men sat down, about five thousand in number.
Jesus took the loaves; and after giving thanks, he distributed them to the disciples, and the disciples to those who were seated; they also took fish, as much as they wanted.
When they were satisfied, he said to his disciples, "Gather up the pieces that are left, so that nothing may be lost." »
So they gathered them up, and filled twelve baskets with the pieces of the five barley loaves that were left of those who had eaten.
When the people saw the sign that Jesus was making, they said, "It is truly the prophet who is coming into the world." »
Jesus, knowing that they were going to come and take him by force to make him king, withdrew again alone to the mountain.
When evening came, his disciples went down to the sea.
They got into the boat, and crossed the sea to Capernaum. It was already night, and Jesus had not come to them.
The sea was agitated by a strong wind that was blowing.
After rowing about twenty-five or thirty stadia, they saw Jesus walking on the sea and approaching the boat; and they were afraid.
But he said to them, "It is I; Don't be afraid. »
They therefore wished to receive him in the boat. Immediately the boat was near the land where they were going.
The next day, the crowd on the other side of the sea saw that there was no other boat there than the one in which his disciples had embarked, and that Jesus had not gone into the boat with his disciples, but that his disciples had gone alone.
Meanwhile, boats coming from Tiberias approached the place where they ate the bread after the Lord had given thanks.
The crowd, seeing that Jesus was not there, nor his disciples, got into the boats themselves and came to Capernaum, looking for Jesus.
When they found him on the other side of the sea, they asked him, "Rabbi, when did you come here?"
Jesus answered them, "Truly I say to you, you seek me, not because you have seen miracles, but because you have eaten bread and have been filled."
Do not seek the food that perishes, but that which endures to eternal life, and which the Son of Man will give you. For God the Father has sealed it. »
So they said to him, "What must we do to do the works of God?"
Jesus answered them, "The work of God is that you believe in Him whom He has sent."
So they said to him, "What are you doing as a sign, that we may see you and believe you? What work do you do?
Our fathers ate manna in the wilderness. As it is written, "He gave them bread from heaven to eat."
So Jesus said to them, "Truly, I say to you, it was not Moses who gave you the bread from heaven, but my Father gives you the true bread from heaven.
For the bread of God is that which comes down from heaven and gives life to the world. »
So they said to him, "Lord, give us this bread always."
Jesus said to them, "I am the bread of life. He who comes to me will not hunger, and he who believes in me will never thirst.
But I told you that you have seen me, and yet you do not believe.
All those whom the Father gives me will come to me. And I will not cast out anyone who comes to me.
For I have come down from heaven to do, not my own will, but the will of him who sent me.
Now it is the will of my Father who sent me that I should lose nothing of all that he has given me, but that I should raise him up at the last day.
This is the will of him who sent me: that whoever sees the Son and believes in him should have eternal life; and I will raise him up on the last day. »
So the Jews murmured about him, because he had said, "I am the bread that came down from heaven."
They said, "Is not this Jesus, the son of Joseph, whose father and mother we know? How then can he say, "I have come down from heaven?"
Jesus answered them, "Do not murmur among yourselves.
No one can come to me unless the Father who sent me draws him; and I will raise him up on the last day.
It is written in the prophets: "All will be instructed by God. Therefore all who hear of the Father and have learned, come to me.
It is not that anyone has seen the Father, but the one who comes from God. He has seen the Father.
Verily, I say to you, whoever believes in me has eternal life.
I am the bread of life.
Your fathers ate manna in the wilderness and died.
This is the bread that comes down from heaven, so that whoever eats of it and does not die.
I am the living bread that came down from heaven. If anyone eats of this bread, he will live forever. Yes, the bread that I will give for the life of the world is my flesh. »
So the Jews were arguing among themselves, saying, "How can this man give us his flesh to eat?"
So Jesus said to them, "Truly I say to you, unless you eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink his blood, you have no life in yourselves.
Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood has eternal life, and I will raise him up at the last day.
For my flesh is truly food, and my blood is truly drink.
He who eats my flesh and drinks my blood lives in me, and I in him.
As the Father who is alive has sent me, and I live through the Father, so he who feeds on me will also live through me.
This is the bread that came down from heaven, and not as our fathers ate manna and died. Whoever eats this bread will live forever. »
He said these things in the synagogue, as he taught in Capernaum.
Therefore many of his disciples, after hearing this, said, "This word is difficult to hear. Who can listen to him? »
But Jesus, knowing to himself that his disciples were murmuring about it, said to them, "Does this cause you to stumble?
What if you saw the Son of Man ascend to where He was before?
It is the spirit that gives life. Flesh is useless. The words I speak to you are spirit, and they are life.
But there are some among you who do not believe. For Jesus knew from the beginning who were those who did not believe, and who was the one who would betray him.
He said, "Therefore I have told you that no one can come to me except it is given to him by my Father."
At this, many of his disciples returned and walked no more with him.
Jesus then said to the twelve, "You also do not want to go away, do you?"
Simon Peter answered him, "Lord, to whom shall we go? You have the words of eternal life.
We have come to believe and know that you are the Christ, the Son of the living God. »
Jesus answered them, "Have I not chosen you, the twelve, and one of you is a devil?"
Now he was speaking of Judas, son of Simon Iscariot, for it was he who was going to betray him, being one of the twelve.
After these things, Jesus was walking in Galilee, because he did not want to walk in Judea, because the Jews were trying to put him to death.
Now, the feast of the Jews, the feast of the Booths, was at hand.
So his brothers said to him, "Go away from here and go to Judea, so that your disciples may also see the works you do."
For no one does anything in secret, while he seeks to be known openly. If you do these things, reveal yourself to the world. »
Because even his brothers did not believe in him.
So Jesus said to them, "My time has not yet come, but your time is always ready.
The world cannot hate you, but it hates me, because I testify about it that its works are evil.
You go up to the feast. I am not yet going up to this feast, because my time is not yet fulfilled. »
After he had told them these things, he remained in Galilee.
But as his brothers had gone up to the feast, he also went up to it, not publicly, but so to speak in secret.
So the Jews looked for him at the feast, and said, "Where is he?"
There was much murmuring among the crowd about him. Some said, "He is a good man." Others said, "No, but he leads the crowd astray."
But no one spoke openly of him, for fear of the Jews.
But, as the feast was already in the middle, Jesus went up into the temple and taught.
So the Jews were astonished, saying, "How does this man know letters, without ever having been instructed?"
So Jesus answered them, "My doctrine is not mine, but of him who sent me.
If anyone wants to do his will, he will know the doctrine, whether it comes from God or whether I speak of myself.
He who speaks of himself seeks his own glory, but he who seeks the glory of him who sent him is true, and there is no injustice in him.
Did not Moses give you the law, and none of you keep it? Why do you seek to kill me? »
The crowd replied, "You have a demon! Who is trying to kill you? »
Jesus answered them, "I have done one work, and you are all astonished because of it.
Moses gave you circumcision (not that it came from Moses, but from the fathers), and on the Sabbath day you circumcise a boy.
