If a boy is circumcised on the Sabbath, so that the law of Moses may not be violated, are you angry with me because I made a man completely sane on the Sabbath?
Do not judge according to appearances, but judge according to justice. »
Therefore some of those in Jerusalem said, "Is this not the one they are trying to put to death?"
Behold, he speaks openly, and they say nothing to him. Could it be that the leaders know that this is really Christ?
However, we know where this man comes from, but when Christ comes, no one will know where he comes from. »
So Jesus cried out in the temple, teaching and saying, "You know me, and you know where I come from. I did not come of my own accord, but he who sent me is true, he whom you do not know.
I know him, because I am of him, and he sent me. »
So they tried to take him; but no one laid hands on him, because his hour had not yet come.
But many among the crowd believed in him. They said, "When Christ comes, he will not make more signs than this man has made, will he?"
The Pharisees heard the crowd murmuring these things about him, and the chief priests and Pharisees sent agents to arrest him.
Then Jesus said, "I will stay with you a little longer, and then I will go to him who sent me.
You will look for me and you will not find me. You can't come where I am. »
So the Jews said among themselves, "Where will this man go, that we may not find him? Will he go to the Dispersion among the Greeks, and teach the Greeks?
What is this word that he said, 'You will seek me, and you will not find me,' and 'Where I am, you cannot come'? » .
Now on the last and greatest day of the feast, Jesus stood up and cried out, "If anyone is thirsty, let him come to me and drink!
Whoever believes in me, as the Scripture has said, rivers of living water will flow from his bosom. »
But he said this about the Spirit that those who believed in him were to receive. For the Holy Spirit was not yet given, because Jesus was not yet glorified.
Many of the crowd, when they heard these words, said, "This is truly the prophet." »
Others said, "It is Christ." But some said, "What, does Christ come from Galilee?
Did not Scripture say that Christ comes from the seed of David, and from Bethlehem, the village where David was? »
So there was a division in the crowd because of him.
Some of them wanted to arrest him, but no one got their hands on him.
So the ushers went to the chief priests and Pharisees, and they said to them, "Why did you not bring him?"
The officers replied, "No one has ever spoken like this man!"
So the Pharisees answered them, "You too are not lost, are you?
Did any of the leaders, or any of the Pharisees, believe in him?
But this multitude, which does not know the law, is cursed. »
Nicodemus, who was one of them, and who had come to him by night, said to them:
"Does our law judge a man without first hearing him personally and without knowing what he is doing?"
They answered him, "Are you also from Galilee? Seek and see that no prophet has arisen from Galilee. »
Everyone went to their own house,
but Jesus went to the Mount of Olives.
But early in the morning he entered the temple again, and all the people came to him. He sat down and taught them.
The scribes and Pharisees brought a woman caught in adultery. Having placed it in the middle,
they said to him, "Master, we have found this adulterous woman in the act."
Now, in our law, Moses commanded us to stone such women. What do you say to her? »
They said this to test him, in order to have something to reproach him with. But Jesus stooped down and wrote on the ground with his finger.
As they continued to question him, he looked up and said to them, "Whoever among you is without sin should throw the first stone at him."
Again he stooped down and wrote on the ground with his finger.
The latter, after hearing this, convinced by their conscience, went out one by one, from the oldest to the last. Jesus was left alone with the woman, where she was, in the middle.
Jesus stood up and saw her and said, "Woman, where are your accusers? No one condemned you? »
She said, "Nobody, Lord." Jesus said, "Neither do I condemn you. Go your way. From now on, sin no more. »
Jesus spoke to them again, saying, "I am the light of the world. He who follows me will not walk in darkness, but will have the light of life. »
So the Pharisees said to him, "You testify of yourself. Your testimony is not valid. »
Jesus answered them, "Even though I bear witness of myself, my testimony is true, for I know whence I come and whither I am going; but you, you know neither where I come from nor where I am going.
You judge according to the flesh. I don't judge anyone.
And even if I judge, my judgment is true, for I am not alone, but I am with the Father who sent me.
It is also written in your law that the testimony of two people is valid.
I am the one who testifies of myself, and the Father who sent me testifies of me. »
So they said to him, "Where is your Father?" Jesus answered, "You know neither me nor my Father. If you knew me, you would also know my Father. »
Jesus spoke these words in the treasury, as he taught in the temple. And no one stopped him, because his time had not yet come.
So Jesus said to them again, "I am going away, and you will seek me, and you will die in your sins. Where I am going, you cannot come. »
So the Jews said, "Will he kill himself, because he says, 'Where I go, you cannot come?'"
He said to them, "You are from below. I'm from above. You are of this world. I am not of this world.
So I told you that you will die in your sins; for if you do not believe that I am Him, you will die in your sins. »
So they said to him, "Who are you?" Jesus said to them, "What I have told you from the beginning.
I have a lot to say and judge about you. But he who sent me is true; and what I have heard from him, I say to the whole world. »
They did not understand that he was talking to them about the Father.
So Jesus said to them, "When you have lifted up the Son of man, you will know that it is I, and I do nothing of myself; but it is as my Father has taught me that I say these things.
He who sent me is with me. The Father has not left me alone, for I always do what is pleasing to Him. »
As he spoke thus, many believed in him.
So Jesus said to the Jews who had believed in him, "If you abide in my word, you are truly my disciples.
You will know the truth, and the truth will set you free. »
They replied, "We are the descendants of Abraham, and we have never been enslaved to anyone. How can you say, "You will be set free"? »
Jesus answered them, "Truly I say to you, whoever commits sin is a slave to sin."
A slave does not always remain in the house. A son remains forever.
If, therefore, the Son makes you free, you will be truly free.
I know that you are the seed of Abraham, and yet you seek to kill me, because my word finds no place in you.
I tell the things that I saw with my Father; and you also do the things you saw with your father. »
They replied, "Our father is Abraham." Jesus said to them, "If you were the children of Abraham, you would do the works of Abraham.
But now you seek to kill me, I who have told you the truth that I have heard from God. It was not Abraham who did this.
You do the works of your father. They said to him, "We were not born of sexual immorality." We have one Father, God. »
That is why Jesus said to them, "If God were your father, you would love me, for I have gone out and come from God. For I did not come of my own accord, but he sent me.
Why don't you understand my word? Because you do not hear my word.
You are your father's devil, and you want to do your father's desires. He was a murderer from the beginning, and he does not stand in the truth, because there is no truth in him. When he tells a lie, he speaks of himself, for he is a liar and the father of lies.
But because I tell the truth, you don't believe me.
Which of you convicts me of sin? If I tell the truth, why do you not believe me?
He who is of God hears the words of God. Therefore you do not hear, because you are not of God. »
Then the Jews answered him, "Do we not say that you are a Samaritan, and that you have a demon?"
Jesus answered, "I have no devil, but I honor my Father and you dishonor me.
But I am not seeking my own glory. There is someone who seeks and judges.
Verily, I say to you, if anyone keeps my word, he will never see death. »
Then the Jews said to him, "We now know that you have a demon. Abraham is dead, as are the prophets; and you say, "If anyone keeps my word, he will never taste death.
Are you greater than our father Abraham, who died? The prophets are dead. Who do you think you are? »
Jesus answered, "If I glory in myself, my glory is nothing. It is my Father who glorifies me, whom you say is our God.
You have not known him, but I know him. If I said, "I don't know him," I'd be like you, a liar. But I know him and I keep his word.
Your father Abraham rejoiced to see my day. He saw it and rejoiced. »
So the Jews said to him, "You are not yet fifty years old! Have you seen Abraham? »
Jesus said to them, "Verily, I say unto you, before Abraham existed, I AM."
So they took stones to throw at him, but Jesus hid himself and went out of the temple, after passing through the midst of them, and so he passed.
As he passed by, he saw a man who had been blind from birth.
His disciples asked him, "Rabbi, who sinned, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?"
Jesus answered, "This man has not sinned, nor his parents, but that the works of God may be revealed in him."
I must do, while it is day, the works of him who sent me. Night comes, when no one can work.
As long as I am in the world, I am the light of the world. »
After saying this, he spat on the ground, made mud with his saliva, anointed the blind man's eyes with this mud,
and said to him, "Go and wash yourself in the pool of Siloam" (which means "Sent"). So he went away, washed himself, and came back seeing .
That is why the neighbors and those who had seen that he was blind before said, "Was it not he who sat and begged?"
Others said, "It is he." Still others said, "He resembles him." He said, "I am him."
So they asked him, "How were your eyes opened?"
He replied, "A man called Jesus made mud, anointed my eyes, and said, 'Go and wash yourself in the basin of Siloam.' So I left, I washed myself, and I recovered my sight. »
Then they asked him, "Where is he?" He said, "I don't know."
The one who had been blind was brought to the Pharisees.
It was a Sabbath when Jesus made the mud and opened his eyes.
The Pharisees asked him again how he had recovered his sight. He answered them, "He has put mud on my eyes, I have washed myself, and I see."
Some of the Pharisees, therefore, said, "This man is not of God, because he does not keep the Sabbath." Others said, "How can a man who is a sinner make such signs?" There was therefore division among them.
Therefore they asked the blind man again, "What do you say about him, since he has opened your eyes?" He said, "He's a prophet."
So the Jews did not believe about him that he had been blind and had recovered his sight, until they called the relatives of him who had received his sight,
and asked them, "Is this your son, whom you say was born blind? How does he see now? »
His parents replied, "We know that this is our son, and that he was born blind;
but we do not know how he sees now, nor who opened his eyes. He is of age. Ask him. He will speak himself. »
His parents said this because they feared the Jews; for the Jews had already agreed that if anyone would confess him as Christ, he should be cast out of the synagogue.
That is why his parents said: "He is of age. Ask him. »
So they called the blind man a second time and said to him, "Give glory to God. We know that this man is a sinner. »
So he answered, "I don't know if he is a sinner. But I know one thing: I was blind, and now I see. »
They said to him, "What has he done to you? How did he open your eyes? »
He answered them, "I have already told you, and you have not listened. Why do you want to hear it again? You don't want to become his disciples either, do you?
They insulted him and said, "You are his disciple, but we are the disciples of Moses.
We know that God spoke to Moses. But as for this man, we do not know where he comes from. »
The man replied, "It is astonishing! You don't know where he comes from, and yet he opened my eyes.
We know that God does not listen to sinners, but if someone is a worshipper of God and does His will, he listens to Him.
Since the beginning of the world, it has never been heard of anyone opening the eyes of a man born blind.
If this man did not come from God, he could not do anything. »
They answered him, "You were born entirely in sin, and you teach us?" So they threw him out.
When Jesus heard that they had cast him out, he found him and said to him, "Do you believe in the Son of God?"
He answered, "Who is he, Lord, that I should believe in him?"
Jesus said to him, "You have both seen him, and he is speaking to you."
He said, "Lord, I believe," and he prostrated himself before him.
Jesus said, "I have come into this world to judge, that those who do not see may see, and those who see may become blind."
Those of the Pharisees who were with him heard these things, and said to him, "Are we also blind?"
Jesus said to them, "If you were blind, you would have no sin; but now you say, "We see." Therefore your sin remains.
"Verily, I say to you, he who does not enter the sheepfold by the door, but goes up by another way, is a thief and a robber.
But the one who enters through the door is the shepherd of the sheep.
The doorkeeper opens the door for him, and the sheep listen to his voice. He calls his sheep by name and brings them out.
When he brings out his sheep, he goes ahead of them, and the sheep follow him, for they know his voice.
They will not follow a stranger, but they will flee from him, for they do not know the voice of strangers. »
Jesus told them this parable, but they did not understand what he was saying to them.
So Jesus said to them again, "Verily, I say to you, I am the gate of the sheep.
All those who came before me are thieves and robbers, but the sheep did not listen to them.
I am the door. If anyone enters through me, he will be saved, he will come in and out and find pasture.
The thief comes only to steal, kill and destroy. I have come that they may have life, and that they may have it in abundance.
"I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for his sheep.
He who is a hireling, and not a shepherd, who does not possess the sheep, sees the wolf coming, leaves the sheep and flees. The wolf seizes the sheep and scatters them.
The hireling runs away because he is a hireling and does not take care of the sheep.
I am the good shepherd. I know my own, and I am known to my own;
as the Father knows me, and I know the Father. I lay down my life for the sheep.
I have other sheep that are not of this fold. I must bring them also, and they will hear my voice. They will become one flock with one shepherd.
That is why the Father loves me, because I lay down my life, in order to take it back.
No one takes it away from me, but I give it myself. I have the power to give it, and I have the power to take it back. I received this commandment from my Father. »
Therefore there was again a division among the Jews because of these words.
Many of them said, "He has a demon and he is mad! Why do you listen to him? »
Others said, "These are not the words of a demon-possessed. It is not possible for a demon to open the eyes of a blind man, is it? » .
It was the feast of the Dedication in Jerusalem.
It was winter, and Jesus was walking in the temple, under the portico of Solomon.
So the Jews surrounded him and said to him, "How long will you keep us in suspense? If you are the Christ, tell us frankly. »
Jesus answered them, "I have told you, and you do not believe. The works that I do in the name of my Father bear witness to me.
But you do not believe, because you are not of my sheep, as I have told you.
My sheep hear my voice, I know them, and they follow me.
I give them eternal life. They will never perish, and no one will snatch them from my hand.
My Father, who gave them to me, is greater than all. No one can snatch them out of my Father's hand.
I and the Father are one. »
So the Jews again took stones to stone him.
Jesus answered them, "I have shown you many good works of my Father. For which of these works do you stone me? »
The Jews answered him, "It is not for a good work that we stone you, but for blasphemy, for being a man you make yourself God."
Jesus answered them, "Is it not written in your law, 'I said, 'You are gods?'
If he called them gods, to whom the word of God has come - and the Scripture cannot be broken,
Do you say of him whom the Father sanctified and sent into the world: "You blaspheme, because I said, I am the Son of God?"
If I do not do the works of my Father, do not believe me.
But if I do them, though you do not believe me, believe the works, that you may know and believe that the Father is in me, and that I am in the Father. »
They again tried to seize him, but he escaped from their hands.
He went again beyond the Jordan, to the place where John had first baptized, and he stayed there.
Many people came to him. They said, "John did not work miracles, but all that John said about this man is true."
There, many believed in him.
Now, a man was sick, Lazarus, from Bethany, from the village of Mary and her sister Martha.
It was this Mary, who had anointed the Lord with ointment and had wiped his feet with her hair, with whom brother Lazarus was sick.
So the sisters sent to him, saying, "Lord, behold, he for whom you have a great affection is sick."
But Jesus, having heard this, said, "This sickness is not for death, but for the glory of God, that the Son of God may be glorified by it."
Now Jesus loved Martha and her sister and Lazarus.
Having heard that the latter was ill, he remained two days in the place where he was.
Then, after this, he said to the disciples, "Let us return to Judea."
The disciples asked him, "Rabbi, the Jews wanted to stone you. Will you go back? »
Jesus answered, "Is there not twelve hours of daylight? If a man walks during the day, he does not flinch, because he sees the light of this world.
But if a man walks during the night, he stumbles, because the light is not in him. »
He said these things, and after that he said to them, "Our friend Lazarus has fallen asleep, but I am going to wake him from his sleep."
So the disciples said, "Lord, if he has fallen asleep, he will recover."
Now Jesus had spoken of his death, but they thought that he was talking about resting in sleep.
So Jesus said to them plainly, "Lazarus is dead."
I rejoice for you that you have not been there, so that you may believe. Nevertheless, let's go to him. »
Thomas, therefore, who is called Didymus, said to his companions in misfortune, "Let us go also, that we may die with him."
When Jesus arrived, he found that he had already been in the tomb for four days.
Now Bethany was near Jerusalem, about fifteen stadia away.
Many Jews had joined the women who surrounded Martha and Mary, to console them about their brother.
Martha, having heard that Jesus was coming, went to meet him, but Mary remained in the house.
Martha then said to Jesus, "Lord, if you had been here, my brother would not have died.
Even now, I know that whatever you ask of God, God will give you. »
Jesus said to him, "Your brother will be resurrected."
Martha said to him, "I know that he will rise again in the resurrection, on the last day."
Jesus said to him, "I am the resurrection and the life. Whoever believes in me will live, even if he dies.
He who lives and believes in me will never die. Do you believe that? »
She said to him, "Yes, Lord. I have come to believe that you are the Christ, the Son of God, the one who comes into the world. »
After saying this, she went away and secretly called Mary, her sister, saying, "The Master is here and he is calling you."
Having heard this, she quickly got up and went to him.
Now, Jesus had not yet entered the village, but he was at the place where Martha had met him.
Then the Jews who were with her in the house and comforted her, seeing that Mary was quickly getting up and going out, followed her, saying, "She is going to the tomb to weep."
Therefore, when Mary arrived at the place where Jesus was and saw him, she fell at his feet and said to him, "Lord, if you had been there, my brother would not have died."
Seeing therefore that she wept, and that the Jews who had come with her wept, Jesus groaned in spirit and was troubled,
and said, "Where did you lay him?" They said to him, "Lord, come and see."
Jesus wept.
So the Jews said, "See what affection he had for him!"
Some of them said, "Could not this man, who opened the eyes of the blind man, have prevented this man from dying?"
Jesus, groaning again within himself, went to the tomb. It was a cave, and a stone was placed against it.
Jesus said, "Take away the stone." Martha, the sister of the one who had died, said to him, "Lord, there is already a foul smell, for it is four days since he died."
Jesus said to him, "Have I not told you that if you believe, you will see the glory of God?"
So they removed the stone from the place where the dead man was lying. Jesus looked up and said, "Father, I thank you for listening to me.
I know that you always listen to me, but I said this because of the crowd that was standing there, so that they would believe that you sent me. »
When he had said this, he cried out in a loud voice, "Lazarus, get out of there!"
The one who was dead went out, his hands and feet bound with bandages, and his face was wrapped in a cloth. Jesus said to them, "Set him free, and let him go."
Therefore many of the Jews, who had come to Mary and seen what Jesus was doing, believed in him.
But some of them went to the Pharisees and told them the things that Jesus had done.
Then the chief priests and Pharisees took counsel and said, "What are we doing? For this man does many miracles.
If we leave him thus, everyone will believe in him, and the Romans will come and take away our place and our nation. »
But a certain Caiaphas, who was high priest that year, said to them, "You know nothing at all,
and you do not think that it is advantageous for us that one man should die for the people, and that the whole nation should not perish. »
He had not said this of himself, but, being high priest that year, he had prophesied that Jesus would die for the nation,
and not only for the nation, but also to gather into one the scattered children of God.
From that day on, they held a council to put him to death.
So Jesus no longer walked openly among the Jews, but went from there to the land near the desert, to a city called Ephraim. He stayed there with his disciples.
Now, the Passover of the Jews was at hand. Many went up from the country to Jerusalem before the Passover, to purify themselves.
Then they would look for Jesus, and standing in the temple, they would say to one another, "What do you think he doesn't come to the feast at all?"
Now the chief priests and the Pharisees had commanded that if anyone knew where he was, he should report it, so that they might seize him.
Six days before the Passover, Jesus went to Bethany, where was Lazarus, who had died, and whom he had raised from the dead.
There, they made him a supper. Martha was serving, but Lazarus was among those who were at table with him.
Mary took a pound of ointment of pure spikenard, very precious, and she anointed the feet of Jesus; she wiped his feet with her hair. The house was filled with the smell of perfume.
Then Judas Iscariot, son of Simon, one of his disciples, who was about to betray him, said:
"Why was not this ointment sold for three hundred denarii and given to the poor?"
He said this, not because he cared for the poor, but because he was a thief and having the piggy bank, he was in the habit of stealing what was put in it.
But Jesus said, "Leave her alone. She saved it for the day of my burial.
For you always have the poor with you, but you do not always have me. »
So a great crowd of Jews heard that he was there, and they came, not only for Jesus' sake, but also to see Lazarus, whom he had raised from the dead.
But the chief priests plotted to put Lazarus to death also,
because, because of him, many Jews went away and believed in Jesus.
The next day, a large crowd came to the party. When they heard that Jesus was coming to Jerusalem,
they took the branches of the palm trees, went out to meet her, and cried out, "Hosanna! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord, the king of Israel! »
Jesus, having found a young donkey, sat on it. According to the fact that it is written:
"Fear not, daughter of Zion. Behold, your King comes, seated on a colt. »
His disciples did not at first understand these things; but when Jesus was glorified, they remembered that these things were written of him, and that they had done them for him.
The crowd that was with him, when he called Lazarus out of the tomb and raised him from the dead, was therefore bearing witness to this.
Therefore also the crowd went to meet him, because they had heard that he had performed this miracle.
Then the Pharisees said to one another, "See how you do nothing. Behold, the world has gone after him. »
Now there were some Greeks among those who went up to prostrate themselves at the feast.
So they came to Philip, who was from Bethsaida in Galilee, and asked him, "Lord, we want to see Jesus."
Philip came to tell Andrew; and Andrew came in his turn with Philip, and they told Jesus.
Jesus answered them, "The time has come when the Son of Man will be glorified.
Truly I say to you, unless the grain of wheat falls to the ground and dies, it remains alone. But if it dies, it bears much fruit.
He who loves his life will lose it. Whoever hates his life in this world will keep it for eternal life.
If anyone serves me, let him follow me. Where I am, there will also be my servant. If anyone serves me, the Father will honor him.
"Now my soul is troubled. What shall I say? "Father, save me from this time"? But it is for this reason that I have arrived at this moment.
Father, glorify your name! Then a voice came out of heaven, saying, "I have glorified him and I will glorify him again." »
That's why the crowd that stood there and heard it said it was thunder. Others said, "An angel has spoken to him."
Jesus answered, "This voice did not come for my sake, but for your sake.
Now, this is the judgment of this world. Now the prince of this world will be cast out.
And I, if I am lifted up from the earth, will draw all peoples to myself. »
But he said this by indicating by what kind of death he was to die.
The crowd replied, "We have learned by the law that Christ abides forever. How do you say, "The Son of Man must be lifted up"? Who is this Son of man? »
So Jesus said to them, "The light is with you for a little while. Walk while you have the light, so that the darkness does not overtake you. He who walks in darkness does not know where he is going.
While you have the light, believe in the light, so that you become children of light. Jesus said these things, and then went away and hid himself from them.
But although he had performed so many miracles before them, they did not believe in him,
that the word which Isaiah the prophet had spoken might be fulfilled: "Lord, who believed our report? To whom has the arm of the Lord been revealed? »
Therefore they could not believe, for Isaiah also said:
"He blinded their eyes, and hardened their hearts, lest they see with their eyes, and perceive with their hearts, and turn, and I would heal them."
Isaiah said these things when he saw his glory, and he spoke of him.
However, many chiefs believed in him; but because of the Pharisees they did not confess it, so that they might not be excluded from the synagogue,
for they loved the praises of men better than those of God.
Jesus cried out, "He who believes in me does not believe in me, but in him who sent me.
He who sees me sees the one who sent me.
I have come as a light into the world, so that whoever believes in me may not remain in darkness.
If anyone listens to my words and does not believe, I do not judge him. For I have come not to judge the world, but to save the world.
He who rejects me, and does not receive my words, has someone who judges him. The word I have spoken will judge him on the last day.
For I have not spoken of myself, but the Father who sent me has given me a commandment, that I should know what I must say and what I must say.
I know that his commandment is eternal life. The things I say, therefore, I say as the Father has told me. »
Now, before the feast of the Passover, Jesus, knowing that his hour had come to leave this world for the Father, having loved his own who were in the world, loved them to the end.
During the meal, the devil having already put in the heart of Judas Iscariot, son of Simon, the desire to betray him,
Jesus, knowing that the Father had put all things into his hands, that he came from God and that he was going to God,
got up from the meal and laid aside his outer clothes. He took a towel and wrapped it around his waist.
Then he poured water into the basin, began to wash the disciples' feet and wipe them with the towel with which he was wrapped.
Then he approached Simon Peter. He said to him, "Lord, are you the one who washes my feet?"
Jesus replied, "You don't know what I'm doing now, but you'll understand later."
Peter said to him, "You will never wash my feet!" Jesus replied, "If I do not wash you, you have nothing to do with me."
Simon Peter said to him, "Lord, not only my feet, but also my hands and my head!"
Jesus said to him, "Someone who has bathed only needs to wash his feet, but he is completely pure. You are pure, but not all. »
For he knew the one who was going to betray him; therefore he says, "You are not all clean."
After washing their feet, putting on his outer garment and sitting down, he said to them, "Do you know what I have done to you?
You call me: "Master" and "Lord". You say it well, for I am like that.
If, therefore, I, the Lord and Master, have washed your feet, you must also wash one another's feet.
For I have given you an example, that you should also do as I have done to you.
Truly I say to you, the servant is not greater than his master, nor is the one sent greater than the one who sent him.
If you know these things, you are blessed if you put them into practice.
I am not talking about all of you. I know whom I have chosen, but it is so that the words of Scripture may be fulfilled: "He who eats bread with me has lifted up his heel against me."
From now on, I tell you before it happens, so that when it happens, you will believe that it is I.
I tell you with all certainty: he who receives him whom I send receives me; and he who receives me, receives him who sent me. »
When Jesus had said this, he was troubled in spirit, and he said, "I tell you with all certainty, one of you will deliver me up."
The disciples looked at each other, puzzled as to the person he was talking about.
One of his disciples, whom Jesus loved, was at table, leaning against Jesus' breast.
So Simon Peter beckoned him to come, and said to him, "Tell us who he is talking about."
He, leaning as he was on Jesus' breast, asked him, "Lord, who is it?"
So Jesus answered, "He to whom I will give this piece of bread when I have soaked it." So he dipped the piece of bread, and gave it to Judas, son of Simon Iscariot.
After the piece of bread, Satan entered into him. Then Jesus said to him, "What you do, do it quickly."
Now, no one at the table knew why he was saying this to her.
For some thought, because Judas had the piggy bank, that Jesus had said to him, "Buy what we need for the feast," or that he had to give something to the poor.
Having received this piece, he went out at once. It was night.
When he had gone out, Jesus said, "Now the Son of Man has been glorified, and God has been glorified in him."
If God has been glorified in him, God will also glorify him in himself, and he will glorify him immediately.
Little children, I will stay with you a little longer. You will seek me, and as I said to the Jews, "Where I go, you cannot come," I tell you now.
I give you a new commandment: Love one another. As I have loved you, you also, love one another.
By this all will know that you are my disciples, if you have love for one another. »
Simon Peter said to him, "Lord, where are you going?" Jesus answered, "Where I am going, you cannot follow me now, but you will follow me afterward."
Peter said to him, "Lord, why can't I follow you now? I will lay down my life for you. »
Jesus answered him, "Will you lay down your life for me? Verily, I say to you, the will not crow until you have denied me three times.
"Don't let your heart be troubled. Believe in God. Believe in me too.
In my Father's house, there are several houses. If it were not so, I would have told you. I'll prepare a place for you.
If I go and prepare a place for you, I will come back and receive you at my house, so that where I am, you will also be there.
You know where I am going, and you know the way. »
Thomas said to him, "Lord, we do not know where you are going. How can we know the way? »
Jesus said to him, "I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father except through me.
If you had known me, you would have known my Father also. From now on, you know him and you have seen him. »
Philip said to him, "Lord, show us the Father, and that will be enough for us."
Jesus said to him, "I have been with you so long, and you do not know me, Philip? Whoever has seen me has seen the Father. How do you say, "Show us the Father"?
Do you not believe that I am in the Father, and that the Father is in me? The words I speak to you, I do not speak of myself; but the Father who lives in me does his works.
Believe me that I am in the Father, and that the Father is in me; or believe me because of the works themselves.
Truly I say to you, he who believes in me will also do the works that I do, and he will do greater works, because I am going to my Father.
Whatever you ask in my name, I will do, so that the Father may be glorified in the Son.
If you ask for anything on my behalf, I will do it.
If you love me, keep my commandments.
I will pray to the Father, and he will give you another counselor, that he may abide with you forever:
the Spirit of truth, which the world cannot receive, because it does not see it and does not know it. You know him, for he dwells with you and he will be in you.
I will not leave you orphans. I will come to you.
A little while longer, and the world will see me no more; but you, you will see me. Because I live, you will live too.
In that day, you will know that I am in my Father, that you are in me, and that I am in you.
He who has my commandments and keeps them, he is the one who loves me. Whoever loves me will be loved by my Father, and I will love him, and I will reveal myself to him. »
Judas (and not Iscariot) said to him, "Lord, what has happened that you reveal yourself to us, and not to the world?"
Jesus answered him, "If a man loves me, he will keep my word. My Father will love him, and we will come to him, and we will make our home with him.
He who does not love me does not keep my words. The word you hear is not mine, but that of the Father who sent me.
"I told you these things while I was still living with you.
But the counselor, the Holy Spirit, whom the Father will send in my name, will teach you all things and will remind you of all that I have said to you.
I leave you in peace. It is my peace that I give you; it is not that which the world I give you gives. Let not your heart be troubled and may it not be afraid.
You have heard how I said to you: "I am going away, and I will return to you". If you loved me, you would rejoice in what I said, "I am going to my Father," for the Father is greater than I.
Now I told you this before it happened, so that when it happens, you may believe.
I will not speak much more with you, for the prince of the world is coming, and he has nothing in me.
But that the world may know that I love the Father, and that I do what the Father has commanded me. Get up, let us get out of here.
"I am the true vine, and my Father is the cultivator.
Every branch that is in me that does not bear fruit, he takes away. Every branch that bears fruit he prunes, so that it bears even more fruit.
You are already pruned, because of the word I have spoken to you.
Stay in me, and I in you. Just as the branch cannot bear fruit of itself unless it abides in the vine, so neither can you bear fruit unless you abide in me.
I am the vine. You are the branches. He who abides in me and in whom I abide bears much fruit, for outside of me you can do nothing.
If a man does not abide in me, he is cast up like a branch and withers; it is picked up, thrown into the fire and burned.
If you abide in me, and my words abide in you, you shall ask whatever you will, and it will be granted to you.
"My Father is glorified in that you bear much fruit; so you will be my disciples.
As the Father has loved me, I also have loved you. Abide in my love.
If you keep my commandments, you will abide in my love, as I have kept the commandments of my Father and abide in his love.
I have spoken these things to you, that my joy may abide in you, and that your joy may be complete.
"This is my commandment: Love one another, as I have loved you.
There is no greater love than this: that a man lay down his life for his friends.
You are my friends, if you do all that I command you.
I no longer call you servants, for the servant does not know what his master is doing. But I have called you friends, for all that I have heard from my Father I have made known to you.
It is not you who have chosen me, but I who have chosen and appointed you, that you may go and bear fruit, and that your fruit may remain, so that whatever you ask of the Father in my name, he may give it to you.
I command you these things, that you may love one another.
If the world hates you, you know that it hated me before it hated you.
If you were of the world, the world would love its own. But because you are not of the world, because I have chosen you out of the world, that is why the world hates you.
Remember the word I spoke to you: "A servant is not greater than his master." If they persecuted me, they will persecute you also. If they have kept my word, they will also keep yours.
But they will do all these things to you for my name's sake, because they do not know him who sent me.
If I had not come to speak to them, they would not have had sin; but now they have no excuse for their sin.
He who hates me, hates my Father also.
If I had not done among them the works that no one else has done, they would not have had sin. But now they have seen and they have also hated both me and my Father.
But this happened in order that the word that was written in their law might be fulfilled: "They hated me without cause.
When the counselor comes whom I will send you from the Father, the Spirit of truth, who comes from the Father, he will bear witness to me.
You also will bear witness, because you have been with me from the beginning.
"I have told you these things so that you may not be misled.
You will be chased out of the synagogues. Yes, the time is coming when the one who kills you will think that he is offering a service to God.
They will do these things because they have not known the Father or me.
But I have told you these things, so that when the time comes you may remember that I have spoken to you about them. I did not tell you these things from the beginning, because I was with you.
But now I am going to him who sent me, and none of you ask me, "Where are you going?"
But because I have told you these things, sorrow has filled your heart.
But I tell you the truth: it is advantageous for you that I go away, for if I do not go, the counselor will not come to you. But if I leave, I will send it to you.
When he comes, he will convict the world about sin, righteousness, and judgment;
concerning sin, because they do not believe in me;
concerning righteousness, because I am going to my Father, and you will see me no more;
concerning the judgment, because the prince of this world has been judged.
I still have many things to tell you, but you can't stand them now.
But when the Spirit of truth comes, he will lead you into all truth; for he will not speak of himself, but he will say all that he has heard. He will tell you the things that are to happen.
He will glorify me, for he will take of what is mine and declare it to you.
All that the Father has is mine; Therefore I have said that he takes of what is mine and will declare it to you.
"A little more time, and you won't see me. A little more time, and you will see me. »
So some of his disciples said to one another, "What does it mean that he says to us, 'A little while longer, and you will not see me; and a little more time, and you will see me; and: "Because I am going to the Father"? »
So they said, "What does it mean that he says, 'A little time?' We don't know what he says. »
Jesus understood that they wanted to question him, and he said to them, "You are asking yourselves what I have said: 'A little while longer, and you will not see me; then a little more time, and you will see me."
Verily, I say to you, you will weep and mourn, but the world will rejoice. You will be in sadness, but your sadness will turn into joy.
The woman, when she gives birth, is sad, for her hour has come. But when she gave birth to the child, she no longer remembers the anguish, because of the joy that comes from the birth of a human being in the world.
Therefore you are now in sorrow, but I will see you again, and your heart will rejoice, and no one will take away your joy.
"On that day, you will no longer ask me questions. Verily I say to you, whatever you ask of the Father in my name, he will give you.
So far, you have not asked for anything on my behalf. Ask, and you will receive, so that your joy may be complete.
"I have told you these things in figures of rhetoric. But the time is coming when I will no longer speak to you in words, but when I will speak to you clearly of the Father.
In that day you shall ask in my name; and I do not say to you that I will pray to the Father for you,
for the Father himself loves you, because you have loved me and believed that I came from God.
I came from the Father and I came into the world. Again, I leave the world and go to the Father. »
His disciples said to him, "Behold, you speak clearly and without a figure of speech.
We now know that you know everything, and that you don't need to be questioned. That is why we believe that you came from God. »
Jesus answered them, "Do you believe now?
Behold, the time is coming, and it has already come, when you will be scattered, each to his own, and when you will leave me alone. But I am not alone, for the Father is with me.
I have spoken these things to you, that in me you may have peace. In the world, you have difficulties; but take courage! I have conquered the world."
Jesus said these things, and then, raising his eyes to heaven, he said, "Father, the time has come. Glorify your Son, so that your Son also may glorify you.
As you have given him authority over all flesh, so he will give eternal life to all whom you have given him.
Eternal life is that they may know you, the only true God, and the one whom you have sent, Jesus Christ.
I have glorified you on earth. I have done the work that you gave me to do.
Now, Father, glorify me to yourself with the glory I had with you before the world existed.
"I have revealed your name to the people whom you have given me out of the world. They were yours, and you gave them to me. They have kept your word.
They now know that everything you have given me comes from you,
for the words which thou hast given me, I have given them; they received them, and they knew for sure that I came from you. They thought you had sent me.
I pray for them. I do not pray for the world, but for those whom you have given me, for they are yours.
All that is mine is yours, and you are mine, and I am glorified in them.
I am no longer in the world, but they are in the world, and I come to you. Holy Father, keep them by your name which you have given me, that they may be one, as we are.
While I was with them in the world, I kept them in your name. I have kept the ones you gave me. None of them is lost, except the son of destruction, that the Scripture may be fulfilled.
But now I come to you, and I speak these things in the world, that they may have my perfect joy in themselves.
I have given them your word. The world hated them because they are not of the world, just as I am not of the world.
I do not pray you to take them out of the world, but to preserve them from the evil one.
They are not of the world, just as I am not of the world.
Sanctify them in your truth. Your word is truth.
As you sent me into the world, so I sent them into the world.
For their sake I sanctify myself, that they also may be sanctified in the truth.
It is not only for them that I pray, but also for those who will believe in me by their word,
that they may all be one, as you, Father, are in me, and I in you, so that they also may be one in us, so that the world may believe that you have sent me.
The glory which thou hast given me, I have given them, that they may be one, as we are one,
I in them, and you in me, that they may become one, so that the world may know that you have sent me and that you have loved them as you have loved me.
Father, I desire that those whom you have given me should also be with me where I am, that they may see the glory you have given me, for you loved me before the foundation of the world.
Righteous Father, the world did not know you, but I knew you, and they knew that you had sent me.
I have made your name known to them, and I will make it known, so that the love with which you have loved me may be in them, and that I may be in them. »
When Jesus had spoken these words, he went out with his disciples to the other side of the Kidron stream, where there was a garden, into which he entered with his disciples.
Judas, who betrayed him, also knew this place, for Jesus often met there with his disciples.
Judas, therefore, having taken a detachment of soldiers and officers of the chief priests and Pharisees, came thither with lanterns, torches, and weapons.
So Jesus, knowing all that was happening to him, went out and said to them, "Whom are you looking for?"
They answered him, "Jesus of Nazareth." Jesus said to them, "I am he." Judas, who betrayed him, also stood with them.
When he said to them, "It is I," they stepped back and fell to the ground.
So he asked them again, "Whom are you looking for?" They said, "Jesus of Nazareth."
Jesus replied, "I told you it was I. If you seek me, let them go."
that the word which he has spoken may be fulfilled, "Of those whom you have given me, I have lost none."
Simon Peter, having a sword, drew it, struck the servant of the high priest, and cut off his right ear. The name of the servant was Malchus.
Jesus then said to Peter, "Put the sword back in its scabbard. Shall I not drink the cup which the Father has given me? »
So the detachment, the commander and the officers of the Jews seized Jesus, bound him,
and took him first to Annas, for he was the father-in-law of Caiaphas, who was high priest that year.
Now it was Caiaphas who had advised the Jews that it was fitting that one man should perish for the people.
Simon Peter followed Jesus, as well as another disciple. Now this disciple was known to the high priest, and he entered with Jesus into the court of the high priest;
but Pierre stood at the door, outside. The other disciple, who was known to the high priest, went out, spoke to the servant who guarded the door, and brought Peter in.
Then the maid who was guarding the door said to Peter, "Are you also one of this man's disciples?" He said, "I'm not."
Now the servants and officers were standing there, having made a fire of coals, for it was cold. They warmed up. Peter was with them, standing and warming himself.
So the high priest asked Jesus about his disciples and his teaching.
Jesus answered him, "I have spoken openly to the world. I have always taught in the synagogues and in the temple, where the Jews always gather. I didn't say anything in secret.
Why do you question me? Ask those who heard me what I told them. Here they know the things I have said. »
When he had said this, one of the officers who was standing there struck Jesus with his hand, saying, "Is this how you answer the high priest?"
Jesus answered him, "If I have spoken evil, testify to evil; but if I have spoken well, why do you strike me? »
Annas sent him bound to Caiaphas, the high priest.
Now Simon Peter was standing up and warming himself. So they said to him, "You are not also one of his disciples, are you?" He denied it and said, "I'm not."
One of the servants of the high priest, a relative of the one whose ear Peter had cut off, said, "Did I not see you with him in the garden?"
So Peter denied him again, and immediately the crowed.
So they led Jesus from Caiaphas to the praetorium. It was early, and they themselves did not enter the courtroom, so as not to defile themselves, but to be able to eat the Passover.
So Pilate went out to them and said, "What accusation do you bring against this man?"
They replied, "If this man were not a criminal, we would not have handed him over to you."
Pilate said to them, "Take him yourselves, and judge him according to your law." That is why the Jews said to him, "We are forbidden to put anyone to death."
that the word of Jesus, which he had spoken, might be fulfilled, indicating by what kind of death he was to die.
So Pilate went into the praetorium again, called Jesus, and said to him, "Are you the king of the Jews?"
Jesus answered him, "You say this to yourself, or have others told you about me?"
Pilate replied, "I am not a Jew, am I? Your own nation and the chief priests have delivered you up to me. What did you do? »
Jesus answered, "My kingdom is not of this world. If my kingdom were of this world, then my servants would fight, so that I would not be handed over to the Jews. But now, my Kingdom is not of this world. »
So Pilate said to him, "Are you a king?" Jesus answered, "You say that I am a king. That is why I was born, and that is why I came into the world, to bear witness to the truth. All who are of the truth listen to my voice. »
Pilate said to him, "What is truth?" When he had said this, he went out again to the Jews, and said to them, "I find no reason to accuse him.
But it is your custom for me to deliver someone to you at the Passover. Do you want me to release the king of the Jews to you? »
Then they all cried out again, saying, "Not this man, but Barabbas!" Now Barabbas was a brigand.
Pilate then took Jesus and had him whipped.
The soldiers twisted thorns into a crown, which they put on his head, and clothed him with a purple garment.
They kept saying, "Hail, King of the Jews!" and slapping him.
Then Pilate went out again, and said to them, "Behold, I bring him to you, that you may know that I find no reason to accuse him."
So Jesus went out, wearing the crown of thorns and the purple garment. Pilate said to them, "Behold the man!"
When the chief priests and ushers saw him, they cried out, and said, "Crucify! Crucified! Pilate said to them, "Take him yourselves and crucify him, for I find no reason to accuse him." »
The Jews answered him, "We have a law, and by our law he must die, because he has made himself the Son of God."
When Pilate heard these words, he was even more afraid.
He went into the praetorium again, and said to Jesus, "Where are you from?" But Jesus did not answer him.
Then Pilate said to him, "Do you not speak to me? Don't you know that I have the power to set you free and that I have the power to crucify you? »
Jesus answered, "You would have no power over me unless it were given to you from above. Therefore he who delivered me to you has a greater sin. »
At that time, Pilate was trying to release him, but the Jews cried out, "If you release this man, you are not Caesar's friend! Whoever makes himself king speaks against Caesar! »
As soon as Pilate heard these words, he brought Jesus out and sat down on the seat of the tribunal, in a place called "the Pavement," but in Hebrew, "Gabbatha."
Now it was the day of the preparation of the Passover, about the sixth hour. He said to the Jews, "Behold your King!"
They cried out, "Let him be driven away! Let us take him! Crucify him! Pilate said to them, "Shall I crucify your King?" The chief priests replied, "We have no king but Caesar!" »
Then he handed him over to them to be crucified. So they took Jesus and took him away.
He went out, carrying his cross, to go to the place called "place of the skull," which is called in Hebrew "Golgotha."
where they crucified him, together with two other persons, on each side, and Jesus in the middle.
Pilate also wrote a title, and put it on the cross. It was written: "JESUS OF NAZARETH, THE KING OF THE JEWS".
Many Jews read this title, because the place where Jesus was crucified was near the city; and it was written in Hebrew, Latin, and Greek.
So the chief priests of the Jews said to Pilate, "Do not write, 'The king of the Jews,' but, 'He said, 'I am the king of the Jews.'
Pilate replied, "What I have written, I have written."
The soldiers, after crucifying Jesus, took his garments and made four parts of them, one part for each soldier, and also the tunic. Now the tunic was seamless, woven from top to bottom.
Then they said to one another, "Let us not tear it up, but let us cast lots to whom it shall belong," so that the Scripture might be fulfilled, which says, "They have divided my garments among themselves. They drew lots for my clothes. That's why the soldiers did these things.
But near the cross of Jesus stood his mother, his mother's sister, Mary, wife of Clopas, and Mary Magdalene.
Jesus, seeing his mother and the disciple whom he loved standing there, said to his mother, "Woman, behold your son."
Then he said to the disciple, "Behold your mother." From that hour the disciple took her into his home.
After this, Jesus, seeing that all was now finished, in order that the Scripture might be fulfilled, said, "I am thirsty!"
A vase full of vinegar was placed there; a sponge full of vinegar was put on some hyssop, and it was brought to his mouth.
When Jesus had received the vinegar, he said, "It is finished." Then he lowered his head and gave up his mind.
The Jews, as it was the day of preparation, in order that the bodies might not remain on the cross on the Sabbath (for that Sabbath was special), asked Pilate to break their legs and carry them away.
So the soldiers came to break the legs of the first and the other who had been crucified with him.
But when they came to Jesus and saw that he was already dead, they did not break his legs.
But one of the soldiers pierced his side with a spear, and immediately blood and water came out.
He who has seen has given his testimony, and his testimony is true. He knows that he is speaking the truth, so that you may believe.
For these things have come to pass in order that the Scripture may be fulfilled: "None of his bones shall be broken."
Yet another Scripture says, "They shall look upon him whom they have pierced."
After this, Joseph of Arimathea, who was a disciple of Jesus, but in secret out of fear of the Jews, asked Pilate to be allowed to take away the body of Jesus. Pilate gave him permission. So he came and took away the body of Jesus.
Nicodemus, who had first come to see Jesus by night, also came to bring a mixture of myrrh and aloes, about a hundred Roman pounds.
So they took the body of Jesus, and bound it with the spices in cloths, according to the Jewish custom of burying it.
Now, in the place where he had been crucified, there was a garden. In this garden was a new tomb, in which no man had ever been put before.
Then, because of the day of the preparation of the Jews (for the tomb was near), they laid Jesus there.
On the first day of the week, Mary Magdalene went early, as it was still night, to the sepulchre, and she saw that the stone had been removed from the sepulchre.
So she ran and came to Simon Peter and the other disciple whom Jesus loved, and said to them, "They have taken the Lord out of the tomb, and we do not know where they have laid him."
So Peter and the other disciple went out and went to the tomb.
They were both running together. The other disciple preceded Peter and arrived first at the tomb.
Bending down to look, he saw the linen cloths that were there; but he did not enter.
Then Simon Peter, who followed him, entered the tomb. He saw the linen lying down,
and the linen that had been on Jesus' head, not lying with the linens, but rolled up in a separate place.
Then the other disciple, who had arrived first at the tomb, also entered; he saw and believed.
For they did not yet know the Scripture, according to which he must rise from the dead.
So the disciples went home.
Mary was standing outside, near the tomb, and she was weeping. As she wept, she stooped down and looked into the tomb,
and she saw two angels in white sitting, one at the head and the other at the feet, where the body of Jesus had been laid.
They asked her, "Woman, why are you crying?" She said to them, "Because they have taken my Lord away, and I do not know where they have put him."
Saying this, she turned around and saw Jesus standing, and she did not know that it was Jesus.
Jesus said to her, "Woman, why do you weep? Who are you looking for? She, supposing it to be the gardener, said to him, "Sir, if you have taken it away, tell me where you have deposited it, and I will take it away." »
Jesus said to her, "Mary." She turned around and said, "Rabboni!" which means, "Master!"
Jesus said to him, "Do not detain me, for I have not yet ascended to my Father; but go to my brethren and say to them, "I am ascending to my Father and your Father, to my God and your God." »
Mary Magdalene came to announce to the disciples that she had seen the Lord, and that he had spoken these things to her.
On the evening of that day, the first day of the week, the doors of the place where the disciples were assembled being locked, for fear of the Jews, Jesus came and placed himself in the midst of them and said to them, "Peace be with you."
When he had said this, he showed them his hands and his side. So the disciples rejoiced when they saw the Lord.
Jesus then said to them again, "Peace be with you. As the Father has sent me, I also send you. »
When he had said this, he breathed on them, and said to them, "Receive the Holy Spirit."
If you forgive someone's sins, they are forgiven them. If you retain someone's sins, they have been retained. »
But Thomas, one of the twelve, called Didymus, was not with them when Jesus came.
So the other disciples said to him, "We have seen the Lord!" But he said to them, "Unless I see the imprint of the nails in his hands, and put my finger in the imprint of the nails, and put my hand in his side, I will not believe."
Eight days later, his disciples were back inside and Thomas was with them. Jesus came, the doors being shut, placed himself in the middle and said, "Peace be with you."
Then he said to Thomas, "Put your finger out here, and look at my hands. Draw your hand here, and put it in my side. Do not be unbelieving, but believing. »
Thomas answered him, "My Lord and my God!"
Jesus said to him, "Because you have seen me, you have believed. Blessed are those who have not seen and who have believed. »
Jesus performed many other miracles in the presence of his disciples, which are not written in this book;
but these things were written so that you might believe that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God, and that by believing you might have life in his name.
After these things, Jesus revealed himself again to the disciples on the Sea of Galilee. He thus revealed himself.
Simon Peter, Thomas called Didymus, Nathanael, of Cana in Galilee, the sons of Zebedee and two other of his disciples were together.
Simon Peter said to them, "I am going to fish." They said to him, "We also come with you." They immediately went out and entered the boat. That night, they took nothing.
But, as the day had already come, Jesus stood on the beach; but the disciples did not know that it was Jesus.
So Jesus said to them, "Children, have you anything to eat?" They said, "No."
He said to them, "Cast the net on the right side of the boat, and you will find some." So they threw it away, and now they could not pull it for the multitude of fish.
So the disciple whom Jesus loved said to Peter, "It is the Lord!" When Simon Peter heard that it was the Lord, he wrapped himself in his cloak, for he was naked, and threw himself into the sea.
But the other disciples came in the little boat (for they were not far from the land, but about two hundred cubits), dragging the net full of fish.
When they came to dry land, they saw there a fire of coals, with fish and bread laid on it.
Jesus said to them, "Bring some of the fish you have just caught."
Simon Peter climbed up and drew ashore the net, full of one hundred and fifty-three large fish. Even though there were so many, the net did not tear.
Jesus said to them, "Come and have breakfast." None of the disciples dared to ask him, "Who are you?" knowing that it was the Lord.
Then Jesus came and took the bread and gave it to them, as well as the fish.
This is now the third time that Jesus reveals himself to his disciples after his resurrection from the dead.
After they had eaten, Jesus said to Simon Peter, "Simon, son of Jonah, do you love me more than these?" He said to him, "Yes, Lord; You know that I have affection for you. He said to him, "Feed my lambs." »
He said to him a second time, "Simon, son of Jonah, do you love me?" He said to him, "Yes, Lord; You know that I have affection for you. He said to him, "Serve my sheep." »
He said to him for the third time, "Simon, son of Jonah, do you have any affection for me?" Peter was grieved because he asked him for the third time, "Do you have any affection for me?" He replied, "Lord, you know everything. You know that I have affection for you. Jesus said to him, "Feed my sheep."
Truly, I tell you, when you were young, you dressed yourself and walked where you wanted. But when you are old, you will stretch out your hands, and another will dress you and carry you where you do not want to go. »
Now he said this to signify by what kind of death he would glorify God. When he had said this, he said to him, "Follow me."
Then Peter, turning round, saw a disciple following him. This was the disciple whom Jesus loved, the one who had also leaned on Jesus' breast during the meal and asked, "Lord, who is going to betray you?"
Peter, seeing him, said to Jesus, "Lord, what about this man?"
Jesus said to him, "If I want him to stay until I come, what does it matter to you? You follow me. »
Therefore this word spread among the brethren, that this disciple would not die. Now Jesus did not tell him that he would not die, but, "If I desire him to stay until I come, what does it matter to you?"
This is the disciple who testifies of these things, and who wrote these things. We know that his testimony is true.
There are also many other things that Jesus did, and if they were all written, I guess the world itself would have no room for the books that would be written.
The first book I wrote, Theophilus, is about everything that Jesus began to do and teach,
until the day when he was received, after having given his orders by the Holy Spirit to the apostles whom he had chosen.
It was to them also that he showed himself alive, after having suffered, by many proofs, by appearing to them for forty days and speaking to them of the kingdom of God.
Then he met with them, and commanded them, "Do not depart from Jerusalem, but wait for the promise of the Father, which you have heard from me."
For John baptized in water, but you, in a few days, will be baptized in the Holy Spirit. »
Wherefore, when they came together, they asked him, "Lord, is it now that you restore the kingdom of Israel?"
He said to them, "It is not for you to know the times and seasons that the Father has appointed of his own accord.
But you will receive power, when the Holy Spirit is descended upon you. You will be my witnesses in Jerusalem, in all Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth. »
When they had said these things, as they were looking, he was taken away, and a cloud hid him from their eyes.
As they stared at the sky as he went away, behold, two men in white garments stood near them.
They also said, Men of Galilee, why do you stand there looking at the sky? This Jesus, who was taken from you into heaven, will return in the same way you saw him go into heaven. »
Then they returned to Jerusalem, from the mountain called Olives, which is near Jerusalem, at the distance of a Sabbath day.
After their arrival, they went up to the upper room where they were staying, that is, Peter, John, James, Andrew, Philip, Thomas, Bartholomew, Matthew, James, son of Alphaeus, Simon the Zealot, and Judas, son of James.
All these, with one accord, persevered in prayer and supplication, as well as the women, Mary, mother of Jesus, and her brothers.
In those days Peter stood up in the midst of the disciples (whose number was about one hundred and twenty), and said:
Brethren, it was necessary that this Scripture should be fulfilled, which the Holy Spirit had already announced by the mouth of David concerning Judas, who served as a guide to those who had taken Jesus.
For he was numbered among us, and he received his share in this ministry.
Now this man has procured a field for himself with the reward of his wickedness; and, falling head first, his body opened and all his intestines gushed out.
All the inhabitants of Jerusalem learned that, in their language, this field was called "Akeldama", that is, "field of blood".
For it is written in the book of Psalms, "Let his dwelling be desolate. Let no one live there. and, "Let another take his post.
"Of the men who have accompanied us all the time that the Lord Jesus has entered and gone forth among us,
from the baptism of John until the day he was received from among us, one of them must become a witness of his resurrection with us. »
They presented two: Joseph, called Barsabbas, who was also called Justus, and Matthias.
They prayed and said, "You, Lord, who know the hearts of all men, show which of these two you have chosen
to participate in this ministry and apostolate of which Judas has divested himself, so that he may go in his place. »
Lots were cast for them, and the lot fell on Matthias; he was numbered among the eleven apostles.
On the day of Pentecost, they were all together in the same place.
Suddenly there came from heaven a noise like the breath of a great wind, and it filled the whole house where they were sitting.
Tongues like tongues of fire appeared and were distributed to them, and there was one on each of them.
They were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in other languages, according as the Spirit gave them the faculty of speaking.
Now there were Jews in Jerusalem, pious men, from all the nations that are under heaven.
When this noise was heard, the crowd assembled and was disconcerted, for each one heard them speaking in his own language.
They were all astonished and astonished, saying to one another, "Behold, are not all those who speak Galileans?
How do we hear each in his or her mother tongue?
Parthians, Medes, Elamites, people of Mesopotamia, Judea, Cappadocia, Pontus, Asia,
of Phrygia, of Pamphylia, of Egypt, of the vicinity of Cyrene in Libya, of the visitors of Rome, Jews and proselytes,
Cretans and Arabs, we hear them speak in our languages of the wonders of God. »
They were all amazed and perplexed, saying to one another, "What does this mean?"
Others, mockingly, said, "They are filled with new wine."
But Peter, standing with the eleven, raised his voice and said to them, "Men of Judea and all you who dwell in Jerusalem, know this and listen to my words.
For these are not drunk, as you suppose, since it is only the third hour of the day.
But this is what was announced by the prophet Joel:
"It will be so in the last days," says God, "that I will pour out my Spirit on all flesh. Your sons and daughters will prophesy. Your young men will have visions. Your old men will have dreams.
Yes, and on my servants and on my handmaids in those days, I will pour out my Spirit, and they will prophesy.
I will make wonders appear in the heavens above, and signs on the earth below: blood, fire, and clouds of smoke.
The sun will be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, before the great and glorious day of the Lord comes.
Whoever calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.
"Men of Israel, listen to these words! Jesus of Nazareth, a man approved by God in your eyes, by the miracles, wonders, and signs that God has done through him in your midst, as you yourselves know,
he who, delivered up according to the fixed plan and foreknowledge of God, was taken by the hand of lawless men, crucified and killed,
whom God raised from the dead, delivering him from the torment of death, because it was not possible for him to be held by it.
For David said of him, I saw the Lord always before me, for he is at my right hand, so that I should not be moved.
Therefore my heart rejoiced, and my tongue rejoiced. Moreover, my flesh also will dwell in hope,
for you will not leave my soul in hell, nor will you allow your Saint to see the decay.
You have made me know the paths of life. You will fill me with joy by your presence."
"Brethren, I can tell you freely of the patriarch David, that he died and was buried, and that his tomb is still with us today.
Therefore, being a prophet, and knowing that God had sworn to him by oath that from the fruit of his body, according to the flesh, he would raise up Christ to sit on his throne,
foreseeing this, he spoke of the resurrection of Christ, so that his soul might not remain in hell and his flesh might not see decay.
God raised this Jesus, of which we are all witnesses.
Being therefore exalted by the right hand of God, and having received from the Father the promise of the Holy Spirit, he poured out what you now see and hear.
For David did not ascend into heaven, but he himself said, The Lord said to my Lord, "Sit at my right hand."
until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet. »
"Let all the house of Israel know for a certainty that God has made him both Lord and Christ, this Jesus whom you have crucified."
When they heard this, they were heartbroken, and said to Peter and the other apostles, "Brethren, what shall we do?"
Peter said to them, "Repent and be baptized, every one of you, in the name of Jesus Christ, for the forgiveness of sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit.
For the promise is for you, for your children, and for all those who are far off, as many as the Lord our God will call to him. »
With many other words, he bore witness to them and exhorted them, saying, "Save yourselves from this perverse generation!"
Then those who received his word with joy were baptized. On that day, there were about three thousand more souls.
They persevered in the teaching of the apostles and in fraternal communion, in the breaking of bread and in prayer.
Fear took hold of all, and many wonders and miracles were done by the apostles.
All those who believed were together, and had everything in common.
They sold their goods and property, and distributed them to all, according to the needs of each.
Every day, persevering with one accord in the temple, and breaking bread in the houses, they took their food with joy and simplicity of heart,
praised God and were favored by all the people. The Lord added to the congregation every day those who were saved.
Peter and John went up to the temple at the hour of prayer, the ninth hour.
A lame man was carried from his mother's womb, which was deposited every day at the door of the temple called the Beautiful, to ask for gifts for the needy from those who entered the temple.
Seeing Peter and John about to enter the temple, he asked to receive gifts for the needy.
Peter, fixing his eyes on him, said with John, "Look at us."
He listened to them, expecting to receive something from them.
But Peter said, "I have neither silver nor gold; but what I have, I give you. In the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, arise and walk! »
He took him by the right hand and made him stand up. Immediately, his feet and the bones of his ankles regained their strength.
With a bound, he got up and began to walk. He entered the temple with them, walking, jumping, and praising God.
All the people saw him walking and praising God.
They recognized him: he was the one who used to sit at the Beautiful Gate of the temple to beg for donations for the needy. They were amazed and stunned by what had happened to him.
As the lame man who had been healed clung to Peter and John, all the people ran to them in the portico called Solomon, in great astonishment.
When Peter saw him, he answered the people, "Men of Israel, why are you astonished at this man? Why do you fix your eyes on us, as if we had made him walk by our own strength or piety?
The God of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, the God of our fathers, glorified his servant Jesus, whom you betrayed and denied before Pilate, who had decided to release him.
But you have denied the Holy and the Righteous and asked that you be granted a murderer,
and you have killed the Prince of life, whom God has raised from the dead, of which we are witnesses.
It is by faith in his name that this man, whom you see and know, has been made strong. Yes, the faith that is in him has given him this perfect solidity in the presence of all of you.
"Now, brethren, I know that you have done this out of ignorance, as have your leaders.
But what God had announced by the mouth of all his prophets, that Christ was to suffer, he has fulfilled.
Repent therefore and return, that your sins may be blotted out, that times of refreshing may come from the Lord,
and that he may send Jesus Christ, who was ordained for you before,
and that heaven is to receive until the time of restitution of all things, of which God spoke long ago through the mouth of his holy prophets.
Moses said to the fathers, "The Lord God will raise up for you from among your brethren a prophet like me. You will listen to him in everything he tells you.
Any soul that does not listen to this prophet will be exterminated from the people.
Yes, and all the prophets, from Samuel and those who followed, all who spoke, also spoke of those days.
You are the children of the prophets and of the covenant that God made with our fathers, saying to Abraham, "All the families of the earth will be blessed by your seed."
God, who raised up his servant Jesus, first sent him to you to bless you, turning each one of you away from his wickedness. »
As they were speaking to the people, the priests, the commander of the temple, and the Sadducees came to them,
dissatisfied with the fact that they taught the people and proclaimed in Jesus the resurrection of the dead.
They laid hands on them and put them in custody until the next day, for evening was falling.
But many of those who had heard the word believed, and the number of these men amounted to about five thousand.
In the morning, the rulers, elders, and scribes assembled in Jerusalem.
The high priest Hannah was there, with Caiaphas, John, Alexander, and all those who were related to the high priest.
After placing Peter and John in the midst of them, they asked them, "By what power, or in what name, have you done this?"
Then Peter, filled with the Holy Spirit, said to them, "Rulers of the people and elders of Israel,
If we are asked today about a benefit done to a cripple, about the manner in which this man was healed,
let it be known to all of you, and to all the people of Israel, that in the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom you crucified, and whom God raised from the dead, this man stands here before you wholly in him.
He is "the stone that you, the builders, regarded as worthless, and which has become the head of the corner".
There is no salvation in anyone else, for there is no other name under heaven that has been given among men, by which we must be saved! »
Now when they saw the audacity of Peter and John, and understood that they were ignorant and uneducated men, they were astonished. They recognized that they had been with Jesus.
And seeing that the healed man was standing with them, they could say nothing against it.
But after ordering them to withdraw from the Sanhedrin, they consulted among themselves.
saying, "What shall we do to these men? For, indeed, a remarkable miracle has been wrought by them, as all the inhabitants of Jerusalem clearly see, and we cannot deny it.
But lest this may spread further among the people, let us threaten them, so that henceforth they may speak to no one in this name. »
They called them and ordered them not to speak at all or to teach in the name of Jesus.
But Peter and John answered them, "If it is right in the sight of God to listen to you rather than to listen to God, judge for yourselves,
for we cannot help recounting the things we have seen and heard. »
After making them new threats, they let them go, finding no way to punish them, for the people's sake; for all glorified God for what had happened.
For the man on whom this miracle of healing occurred was more than forty years old.
After they had been released, they returned to them and related all that the chief priests and elders had told them.
When they heard him, they raised their voices with one accord to God and said, "Lord, you are God, you who made the heavens, the earth, the sea, and all that is in them;
you who, through the mouth of your servant David, said, "Why are the nations angry? and the people plot in vain?
The kings of the earth take a stand, and the rulers plot together, against the Lord, and against his Christ.
"For Herod and Pontius Pilate, with the Gentiles and the people of Israel, have leagued against your holy servant Jesus, whom you have anointed,
to do all that your hand and your council have decided to accomplish.
Now, Lord, look upon their threats, and grant that your servants may speak your word boldly,
while thou stretches out thy hand to heal, and signs and wonders are performed in the name of thy holy servant Jesus. »
After they had prayed, the place where they were gathered was shaken. They were all filled with the Holy Spirit, and they spoke the word of God with boldness.
The multitude of those who believed had but one heart and one soul. None of them claimed that any part of what he possessed belonged to him in his own right, but they had everything in common.
With great power, the apostles bore witness to the resurrection of the Lord Jesus. A great grace rested upon them all.
For there was no needy person among them, for all those who owned land or houses sold them, brought the proceeds of their sale,
and laid him at the feet of the apostles; and it was distributed to each according to his needs.
