Joses, nicknamed by the apostles Barnabas (which means, according to the interpretation, Son of encouragement), Levite, originally from Cyprus,
having a field, sold it, brought the money, and laid it at the feet of the apostles.
Now a man named Ananias, with Sapphira, his wife, sold a property,
and retained a part of the prize; his wife also knew this, and then she brought some of it and laid it at the feet of the apostles.
But Peter said, Annanias, why did Satan fill your heart to lie to the Holy Spirit and to withhold a portion of the price of the land?
As long as you kept it, did it not remain yours? After its sale, was it not in your power? How is it that you conceived this thing in your heart? You have not lied to men, but to God. »
Ananias, hearing these words, fell and died. Great fear took hold of all who heard these things.
The young men, having risen, enveloped him, carried him away, and buried him.
About three hours later, his wife, who did not know what had happened, came in.
Peter said to him, "Tell me if you sold the land at such a price." She said, "Yes, for so many things."
But Peter said to him, "How is it that you have agreed to tempt the Spirit of the Lord? Behold, the feet of those who buried your husband are at the door, and they will carry you out. »
She immediately fell at his feet and died. The young men entered and found her dead; they carried her out and buried her near her husband.
Great fear took hold of the whole assembly and of all those who heard these things.
Through the hands of the apostles, many signs and wonders were performed among the people. They were all by common consent under the portico of Solomon.
None of the others dared to join them, but the people honored them.
More and more believers joined the Lord, multitudes of men and women.
The sick were even carried through the streets and laid on beds and mattresses, so that when Peter passed by, his shadow at least covered some of them.
The crowd also gathered from the cities near Jerusalem, bringing the sick and those tormented by unclean spirits; and all were healed.
But the high priest arose, and all those who were with him (this is the sect of the Sadducees), and they were filled with jealousy
and laid their hands on the apostles, and then put them in public prison.
But an angel of the Lord opened the doors of the prison by night, brought them out, and said to them:
"Go and stand and speak to the people in the temple of all the words of this life."
After hearing this, they entered the temple around dawn and taught. But the high priest and those who were with him came to summon the council, with all the senate of the children of Israel, and sent to the prison to have them brought in.
But the officers who had come did not find them in the prison. They returned and made this report:
"We found the prison closed and locked, and the guards standing before the doors; but when we opened them, we couldn't find anyone inside! » .
Now, when the high priest, the commander of the temple, and the chief priests heard these words, they were very perplexed about them and what might result from them.
Someone came and said to them, "Behold, the men whom you have put in prison are in the temple, standing and teaching the people."
Then the captain went with the officers and brought them back without violence, for they feared that the people would stone them.
When they had brought them, they presented them to the Sanhedrin. The high priest questioned them,
saying, "Have we not strictly commanded you not to teach in this name? Behold, you have filled Jerusalem with your teaching, and you intend to make the blood of this man fall upon us. »
But Peter and the apostles replied, "We must obey God rather than men.
The God of our fathers raised Jesus from the dead, whom you killed by hanging him on the tree.
God raised him up by his right hand to be Prince and Savior, to give repentance to Israel and forgiveness of sins.
We are his witnesses of these things, as well as the Holy Spirit, which God has given to those who obey him. »
But when they heard this, their hearts were squeezed, and they were resolved to put them to death.
But someone arose in the Sanhedrin, a Pharisee named Gamaliel, a doctor of the law, honored by all the people, and ordered the apostles to be put aside for a little while.
He said to them, "Men of Israel, beware of these men, of what you are going to do.
For, before these days, Theudas arose, pretending to be somebody, and a number of men, about four hundred, joined him. He was killed, and all who obeyed him were scattered and reduced to nothing.
After this man, Judas of Galilee arose at the time of the inscription, and he dragged some people after him. He also perished, and all those who obeyed him were scattered.
Now, I say to you, withdraw from these men and leave them alone. For if this counsel or work be of men, it will be overthrown.
But if it is of God, you will not be able to overthrow it, and it would even be found that you are fighting against God! » .
They agreed with him. They summoned the apostles, beat them, commanded them not to speak in the name of Jesus, and released them.
So they withdrew from the presence of the Sanhedrin, rejoicing that they had been judged worthy to suffer reproach for Jesus' name.
Every day, in the temple and in the homes, they did not cease to teach and preach Jesus, the Christ.
In those days, when the number of the disciples was multiplying, a complaint arose from the Hellenes against the Hebrews, because their widows were neglected in the daily service.
The twelve summoned the multitude of the disciples and said, "It is not fitting that we should forsake the word of God to serve tables.
Choose from among you, brethren, seven men of good reputation, full of the Holy Spirit and wisdom, whom we will name responsible for this matter.
But we will continue to persevere in prayer and in the ministry of the word. »
These words pleased the whole crowd. They chose Stephen, a man full of faith and of the Holy Spirit, Philip, Prochorus, Nicanor, Timon, Parmenas, and Nicholas, a proselyte of Antioch,
which they set before the apostles. After praying, they laid their hands on them.
The word of God increased and the number of disciples multiplied in Jerusalem. A large part of the priests obeyed the faith.
Stephen, full of faith and power, performed great wonders and miracles among the people.
But some of those of the synagogue called the Libertines, the Cyreneans, the Alexandrians, the Cilicians, and the Asiatics, rose up to dispute with Stephen.
They could not resist the wisdom and Spirit through which he spoke.
Then they sent word secretly to men, "We have heard him speak blasphemous words against Moses and against God."
They stirred up the people, the elders and the scribes, and came against him. They seized him, and then brought him before the council,
and set false witnesses who said, "This man does not cease to utter blasphemous words against this holy place and the law.
For we have heard him say that this Jesus of Nazareth will destroy this place and change the customs that Moses handed down to us. »
All those who sat in the council, fixing their eyes on him, saw his face like that of an angel.
The high priest said, "Are these things true?"
He said, "Brothers and fathers, listen. The God of glory appeared to our father Abraham when he was in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Haran,
and he said to him, "Leave your country and your family, and come to a land that I will show you."
So he left the land of the Chaldeans and settled in Haran. From there, after the death of his father, God brought him to this country where you now live.
He gave him no inheritance, not even enough to set foot on it. He promised to give it to him as property, as well as to his descendants after him, when he had not yet had any children.
God spoke thus: His descendants would live as strangers in a foreign land, and they would be enslaved and abused for four hundred years.
I will judge the nation to which they shall be enslaved, saith God, and after that they shall go forth and serve me in that place.
He gave her the covenant of circumcision. Abraham begat Isaac and circumcised him on the eighth day. Isaac became the father of Jacob, and Jacob became the father of the twelve patriarchs.
"The patriarchs, impelled by jealousy against Joseph, sold him into Egypt. God was with him
and delivered him from all his afflictions, he gave him favor and wisdom before Pharaoh king of Egypt. He made him governor of Egypt and of all his household.
Now there came famine and great distress throughout the land of Egypt and Canaan. Our fathers found no food.
But when Jacob heard that there was wheat in Egypt, he sent our fathers for the first time.
The second time, Joseph was known to his brothers, and Joseph's family was revealed to Pharaoh.
Joseph sent and summoned Jacob, his father, and all his relatives, seventy-five souls.
Jacob went down into Egypt and died, he and our fathers;
they were brought back to Shechem and laid in the tomb which Abraham had bought for money from the sons of Hamor of Shechem.
But as the time of God's promise to Abraham drew near, the people increased and multiplied in Egypt.
until another king came along who did not know Joseph.
He took advantage of our race and ill-treated our fathers, and forced them to abandon their babies, so that they would not remain alive.
At that time Moses was born, who was exceedingly beautiful in the eyes of God. He was fed for three months in his father's house.
When he was abandoned, the Pharaoh's daughter took him in and raised him as her own son.
Moses was instructed in all the wisdom of the Egyptians. He was powerful in his words and in his works.
But when he was forty years old, it occurred to him to visit his brothers, the children of Israel.
Seeing that one of them was wronged, he defended him and avenged the oppressed, by striking the Egyptian.
He supposed that his brothers understood that God, through his hand, granted them deliverance; but they did not understand.
"The next day, he appeared to them while they were fighting, and exhorted them to find peace, saying, 'Gentlemen, you are brothers.
But the one who wronged his neighbor repulsed him, saying, "Who has made you ruler and judge over us?
Do you want to kill me as you killed the Egyptian yesterday?
At this word Moses fled and became a stranger in the land of Midian, where he begat two sons.
"When forty years had passed, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in the wilderness of Mount Sinai, in a flame of fire, in a bush.
When Moses saw him, he was amazed by the sight. As he drew near to see, the voice of the Lord came to him:
"I am the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac and the God of Jacob". Moses trembled and did not dare to look.
The Lord said to him, "Take off your sandals, for the place where you are standing is holy ground.
I have seen the affliction of my people in Egypt and I have heard their groaning. I went down to deliver them. Come now, I will send you to Egypt."
This Moses whom they refused, saying, "Who made you ruler and judge?" God sent him as ruler and deliverer by the hand of the angel who appeared to him in the bush.
It was he who led them, after having performed wonders and signs in Egypt, to the Red Sea, and in the wilderness for forty years.
It was this Moses who said to the children of Israel: "The Lord our God will raise up for you from among your brethren a prophet like me."
He was in the congregation in the wilderness with the angel who spoke to him on Mount Sinai, and with our fathers, who received living revelations to transmit to us,
and whom our fathers would not obey, but whom they rejected and returned to Egypt in their hearts,
saying to Aaron, "Make us gods who go before us, for this Moses who brought us out of the land of Egypt, we do not know what has become of him.
In those days they made a calf, offered a sacrifice to the idol, and rejoiced in the work of their hands.
But God turned away from them and delivered them into the service of the army of heaven, as it is written in the book of the prophets, "Have you offered me dead animals and sacrifices forty years in the wilderness, house of Israel?
You have set up the tabernacle of Moloch, the star of your god Rephan, the figures you have made to worship, then I will take you beyond Babylon.
Our fathers had the tabernacle of testimony in the wilderness, just as he who spoke to Moses commanded him to build it after the pattern he had seen.
Our fathers, in their turn, brought it with Joshua, when they came into possession of the nations whom God drove out before the face of our fathers until the days of David,
who found favor in the sight of God and asked to find a dwelling place for the God of Jacob.
But Solomon built him a house.
But the Most High does not dwell in temples made with hands, as the prophet says,
"Heaven is my throne, and earth is a footstool for my feet. What kind of house are you going to build for me? says the Lord. Or where is my resting place?
Didn't my hand do all these things?
"Men of stiff necks, uncircumcised in heart and ear, you are still resisting the Holy Spirit! You are doing what your fathers did.
Which of the prophets did not your fathers persecute? They have killed those who announced the coming of the Righteous One, of whom you have now become traitors and murderers.
You have received the law as it was ordained by the angels, and you have not kept it! » .
But when they heard these things, they were heartbroken, and they gnashed their teeth against him.
But he, filled with the Holy Spirit, looked fixedly to heaven and saw the glory of God and Jesus standing at the right hand of God,
and he said, "Behold, I see the heavens opened, and the Son of Man standing at the right hand of God."
But they cried out with a loud voice and stopped their ears, and then rushed at him with one accord.
They threw him out of the city and stoned him. The witnesses laid their clothes at the feet of a young man named Saul.
They stoned Stephen, who cried out, "Lord Jesus, receive my spirit."
He knelt down and cried out in a loud voice, "Lord, do not hold this sin against them!" After saying this, he fell asleep.
Saul consented to his death. A great persecution arose against the congregation which was in Jerusalem that day. They were all scattered throughout the regions of Judea and Samaria, except for the apostles.
Pious men buried Stephen and lamented his fate.
But Saul ravaged the assembly, entering all the houses and dragging men and women to prison.
So those who were scattered went from place to place preaching the word.
Philip went down to the city of Samaria and preached Christ to them.
The crowd listened with one accord to the words of Philip, when they heard and saw the miracles he performed.
For unclean spirits came out of many of those who had them. They came out shouting in a loud voice. Many of the paralyzed and lame were healed.
There was great joy in this city.
Now there was in the city a man named Simon, who used to practice sorcery and astonish the inhabitants of Samaria, pretending to be a great man,
and that all listened, from the least to the greatest, saying, "This man is the great power of God."
They listened to him, because he had long since astonished them by his spells.
But when they believed that Philip was preaching the good news of the kingdom of God and of the name of Jesus Christ, they were baptized, men and women.
Simon himself also believed . After being baptized, he continued his journey with Philip. Seeing signs and great miracles happening, he was amazed.
The apostles who were in Jerusalem, when they heard that Samaria had received the word of God, sent Peter and John there.
The latter, having come down, prayed for them, that they might receive the Holy Spirit;
for he had not yet fallen upon any of them. They had only been baptized in the name of Jesus Christ.
Then they laid their hands on them, and they received the Holy Spirit.
Simon, seeing that the Holy Spirit was given by the laying on of hands of the apostles, offered them money,
saying, "Give me this power also, that whosoever layeth his hands upon me may receive the Holy Ghost."
But Peter said to him, "Let your money perish with you, because you thought you could obtain the gift of God with money.
You have neither part nor lot in this matter, for your heart is not right before God.
Repent therefore of this, of your wickedness, and ask God if perhaps the thought of your heart can be forgiven you.
For I see that you are in the poison of bitterness and in the bondage of iniquity. »
Simon answered, "Pray to the Lord for me, that nothing of what you have said may happen to me."
After they had testified and spoken the word of the Lord, they returned to Jerusalem, and preached the Good News in several villages of the Samaritans.
Then an angel of the Lord spoke to Philip, saying, "Arise, and go to the south, on the road that descends from Jerusalem to Gaza. It's a desert. »
He got up and left. And behold, a man from Ethiopia, a eunuch of great authority under Candace, queen of the Ethiopians, who was at the head of all his treasure, had come to Jerusalem to prostrate himself.
He would return, sitting in his chariot, and read the prophet Isaiah.
The Spirit said to Philip, "Draw near, and cleave to this chariot."
Philip ran to him, heard him read the prophet Isaiah, and said, "Do you understand what you read?"
He said, "How can I do it, if no one explains it to me?" He begged Philip to come up and sit down with him.
Now, the passage of Scripture he was reading was this, "He was led like a sheep to the slaughterhouse. Like a lamb that is silent before its shearer, so that he does not open his mouth.
In his humiliation, his judgment was taken away. Who will declare his generation? For his life is taken from the earth. »
The eunuch answered Philip, "Of whom does the prophet speak? Of himself, or of someone else? »
Philip opened his mouth, and, beginning with this Scripture, he announced Jesus to him.
As they went on their way, they came to water, and the eunuch said, "Here is water. What prevents me from being baptized? »
He ordered the chariot to stop, and they both went down into the water, Philip and the eunuch, and he baptized him.
When they came out of the water, the Spirit of the Lord carried Philip away, and the eunuch saw him no more, for he went away joyfully.
But Philip was found at Azotus. As he passed, he preached the good news in all the cities, until he arrived at Caesarea.
But Saul, who continued to utter threats and slaughter the Lord's disciples, went to the high priest
and asked him for letters for the synagogues of Damascus, so that, if he found men or women of the Way, he might bring them bound to Jerusalem.
As he traveled, he approached Damascus, and suddenly a light from heaven shone around him.
He fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to him, "Saul, Saul, why do you persecute me?"
He said, "Who are you, Lord?" The Lord says, "I am Jesus, whom you persecute.
But get up and go into the city; then you will be told what you should do. »
The men who were travelling with him were speechless, hearing the noise, but seeing no one.
Saul rose from the ground, and his eyes were opened, but he saw no one. They led him by the hand, and brought him to Damascus.
He remained three days without seeing, and he neither ate nor drank.
Now there was in Damascus a disciple named Ananias. The Lord said to him in a vision, "Ananias!" He said, "Behold, it is I, Lord."
The Lord said to him, "Get up, go to the street called Straight, and look in the house of Judah for a man named Saul, a native of Tarsus. For behold, he is praying,
and he saw in a vision a man, named Ananias, enter and lay his hands on him, that he might recover his sight. »
But Ananias spoke up and said, "Lord, many have told me about this man, and how much harm he has done to your saints in Jerusalem.
He has power here from the chief priests to bind all those who call on your name. »
But the Lord said to him, "Go, for he is the vessel which I have chosen to bear my name before the nations and kings, and before the children of Israel.
For I will show him how many things he must suffer for my name's sake. »
Ananias went away and entered the house. Laying his hands on him, he said, "Brother Saul, the Lord, who appeared to you on the way you came, has sent me to receive your sight and be filled with the Holy Spirit."
Immediately something like scales fell from his eyes, and he recovered his sight. He arose and was baptized.
He took food and was strengthened. Saul stayed several days with the disciples who were in Damascus.
Immediately, in the synagogues, he proclaimed Christ, that he is the Son of God.
All who heard him were amazed and said, "Was it not he who in Jerusalem wronged those who called on that name? And he had come here with the intention of bringing them bound before the chief priests! » .
But Saul grew stronger and stronger, and he confounded the Jews who dwelt in Damascus, proving that it was Christ.
Several days having passed, the Jews formed a plot to put him to death.
But Saul got wind of their plan. They watched the gates day and night, in order to kill him.
But his disciples took him by night, brought him down the wall, and lowered him in a basket.
When Saul arrived in Jerusalem, he tried to join the disciples; but they were all afraid of him, not believing that he was a disciple.
But Barnabas took him and brought him to the apostles, and he told them how he had seen the Lord on the way, and how he had spoken to him, and how in Damascus he had preached boldly in the name of Jesus.
He entered with them into Jerusalem,
and boldly preached in the name of the Lord Jesus. He talked and disputed with the Hellenists, but they sought to put him to death.
When the brothers heard of this, they sent him down to Caesarea and sent him to Tarsus.
Thus in all Judea, Galilee, and Samaria the assemblies knew peace and were edified. They multiplied, walking in the fear of the Lord and in the comfort of the Holy Spirit.
As Peter was travelling through all these countries, he also went down to the saints who dwelt in Lydda.
There he found a man named Aeneas, who had been bedridden for eight years because he was paralyzed.
Peter said to him, "Aeneas, Jesus Christ heals you. Get up and make your bed! Immediately, he got up.
All the inhabitants of Lydda and Sharon saw him, and they were converted to the Lord.
Now there was a disciple in Joppa named Tabitha, which, translated, means Dorcas. This woman was full of good works and acts of mercy that she performed.
At that time, she fell ill and died. After washing it, it was placed in an upper room.
As Lydda was near Joppa, the disciples, hearing that Peter was there, sent two men to him, begging him not to delay in coming to join them.
Peter got up and went with them. When he arrived, they brought him into the upper room. All the widows stood by him, weeping, and showing the tunics and other garments that Dorcas had made while she was with them.
Peter brought them out, then he knelt down and prayed. Turning to the body, he said, "Tabitha, get up!" She opened her eyes, and when she saw Peter, she straightened up.
He gave her his hand and made her stand up. Calling the saints and widows, he presented her alive.
This spread throughout the city of Joppa, and many believed in the Lord.
He stayed several days at Joppa with a currier named Simon.
There was at Caesarea a man named Cornelius, centurion of what was called the regiment of Italy,
a pious and God-fearing man with all his household, who generously gave gifts to the people for the needy and who always prayed to God.
About the ninth hour of the day, he saw clearly in a vision an angel of God coming to him and saying to him, "Cornelius!"
He, fixing his eyes on him and frightened, said, "What is the matter, Lord?" He said to him, "Your prayers and gifts to the needy have gone up in remembrance before God.
Now send men to Joppa, and bring Simon, who is also called Peter.
He is at the house of a currier, named Simon, whose house is by the sea.
When the angel who had spoken to him was gone, Cornelius called two of his servants and a pious soldier from among those who served him continually.
After explaining everything to them, he sent them to Joppa.
The next day, as they were on their way and approaching the city, Peter went up to the roof of the house to pray about noon.
He was hungry and wanted to eat, but while the meal was being prepared, he fell into a trance.
He saw the heavens open and a vessel descending towards him, like a great sheet spread out from the four corners on the earth,
in which were found all kinds of quadrupedal animals of the earth, wild beasts, reptiles and birds of the air.
A voice spoke to him: "Arise, Peter, kill and eat!"
But Peter said, "No, Lord, for I have never eaten anything common or unclean."
The second time, a voice was heard: "What God has cleansed, you must not call unclean."
This was done three times, and immediately the thing was received in heaven.
When Peter was very perplexed as to the meaning of the vision he had seen, behold, the men sent by Cornelius, having inquired about the house of Simon, presented themselves before the door,
and called to ask if Simon, also called Peter, was lodged there.
While Peter was pondering the vision, the Spirit said to him, "Behold, three men are looking for you.
But arise, come down, and go with them, without doubting anything; for I have sent them. »
Peter went down to the men, and said, "Behold, I am the one you seek. Why did you come? »
They answered, "Cornelius, a centurion, a righteous and God-fearing man, and of whom the whole nation of the Jews speaks well, has been commissioned by a holy angel to invite you to his house and to hear what you say."
So he sent for them and provided them with lodging. The next day Peter got up and went out with them, and some of Joppa's brothers accompanied him.
The next day, they entered Caesarea. Cornelius was waiting for them, having summoned his relatives and close friends.
When Peter entered, Cornelius came to meet him, threw himself at his feet and adored him.
But Peter raised him up, saying, "Arise! I too am a man. »
As he was talking with him, he went in and found many people assembled.
He said to them, "You yourselves know that it is forbidden for a man of the Jewish race to unite or to approach a man of another nation; but God has shown me that I should not call any man ungodly or unclean.
That's why I also came without complaining when I was sent for . I therefore ask you why you have sent for me. »
Cornelius says: "Four days ago I fasted until this hour; At the ninth hour I prayed in my house, and behold, a man stood before me, dressed in a bright garment
and saying, 'Cornelius, your prayer has been heard, and God remembers your gifts to the needy.'
Send therefore to Joppa and send for Simon, who is also called Peter. He lodged in the house of a currier named Simon, by the sea. When he arrives, he will talk to you.
So I sent you immediately, and you did well to come. Now, therefore, we are all here before God to hear all that God has commanded you. »
Peter opened his mouth and said, "Verily, I know that God does not show favoritism,
but let him accept in all nations him who fears him and practices justice.
The word which he sent to the children of Israel, proclaiming the good news of peace through Jesus Christ, who is Lord of all,
you yourselves know what happened, and which was proclaimed in all Judea, beginning with Galilee, after the baptism which John preached,
how God anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the Holy Spirit and power, who went from place to place doing good and healing all those who were oppressed by the devil, for God was with him.
We are witnesses of all that he did, both in the land of the Jews and in Jerusalem, where they also killed him, hanging him on the tree.
God raised him up on the third day and made him known,
not to all the people, but to witnesses chosen beforehand by God, to us who ate and drank with him after his resurrection from the dead.
He commanded us to preach to the people and to testify that it is he who has been appointed by God as judge of the living and the dead.
All the prophets testify of him that, by his name, whoever believes in him receives forgiveness of sins. »
While Peter was still speaking these words, the Holy Spirit fell upon all who listened to the word.
Those of the circumcised who had believed were amazed, all those who had come with Peter, because the gift of the Holy Spirit was also poured out on the Gentiles.
For they heard them speak in other tongues and magnify God. Peter answered:
"Can anyone forbid these people to be baptized with water? They received the Holy Spirit, just like us. »
He commanded them to be baptized in the name of Jesus Christ. Then they asked him to stay a few days.
The apostles and brethren who were in Judea heard that the Gentiles also had received the word of God.
When Peter went up to Jerusalem, those of the circumcision disputed him,
saying, "You went to the uncircumcised and ate with them."
Peter began, and explained to them in order, saying:
"I was in the city of Joppa, praying, and I had a vision: a vessel that came down, like a great canvas stretched from heaven from four corners. He came to me.
After looking at it carefully, I considered and saw the quadrupeds of the earth, the wild animals, the reptiles and the birds of the air.
I also heard a voice saying to me: "Arise, Peter, kill and eat!"
But I said, "No, Lord, for nothing filthy or unclean has ever entered my mouth."
But for the second time, a voice answered me from heaven: "What God has purified, do not call it unclean.
This happened three times, and all ascended to heaven.
Immediately three men presented themselves before the house where I was, sent from Caesarea to me.
The Spirit tells me to go with them without distinction. These six brothers also accompanied me, and we entered the house of this man.
He told us that he had seen the angel stand in his house and say to him, "Send to Joppa to fetch Simon, surnamed Peter,
who will speak to you the words by which you and all your household will be saved."
As I began to speak, the Holy Spirit fell upon them, as upon us in the beginning.
And I remembered the word of the Lord, who said: "John baptized in water, but you will be baptized in the Holy Spirit."
If, then, God gave them the same gift as it did to us, when we believed in the Lord Jesus Christ, who was I, to resist God? »
When they heard these things, they were silent and glorified God, saying, "Then God also granted the Gentiles repentance to life!"
Those who had been scattered by the oppression which had arisen over Stephen, went as far as Phoenicia, Cyprus, and Antioch, speaking to no one, except to the Jews only.
But some of them, men from Cyprus and Cyrene, came to Antioch and addressed the Hellenes, preaching to the Lord Jesus.
The hand of the Lord was with them, and many believed and turned to the Lord.
The rumour about them reached the ears of the assembly in Jerusalem. They sent Barnabas as far as Antioch,
who, after arriving and seeing the grace of God, rejoices. He exhorted them all to cleave with all their hearts to the Lord.
For he was a good man, full of the Holy Spirit and faith, and many people were added to the Lord.
Barnabas set out for Tarsus, in search of Saul.
Having found him, he took him to Antioch. For a whole year they were gathered together with the congregation, and they taught many people. It was in Antioch that the disciples were first called Christians.
In those days, prophets came down from Jerusalem to Antioch.
One of them, named Agabus, arose and announced by the Spirit that there must be a great famine in the whole world, which also happened in the time of Claudius.
All the disciples, who were in abundance, resolved to send help to the brethren who dwelt in Judea.
which they also did, sending them to the elders by the hands of Barnabas and Saul.
About this time King Herod stretched out his hands to oppress a part of the assembly.
He put to death by the sword James, the brother of John.
Seeing that this pleased the Jews, he also seized Peter. It was during the days of unleavened bread.
After arresting him, he put him in prison and handed him over to four squads of four soldiers each, to guard him, with the intention of bringing him out before the people after the Passover.
Peter was therefore kept in the prison, but the assembly did not cease to pray to God for him.
On the very night that Herod was about to bring him out, Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound by two chains. Guards outside the door guarded the prison.
And behold, an angel of the Lord stood by him, and a light shone in the cell. He struck Peter on the side and woke him up, saying, "Get up quickly!" His chains fell from his hands.
The angel said to him, "Dress yourself and put on your sandals." He did so. Then he said to him, "Put on your cloak and follow me."
And he went out and followed him. He didn't know that what the angel was doing was real, but he believed he had a vision.
When they had passed the first and second guards, they arrived at the iron gate which leads to the city, and which opened by itself. They went out and went down a street, and immediately the angel withdrew from him.
When Peter came to himself, he said, "Now I truly know that the Lord has sent his angel and delivered me from the hand of Herod and from all that the Jewish people expected."
Thinking of this, he went to the house of Mary, mother of John, surnamed Mark, where many people were gathered and praying.
When Peter knocked at the door of the house, a servant, named Rhoda, came to answer him.
When she recognized Peter's voice, she did not open the door with joy, but ran to report that Peter was standing before the door.
They said to him, "You are mad!" But she insisted that it should be so. They said, "He is his angel."
But Pierre continued to strike. When they opened it, they saw it and were amazed.
But he, beckoning them with his hand to be silent, told them how the Lord had brought him out of prison. He said, "Say these things to James and the brethren." Then he went and went to another place.
As soon as it was daylight, there was a great commotion among the soldiers to find out what had become of Peter.
Herod, having sought him and not finding him, questioned the guards, and then ordered them to be put to death. He went down from Judea to Caesarea, and stayed there.
Now Herod was very angry with the inhabitants of Tyre and Sidon. They came to him with one accord and, having made Blastus the king's personal helper, their friend, they sued for peace, for their country depended on the king's country for its food.
On a appointed day, Herod dressed himself in his royal garments, sat down on the throne, and addressed them in a speech.
The people cried out, "The voice of a god, and not of a man!"
Immediately an angel of the Lord struck him, for he did not give glory to God. Then he was devoured by worms and died.
But the word of God grew and multiplied.
Barnabas and Saul, after having performed their service, returned to Jerusalem, taking with them also John, called Mark.
Now in the assembly that was at Antioch there were some prophets and teachers: Barnabas, Simeon called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen, the adopted brother of Herod the tetrarch, and Saul.
As they served the Lord and fasted, the Holy Spirit said, "Set apart for me Barnabas and Saul, for the work to which I have called them."
Then, after fasting and praying, and laying hands on them, they sent them away.
So, after being sent by the Holy Spirit, they went down to Seleucia. From there they embarked for the island of Cyprus.
When they arrived at Salamis, they proclaimed the word of God in the Jewish synagogues. They also had John as their assistant.
After crossing the island to Paphos, they found a sorcerer, a false prophet, a Jew whose name was Bar Jesus,
who was with the proconsul Sergius Paulus, an intelligent man. This man summoned Barnabas and Saul, and sought to hear the word of God.
But Elymas the sorcerer (for that is what his name is called according to the interpretation) put up a resistance to them, seeking to turn the proconsul away from the faith.
But Saul, who is also called Paul, filled with the Holy Ghost, fixed his eyes on him
and said, "Son of the devil, full of every kind of deceit and cunning, enemy of all righteousness, will you not cease to pervert the right ways of the Lord?
Now behold, the hand of the Lord is upon you, and you will be blind, you will not see the sun for a while! » . Immediately, a fog and darkness descended on him. He walked to and fro, looking for someone to lead him by the hand.
Then the proconsul, seeing what had happened, believed, being astonished at the teaching of the Lord.
Paul and his troop set out from Paphos and arrived at Perga, in Pamphylia. John separated from them and returned to Jerusalem.
They, leaving Perga, went to Antioch from Pisidia. They entered the synagogue on the Sabbath and sat down.
After the reading of the law and the prophets, the rulers of the synagogue sent to them to say, "Brethren, if you have any word of exhortation to the people, speak."
Paul stood up, and gesturing with his hand, he said, "Men of Israel, and you who fear God, listen.
The God of this people chose our fathers, exalted the people when they sojourned as strangers in the land of Egypt, and with his arm raised he brought them out of that land.
For a period of about forty years, he endured them in the wilderness.
When he had destroyed seven nations in the land of Canaan, he gave them their land as an inheritance for about four hundred and fifty years.
After this, he gave them judges until Samuel the prophet.
Then they asked for a king, and God gave them Saul, son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, for forty years.
After deposing him, he raised up David for them as king, to whom he bore this testimony: "I have found David the son of Jesse, a man after my own heart, who will do all my will.
It was from this man's seed that God brought salvation to Israel, in accordance with his promise,
before his coming, when John had first preached the baptism of repentance to Israel.
As John was doing his task, he said, "What do you suppose I am? I am not him. But behold, someone is coming after me, and I am not worthy to untie the sandals from his feet."
"Brethren, children of the stock of Abraham, and those of you who fear God, the word of salvation is addressed to you.
For the inhabitants of Jerusalem and their rulers, because they did not know him, nor the voices of the prophets that are read every Sabbath, fulfilled them by condemning him.
Although they found no cause of death, they still asked Pilate to put him to death.
When they had fulfilled all that was written about him, they took him down from the wood and laid him in a tomb.
But God raised him from the dead,
and he was seen for many days by those who had gone up with him from Galilee to Jerusalem, and who are his witnesses to the people.
We preach to you the good news of the promise made to the fathers,
"Concerning the fact that he raised him from the dead, that he might not return to corruption again, he spoke thus: 'I will give you the holy and sure blessings of David.'
That is why he also says in another psalm: "You shall not allow your Holy One to see corruption.
For David, after having, in his generation, served the counsel of God, fell asleep, lay down with his fathers, and saw decay.
But he whom God raised up did not see decadence.
Know, therefore, brethren, that through this man the remission of sins is proclaimed to you;
and that by him whoever believes is justified from all things of which you could not be justified by the law of Moses.
Take heed, therefore, that what is spoken by the prophets does not come upon you:
"See, mockers! To marvel and perish, for I am doing a work in your days, a work that you will not believe at all, if you are told it. »
When the Jews came out of the synagogue, the Gentiles asked that these words be announced to them on the following Sabbath.
At the end of the synagogue, many of the Jews and pious proselytes followed Paul and Barnabas, who, speaking to them, exhorted them to persevere in the grace of God.
On the next Sabbath, almost the whole city was gathered together to hear the word of God.
But the Jews, seeing the crowd, were filled with jealousy, contradicted Paul's words, and blasphemed.
Paul and Barnabas boldly spoke up and said, "The word of God must first be preached to you. Since you have rejected it of yourselves, and consider yourselves unworthy of eternal life, behold, we turn to the Gentiles.
For thus the Lord commanded us, saying, I have made thee light unto the Gentiles, that thou mayest bring salvation to the ends of the earth. »
The Gentiles, having heard this, rejoiced and glorified the word of God. All those who were destined for eternal life believed.
The word of the Lord spread throughout the region.
But the Jews, stirring up the pious women and notables, as well as the leading men of the city, stirred up a persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and drove them out of their territory.
But they shook the dust from their feet against them, and came to Iconium.
The disciples were filled with joy and the Holy Spirit.
At Icon, they entered together into the synagogue of the Jews, and they spoke in such a way that a great multitude of Jews and Greeks believed.
But the unbelieving Jews stirred up and embittered the souls of the Gentiles against the brethren.
They remained there a long time, speaking boldly to the Lord, who bore witness to the word of his grace, granting that signs and wonders should be done by their hands.
But the crowd of the city was divided. One part sided with the Jews and the other with the apostles.
Some of the pagans and Jews, with their leaders, seeking to ill-treat and stone them,
They preached the Good News there.
At Lystra, a man was sitting, impotent in his feet, crippled from his mother's womb, and who had never walked.
He listened to Paul speak, who, fixing his eyes on him and seeing that he had faith to be healed,
said in a loud voice, "Stand up on your feet!" He jumped up and walked.
The crowd, seeing what Paul had done, raised their voices, and said in the Lycaonian language, "The gods have come down to us in the form of men."
They called Barnabas "Jupiter," and Paul "Mercury," because he was the chief orator.
The priest of Jupiter, whose temple was opposite their city, brought oxen and garlands to the gates, and he would have offered a sacrifice with the crowd.
But the apostles Barnabas and Paul, when they heard this, tore their garments and threw themselves into the crowd, crying:
"Men, why do you do this? We also are men of the same nature as you, and we bring you good news, that you may turn from these vain things to the living God, who made heaven, earth, sea, and all that is in them;
who, in past generations, has let all nations go their own ways.
Yet he did not leave himself without a witness, in that he did good and gave you rains from heaven and fruitful seasons, filling our hearts with food and joy. »
Even in saying these things, they hardly prevented the crowd from offering them a sacrifice.
But some Jews from Antioch and Iconium, having arrived there, persuaded the crowd to stone Paul and drag him out of the city, believing that he was dead.
But as the disciples were standing around him, he arose, and entered the city. The next day, he left with Barnabas for Derbe.
After preaching the good news in that city and making many disciples, they returned to Lystra, Iconus, and Antioch,
strengthening the souls of the disciples, exhorting them to persevere in the faith, and telling them that it is through many afflictions that they must enter the kingdom of God.
After appointing elders for them in every assembly, and after praying and fasting, they commended them to the Lord in whom they had believed.
They crossed Pisidia and arrived in Pamphylia.
After proclaiming the word to Perga, they went down to Attalia.
From there they sailed for Antioch, whence they had been committed to the grace of God for the work they had done.
When they came and gathered the congregation, they told all that God had done with them, and that he had opened a door of faith to the nations.
They stayed there for a long time with the disciples.
Some men came down from Judea and taught the brethren, "Unless you are circumcised according to the custom of Moses, you cannot be saved."
Paul and Barnabas did not fail to argue with them, and they commissioned Paul, Barnabas, and some others of them to go up to Jerusalem to consult the apostles and elders on this matter.
After being sent by the assembly, they passed through Phoenicia and Samaria, announcing the conversion of the pagans. They caused great joy to all the brethren.
When they arrived in Jerusalem, they were received by the assembly, the apostles and the elders, and they related all that God had done with them.
But some of the sect of the believing Pharisees arose, saying, "They must be circumcised and commanded to observe the law of Moses."
The apostles and elders met to deliberate on this matter.
After much discussion, Peter stood up and said to them, "Brethren, you know that God made a choice among you long ago, so that through my mouth the nations might hear the word of the Good News and believe.
God, who knows hearts, has borne witness to them, giving them the Holy Spirit, as he has done for us.
He made no difference between us and them, purifying their hearts by faith.
Now, then, why do you tempt God, by putting on the necks of the disciples a yoke which neither our fathers nor we could bear?
But we believe that we are saved by the grace of the Lord Jesus, just like them. »
The whole crowd was silent, and they listened to Barnabas and Paul relate the signs and wonders that God had done through them among the nations.
After they had been silent, James spoke up and said, "Brethren, listen to me.
Simeon reported how God first visited the nations to bring out a people for his name.
This is in accordance with the words of the prophets. As it is written,
"After that, I will come back. I will rebuild the tabernacle of David, which has fallen. I will rebuild its ruins. I'm going to erect it
that the rest of men may seek the Lord: all the Gentiles who are called by my name, saith the Lord, who does all these things."
"All the works of God are known to him from all eternity.
Therefore I am of opinion that we do not bother those of the Gentiles who are converted to God,
but that we write to them to abstain from the pollution of idols, sexual immorality, what is strangled and blood.
For Moses, from generation to generation, has in every city those who preach him, being read in the synagogues every Sabbath. »
Then it seemed good to the apostles and elders, with the whole assembly, to choose men from among them, and to send them to Antioch with Paul and Barnabas: Judas, called Barsabbas, and Silas, leaders of the brethren.
They wrote these things with their own handwriting: "The apostles, the elders, and the brethren, to the brethren who are of the heathen, in Antioch, in Syria, and in Cilicia: greetings.
We have heard that some of those who have gone out of us have troubled you with words, and have troubled your souls, saying, "You must be circumcised and keep the law, although we have given no commandment;
it seemed good to us, after having come to an agreement, to choose men and send them to you with our beloved Barnabas and Paul,
men who risked their lives for the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
So we have sent Judas and Silas, who will also tell you the same things by word of mouth.
For it has seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to lay no other burden on you than these necessary things:
let you abstain from meat sacrificed to idols, blood, strangled animals, and immorality, things of which you will be very careful. Farewell. »
Thus, after being sent, they arrived at Antioch. Having gathered the crowd, they handed over the letter.
After reading it, they rejoiced at this encouragement.
Judas and Silas, who were themselves prophets, encouraged the brethren with many words and strengthened them.
After spending some time in these places, the brethren sent them back in peace to the apostles.
Paul and Barnabas remained in Antioch, teaching and preaching the word of the Lord, with many others.
A few days later, Paul said to Barnabas, "Let us now return to visit our brethren in every city where we have preached the word of the Lord, to see how they are."
Barnabas intended to take with them also John, who was called Mark.
But Paul did not think it was a good idea to take with them someone who had withdrawn from them in Pamphylia, and who had not gone with them to do the work.
Then the dispute became so sharp that they parted from each other. Barnabas took Mark with him and sailed for the island of Cyprus,
but Paul chose Silas and departed, recommended by the brethren to the grace of God.
He traveled through Syria and Cilicia, fortifying the assemblies.
He arrived at Derbe and Lystra. And behold, there was a disciple named Timothy, the son of a believing Jewess, but whose father was a Greek.
The brethren who were at Lystra and Iconium bore good testimony of him.
Paul wanted to take him with him, and he took him and circumcised him because of the Jews who were in those countries. for all knew that his father was a Greek.
As they passed through the cities, they gave them the decrees to be observed, which had been ordained by the apostles and elders who were in Jerusalem.
The assemblies were thus strengthened in the faith, and their number increased every day.
When they had passed through the region of Phrygia and Galatia, the Holy Spirit forbade them to proclaim the word in Asia.
When they arrived in front of Mysia, they tried to go to Bithynia, but the Spirit would not allow them.
Passing through Mysia, they descended to Troas.
A vision appeared to Paul during the night. There was a man from Macedonia there, who begged him, saying, "Go over to Macedonia and help us."
After having seen this vision, we immediately sought to go to Macedonia, concluding that the Lord had called us to proclaim the Good News to them.
Leaving Troas, therefore, we made a direct course for Samothrace, and the next day for Neapolis,
and thence to Philippi, a city of Macedonia, the most important in the district, a Roman colony. We stayed a few days in this city.
On the Sabbath day, we went out of the city, to the bank of a river, where we thought there was a place of prayer, and we sat down to talk to the women who had gathered.
A woman named Lydia, a purple seller, from the city of Thyatira, who worshipped God, listened to us. The Lord opened her heart to listen to what Paul was saying.
When she was baptized with her family, she pleaded with us, saying, "If you have judged me faithful to the Lord, come to my house and stay there." So she persuaded us.
As we were going to pray, we met a young girl gifted with a spirit of divination, who brought a great deal to her masters by telling them fortunes.
Following Paul and us, she cried out, "These men are servants of the Most High God, who proclaim to us a way of salvation!"
She acted like this for several days. But Paul, very angry, turns around and says to the spirit, "I command you, in the name of Jesus Christ, to come out of her." He went out at the same hour.
But seeing that the hope of gain had disappeared, his masters seized Paul and Silas and dragged them into the public square before the magistrates.
Having brought them before the magistrates, they said: "These men, who are Jews, are agitating our city
and advocate customs which we are not permitted to accept or observe, being Romans. »
The crowd rose up against them, and the magistrates tore off their clothes, and then ordered them to be beaten with rods.
After having subjected them to many blows with rods, they threw them into prison, instructing the jailer to keep them safe.
Having received this order, he threw them into the inner prison and fixed their feet in the vines.
Around midnight, Paul and Silas prayed and sang hymns to God, and the prisoners listened to them.
Suddenly there was a great earthquake, so that the foundations of the prison were shaken; at that very moment, all the doors were opened, and the bonds of each were broken.
The jailer, awakened by sleep and seeing the doors of the prison open, drew his sword and was about to kill himself, thinking that the prisoners had escaped.
But Paul cried out in a loud voice, "Do not hurt yourself, for we are all here."
He asked for lights, entered, threw himself trembling before Paul and Silas,
He sent them out, and said, "Gentlemen, what must I do to be saved?"
They said, "Believe in the Lord Jesus Christ, and you and your family will be saved."
They preached the word of the Lord to him, and to all those who were in his house.
He took them at the very hour of the night, washed their wounds, and was immediately baptized, he and all his family.
He brought them up to his house, served them food, and rejoiced greatly with all his family, because they had believed in God.
But when the day came, the magistrates sent the sergeants to say, "Let these men go."
The jailer reported these words to Paul, saying, "The magistrates have sent to release you; go out and go in peace. »
But Paul said to them, "They have beaten us publicly without trial, Romans, and have thrown us into prison. Will they now secretly release us? No, most certainly, but let them come themselves and take us out! » .
The sergeants reported these words to the magistrates, who were frightened to learn that they were Romans.
and they came to beg them. When they had brought them out, they begged them to leave the city.
They left the prison and entered the house of Lydia. After seeing the brothers, they encouraged them, and then they left.
After passing through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they arrived at Thessalonica, where there was a Jewish synagogue.
Paul, according to his custom, went into their house; and for three sabbaths he conversed with them according to the Scriptures,
explaining and demonstrating that Christ was to suffer and rise from the dead, and saying, "This Jesus, whom I proclaim to you, is the Christ."
Some of them were persuaded and joined Paul and Silas; among the pious Greeks, a great crowd, and several trusted women.
But the Jews, who were not convinced, took with them some wicked men from the place and, gathering a crowd, stirred up the city. Assailing Jason's house, they sought to bring them out before the people.
When they did not find them, they dragged Jason and some of the brothers before the chiefs of the city, crying out, "Those who have turned the world upside down have also come hither,
and Jason received them. All these act contrary to the decrees of Caesar, by saying that there is another king, Jesus! »
The crowd and the leaders of the city were troubled when they heard these things.
After taking the guarantee of Jason and the others, they let them go.
The brothers immediately sent Paul and Silas by night to Beroe. When they arrived, they entered the Jewish synagogue.
Now these people were nobler than those of Thessalonica, in that they received the word with complete availability of mind, examining the Scriptures every day to see if these things were true.
Many of them therefore believed, as well as eminent Greek women, and many men.
But when the Jews of Thessalonica heard that the word of God had been spoken by Paul in Beroe also, they also came, stirring up the crowd.
Then the brothers immediately sent Paul to the sea, while Silas and Timothy remained there.
But those who escorted Paul took him as far as Athens. Having received orders from Silas and Timothy to come to him very quickly, they departed.
While Paul was waiting for them in Athens, his spirit was inflamed within him, when he saw the city full of idols.
So he argued in the synagogue with the Jews and the pious people, and every day in the public square with those who met him.
Some of the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers also conversed with him. Some said: "What does this talkative man mean?" Others said, "He seems to be advocating foreign deities," because he was preaching Jesus and the resurrection.
They seized him and brought him to the Areopagus, saying, "Can we know what this new doctrine of which you speak is?
For you make our ears hear strange things. So we want to know what these things mean. »
Now all the Athenians and foreigners who lived there spent their time only in telling or hearing something new.
Paul, standing in the midst of the Areopagus, said, Men of Athens, I see that you are very religious in every respect.
In fact, in passing and observing the objects of your worship, I found an altar bearing this inscription: "TO AN UNKNOWN GOD"; I therefore announce to you what you worship out of ignorance.
The God who made the world and all that is in it, who is the Lord of heaven and earth, does not dwell in temples made with hands.
He is not served by the hands of men, as if he needed something, since he himself gives life, breath and all things to all.
He created all the nations of men with one blood to dwell on the whole face of the earth, fixing the seasons and the limits of their dwellings,
so that they might seek the Lord, if perhaps they could reach him and find him, although he is not far from each one of us.
For it is in him that we live, that we move, and that we have our existence. As some of your poets have said: "For we are also his descendants".
Being therefore the offspring of God, we must not think that the divine nature is like gold, silver, or stone, engraved by the art and purpose of man.
So God has neglected the times of ignorance. But now he commands that all men, everywhere, repent,
because he has appointed a day when he will judge the world according to righteousness, by the man whom he has appointed, and whose assurance he has given to all men that he has raised him from the dead. »
When they heard of the resurrection of the dead, some laughed; but the others said, "We want to hear from you about this again."
So Paul withdrew from among them.
But some men joined him, and believed, among others Dionysius the Areopagite, and a woman named Damaris, and others with them.
After this, Paul left Athens and went to Corinth.
He found a Jew named Aquila, a native of Pontus, who had just arrived from Italy with his wife Priscilla, for Claudius had ordered all the Jews to leave Rome. He came to them,
and, as he exercised the same trade, he lived with them and worked, for they were tent-makers.
He gave speeches in the synagogue every Sabbath and persuaded Jews and Greeks.
When Silas and Timothy came down from Macedonia, Paul, moved by the Spirit, testified to the Jews that Jesus was the Christ.
When they opposed him and blasphemed, he shook off his clothes and said to them, "Let your blood be on your heads! I am pure. From now on, I will go to the pagans! »
He left thence and entered the house of a man named Justus, a worshipper of God, whose house was next to the synagogue.
Crispus, the ruler of the synagogue, believed in the Lord with all his household. Many of the Corinthians, after hearing this, believed and were baptized.
The Lord said to Paul at night in a vision, "Do not be afraid, but speak and be not silent;
for I am with you, and no one will attack you to hurt you, for I have many people in this city. »
He stayed there a year and six months, teaching the word of God in their midst.
But when Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews, with one accord, rose up against Paul and brought him before the tribunal.
saying, "This man persuades men to worship God contrary to the law."
As Paul was about to open his mouth, Gallio said to the Jews, "If it were indeed a matter of evil or crime, you Jews would be reasonable for me to bear with you;
but if it is a question of words and names and of your own law, look for yourselves. Because I don't want to be the judge of these questions. »
He therefore expelled them from the tribunal.
Then all the Greeks seized Sosthenes, the ruler of the synagogue, and defeated him before the tribunal. Gallio didn't care about any of these things.
Paul, having stayed several days after this, took leave of the brethren, and embarked from there for Syria, with Priscilla and Aquila. He shaved his head at Cenchrea, for he had made a vow.
He arrived at Ephesus, where he left them, but he himself entered the synagogue and conversed with the Jews.
When they asked him to stay longer with them, he refused;
but, taking leave of them, he said, "I must absolutely celebrate the feast that is coming to Jerusalem, but I will return to you if God wills." Then he set out from Ephesus.
After landing at Caesarea, he went up and greeted the assembly, and then he went down to Antioch.
After spending some time there, he set out and passed through the region of Galatia and Phrygia, to settle all the disciples.
Now a Jew named Apollos, of Alexandrian race, an eloquent man, came to Ephesus. He was versed in the Scriptures.
This man had been instructed in the way of the Lord; and, fervent in spirit, he spoke and taught with accuracy the things concerning Jesus, although he knew only the baptism of John.
He began to speak confidently in the synagogue. But Priscilla and Aquila, having heard him, took him aside and explained to him more accurately the way of God.
When he had decided to go over to Achaia, the brothers encouraged him, and they wrote to the disciples to receive him. When he arrived, he greatly helped those who had believed by grace;
for he strongly refuted the Jews, publicly demonstrating by the Scriptures that Jesus was the Christ.
While Apollos was at Corinth, Paul, having passed through the high country, arrived at Ephesus, where he found some disciples.
He said to them, "Did you receive the Holy Spirit when you believed?" They told him, "No, we haven't even heard that there is a Holy Spirit."
He said, "What have you been baptized into?" They said, "At the baptism of John."
Paul says, "For John baptized with a baptism of repentance, telling the people that they should believe in him who would come after him, that is, in Christ Jesus."
After hearing this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
When Paul had laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came upon them, and they spoke in other tongues and prophesied.
There were about twelve men in all.
He entered the synagogue, and for three months he spoke boldly, reasoning, and persuading about things pertaining to the kingdom of God.
But, as some were hardened and disobedient, speaking ill of the Way before the crowd, he separated himself from them and separated the disciples, reasoning every day in the school of Tyrannus.
This lasted for two years, so that all who dwelt in Asia heard the word of the Lord Jesus, both Jews and Greeks.
God worked special miracles through Paul's hands,
so that even handkerchiefs or aprons were carried from his body to the sick, and diseases withdrew from them, and evil spirits went out.
But some itinerant Jews, exorcists, undertook to invoke upon those who had evil spirits the name of the Lord Jesus, saying, "We adjure you by Jesus that Paul preaches."
There were seven sons of a certain Sceva, a Jewish high priest, who did this.
The evil spirit answered, "I know Jesus and I know Paul, but who are you?"
The man in whom the evil spirit was leaped upon them, subdued them, and prevailed over them, so that they fled from that house, naked and wounded.
This was known to all the inhabitants of Ephesus, Jews and Greeks. Fear took hold of them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was glorified.
Many of those who had believed also came, confessing and declaring their works.
Many of those who practiced the magical arts gathered together their books and burned them in the eyes of all. They counted the price, which amounted to fifty thousand pieces of silver.
Thus, the word of the Lord spread and became powerful.
Now after these things had come to an end, Paul resolved by the Spirit, after he had passed through Macedonia and Achaia, to go to Jerusalem, saying, "After I have been there, I must also see Rome."
Having sent two of those who served him, Timothy and Erastus, to Macedonia, he himself remained for some time in Asia.
About this time there was a great commotion about the way.
In fact, a man named Demetrius, a goldsmith who made silver statues of Artemis, brought a small business to the craftsmen,
which he gathered together with the workers of the same profession, and said: "Gentlemen, you know that it is by this trade that we are rich.
You see and hear that it was not only in Ephesus, but in almost all Asia, that this Paul persuaded and turned away many people, by saying that gods made with hands are not gods.
Not only is our trade in danger of being discredited, but also the temple of the great goddess Artemis, whom all Asia and the whole world venerate, is in danger of being counted for nothing and its majesty destroyed. »
When they heard this, they were filled with anger and cried out, "Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!"
The whole city was filled with confusion, and they all rushed together into the theatre, having taken Gaius and Aristarchus, men of Macedonia, Paul's travelling companions.
When Paul wanted to enter among the people, the disciples would not allow him.
Some of the Asiarci, who were his friends, sent him a letter begging him not to venture on the stage.
Some therefore cried out one thing, others another, for the assembly was in confusion. Most of them didn't know why they had come together.
Alexander was brought out of the midst of the crowd, the Jews having brought him forward. Alexander waved to them with his hand, and he would have liked to speak before the people.
But when they saw that he was a Jew, they all cried out with one voice and for about two hours, "Great is Artemis of the Ephesians!"
When the secretary of the city had calmed the crowd, he said, "Men of Ephesus, what man is there who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is the guardian of the temple of the great goddess Artemis and the fallen image of Zeus?
Since you cannot deny these things, stay quiet and do not do anything rash.
For you have brought these men, who are neither robbers of temples nor blasphemers of your goddess.
If, therefore, Demetrius and the artisans who are with him have a case against anyone, the courts are open and there are proconsuls. Let them file a complaint against each other.
But if you are looking for something about other business, it will be settled in the regular assembly.
Indeed, we risk being accused about today's riot, without there being any reason. On this subject, we could not give an account of this agitation. »
After the tumult had ceased, Paul summoned the disciples, took leave of them, and set out for Macedonia.
After having traversed these countries and encouraged them with many words, he arrived in Greece.
As he had spent three months there, and a plot had been formed against him by Jews, at the moment when he was embarking for Syria, he resolved to return by way of Macedonia.
These accompanied him as far as Asia: Sopater of Beroe, Aristarchus and Secundus of the Thessalonians, Gaius of Derbe, Timothy, Tychicus and Trophimus of Asia.
But the latter had gone ahead, and they were waiting for us at Troas.
We left Philippi after the days of unleavened bread, and joined them at Troas in five days, where we stayed seven days.
On the first day of the week, the disciples being assembled to break bread, Paul conversed with them, intending to depart the next day, and he continued his discourse until midnight.
There were many lights in the upper room where we were gathered.
A young man, named Eutychus, was sitting at the window, overwhelmed by a deep sleep. While Paul was still speaking, overwhelmed by his sleep, he fell from the third floor and was carried away dead.
Paul went down, threw himself on him, and, embracing him, said, "Do not be troubled, for his life is in him."
When he had gone upstairs, had broken bread and eaten, and had conversed with them for a long time, until daybreak, he went away.
They brought the child back alive, and were greatly comforted.
But we went to the boat, and sailed to Assos, intending to take Paul on board, for he had made his arrangements, and intended to come by land.
When he met us at Assos, we took him on board, and arrived at Mitylene.
From there we sailed the next day opposite Chios. The next day we touched at Samos and stopped at Trogyllium, and the next day we arrived at Miletus.
Paul had indeed decided to pass before Ephesus, in order not to have to stay in Asia, for he was hastening, if he could, to be in Jerusalem on the day of Pentecost.
From Miletus he sent to Ephesus and summoned the elders of the assembly.
When they came to him, he said to them, "You yourselves know, from the first day I set foot in Asia, how I have always been with you,
serving the Lord in all humility, with many tears, and in the trials that came upon me through the plots of the Jews;
how I have not been afraid to announce to you all that was useful, teaching you publicly and from house to house,
testifying to the Jews and Greeks repentance towards God and faith in our Lord Jesus.
Now behold, I am going to Jerusalem bound by the Spirit, not knowing what will happen to me there,
except that the Holy Spirit bears witness in every city that bonds and tribulations await me.
But these things do not count, and I do not value my life, in order to gladly complete my course and the ministry I have received from the Lord Jesus, to bear full witness to the Good News of God's grace.
"Now, behold, I know that all of you, in the midst of whom I went preaching the kingdom of God, you will no longer see my face.
Therefore I testify to you today that I am cleansed from the blood of all men,
for I have not feared to explain to you all the counsel of God.
Take heed, therefore, to yourselves and to all the flock, in which the Holy Spirit has appointed you overseers, to shepherd the assembly of the Lord and God, which he has purchased for himself by his own blood.
For I know that after my departure, vicious wolves will enter among you, without sparing the flock.
Men will arise from among you who will say evil things, to drag the disciples after them.
Watch then, remembering that for three years I have not ceased to exhort everyone night and day with tears.
Now, brethren, I commit you to God and to the word of his grace, which is able to edify you and give you the inheritance among all those who are sanctified.
I have coveted neither silver, nor gold, nor anyone's clothes.
You yourselves know that these hands have served my needs, and those who were with me.
In all things I have set an example for you, that in your work you may succor the weak, and remember the words of the Lord Jesus, who Himself said, "It is more blessed to give than to receive."
When he had said these things, he knelt down and prayed with them all.
They all wept profusely, and, throwing themselves on Paul's neck, they kissed him,
saddened above all by the word he had spoken, that they would no longer see his face. Then they accompanied him to the ship.
After leaving them and setting sail, we headed straight for Cos, then the next day for Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
Having found a ship that was making the crossing to Phoenicia, we went up there and sailed.
After sighting the island of Cyprus, which we left on our left, we sailed for Syria, and landed at Tyre, for the ship was there to unload her cargo.
Having found disciples, we stayed there seven days. They told Paul, by the Spirit, that he should not go up to Jerusalem.
When these days were over, we set out and set out. All of them, with wives and children, accompanied us until we had left the city. Kneeling on the beach, we prayed.
After saying goodbye, we boarded the ship, and they returned home.
When we had finished the journey from Tyre, we arrived at Ptolemais. We greeted the brothers and stayed with them one day.
The next day, we who were Paul's companions set out and arrived at Caesarea. We entered the house of Philip the Evangelist, who was one of the seven, and we remained with him.
Now this man had four virgin daughters who prophesied.
As we had been there for a few days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.
Coming to us and taking Paul's girdle, he bound his hands and feet, and said, "The Holy Spirit said, The Jews of Jerusalem will bind the man to whom this girdle belongs, and deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles."
When we heard these things, we begged him and the inhabitants of that place not to go up to Jerusalem.
Paul answered, "What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be bound, but also to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus. »
Since he would not be convinced, we stopped saying, "The will of the Lord be done."
After these days, we packed our bags and went up to Jerusalem.
Some of the disciples from Caesarea accompanied us, as well as a certain Mnason, from Cyprus, a disciple of the first hour, with whom we were to lodge.
When we arrived in Jerusalem, the brethren received us with joy.
The next day, Paul went with us to James' house, and all the elders were present.
After greeting them, he related one by one the things that God had wrought among the pagans through his ministry.
These, after hearing him, glorified God. They said to him, "You see, brother, that there are thousands of believers among the Jews, and all are zealous for the law.
It has been learned about you that you teach all the Jews who are among the Gentiles to renounce Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children and not to follow the customs.
What to do then? The assembly must certainly meet, for they will hear that you have come.
Do as we tell you. We have four men who have made a wish.
Take them and purify yourself with them, and pay for them their expenses, so that they may shave their heads. Then all will know that there is no truth in the things they have been told about you, but that you too walk in keeping the law.
But as for the pagans who believed, we have written our decision that they must observe nothing of the kind, except that they must beware of food offered to idols, blood, strangled objects, and fornication. »
Then Paul took the men, purified himself the next day, and entered with them into the temple, announcing the fulfillment of the days of purification, until the offering had been presented for each of them.
When the seven days were nearly over, the Jews of Asia, seeing him in the temple, lifted up the whole crowd and laid their hands on him.
crying out, "Men of Israel, help! This is the man who teaches all men everywhere against the people, against the law, and against this place. In addition, he brought Greeks into the temple and defiled this holy place! »
For they had seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city, and they supposed that Paul had brought him into the temple.
The whole city was moved and the people came running. They seized Paul and dragged him out of the temple. Immediately the doors were closed.
As they sought to kill him, the news reached the commander of the regiment that all Jerusalem was in turmoil.
Immediately he took soldiers and centurions and ran to them. The latter, seeing the tribune and the soldiers, ceased to beat Paul.
Then the tribune approached, stopped him, ordered him to be bound with two chains, and asked who he was and what he had done.
Some shouted one thing and others another, among the crowd. As he could not know the truth because of the noise, he ordered that he be taken to the barracks.
When he arrived at the staircase, he was carried by the soldiers, because of the violence of the crowd;
for the multitude of the people followed him, crying, "Let him go!"
As Paul was about to be taken to the barracks, he asked the commanding officer, "May I speak to you?" He said, "Do you know Greek?
Are you not the Egyptian who, before these days, stirred up to sedition and led the four thousand men of the assassins into the desert?
But Paul said, "I am a Jew from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of a city that is not insignificant. Please allow me to speak to the people. »
After giving him permission, Paul, standing on the stairs, beckoned to the people. As there was a great silence, he spoke to them in the Hebrew language, saying,
"Brothers and fathers, listen to the defense I now make to you."
When they heard that he spoke to them in the Hebrew language, they were even more silent. He said:
"I am truly a Jew, born in Tarsus in Cilicia, but brought up in this city at the feet of Gamaliel, instructed according to the strict tradition of the law of our fathers, zealous for God, as you all are today.
I persecuted this way unto death, binding and delivering men and women to prison,
as the high priest and all the council of elders testify, from whom I also received letters for the brethren, and I went to Damascus to bring to Jerusalem those who were there, bound to be punished.
"As I was on my way and approaching Damascus, about noon, a great light suddenly burst forth from the sky around me.
I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, "Saul, Saul, why do you persecute me?"
I answered, "Who are you, Lord?" He said to me, "I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom you persecute.
Those who were with me saw the light and were afraid, but they did not understand the voice of the one who spoke to me.
I said, "What shall I do, Lord?" The Lord answered me, 'Get up and go to Damascus. There you will be informed of all that is prescribed to you.
As I could not see because of the glory of this light, being led by the hand of those who were with me, I entered Damascus.
A certain Ananias, a pious man according to the law, well known to all the Jews who inhabited Damascus,
came to me, and, standing by me, he said to me, "Brother Saul, receive your sight. At the same hour, I raised my eyes to him.
He said, "The God of our fathers has ordained you to know his will, to see the righteous one, and to hear the voice of his mouth.
For you will be a witness to him before all men of what you have seen and heard.
Now, why are you waiting? Arise, be baptized, and wash away your sins, calling on the name of the Lord'.
"When I returned to Jerusalem and prayed in the temple, I fell into a trance
and I saw him saying to me, "Make haste to come out of Jerusalem, for they do not want to receive from you the testimony that concerns me.
I replied, "Lord, they themselves know that I imprisoned and beat in all the synagogues those who believed in you.
And when the blood of Stephen, your witness, was shed, I too was there, consenting to his death and guarding the cloaks of those who killed him.
"He said to me, 'Go away, for I will send you far from here to the Gentiles.'"
They listened to him until he said this, and then they raised their voices and said, "Get rid of this man's earth, for he is not worthy to live."
As they screamed, threw off their cloaks, and threw dust into the air,
the tribune ordered him to be brought into the barracks, and to be examined by scourging, in order to know for what crime they were thus crying out against him.
