When they had tied him with thongs, Paul asked the centurion who was standing there, "Is it lawful for you to scourge a man who is a Roman and has not been found guilty?"
The centurion, when he heard this, went to the commander and said to him, "Be careful what you are going to do, for this man is a Roman."
The commander came and asked him, "Tell me, are you a Roman?" He said, "Yes."
The commander replied, "I bought my citizenship at a great price." Paul said, "But I was born a Roman."
Immediately those who were about to interrogate him withdrew from him, and the tribune was also frightened when he perceived that he was a Roman, for he had caused him to be bound.
But the next day, desiring to know the truth as to why he was accused by the Jews, he freed him from bonds, and ordered the chief priests and the whole council to assemble, to bring Paul down, and to bring him before them.
Paul, looking fixedly at the counsel, said, "Brethren, I have lived before God in good conscience to this day."
The high priest, Ananias, ordered those who stood near him to slap him on the mouth.
Then Paul said to him, "God will strike you, whitewashed wall! Do you sit down to judge me according to the law, and command me to be struck contrary to the law?
Those who stood there said, "Are you defaming the high priest of God?"
Paul said, "I did not know, brethren, that he was high priest. For it is written: "You shall not speak ill of a ruler of your people."
But Paul, seeing that some were Sadducees and others Pharisees, cried out in the Sanhedrin, "Men and brethren, I am a Pharisee, the son of Pharisees. It is on the hope and resurrection of the dead that I am judged! »
As soon as he had said this, a dispute arose between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the crowd was divided.
For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, no angel, no spirit; but the Pharisees confess all this.
A great clamor arose, and some of the scribes, on the side of the Pharisees, arose and disputed, saying, "We find no evil in this man. But if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him, let us not fight against God! »
A great dispute having arisen, the commander, fearing that Paul would be torn to pieces by them, ordered the soldiers to come down, take him by force among them, and bring him to the barracks.
The next night the Lord stood by him and said, "Be of good cheer, Paul, for as you bore witness of me in Jerusalem, so you must also bear witness to Rome."
When it was day, some of the Jews gathered together and bound themselves by a curse, saying that they would not eat or drink until they had killed Paul.
There were more than forty persons who had formed this conspiracy.
They went to the chief priests and the elders, and said, "We have bound ourselves with a great curse that we will not taste anything until we have killed Paul."
Now, therefore, you, with the council, inform the tribune that he is to bring him to you tomorrow, as if you were going to judge his case more exactly. We are ready to kill him before he gets closer. »
The son of Paul's sister, having heard that they were on the lookout, entered the barracks and informed Paul.
Paul sent for one of the centurions and said, "Bring this young man to the commander, for he has something to say to him."
So he took him and brought him to the commandant, saying, "Paul, the prisoner, has summoned me and asked me to bring this young man to you. He has something to tell you. »
The commander took him by the hand and, going away, asked him privately: "What have you to say to me?"
He said, "The Jews have agreed to ask you to bring Paul to the council tomorrow, as if they intended to inquire a little more about him.
Do not yield to them, for more than forty men are waiting for him, who have bound themselves by a curse not to eat or drink until they have killed him. Now they are ready, waiting for the promise from you. »
So the commander let the young man go, recommending him, "Don't tell anyone that you have revealed these things to me."
He called two of the centurions, and said, "Prepare two hundred soldiers to go to Caesarea, with seventy horsemen and two hundred men armed with spears, at the third hour of the night."
He asked them to provide mounts, in order to get Paul on one of them and bring him safe and sound to Felix, the governor.
He wrote a letter in the following terms:
"Claudius Lysias to the most excellent governor Felix: Greetings.
This man had been seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them, when I arrived with the soldiers and rescued him, having learned that he was a Roman.
Wishing to know why they accused him, I brought him down to their council.
I found that he was accused on matters pertaining to their law, but that he was not accused of anything that deserved death or imprisonment.
When I was told that the Jews were waiting for this man, I sent him to you immediately, charging his accusers to present to you their accusations against him as well. Farewell. »
The soldiers, carrying out their orders, took Paul and conducted him by night to Antipatris.
The next day, they left the horsemen who were to accompany him and returned to the barracks.
When they arrived at Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor, they also presented Paul to him.
After reading it, the governor asked what province he came from. When he understood that he was from Cilicia, he said:
"I will hear you fully when your accusers have also arrived." He ordered him to be kept in Herod's palace.
Five days after, the high priest Ananias came down with some elders and an orator, a certain Tertullus. They informed the governor against Paul.
When he was summoned, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying, "Since through you we enjoy great peace, and through your foresight prosperity comes to this nation,
But, in order not to delay you, I beg you to put up with us and listen to a few words.
For we have found this man to be a scourge, an instigator of insurrections among all the Jews of the whole world, and a leader of the sect of the Nazarenes.
He even tried to desecrate the temple, and we arrested him.
By examining him yourself, you will be able to ascertain all these things of which we accuse him. »
The Jews also joined the attack, claiming that these things were true.
When the governor beckoned him to speak, Paul spoke up and said, "Since I know that you have long been a judge of this nation, I willingly accept to defend myself.
since you can verify that it is not more than twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem to worship.
I was not found in the temple arguing with anyone or stirring up a crowd, neither in the synagogues nor in the city.
Nor can they prove to you the things they are now accusing me of.
But I confess to you that, according to the way which they call a sect, I serve the God of our fathers, believing in all that is according to the law and that which is written in the prophets,
hoping in God, which they themselves hope, that there will be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and the unjust.
This is what I also practice, always having a conscience free from offense to God and to men.
Now, after a few years, I have come to bring to my nation gifts for the needy and offerings;
in the midst of which some Jews of Asia found me purified in the temple, not with a crowd, nor with tumult.
They should have come here before you and filed a complaint, if they had anything against me.
Or let these men themselves say what injustice they found in me when I appeared before the council,
unless it was for this reason alone that I cried out in the midst of them, "It is on the resurrection of the dead that I am judged before you today."
But Felix, who had a more precise knowledge of the way, reported them, saying, "When Lysias, the commander, has come down, I will decide your case."
He commanded the centurion to keep Paul and to grant him some privileges, and not to forbid any of his friends to serve him or visit him.
A few days after, Felix, accompanied by Drusilla, his wife, who was a Jew, sent for Paul and heard him about faith in Jesus Christ.
As he discoursed on justice, self-control, and the judgment to come, Felix was terrified and replied, "Go away for the present, and when it suits me, I will summon you."
In the meantime, he also hoped that Paul would give him money, in order to free him. Therefore he sent for him more often and conversed with him.
Two years later, Porcius Festus succeeded Felix. Eager to curry favor with the Jews, Felix left Paul in prison.
Festus, having arrived in the province, went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem at the end of three days.
Then the high priest and the leading men of the Jews gave him information against Paul, and they begged him,
asking him for a favor, to summon him to Jerusalem, plotting to kill him on the way.
But Festus replied that Paul was to be kept in custody at Caesarea, and that he himself would soon depart.
"Let those who have power among you," he said, "come down with me, and if there is anything evil in this man, let them accuse him."
After spending more than ten days among them, he went down to Caesarea, and the next day he sat down on the tribunal, and ordered Paul to be brought in.
When he was brought in, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him, bringing against him many and grave accusations which they could not prove.
while he said in his defence, "I have committed no sin, neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar."
But Festus, desirous of gaining the favor of the Jews, spoke up and said to Paul, "Will you go up to Jerusalem and be judged by me about these things?"
But Paul answered, "I stand before the tribunal of Caesar, where I am to be judged. I have done nothing wrong to the Jews, as you also know very well.
For if I have committed a fault and something that deserves death, I do not refuse to die; but if none of these things of which they accuse me is true, no one can deliver me up to them. I appeal to Caesar! »
Then Festus, after consulting the council, spoke up and said, "You have appealed to Caesar. It is to Caesar that you will go. »
A few days later, King Agrippa and Berenice arrived in Caesarea and greeted Festus.
When he remained there several days, Festus explained to the king the cause of Paul, saying, "There is a man whom Felix has left prisoner,
and concerning which, when I was in Jerusalem, the chief priests and elders of the Jews informed me, asking for a sentence against him.
I told them that it is not the custom of the Romans to deliver a man to death before the accused has met his accusers and had an opportunity to defend himself on the charges against him.
So when they gathered here, I didn't delay, but the next day, I sat on the seat of the court and ordered the man to be brought in.
The accusers, having risen, did not accuse him of the things I had supposed,
but they asked him questions about their own religion and about a certain Jesus, dead, whom Paul declared to be alive.
Not knowing how to inquire about these things, I asked him if he would go to Jerusalem and be judged there on this subject.
But when Paul asked that he be kept for the emperor's judgment, I ordered him to be kept until I could send him to Caesar. »
Agrippa said to Festus, "I would like to hear it myself." "To-morrow," he said, "you will hear it."
The next day, Agrippa and Berenice having come with great pomp, and having entered the place of audience with the commanders and principals of the city, by order of Festus, Paul was brought in.
Festus said, "King Agrippa, and all who are here with us, you see this man about whom all the multitude of the Jews have made supplications to me, both in Jerusalem and here, saying that he should live no more.
But as I found that he had committed nothing that deserved death, and as he himself appealed to the emperor, I decided to send him,
he of whom I have nothing certain to write to my lord. Therefore I have brought him before you, and especially before you, King Agrippa, so that, after examination, I may have something to write.
Because it seems to me unreasonable, in sending a prisoner, not to specify the charges against him. »
Agrippa said to Paul, "You can speak in your own name." Then Paul stretched out his hand and defended him.
"I consider myself fortunate, King Agrippa, to have to defend myself before you today on all the things of which I am accused by the Jews,
all the more so since you are an expert in all the customs and in all the questions that arise among the Jews. I therefore beg you to listen to me with patience.
"For all the Jews know my way of life from my youth, which from the beginning was among my own nation and in Jerusalem;
having known me from the beginning, if they will testify, that according to the strictest sect of our religion I have lived as a Pharisee.
Now, I stand here to be judged because of the hope of the promise made by God to our fathers,
which our twelve tribes, serving with ardor night and day, hope to reach. It is on this hope that I am accused by the Jews, King Agrippa!
Why do you think it is incredible that God raises the dead?
"I myself have most certainly thought that I must do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
This is also what I did in Jerusalem. I have caused a great number of saints to be shut up in prisons, having received the authority of the chief priests; and when they were put to death, I voted against them.
Often punishing them in all the synagogues, I strove to make them blaspheme. Being extremely furious with them, I persecuted them even in foreign cities.
"While I was going to Damascus with the authorization and mission of the chief priests,
At noon, O king, I saw on the way a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, which surrounded me and those who traveled with me.
When we had all fallen to the ground, I heard a voice saying to me in Hebrew, "Saul, Saul, why do you persecute me? It is difficult for you to strike against the goads."
"I said, 'Who are you, Lord? He said, "I am Jesus, whom you persecute.
But arise and stand on your feet, for for this purpose I have appeared to you, to make you a servant and witness of the things which you have seen and of those which I will reveal to you,
to deliver you from the people and the pagans to whom I send you,
to open their eyes, that they may pass from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive the remission of sins, and an inheritance from those who are sanctified by faith in me.
"Wherefore, King Agrippa, I have not disobeyed the heavenly vision,
but I have announced first to those of Damascus, to Jerusalem, to all the land of Judea, and also to the Gentiles, that they must repent and turn to God, doing works worthy of repentance.
That is why the Jews seized me in the temple and wanted to put me to death.
Having therefore obtained the help that comes from God, I stand to this day to bear witness to the small and the great, saying nothing but what the prophets and Moses have announced,
how Christ must suffer and how, through the resurrection of the dead, he will be the first to announce light to this people and to the pagans. »
As he was thus defending him, Festus said in a loud voice, "Paul, you are mad! Your great knowledge drives you crazy! »
But he answered, "I am not mad, most excellent Festus, but I boldly speak words of truth and reason.
For the king is aware of these things, and it is to him also that I speak freely. For I am persuaded that none of these things are hidden from him, since it was not done in a corner.
King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know you believe. »
Agrippa said to Paul, "With a little persuasion, are you trying to make me a Christian?"
Paul says, "I pray to God, that with little or with much, not only you, but also all who listen to me today, may become as I am, except for these bonds."
The king arose with the governor and Berenice, and those who were seated with them.
When they had retired, they spoke to each other, saying, "This man does nothing that deserves death or imprisonment."
Agrippa said to Festus, "This man might have been freed if he had not appealed to Caesar."
When it was decided that we should sail for Italy, they delivered Paul and some other prisoners to a centurion named Julius, of the army of Augustus.
We embarked on a ship from Adramyttium, which was going to sail to places situated on the coast of Asia, Aristarchus, a Macedonian from Thessalonica, being with us.
The next day, we landed at Sidon. Julius treated Paul kindly, and gave him permission to go to his friends to refresh himself.
From there we set sail to leeward of the island of Cyprus, for the winds were contrary.
After crossing the sea which is off Cilicia and Pamphylia, we arrived at Myra, a city of Lycia.
There the centurion found a ship from Alexandria on its way to Italy, and he put us on board.
After sailing slowly for several days, and arriving with difficulty in front of Cnidus, the wind not permitting us to go any further, we sailed to leeward of Crete, opposite Salmone.
We skirted it with difficulty, and arrived at a place called Havres de plaisance, near the town of Lasea.
As much time had passed and the journey had become dangerous, because the fast had already passed, Paul warned them
and said to them, "Gentlemen, I see that the voyage will be made with considerable damage and loss, not only to the cargo and the ship, but also to our lives."
But the centurion paid more attention to the captain and the owner of the ship than to Paul's words.
As the harbor was not conducive to wintering, most people advised to set sail from there, if they could reach Phoenix and spend the winter there, which is a port of Crete, looking southwest and northwest.
When the south wind blew gently, supposing that they had reached their goal, they weighed anchor and sailed along Crete, close to the shore.
But soon a stormy wind beat on the shore, which is called Euroclydon.
The ship being taken and unable to face the wind, we yielded to her and were dragged away.
Running to leeward of a small island called Clauda, we were able, with difficulty, to stow the boat.
After hoisting it, they used cables to help reinforce the ship. Fearing to run aground on the sandbanks of Syrtis, they lowered the sea anchor and let themselves be carried away.
As we were very tried by the storm, the next day they began to throw objects overboard.
On the third day, they threw the ship's tackle with their own hands.
When, for several days, neither the sun nor the stars had shone upon us, and no small storm pressed upon us, all hope of being saved vanished.
After they had been a long time without eating, Paul stood up in the midst of them and said, "Gentlemen, you should have listened to me, and not left Crete, to have this wound and loss.
Now I urge you to take courage, for there will be no loss of life among you, but only that of the ship.
For this night stood by me an angel, belonging to the God whom I am and whom I serve,
and who said to me, "Fear not, Paul. You must present yourself before Caesar. And behold, God has granted you all those who sail with you.
That is why, gentlemen, rejoice! For I believe in God, and it will be as I have been told.
But we have to run aground on an island. »
But the fourteenth night having arrived, as we were tossed about in the Adriatic Sea, about midnight the sailors supposed that they were approaching some land.
They sounded and found twenty fathoms. A little later, they sounded again and found fifteen fathoms.
Fearing that we would run aground on rocky ground, they dropped four anchors from the stern, and wished it would be daylight.
As the sailors were trying to escape from the ship, and had lowered the boat into the sea, pretending that they were going to drop anchors by the bow,
Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, "If these do not remain in the ship, you cannot be saved."
Then the soldiers cut the ropes of the boat and let it fall.
As the day drew near, Paul begged them to take food, saying, "Today is the fourteenth day that you are waiting and fasting, without having taken anything.
Therefore I beg you to take food, for it is for your salvation, for not a hair of your heads will perish. »
When he had said this and taken bread, he gave thanks to God in the presence of all; then he broke it and began to eat.
Then they all rejoiced, and they also took food.
In all, we were two hundred and seventy-six people on the ship.
When they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship and threw the wheat into the sea.
When the day came, they did not recognize the land, but they noticed a certain bay with a beach, and they decided to try to drive the ship there.
Casting the anchors, they left them in the sea, at the same time as they untied the ropes of the rudder. They hoist the headsail upwind and head for the beach.
But arriving at a place where two seas met, they ran the ship aground. The bow struck and remained motionless, but the stern began to break with the violence of the waves.
The advice of the soldiers was to kill the prisoners, so that none of them could save themselves by swimming.
But the centurion, wishing to save Paul, turned them away from their purpose, and ordered those who knew how to swim to throw themselves overboard first to reach the mainland;
and that the others follow, some on planks and others on other objects of the ship. In this way they all escaped to dry land.
When we escaped, they learned that the island was called Malta.
The natives showed us an uncommon kindness, for they lit a fire and received us all, because of the rain that was falling and the cold.
But when Paul had gathered a bundle of twigs and put them on the fire, a viper came out because of the heat and clung to his hand.
When the natives saw the creature hanging from his hand, they said to one another, "No doubt this man is a murderer, whom, although he has escaped from the sea, justice has not allowed him to live."
However, he shook the creature in the fire, and was not hurt.
They expected that he would have swollen or fallen dead suddenly, but as they watched for a long time and saw nothing bad happen to him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.
Now in the vicinity of this place there was land belonging to the chief of the island, named Publius, who received us and conversed courteously with us for three days.
Publius' father was ill with fever and dysentery. Paul went into his house, prayed, and, after laying his hands on him, healed him.
When this was done, the other sick of the island also came and were healed.
They also paid us many honors, and when we sailed, they put on board the things we needed.
At the end of three months, we embarked on a ship from Alexandria which had wintered on the island, and whose figurehead was "The Twin Brothers."
We landed at Syracuse, where we stayed three days.
From there we went round and arrived at Rhegium. A day later, a south wind arose, and on the second day we arrived at Puteoli,
where we found brethren, and we were requested to stay with them seven days. We therefore arrived at Rome.
From thence the brethren, having heard of us, came to meet us as far as the market of Appius and the three taverns. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and took courage.
When we entered Rome, the centurion handed over the prisoners to the chief of the guards, but Paul was allowed to remain alone with the soldier who guarded him.
Three days later, Paul summoned the leaders of the Jews. When they were assembled, he said to them, "I, brethren, though I have done nothing against the people or against the customs of our fathers, have been delivered up as a prisoner of Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans."
The latter, after examining me, wanted to release me, because there was no cause of death in me.
But as the Jews opposed it, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar, without having anything to reproach my nation with.
That is why I have asked to see you and to speak with you. For it is because of the hope of Israel that I am bound by this chain. »
They said to him, "We have not received any letters from Judea about you, and none of the brethren have come here to report or speak ill of you.
But we want to know what you think about you. For, as far as this sect is concerned, we know that everywhere it is denounced. »
When a day was appointed for him, many people came to him in his lodgings. He gave them explanations, testified to the kingdom of God, and persuaded them about Jesus, according to the law of Moses and the prophets, from morning to night.
Some believed in the things that were said, and others did not.
When they disagreed among themselves, they departed, after Paul had spoken a single message: "The Holy Spirit rightly spoke to our fathers through the prophet Isaiah,
saying, Go to this people and say to them, when you hear, you will hear, but will not understand in any case. When you see, you will see, but that he will not perceive in any case.
For the heart of this people has become insensitive. Their ears are deaf. They closed their eyes. Lest they see with their eyes, hear with their ears, understand with their hearts, and turn again, then I will heal them.
"Know therefore that the salvation of God is sent to the nations, and that they will hear."
Paul stayed two whole years in the house he rented and received all who came to him,
preaching the kingdom of God and teaching concerning the Lord Jesus Christ, with all boldness and without hindrance.
Paul, servant of Jesus Christ, called to be an apostle, set apart for the Good News of God,
which he promised before by his prophets in the holy scriptures,
concerning his Son, born of the seed of David according to the flesh,
declared the Son of God with power according to the Spirit of holiness, through the resurrection of the dead, Jesus Christ our Lord,
by which we have received grace and the apostolate for the obedience of the faith among all nations, for his name's sake;
among whom you are also called to belong to Jesus Christ;
To all those who are in Rome, beloved of God, called to be holy: Grace and peace to you, from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for all of you, that your faith is proclaimed throughout the world.
For God is my witness, whom I serve in spirit in the Good News of his Son, how unceasingly I mention you in my prayers,
asking if, in one way or another, the will of God finally allows me to go to you.
For I ardently desire to see you, that I may impart to you some spiritual gift, that you may be strengthened;
that is to say, that I may be encouraged in you, each one of us by the faith of the other, yours and mine.
Now I do not want you to be ignorant, brethren, that I have often planned to come to you (and have been prevented from doing so until now), in order to bear fruit among you also, as well as among the rest of the pagans.
I owe a debt to the Greeks and foreigners, to the wise and the foolish.
Thus, as far as it is in me, I am eager to proclaim the Good News to you who are also in Rome.
In fact, I am not ashamed of the Good News of Christ, for it is the power of God for the salvation of everyone who believes, of the Jew first, and also of the Greek.
For in it is revealed the righteousness of God, from faith to faith. As it is written, "The righteous shall live by faith."
For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men who suppress the truth in unrighteousness,
because what is known to God is revealed in them, for God has revealed it to them.
For the invisible things of God, from the creation of the world, are clearly seen, being perceived by the things made, even his eternal power and divinity, so that they may be without excuse.
Because, knowing God, they did not glorify Him as God, nor gave thanks, but they became vain in their reasonings, and their foolish hearts were darkened.
Pretending to be wise, they have gone mad,
and they have exchanged the glory of the incorruptible God for the image of corruptible man, birds, quadrupeds, and reptiles.
Therefore God has given them up to impurity in the lusts of their hearts, that their bodies might be dishonored in their midst.
They turned God's truth into a lie, and they worshipped and served the creature rather than the Creator, who is eternally blessed. Amen.
That is why God has given them over to infamous passions. For their wives have changed the natural function into what is unnatural.
In the same way, men, abandoning the natural function of woman, have become inflamed in their lust for one another, men doing what is unbecoming with men, and receiving in themselves the punishment due to their error.
As they refused to have God in their knowledge, God gave them over to a reprobate spirit, to do what is not proper;
being filled with all iniquity, sexual immorality, wickedness, greed, malice; full of envy, murders, quarrels, deceits, bad habits, slanderers in secret,
backbiters, odious to God, insolent, arrogant, boastful, inventors of misfortunes, disobedient to their parents,
without intelligence, violators of covenants, without natural affection, pitiless, without mercy,
who, knowing the decree of God, that those who practice such things deserve death, not only do the same, but also approve of those who practice them.
Therefore you are without excuse, O man, whoever judges it may be. For in what you judge another, you condemn yourself. For you who judge, you practice the same things.
We know that God's judgment is in accordance with the truth against those who practice such things.
Do you think, O man who judges those who practice such things, and does the same, that you will escape the judgment of God?
Or do you despise the riches of His goodness, long-suffering, and patience, not knowing that the goodness of God leads you to repentance?
But according to your harshness and impenitence, you reserve for yourselves wrath in the day of the wrath, of revelation, and of the righteous judgment of God,
who "will render to each one according to his works".
to those who, by perseverance in good deeds, seek glory, honor, and incorruption, eternal life;
but to those who delight in selfishness and do not obey the truth, but obey injustice, there will be anger, indignation,
oppression and anguish on every soul of man who does evil, first to the Jew, and also to the Greek.
But glory, honor, and peace go to every man who does good, to the Jew first, and also to the Greek.
For there is no partiality in God.
For all those who have sinned without the law will also perish without the law. All those who have sinned under the law will be judged by the law.
For it is not those who listen to the law who are righteous before God, but those who do it who will be justified
( for when the Gentiles who have not the law do by nature the things of the law, those, not having the law, are a law unto themselves,
in that they show the work of the law written in their hearts, their conscience in bearing witness with them, and their thoughts among themselves accusing or excusing them)
on the day when God will judge the secrets of men, according to my Good News, by Jesus Christ.
For thou bearest the name of Jew, thou rest on the law, thou glory in God,
you know his will, and you approve of good things, being instructed by the law,
and you have the assurance that you yourself are a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in darkness,
a corrector of fools, an educator of babies, having in the law the form of knowledge and truth.
Are you teaching someone else teaching not? You who preach that man should not steal, do you steal?
You who say that a man should not commit adultery, do you commit adultery? You, who have a horror of idols, do you plunder the temples?
You who glory in the law, do you dishonor God by disobeying the law?
For "the name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles for your sake," as it is written.
For circumcision is useful, if you put the law into practice; but if you transgress the law, your circumcision has become uncircumcision.
If, then, the uncircumcised person observes the ordinances of the law, will not his uncircumcision be considered as a circumcision?
Will not those who are physically uncircumcised, but who fulfill the law, judge you, who, with the letter and circumcision, are a transgressor of the law?
For he who is a Jew is not a Jew, nor an outward circumcision in the flesh;
but he who is a Jew inwardly, and circumcision is that of the heart, of the mind, not of the letter, whose praise does not come from men, but from God.
What advantage does the Jew have? Or what is the benefit of circumcision?
A lot in every respect! Because, first of all, the revelations of God have been entrusted to them.
For what would happen if some were faithless? Will their lack of faith nullify God's faithfulness?
May it never be so! Yes, that we find God true, but every man a liar. As it is written, "that ye may be justified in your words, and may prevail in judgment."
But if our iniquity praises the righteousness of God, what shall we say? Is God unjust, he who inflicts anger? I speak like men.
May it never be so! For then, how will God judge the world?
For if, through my lie, the truth of God has abounded for his glory, why am I still judged as a sinner?
Why not say (as we are calumniously told, and as some say we say): "Let us do evil, that good may come." Those who say this are rightly condemned.
So what? Are we better than them? No, by no means. For we have already warned the Jews and Greeks that they are all under sin.
As it is written, "There is no righteous; No, not a single one.
There is no one who understands. There is no one who seeks God.
They have all turned away. Together, they became unprofitable. There is no one who does good, no, not even one. »
"Their throat is an open tomb. They used their tongues to deceive. "The poison of the vipers is under their lips. »
"Their mouths are full of curses and bitterness."
"Their feet are quick to shed blood.
Destruction and misery are in their ways.
The path of peace they did not know. »
"There is no fear of God before their eyes."
Now we know that whatever the law says, it says to those who are under the law, so that every mouth may be shut and the whole world may be subject to the judgment of God.
For by the works of the law no flesh shall be justified before him, since it is by the law that the knowledge of sin comes.
But now, independently of the law, a righteousness of God has been revealed, attested by the law and the prophets,
the righteousness of God through faith in Jesus Christ, for all and on all who believe. For there is no distinction,
since all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God,
and that they are freely justified by his grace, by the redemption which is in Christ Jesus,
whom God sent as a sin offering by faith in his blood, to manifest his righteousness by the remission of previous sins, in the patience of God,
to manifest his righteousness in the present time, in order to be righteous himself and to justify those who have faith in Jesus.
Where is the boasting? It is excluded. By what law? That of the works? No, but by a law of faith.
We therefore maintain that man is justified by faith, independently of the works of the law.
Or is God the God of the Jews only? Is he not also the God of the pagans? Yes, pagans too,
since there is only one God who justifies the circumcised by faith and the uncircumcised by faith.
Do we then annul the law by faith? May this never be the case! No, we establish the law.
What then shall we say that Abraham, our ancestor, found according to the flesh?
Indeed, if Abraham was justified by works, he has reason to boast, but not before God.
For what does Scripture say? "Abraham believed in God, and it was imputed to him as righteousness."
Now, for the one who works, the reward is not considered as a grace, but as a due.
But to him who does not work, but believes in him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is imputed to righteousness.
In the same way, David pronounces the blessing on the man to whom God counts righteousness without works:
"Blessed are those whose faults are forgiven, whose sins are covered.
Blessed is the man whom the Lord will not burden with sin. »
Is this blessing pronounced only on the circumcised, or also on the uncircumcised? For we say that faith was imputed to Abraham as righteousness.
How, then, was it imputed to him? When he was circumcised, or when he was uncircumcised? Not in circumcision, but in uncircumcision.
He received the sign of circumcision, the seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had in uncircumcision, in order to be the father of all those who believe, in spite of their uncircumcision, so that righteousness may also be imputed to them.
He is the father of circumcision for those who are not only circumcision, but who also walk in the footsteps of the faith of our father Abraham, which he had in uncircumcision.
Indeed, the promise made to Abraham and his descendants to be heirs of the world was not made by law, but by the righteousness of faith.
For if those who are of the law are heirs, faith is null, and the promise is of no effect.
For the law produces anger; Where there is no law, there is no disobedience either.
Therefore it is a question of faith, so that it may be according to grace, so that the promise may be assured to all descendants, not only to those who come from the law, but also to those who come from the faith of Abraham, who is the father of us all.
As it is written, "I have made you the father of many nations." This in the presence of Him in whom he believed: God, who gives life to the dead, and who calls things that are not, as if they were.
Against hope, Abraham believed in hope, that he might be the father of many nations, as it had been said, "Thus shall thy seed be."
Without being weakened in the faith, he did not consider his own body, already worn out, (he was about a hundred years old), and the death of Sarah's womb.
But, looking to the promise of God, he did not stagger through unbelief, but he strengthened himself by faith, giving glory to God,
and being fully assured that what he had promised, he could also fulfill.
This is why it has been rightly credited to him.
However, it has not been written that this was imputed to him because of him alone,
but also because of us, to whom it will be imputed, to us who believe in him who raised Jesus our Lord from the dead,
who was betrayed because of our sins and rose again for our justification.
Being therefore justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ,
by which we also have access, by faith, to that grace in which we find ourselves. We rejoice in the hope of the glory of God.
Not only that, but we also rejoice in our sufferings, knowing that suffering produces perseverance;
and perseverance, a tried character; and the tried character, the hope;
and hope does not disappoint us, because the love of God has been poured into our hearts by the Holy Spirit who has been given to us.
For while we were still weak, Christ died at the proper time for the ungodly.
For one will hardly die for a righteous man. Yet, for a good man, someone would even dare to die.
But God shows us his love, in that, when we were still sinners, Christ died for us.
How much more, therefore, being now justified by his blood, shall we be saved by him from the wrath of God.
For if, while we were enemies, we were reconciled to God by the death of his Son, how much more, being reconciled, shall we be saved by his life.
Not only that, but we also rejoice in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, through whom we have now received reconciliation.
Thus, as sin entered the world through one man, and death through sin, death passed on to all men, because all have sinned.
For until the law sinned was in the world; but sin is not accused when there is no law.
Yet death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over those whose sin was not like Adam's disobedience, which is a foreshadowing of him who was to come.
But the free gift is not like the fault. For if, through the sin of one, the multitude died, how much more did the grace of God and the gift, by the grace of one man, Jesus Christ, abound for the many.
The gift is not as if by one who has sinned; for it was by one that judgment came to condemnation, but it was after many faults that the free gift came to justification.
For if, through the sin of one, death has reigned through one, how much more will those who receive the abundance of grace and the gift of righteousness reign in life through one, Jesus Christ.
Therefore, as by one fault all men were condemned, so by one act of justice all men were justified to life.
For as by the disobedience of one man many were made sinners, so by the obedience of one man many will be made righteous.
The law came so that the offense might be abundant; but where sin has abounded, grace has abounded more,
so that, as sin reigned through death, grace may reign through righteousness unto eternal life, through Jesus Christ our Lord.
What shall we say, then? Shall we continue to sin, that grace may abound?
May it never be so! We who have died to sin, how can we still live in it?
Don't you know that all of us who have been baptized into Jesus Christ have been baptized into His death?
Therefore we were buried with him by baptism into death, so that, as Christ rose from the dead by the glory of the Father, we too might walk in newness of life.
For if we have been united to him by the likeness of his death, we will also share in his resurrection;
knowing that our old self was crucified with him, so that the body of sin might disappear, so that we would no longer be slaves to sin.
For he who is dead is free from sin.
Now, if we have died with Christ, we believe that we will also live with him,
knowing that Christ, risen from the dead, dies no more. Death no longer dominates him!
For the death from which he died, he once died for sin; but the life he lives is for God's sake.
Therefore consider yourselves dead to sin, but alive to God in Christ Jesus our Lord.
Do not therefore let sin reign in your mortal body, that you may obey it in its lusts.
In the same way, do not present your members to sin as instruments of iniquity, but present yourselves to God as living from the dead, and your members as instruments of righteousness to God.
For sin will not have dominion over you, since you are not under the law, but under grace.
What? Are we sinning because we are not under the law but under grace? May it never be so!
Do you not know that when you present yourselves as servants and obey someone, you are the servants of him whom you obey, either from sin to death or from obedience to righteousness?
But thanks be to God that, while you were slaves to sin, you obeyed with all your heart the doctrine to which you were delivered.
Freed from sin, you have become slaves of righteousness.
I speak in human terms because of the weakness of your flesh; for, as you have presented your members as enslaved to uncleanness and wickedness over wickedness, so now present your members as enslaved to righteousness for sanctification.
For when you were slaves to sin, you were free from righteousness.
What fruit did you bear at that time in the things of which you are now ashamed? For the end of these things is death.
But now, being freed from sin and become slaves of God, you have your fruit of sanctification and the result of eternal life.
For the wages of sin is death; but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.
Or do you not know, brethren (for I am speaking to men who know the law), that the law has dominion over man as long as he lives?
For the wife who has a husband is bound by law to the husband as long as he lives; but if the husband dies, she is freed from the law of the husband.
If, therefore, during the lifetime of her husband, she attaches herself to another man, she is called an adulteress. But if the husband dies, she is freed from the law, so that she is not an adulteress, although she is united to another man.
Therefore, my brethren, you also died to the law through the body of Christ, that you might be united to another, to him who rose from the dead, that we might bring forth fruit for God.
For when we were in the flesh, the passions of sin, which were manifested by the law, acted in our members to produce fruit at death.
But now we have been relieved of the law, having died to what we were bound by, so that we serve in newness of spirit, and not in antiquity of letter.
What shall we say then? Is the law a sin? May it never be! However, I would not have known sin if it were not by the law. For I would not have known covetousness if the law had not said, "Thou shalt not covet."
But sin, finding an opportunity in the commandment, has produced in me all kinds of lusts. For without the law, sin is dead.
I was once alive without the law; but, when the commandment came, sin awoke and I died.
The commandment that was for life, I have found for death;
for sin, finding an opportunity in the commandment, has deceived me, and by it has killed me.
Therefore the law is truly holy, and the commandment holy, just, and good.
Has what is good become death for me? May it never be! But sin, in order that it might manifest itself as sin, produced death in me by that which is good, so that, by the commandment, sin might become a great sin.
For we know that the law is spiritual, but I am carnal, sold under sin.
Because I don't understand what I'm doing. For I do not practice what I wish to do; but what I hate, I do.
But if what I do not want, I do, I consent to the law that it is good.
So now it is no longer I who do it, but the sin that dwells in me.
For I know that in me, that is, in my flesh, no good dwells. For desire is present in me, but I do not find it doing what is good.
For the good that I desire I do not; but the evil that I do not desire, I practice.
And if I do what I don't want to, it's not me who does it anymore, it's the sin that dwells in me.
I therefore find the law that, while I desire to do good, evil is present.
For I delight in the law of God according to the inner person,
but I see in my members another law, which fights against the law of my spirit and makes me captive to the law of sin which is in my members.
What a wretch I am! Who will deliver me from the body of this death?
I give thanks to God through Jesus Christ, our Lord. Thus by thought I serve the law of God, but by the flesh the law of sin.
Therefore there is now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus, who do not walk after the flesh, but according to the Spirit.
For the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has set me free from the law of sin and death.
For what the law could not do, since it was weak in the flesh, God did, by sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin, he condemned sin in the flesh,
so that the ordinance of the law may be fulfilled in us who do not walk according to the flesh, but according to the Spirit.
For those who live according to the flesh cleave to the things of the flesh, but those who live according to the Spirit cleave to the things of the Spirit.
For the thought of the flesh is death, but the thought of the Spirit is life and peace;
for the mind of the flesh is hostile to God, because it is not subject to the law of God, and cannot do so.
Those who are in the flesh cannot please God.
Now you are not in the flesh, but in the Spirit, if the Spirit of God dwells in you. Now, if anyone has not the Spirit of Christ, he does not belong to him.
If Christ is in you, the body is dead because of sin, but the spirit is alive because of righteousness.
Now, if the Spirit of him who raised Jesus from the dead dwells in you, he who raised Jesus Christ from the dead will also give life to your mortal bodies through his Spirit that dwells in you.
Therefore, brethren, we are indebted not to the flesh, to live according to the flesh.
For if you live according to the flesh, you must die; but if by the Spirit you put to death the actions of the body, you will live.
For all who are led by the Spirit of God are children of God.
For you have not received a spirit of enslavement to fear, but you have received the Spirit of adoption, by which we cry out, "Abba! Father! »
The Spirit himself testifies by our spirit that we are children of God;
and if we are children, we are also heirs, heirs of God, and joint-heirs with Christ, if we suffer with him, that we may also be glorified with him.
For I consider that the sufferings of the present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory that will be revealed to us.
For creation is looking forward to the children of God being revealed.
For creation was subjected to vanity, not by its own will, but because of Him who subjected it, in hope
that creation itself will also be delivered from the bondage of corruption to enter into the freedom of the glory of the children of God.
For we know that, until now, the whole creation groans and sighs in sorrow.
Not only that, but also we, who have the firstfruits of the Spirit, groan within ourselves, waiting for the adoption, the redemption of our body.
For we have been saved in hope; but the hope that is seen is not a hope. For who hopes for what he sees?
But if we hope for what we do not see, we wait patiently for it.
In the same way, the Spirit comes to the aid of our weaknesses, because we do not know how to pray properly. But the Spirit himself intercedes for us with inexpressible groans.
He who searches hearts knows what the Spirit thinks, for he intercedes for the saints according to God.
We know that all things work together for good to those who love God, to those who are called according to his purpose.
For those whom he foreknew he also predestined to be conformed to the image of his Son, that he might be the firstborn among many brethren.
Those whom he predestined he also called. Those whom he called he also justified. Those whom he justified he also glorified.
What shall we say of these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?
He who did not spare his own Son, but gave him up for us all, how could he not also freely give us all things with him?
Who could bring an accusation against God's chosen people? It is God who justifies.
Who is the one who condemns? It is Christ who died, or rather who rose from the dead, who is at the right hand of God, and who intercedes for us.
Who will separate us from the love of Christ? Oppression, or anguish, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or the sword?
As it is written, "For your good, we are killed all day long. We were considered sheep for slaughter. »
No, in all these things we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us.
For I am persuaded that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor things present, nor things to come, nor powers,
neither haughtiness, nor depth, nor any other creature will be able to separate us from the love of God which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.
I speak the truth in Christ. I do not lie, my conscience testifying to me by the Holy Spirit
that I have in my heart a great sadness and an incessant pain.
For I myself would like to be cursed by Christ for the sake of my brethren, my parents according to the flesh
who are Israelites; to whom belong the adoption, the glory, the covenants, the giving of the law, the service, and the promises;
whose fathers are, and from whom came Christ according to the flesh, who is above all, God, blessed eternally. Amen.
But it is not as if the word of God has remained without effect. For it is not all Israel that is of Israel.
Nor are they all children, since they are the descendants of Abraham. But "your descendants will be numbered like Isaac's."
That is, it is not the children of the flesh who are children of God, but the children of the promise who are counted as heirs.
For this is the word of the promise: "In the appointed time I will come, and Sarah shall have a son."
Not only that, but Rebekah also conceived by one, by our father Isaac.
For not having yet been born, and having done nothing good or evil, that the purpose of God may subsist according to the election, not of works, but of him who calls,
As it is written, "I loved Jacob, but I hated Esau."
What shall we say, then? Is there injustice before God? May there never be any!
For he said to Moses, "I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I will have compassion."
Therefore it is not to him who wills, nor to him who runs, but to God who shows mercy.
For the Scripture says to Pharaoh, "For this purpose I have raised you up, that I might show my power in you, and proclaim my name in all the earth."
So he shows mercy to whom he wills, and hardens whom he wills.
You will then say to me: "Why does he still find fault? For who resists his will? »
But truly, O man, who are you to answer against God? Will the thing formed ask the one who formed it, "Why have you made me so?"
Or does not the potter have a right to the clay, from the same mass, to make one part a vessel for honor, and another for dishonor?
And if God, desiring to show his wrath and make known his power, has borne with great patience vessels of wrath prepared for destruction,
and that he wished to make known the riches of his glory on vessels of mercy, which he prepared beforehand for glory -
we, whom he also called, not only Jews, but also Gentiles?
As he also says in Hosea, "I will call them 'my people,' they who were not my people; and his "beloved", who was not beloved. »
"In the place where it was said to them, 'You are not my people.' they will be called "children of the living God". »
Isaiah cries out about Israel, "If the number of the children of Israel be like the sand of the sea, the remnant will be saved;
for he will finish the work and cut it in righteousness, because the Lord will do a short work on the earth. »
As Isaiah once said, "Unless the Lord of hosts had left us a seed, we would have become like Sodom, and would have been made like Gomorrah."
What shall we say, then? That the pagans, who did not seek righteousness, have attained to righteousness, to the righteousness of faith;
but that Israel, which sought a law of justice, did not arrive at the law of justice.
What for? Because they did not seek it by faith, but, so to speak, by the works of the law. They stumbled over the stumbling block,
as it is written, "Behold, I lay in Zion a stumbling block and a rock of scandal; and none of those who believe in him will be disappointed. »
Brethren, the desire of my heart and the prayer I address to God concern Israel, that it may be saved.
For I testify concerning them that they have a zeal for God, but not according to knowledge.
For, ignorant of the righteousness of God, and seeking to establish their own righteousness, they did not submit to the righteousness of God.
For Christ is the fulfillment of the law for the righteousness of every believer.
For Moses writes of the righteousness of the law: "He who does them will live by them."
But the righteousness of faith says this: "Do not say in your heart, 'Who will ascend to heaven?' (i.e., to bring down Christ);
or, "Who will descend into the abyss? (that is, to raise Christ from the dead.)
But what does he say? "The word is near you, in your mouth and in your heart", that is, the word of faith that we preach:
that if you confess with your mouth that Jesus is Lord, and if you believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.
For it is with the heart that one believes, which brings about righteousness, and with the mouth that one confesses, which brings salvation.
For the Scripture says, "He that believeth in him shall not be disappointed."
For there is no distinction between the Jew and the Greek, for the same Lord is the Lord of all, and he is rich for all who call on him.
Indeed, "Whoever calls on the name of the Lord will be saved."
How, then, shall they call upon Him in whom they have not believed? How will they believe in Him whom they have not heard? How will they hear without a preacher?
And how will they preach without being sent? As it is written: "How beautiful are the feet of those who preach the Good News of peace, which brings happy news of good things!"
But they didn't all listen to the happy news. For Isaiah said, "Lord, who believed our report?"
Thus, faith comes from hearing, and hearing from the word of God.
But, I say, have they not heard? Yes, most certainly, "Their sound has spread throughout the earth, their words to the ends of the world."
But I ask: Didn't Israel know this? First Moses said, "I will provoke you to jealousy with that which is not a nation. I will make you angry with a nation devoid of intelligence. »
Isaiah is very bold and says, "I was found by those who had not sought me. I was revealed to those who had not asked me. »
But about Israel, he says, "All day long I stretched out my hands to a disobedient and rebellious people."
So I ask: Has God rejected his people? May it never be so! For I too am an Israelite, a descendant of Abraham, of the tribe of Benjamin.
God did not reject his people, whom he knew in advance. Do you not know what the Scripture says about Elijah? How he pleads with God against Israel:
"Lord, they have killed your prophets. They have demolished your altars. I was left alone, and they want my life. »
But how does God respond to him? "I have reserved for myself seven thousand men who have not bowed the knee to Baal."
In the same way, at this time too, there is a remnant according to the election of grace.
And if it is by grace, it is no longer by works; otherwise grace is no longer grace. But if it is through works, it is no longer grace, otherwise the work is no longer the work.
What? What Israel seeks, it has not obtained; but the elected have obtained it, and the others have become hardened.
As it is written, "God has given them a spirit of amazement, eyes not to see, and ears not to hear, until this day."
David said, "Let their table become a snare, a trap, a stumbling block, and a punishment for them.
Let their eyes be darkened, so that they do not see. Always keep their backs bent. »
So I ask: Did they stumble to fall? May it never be so! But it was by their fall that salvation came to the pagans, to stir them up to jealousy.
Now, if their fall is the wealth of the world, and their loss the wealth of the heathen, how much more their fullness!
For it is to you who are pagans that I speak. Since, therefore, I am an apostle to the Gentiles, I glorify my ministry,
if, by any means, I can provoke the jealousy of those who are my flesh, and save some of them.
For if their rejection is the reconciliation of the world, what would their acceptance be, if not life from the dead?
If the first fruit is holy, so is the mass. If the root is holy, so are the branches.
But if some of the branches have been cut off, and if you, who are a wild olive tree, have been grafted into the midst of them, and you share with them in the root and richness of the olive tree,
do not glory in the branches. But if you boast, remember that it is not you who sustain the root, but that it is the root that sustains you.
Then you will say, "The branches have been plucked up, that I may be grafted."
It's true; it is by their unbelief that they have been cut off, and you are standing by your faith. Do not be proud, but fear;
for if God has not spared the natural branches, he will not spare you either.
See, then, the goodness and severity of God. With regard to those who have fallen, severity; but with regard to you, goodness, if you persist in its goodness; if not, you too will be cut off.
They too, if they do not persist in their unbelief, will be grafted, for God is able to graft them again.
For if you have been cut off from the wild olive tree, which is by nature a wild olive tree, and grafted, contrary to nature, onto a good olive tree, how much more will these, which are the natural branches, be grafted onto their own olive tree?
For I do not want you, brethren, to be ignorant of this mystery, so that you may not go astray in your own ideas: that a partial hardening has come upon Israel, until the fullness of the Gentiles has entered.
and thus may all Israel be saved. As it is written, "Out of Zion shall come the deliverer, and he shall turn away the ungodliness of Jacob.
This is my covenant with them, when I take away their sins. »
As for the Good News, they are enemies because of you. But as for the election, they are loved because of the fathers.
For the gifts and the call of God are irrevocable.
For as you once disobeyed God, but now have obtained mercy through your disobedience,
so these also have now disobeyed, so that, by the mercy that has been shown you, they may also obtain mercy.
For God has bound all men to disobedience, that he might show mercy to all.
Oh! the depth of the riches of wisdom and knowledge of God! How unfathomable are his judgments, how his paths cannot be traced!
"For who has known the mind of the Lord? Or who was his advisor? »
"Or who gave him first, and that it will be returned to him again?"
For it is from him, through him, and for him that all things come. To him be the glory for ever and ever! Amen.
I exhort you, therefore, brethren, by the mercy of God, to offer your body as a living, holy, God-pleasing sacrifice, which is your spiritual service.
Do not conform yourselves to this world, but be transformed by the renewing of your mind, so that you may discern what is the will of God, what is good, acceptable and perfect.
For I say, by the grace that has been given to me, to all who are among you, not to have too high an opinion of yourselves, but to think reasonably, according as God has given to each one a measure of faith.
For as we have many members in one body, and all the members do not have the same function,
so that we, who are many, are one body in Christ, and we are all members of one another,
having different gifts according to the grace that has been granted to us: If we prophesy, let us prophesy according to the measure of our faith;
if we serve, let us give ourselves to service; if we teach, let us give ourselves to teaching;
if we exhort, let us give ourselves to exhortation; if we give, let us do so generously; if we govern, let us do it with diligence; If we show mercy, let us do it with joy.
May love be without hypocrisy. Abhor what is evil. Stick to what's good.
In the love of your brethren, have tender affection for one another; in honor, prefer one to the other,
do not delay in applying yourselves, with a fervent spirit, to serve the Lord,
rejoice in hope, endure tribulation, persevere in prayer,
contribute to the needs of the saints, and give hospitality.
Bless those who persecute you; bless, and curse not.
Rejoice with those who rejoice. Weep with those who weep.
Have the same feelings towards each other. Do not pretend to exalt yourselves, but associate yourselves with the humble. Don't be wise in your own ideas.
Do not repay evil for evil to anyone. Respect what is honorable in the eyes of all men.
If it is possible, as far as it depends on you, be at peace with all men.
Do not seek revenge yourselves, beloved, but let the wrath of God work. For it is written, "Vengeance is mine, and retribution is mine," says the Lord.
Wherefore, "If thy enemy is hungry, give him something to eat. If he is thirsty, give him something to drink; for by doing this, you will gather burning coals on his head. »
Do not allow yourselves to be overcome by evil, but overcome evil by good.
Let every soul be subject to the higher authorities, for there is no authority but from God, and those who exist are ordained by God.
Therefore he who resists authority resists the ordinance of God; and those who resist will receive judgment for themselves.
For rulers are not a terror for good works, but for evil ones. Do you want not to be afraid of authority? Do what is good, and you will have the praise of authority,
for she is to you a servant of God for good. But if you do evil, fear him, for he does not carry the sword in vain, for he is a servant of God, avenger of the wrath of him who does evil.
You must therefore be submissive, not only because of anger, but also for the sake of conscience.
That is why you also pay taxes, for they are servants of God who continually carry out this task.
Render to each one what he owes: if you owe the tax, pay the tax; if it is the customs, then the customs; if it is respect, then respect; If it is honor, then honor.
To owe nothing to anyone, except to love one another; for he who loves his neighbor has fulfilled the law.
Indeed, the commandments: "You shall not commit adultery," "You shall not kill," "You shall not steal," "You shall not covet," and all the other commandments that exist, all boil down to this word: "You shall love your neighbor as yourself."
Love does not hurt one's neighbor. Love is therefore the fulfillment of the law.
Do this, knowing the time, for it is already time for you to awaken from sleep, for salvation is now nearer to us than when we believed.
The night is past, and the day is at hand. Let us therefore put off the works of darkness, and put on the weapons of light.
Let us walk aright, as in the daylight, without giving ourselves up to rejoicing and drunkenness, without giving ourselves up to debauchery and lust, without giving ourselves up to quarrels and jealousies.
But put on the Lord Jesus Christ, and do not make provision for the flesh, for its lusts.
Now accept the one who is weak in the faith, but not for disputes of opinions.
A man has faith to eat everything, but he who is weak eats only vegetables.
Let not the one who eats despise the one who does not eat. Let not the one who eats judge the one who eats, for God has accepted him.
Who are you to judge the servant of another? It is up to one's own master to stand or fall. Yes, he will stand, for God has the power to make him stand.
A man believes that a day is more important. Another believes that all days are equal. Let everyone be fully reassured in his mind.
He who keeps the day keeps it for the Lord, and he who does not keep the day does not keep it for the Lord. He who eats, eats for the Lord, for he gives thanks to God. He who does not eat, he does not eat to the Lord, and he gives thanks to God.
For none of us lives for himself, and no one dies for himself.
For if we live, we live for the Lord. Or if we die, we die for the Lord. So whether we live or die, we belong to the Lord.
For this is why Christ died, rose again, and lived again, to be Lord of the dead and the living.
But you, why do you judge your brother? Or you, why do you despise your brother? For we will all come before the judgment seat of Christ.
For it is written, 'I live,' says the Lord, 'every knee shall bow before me.' Every tongue will confess to God.'
Therefore, each of us will give an account to God of what he does.
Let us therefore no longer judge one another, but rather judge that no one puts a stumbling block in his brother's way, or an occasion for a fall.
I know and am persuaded in the Lord Jesus that nothing is unclean in itself, except that for him who considers something unclean, for him it is unclean.
Now, if your brother is afflicted because of food, you no longer walk in love. Do not destroy with your food the one for whom Christ died.
Let not your property be slandered,
for the kingdom of God is not eating and drinking, but righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit.
For he who serves Christ in these things is acceptable to God and approved by men.
So then, let us seek what promotes peace, what edifies one another.
Don't reverse God's work for food. Everything is pure, indeed, but it is bad for man to create a stumbling block by eating.
It is good not to eat meat, not to drink wine, and not to do anything that may cause one's brother to stumble, offend, or weaken.
Do you have faith? Have it for yourselves before God. Happy is he who does not judge himself in what he approves.
But he who doubts is condemned if he eats, because it is not faith; and everything that is not of faith is sin.
Now, we who are strong, we must put up with the weaknesses of the weak, and not please ourselves.
Let each one of us please his neighbor for what is good, in order to edify him.
For even Christ did not please himself. But, as it is written, "The outrages of those who revile you have fallen upon me."
For all that was written before was written for our instruction, that by perseverance and by the encouragement of the Scriptures, we might have hope.
Now may the God of perseverance and encouragement grant you to have the same feelings toward one another according to Jesus Christ,
so that, with one accord, you may glorify with one mouth the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
Accept one another, therefore, as Christ accepted you, for the glory of God.
Now I say that Christ was made a servant of the circumcised for the truth of God, in order to confirm the promises made to the fathers,
and that the Gentiles might glorify God for His mercy. As it is written, "Therefore I will praise you among the Gentiles . . . and sing to your name. »
He also said, "Rejoice, O Gentiles, with his people."
Again, "Praise the Lord, all you pagans! Let all peoples praise him. »
Again, Isaiah says, "There shall be the root of Jesse, he who arises to reign over the Gentiles; in him the pagans will hope."
Now may the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in faith, so that you may abound in hope by the power of the Holy Spirit.
I myself am persuaded about you, my brethren, that you yourselves are full of goodness, full of all knowledge, and also capable of exhorting others.
But I am writing to you with all the more boldness, partly to remind you, because of the grace that has been granted to me by God,
that I must be a servant of Jesus Christ to the Gentiles, serving as a priest of the Good News of God, so that the offering of the Gentiles may be made pleasing, sanctified by the Holy Spirit.
It is therefore in Christ Jesus that I glory in the things of God.
For I dare not speak of any other things than those which Christ has done through me for the obedience of the Gentiles, in word and deed,
by the power of signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God, so that, from Jerusalem and around to Illyricum, I have fully preached the Good News of Christ;
yes, by striving to proclaim the Good News, not where Christ was already appointed, so as not to build on the foundation of others.
But, as it is written, "They shall see, they to whom no news of him has come. Those who have not heard will understand. »
That is why I have often been prevented from going to you,
but now that I have no place in these regions, and that I have long desired to come to you,
every time I go to Spain, I will go to you. For I hope to see you on the way and to be helped by you, if first I can enjoy your company a little.
But now, I say to you, I am going to Jerusalem, in the service of the saints.
For Macedonia and Achaia have been willing to make a contribution for the poor among the saints who are in Jerusalem.
Yes, it is their good pleasure, and they are indebted to it. For if the pagans have been made partakers of their spiritual goods, they also owe it to them to serve them in material goods.
So when I have accomplished this, and have sealed this fruit to them, I will pass through your house on my way to Spain.
I know that when I come to you, I will arrive in the fullness of the blessing of the Good News of Christ.
Now I beseech you, brethren, by our Lord Jesus Christ and by the love of the Spirit, to unite yourselves with me in the prayers which you address to God for me,
that I may be delivered from the rebels of Judea, and that the service I have to do in Jerusalem may be pleasing to the saints,
that I may come to you in joy, according to the will of God, and find rest with you.
May the God of peace be with you all. Amen.
I commend to you Phoebe, our sister, who is a servant of the congregation at Cenchrea,
so that you may receive her into the Lord in a manner worthy of the saints, and help her in all that she may ask of you, for she also has been useful to many, and to me.
Greet Prisca and Aquila, my fellow workers in Christ Jesus,
who have risked their lives for mine, and to whom I give thanks, not only to myself, but also to all the assemblies of the Gentiles.
Greet the congregation that is in their house. Greet Epaenetus, my beloved, who is the first fruit of Achaia for Christ.
Greet Mary, who has worked a lot for us.
Greet Andronicus and Junia, my parents and companions in captivity, who are distinguished among the apostles, and who were also in Christ before me.
Greet Amplias, my beloved in the Lord.
Greet Urbanus, our fellow laborer in Christ, and Stachys, my beloved.
Greet Apelles, who was approved in Christ. Greet those who are of the house of Aristobulus.
Greet Herodion, my kinsman. Greet the members of Narcissus' family, who are in the Lord.
Greet Tryphaena and Tryphosa, who work in the Lord. Greet Persis, the beloved, who has worked much in the Lord.
Greet Rufus, the chosen one in the Lord, and his mother and mine.
Greet Asyncritus, Phlegon, Hermes, Patrobas, Hermas, and the brethren who are with them.
Greet Philologus and Julia, Nereus and his sister, and Olympas, and all the saints who are with them.
Greet one another with a holy kiss. The assemblies of Christ greet you.
Now, I beseech you, brethren, beware of those who cause divisions and occasions of sin, contrary to the doctrine which you have learned, and turn away from them.
For these people do not serve our Lord Jesus Christ, but their own womb, and they deceive the hearts of the innocent with flattering speeches.
For your obedience has been known to all. I am therefore delighted about you. But I want you to be wise in what is good, but innocent in what is bad.
And the God of peace will quickly crush Satan under your feet. The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you.
Timothy, my co-worker, greets you, as well as Lucius, Jason, and Sosipater, my relatives.
I, Tertius, who write the letter, greet you in the Lord.
Gaius, my guest and the guest of the whole assembly, greets you. Erastus, the treasurer of the city, greets you, as well as Quartus, the brother.
May the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all! Amen.
Paul, called to be an apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, and our brother Sosthenes,
to the assembly of God which is in Corinth, to those who are sanctified in Christ Jesus, called saints, with all those who call on the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, in every place, among them and among us:
Grace and peace be to you, from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
I always give thanks to my God for you, for the grace of God that has been given to you in Christ Jesus,
that you may be enriched in all things by him, in all word and in all knowledge,
as the testimony of Christ has been confirmed in you,
that you may not be late in any gift, waiting for the revelation of our Lord Jesus Christ,
who will also confirm you to the end, blameless on the day of our Lord Jesus Christ.
God is faithful, by whom you have been called to the communion of his Son, Jesus Christ our Lord.
Now I beseech you, brethren, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that you may all speak of the same thing, and that there may be no divisions among you, but that you may be perfected together in the same spirit and in the same judgment.
For it has been reported to me concerning you, my brethren, by those of the house of Chloe, that there are disputes among you.
Now, I mean that each of you says: "I am Paul", "I am Apollos", "I am Cephas", and "I am the Christ".
Is Christ divided? Was Paul crucified for you? Or have you been baptized in Paul's name?
I thank God that I have not baptized any of you, except Crispus and Gaius,
so that no one may say that I have baptized you in my own name.
(I also baptized the house of Stephanas; apart from them, I don't know if I baptized others).
For it is not to baptize that Christ has sent me, but to preach the Good News, without wisdom of words, so that the cross of Christ may not be annulled.
For the word of the cross is foolishness to those who die, but to us who are saved, it is a power of God.
For it is written, "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise. I will destroy the discernment of those who know how to discern. »
Where is the wise man? Where is the scribe? Where is the orator of this century? Has not God made the wisdom of this world foolish?
For since, in the wisdom of God, the world has not known God, God has willed, by the folly of preaching, to save those who believe.
For the Jews ask for signs, the Greeks seek wisdom,
but we preach Christ crucified, a stumbling block for the Jews and folly for the Greeks,
but to those who are called, Jews and Greeks, Christ is the power of God and the wisdom of God,
for the folly of God is wiser than men, and the weakness of God is stronger than men.
For you see your calling, brethren, that there are not many wise according to the flesh, nor many powerful, nor many noble;
but God has chosen the foolish things of the world to confound the wise. God has chosen the weak things of the world, to cover the strong things with shame.
God chose the humble things of the world, the despised things, the things that do not exist, in order to bring to naught the things that exist,
so that no flesh may glory before God.
It is because of him that you are in Christ Jesus, who was made for us the wisdom of God, righteousness, sanctification and redemption,
so that, as it is written, "He that boasteth boasteth boasteth in the Lord."
When I came to you, brethren, I did not come with the power of word or wisdom, proclaiming to you the testimony of God.
For I have resolved to know nothing among you except Jesus Christ and Jesus Christ crucified.
I have been with you in weakness, in fear, and in great trembling.
My discourse and preaching were not persuasive words of human wisdom, but a demonstration of the Spirit and power,
so that your faith may not rest on the wisdom of men, but on the power of God.
We, however, speak of wisdom, among those who have reached maturity, but of a wisdom that is not that of this world nor that of the rulers of this world, who are about to disappear.
But we speak of the wisdom of God in a mystery, of the hidden wisdom, which God prepared before the worlds for our glory,
and which none of the rulers of this world has known. For if they had known it, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory.
But, as it is written, "Things which eye hath not seen, and ear hath not heard, which hath not entered into the heart of man, which God hath prepared for them that love him."
But to us, God has revealed them by the Spirit. For the Spirit searches all things, even the deep things of God.
For who among men knows the things of a man, but the spirit of man that is in him? In the same way, no one knows the things of God, except the Spirit of God.
Now we have not received the spirit of the world, but the Spirit that comes from God, that we may know the things that have been freely given to us by God.
We also speak of these things, not with the words that the wisdom of men teaches, but with those that the Holy Spirit teaches, comparing spiritual things with spiritual things.
Now the natural man does not receive the things of the Spirit of God, for they are foolishness to him; and he cannot know them, because they are spiritually discerned.
