But he who is spiritual discerns all things, and he must not be judged by anyone.
"For who has known the mind of the Lord to instruct him?" But we have the mind of Christ.
Brethren, I have not been able to speak to you as to spiritual people, but as to carnal people, as children in Christ.
I fed you with milk, not with solid food, for you were not yet ready. And even now, you are not ready,
for you are still carnal. For if there is jealousy, strife, and division among you, are you not carnal, and walk in the ways of men?
For if one says, "I am Paul," and the other, "I am Apollos," are you not carnal?
Who, then, is Apollos, and who is Paul, if not servants through whom you believed, and every one according to what the Lord has given him?
I crashed. Apollos watered. But it is God who has given the increase.
Therefore neither he who plants is nothing, nor he who waters, but God who makes it grow.
Now the one who plants and the one who waters are the same, but each will receive his own reward according to his own work.
For we are God's fellow workers. You are God's agriculture, God's construction.
According to the grace of God which has been given to me, I have laid, as a wise master, a foundation, and another built upon it. But let everyone be careful how he builds on it.
For no one can lay any other foundation than that which has been laid, that is, Jesus Christ.
But if anyone builds on the foundation with gold, silver, precious stones, wood, hay, or straw,
The work of each one will be unveiled. For the Day will make him known, because he reveals himself in fire; and the fire itself will test what is the work of each one.
If any one remains of what he has built on it, he will receive a reward.
If anyone's work is burned, he will suffer a loss, but he will be saved himself, but as by fire.
Do you not know that you are the temple of God and that the Spirit of God dwells in you?
If anyone destroys the temple of God, God will destroy him, for the temple of God is holy, which you are.
Let no one deceive himself. If anyone thinks he is wise among you in this world, let him go mad to become wise.
For the wisdom of this world is foolishness before God. For it is written, "He has caught the wise in their cunning."
And again: "The Lord knows the reasonings of the wise: they are worthless."
Let no one therefore glory in men. For all things are yours,
either Paul, or Apollos, or Cephas, or the world, or life, or death, or things present, or things to come. Everything is yours,
and you are Christ's, and Christ is God's.
Let man, therefore, consider us as the servants of Christ and the stewards of the mysteries of God.
Here, moreover, the intendants are required to be found faithful.
But for me, it is very little that I should be judged by you, or by a human tribunal. Yes, I don't even judge myself.
For I know nothing against myself. And it is not I who am justified by this, but the one who judges me is the Lord.
Therefore judge nothing before the time comes, until the Lord comes, who will bring to light what is hidden in darkness, and who will reveal the purposes of hearts. Then each one will receive his praise from God.
Now, brethren, I have transferred these things figuratively to myself and to Apollos, for your sake, so that you may learn in us not to think beyond what is written, and that neither of you may be inflamed against another.
Because who sets you apart? And what have you that you have not received? But if you have received it, why do you boast as if you had not received it?
You are already satisfied. You've already become rich. You have come to reign without us. Yes, and I would that you would reign, that we also might reign with you!
For I think that God showed us, the apostles, in the last place, as condemned to death. For we are made a spectacle to the world, to angels and to men.
We are fools for Christ's sake, but you are wise in Christ. We are weak, but you are strong. You have glory, but we have dishonor.
At this moment we are hungry, we are thirsty, we are naked, we are beaten, and we have no safe abode.
We toil, we work with our own hands. When we are cursed, we bless. We are persecuted, but we endure.
We are defamed, we beg. We are made like the filth of the world, the dirt wiped off by all, until now.
I do not write these things to shame you, but to warn you as my beloved children.
For if you have ten thousand preceptors in Christ, you have not many fathers. For in Christ Jesus I have become your father through the Good News.
I beg you, therefore, to imitate me.
Therefore I have sent you Timothy, my beloved and faithful child in the Lord, who will remind you of my ways which are in Christ, as I teach everywhere in all assemblies.
Now, some people puff themselves up with pride, as if I did not come to you.
But I will come to you soon, if the Lord wills. And I will know, not the word of those who puff themselves up, but the power.
For the Kingdom of God is not in words, but in power.
What do you want? Shall I come to you with a rod, or with love and in a spirit of gentleness?
For it is reported that there is among you a sexual immorality, and a sexual immorality such as is not even called among the pagans, that one has his father's wife.
You are arrogant, and you have not rather mourned, so that the one who has committed this deed may be removed from among you.
For I, absent in body but present in mind, have already judged, as if I were present, the one who committed this action.
In the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, when you are reunited with my spirit by the power of our Lord Jesus Christ,
you will deliver such a person to Satan for the destruction of the flesh, so that the spirit may be saved in the day of the Lord Jesus.
Your boasting is not good. Don't you know that a little yeast makes the whole mass rise?
Get rid of the old leaven, so that you may be a new dough, as you are unleavened. Indeed, Christ, our Passover, was sacrificed in our place.
Let us therefore celebrate the feast, not with old leaven, nor with a leaven of malice and wickedness, but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.
I wrote to you in my letter not to associate with sexual sinners;
but not at all with the sexual sinners of this world, nor with the greedy and extortionists, nor with the idolaters, for then you would have to leave the world.
Now I have written to you not to associate with one who is called a brother, and who is a sexual sinner, or a greedy, or an idolater, or a slanderer, or a drunkard, or an extortionist. Don't even eat with such a person.
Indeed, what do I have to do with judging also those who are outside? Do you not judge those who are within?
But it is God who judges those outside. "Eliminate the wicked from among yourselves."
Will any of you, having a case against your neighbor, go to justice before the unjust, and not before the saints?
Do you not know that the saints will judge the world? And if it is you who judge the world, are you unworthy to judge the smallest things?
Do you not know that we will judge the angels? Much more do things that concern this life?
If, then, you have to judge things that pertain to this life, do you put them to judge those who are of no importance in the assembly?
I say this to shame you. Is there not one wise man among you who is able to decide between his brothers?
But the brother goes to court with the brother, and that before infidels!
It is therefore already quite a defect on your part to bring lawsuits against one another. Why not be wronged instead? Why not prefer the scam?
No, but it is you yourselves who commit injustice and fraud, and that against your brethren.
Do you not know that the unrighteous will not inherit the kingdom of God? Make no mistake. Neither fornicators, nor idolaters, nor adulterers, nor prostitutes, nor homosexuals,
neither thieves, nor greedy, nor drunkards, nor slanderers, nor extortionists, will inherit the Kingdom of God.
Some of you were such, but they were washed. You have been sanctified. You have been justified in the name of the Lord Jesus, and by the Spirit of our God.
"Everything is allowed to me", but not everything is allowed to me. "Everything is permitted to me, but I will not submit to anything.
"Food for the belly, and the belly for food," but God will bring them and them to naught. But the body is not for sexual immorality, but for the Lord, and the Lord for the body.
Now God has raised the Lord from the dead, and he will also raise us up by his power.
Do you not know that your bodies are members of Christ? Shall I then take the members of Christ and make them the members of a harlot? May it never be so!
Or do you not know that he who unites himself with a prostitute forms but one body? For "both," he says, "will become one flesh."
But he who is united to the Lord is one spirit.
Flee from sexual immorality! "Every sin committed by a man is external to the body, but he who commits sexual immorality sins against his own body.
Do you not know that your body is the temple of the Holy Spirit which is in you, and which you have received from God? You do not belong to yourselves,
because you have been acquired at a high price. Glorify God therefore in your body and in your spirit, which belong to God.
As for the things you have written to me about, it is good that a man does not touch a woman.
But, because of sexual immoralities, let every man have his own wife, and let every woman have her own husband.
Let the husband give to his wife the affection due to her, and likewise the wife to her husband.
The wife does not have authority over her own body, but the husband has authority over it. Similarly, the husband does not have authority over his own body, but the wife has authority over it.
Do not deprive each other, unless it is by common consent for a time, in order to give yourselves up to fasting and prayer, and to be together, so that Satan does not tempt you because of your lack of self-control.
But I say this by concession, not by command.
Yet I would like all men to be like me. But every man has his own gift of God, one of this kind, the other of this kind.
But I tell singles and widows that it is good for them to stay like me.
But if they don't have self-control, let them get married. Because it is better to get married than to burn out of passion.
But to the bride and groom I command, not I, but the Lord, that the wife not leave her husband
(but if she leaves him, let her remain unmarried, or be reconciled with her husband), and the husband does not leave his wife.
But as for the others, I say, and not the Lord, that if a brother has an unbelieving wife, and she is content to live with him, let him not leave her.
The woman who has a non-believing husband, and who is happy to live with her, let her not leave her husband.
For the unbelieving husband is sanctified in the wife, and the unbelieving wife is sanctified in the husband. Otherwise, your children would be unclean, but now they are holy.
However, if the non-believer leaves, let there be separation. In such a case, the brother or sister is not enslaved, but God has called us to peace.
For how do you know, wife, whether you will save your husband? Or how do you know, husband, whether you will save your wife?
Only, as the Lord has distributed to each one, as God has called each one, let him walk thus. This is what I command in all assemblies.
Has anyone been called without having been circumcised? Let him not become uncircumcised. Was anyone called while uncircumcised? Let him not be circumcised.
Circumcision is nothing, and uncircumcision is nothing, but what matters is to keep the commandments of God.
May each one remain in the vocation to which he has been called.
Have you been called to be a servant? Don't let it bother you, but if you have the opportunity to free yourself, take it.
For he who has been called in the Lord as a slave is the free man of the Lord. In the same way, he who has been called free is the servant of Christ.
You have been bought at a high price. Do not become slaves of men.
Brethren, let every man, in whatever condition he may have been called, remain in this condition with God.
Now, as far as virgins are concerned, I have no commandment from the Lord, but I give my judgment as one who has obtained the Lord's mercy to be trustworthy.
That is why I think that because of the distress that befalls us, it is good for a man to remain as he is.
Are you related to a woman? Do not try to free yourself from it. Are you free from a woman? Don't try to get married.
But if you get married, you have not sinned. If a virgin marries, she has not sinned. Yet such people will be oppressed in the flesh, and I will spare you.
But I tell you, brothers: time is pressing. From now on, those who have wives will be as if they had none;
and those who weep, as if they were not weeping; and those who rejoice, as if they did not rejoice; and those who buy, as if they did not possess;
and those who use the world, as if they did not make full use of it. For the mode of this world passes.
But I want you to be free from any worries. He who is not married is anxious about the things of the Lord, how he can please the Lord;
but he who is married is anxious about the things of the world, how he can please his wife.
There is also a difference between a wife and a virgin. The unmarried woman occupies herself with the things of the Lord, in order to be holy in body and mind. But she who is married is interested in the things of the world, to please her husband.
I say this for your sake, not to ensnare you, but for what is proper, so that you may attend to the Lord without distraction.
But if anyone thinks that he is behaving inappropriately towards his virgin, if she is past the prime of life, and if the need arises, let him do what he wills. He does not sin. Let them get married.
But he who remains firm in his heart, without urgency, but who is master of his own will, and who has decided in his heart to keep his own virgin, does well.
Therefore he who gives his own virgin in marriage does well, and he who does not give her in marriage does better.
The wife is bound by the law as long as her husband lives; but if the husband is dead, she is free to marry whomever she wants, only in the Lord.
But she is happier if she stays as she is, according to my judgment, and I think I also have the Spirit of God.
Now, as for the things sacrificed to idols: we know that we all have knowledge. Knowledge swells, but love edifies.
But if anyone thinks he knows something, he does not yet know what he needs to know.
But he who loves God is known to him.
Thus, as to eating meat sacrificed to idols, we know that there is no idol in the world, and that there is no other God but one.
For if there are things which are called "gods," either in heaven or on earth, as there are many "gods" and many "lords,"
for us there is but one God, the Father, from whom all things come, and we for him, and one Lord, Jesus Christ, through whom all things come, and we live through him.
However, this knowledge is not in all men. But some, having hitherto been conscious of an idol, eat as of a thing sacrificed to an idol, and their conscience, being weak, is defiled.
But food will not recommend us to God. For neither if we do not eat, we are worse, nor if we eat, we are better.
But take care that this freedom of yours does not become a stumbling block for the weak.
For if a man sees you, who have knowledge, sitting in the temple of an idol, will not his conscience, if it be weak, be emboldened to eat things sacrificed to idols?
And it is by your knowledge that the weak, the brother for whom Christ died, perishes.
Thus, by sinning against the brethren, and by wounding their consciences when it is weak, you sin against Christ.
Therefore, if food causes my brother to stumble, I will never eat meat again, so that I may not trip my brother.
Am I not free? Am I not an apostle? Have I not seen Jesus Christ, our Lord? Are you not my work in the Lord?
If I am not an apostle for others, I am at least an apostle for you, for you are the seal of my apostolate in the Lord.
Here is my defense before those who examine me:
Don't we have the right to eat and drink?
Have we not the right to take with us a believing woman, like the other apostles, the Lord's brethren, and Cephas?
Or do we not have the right, Barnabas and I, not to work?
What soldier ever served at his own expense? Who plants a vineyard, and does not eat of its fruit? Or who feeds a flock, and does not drink the milk of the flock?
Do I say these things in the manner of men? Or does the law not say the same thing?
For it is written in the law of Moses, "Thou shalt not muzzle the ox while it treads the grain." Is it for the oxen that God is anxious,
Or is it for us that he says it? Yes, it was written for us, for he who ploughs must plough with hope, and he who threshes with hope must share in his hope.
If we have sown spiritual things for you, is it a great thing if we reap your carnal things?
If others have a share in this right over you, have we not even more? Nevertheless, we have not used this right, but we endure everything, so as not to hinder the Good News of Christ.
Do you not know that those who serve around sacred things eat things of the temple, and that those who serve the altar have their share with the altar?
In the same way, the Lord has willed that those who proclaim the Good News live by this Good News.
But I have not used any of these things, and I do not write these things to make it so in my case; for I would rather die than see someone cancel my boast.
For if I preach the Good News, I have no reason to boast, for the necessity is imposed on me; but woe to me if I do not preach the Good News.
For if I do this of my own free will, I have a reward. But if it is not of my own volition, it is a charge entrusted to me.
What is my reward? That when I preach the Good News, I may present the Good News of Christ at no cost, so that I do not abuse my authority in the Good News.
For, although I am free with regard to all, I have made myself a slave to all, in order to gain the greatest number.
As for the Jews, I became a Jew, in order to win over the Jews; for the slaves of the law, as slaves of the law, in order to gain the slaves of the law;
for the lawless, as without law (not being lawless to God, but under law to Christ), in order to win the lawless.
For the weak, I made myself weak, in order to win over the weak. I have become all things to all men, in order to save some by all means.
Now I do this for the sake of the Good News, so that I may share in it in common.
Do you not know that those who run in a race all run, but only one receives the prize? Run thus, in order to win.
Every man who strives in games exercises self-control in all things. They do it to receive a corruptible crown, but we, an incorruptible.
That's why I run like this, not without purpose. I fight like this, not by beating the air,
but by beating my body and subduing it, lest after preaching to others I should be disqualified.
Now I do not want you to be ignorant, brethren, that our fathers were all under the cloud, that they all passed by the sea,
that they were all baptized into Moses in the cloud and in the sea,
that they all ate the same spiritual food,
that they all drank the same spiritual drink. For they drank from a spiritual rock that followed them, and that rock was Christ.
However, God was not pleased with most of them, as they were overthrown in the wilderness.
Now these things have served us as examples, so that we may not covet evil things, as they coveted them.
Do not be idolaters, as some of them were. As it is written, "The people sat down to eat and drink, and got up to play."
Let us not indulge in fornication, as some of them did, and in a single day twenty-three thousand people fell.
Let us not put Christ to the test, as some of them did, and they perished by serpents.
Do not grumble, as some of them grumbled and perished by the destroyer.
Now all these things have happened to them as an example, and they have been written for our instruction, upon whom the end of time has come.
Let him who thinks he is standing take care not to fall.
No temptation has seized you, except that which is common to man. God is faithful, he will not allow you to be tempted beyond your strength, but he will open with temptation the way of flight, so that you can bear it.
Therefore, my beloveds, flee from idolatry.
I speak as if to wise men. Judge of what I say.
Is not the cup of blessing that we bless a participation in the blood of Christ? Is not the bread that we break a participation in the body of Christ?
Because there is one bread, we, who are many, form one body, for we all partake of one bread.
Consider Israel according to the flesh. Do not those who eat the sacrifices partake of the altar?
What am I saying? That a thing sacrificed to idols is something, or that an idol is something?
But I say that the things that the pagans sacrifice, they sacrifice to demons and not to God, and I do not want you to have fellowship with demons.
You cannot drink both the cup of the Lord and the cup of demons. You cannot participate in both the table of the Lord and the table of demons.
Or do we provoke the Lord to jealousy? Are we stronger than him?
"Everything is allowed to me", but not everything is profitable. 23 "Everything is permitted to me", but not everything is profitable.
Let no one seek his own good, but let each seek the good of his neighbor.
Everything that is sold in the butcher's shop, eat it, without asking questions for the conscience,
for "the earth is the Lord's, and its fullness."
If someone of those who do not believe invites you to eat, and you want to go, eat what is offered to you, without asking questions of conscience.
But if anyone says to you, "This has been offered to idols," do not eat of it, out of consideration for the one who told you and for the sake of your conscience. For "the earth is the Lord's, in all its fullness".
Conscience, I say, not yours, but that of the other. For why should my freedom be judged by another conscience?
If I participate with gratitude, why am I denounced for something for which I am grateful?
So, whether you eat or drink, or do anything, do everything for the glory of God.
Do not give any occasion for sin, either to the Jews, or to the Greeks, or to the assembly of God;
just as I also am pleasing to all in all things, seeking not my own advantage, but the advantage of many, that they may be saved.
Be imitators of me, as I myself am of Christ.
Now I praise you, brethren, that you remember me in all things, and that you hold fast to the traditions, as I have handed them down to you.
But I want you to know that the head of every man is Christ, that the head of woman is man, and that the head of Christ is God.
Every man who prays or prophesies, with his head covered, dishonors his head.
But every woman who prays or prophesies, with her head uncovered, dishonors her head. Because it's one and the same thing as if it were razed.
Because if a woman is not covered, let her hair be cut too. But if it is shameful for a woman to have her hair cut or shaved, let her be covered.
For man must not cover his head, because he is the image and glory of God, but woman is the glory of man.
For man does not come from woman, but woman comes from man;
for man was not created for woman, but woman for man.
Therefore the woman must have authority over her own head, for the angels' sake.
Nevertheless, in the Lord, woman is not independent of man, nor man independent of woman.
For as woman is descended from man, so man is descended from woman; but everything comes from God.
Judge for yourselves. Is it proper for a woman to pray to God without being veiled?
Does not nature herself teach you that if a man has long hair, it is a disgrace to him?
But if a woman has long hair, it is a glory to her, for her hair is given to her for covering.
But if anyone seems to be arguing, we don't have that custom, nor the assemblies of God.
But in giving you this commandment, I do not congratulate you, for you are meeting not for the better, but for the worse.
For in the first place, when you meet in assembly, I hear that there are divisions among you, and I believe it in part.
For there must also be divisions among you, so that those who are approved may be revealed among you.
So when you come together, it is not the Lord's Supper that you eat.
Because, in your meals, everyone first takes his own meal. One is hungry, and the other is drunk.
What, have you not houses to eat and drink? Or do you despise God's congregation and shame those who do not have enough? What shall I tell you? Should I hire you? In this, I do not praise you.
For I have received from the Lord what I have also transmitted to you, namely, that the Lord Jesus, in the night that he was betrayed, took bread.
After giving thanks, he broke it and said, "Take, eat." This is my body, which is broken for you. Do this in memory of me. »
In the same way, after the meal, he took the cup, saying, "This cup is the new covenant in my blood. Do this, every time you drink of it, in remembrance of me. »
For every time you eat this bread and drink this cup, you proclaim the Lord's death until he comes.
Therefore whoever eats this bread or drinks the cup of the Lord in a manner unworthy of the Lord will be guilty of the body and blood of the Lord.
But let a man examine himself, and thus let him eat bread and drink from the cup.
For he who eats and drinks in an unworthy manner eats and drinks judgment on himself, if he does not discern the body of the Lord.
That is why many of you are weak and sick, and there are not many who are sleeping.
For if we discerned ourselves, we would not be judged.
But when we are judged, we are disciplined by the Lord, so that we are not condemned with the world.
Therefore, my brethren, when you gather together to eat, wait for one another.
But if anyone is hungry, let him eat at home, so that your meeting may not be a judgment. The rest I will put in order when I come.
Now, as far as spiritual things are concerned, brethren, I do not want you to be ignorant.
You know that when you were pagans, you allowed yourselves to be drawn into these dumb idols, no matter how you let yourselves be led.
Wherefore I make known unto you that no one, speaking by the Spirit of God, says, "Jesus is cursed." No one can say, "Jesus is Lord," except by the Holy Spirit.
There are many kinds of gifts, but one and the same Spirit.
There are various kinds of services, and the same Lord.
There are various kinds of works, but the same God who works all things in all.
But to each is given the manifestation of the Spirit for the benefit of all.
For to one is given by the Spirit the word of wisdom, to another the word of knowledge according to the same Spirit,
to another faith by the same Spirit, to another the gift of healings by the same Spirit,
to another the action of miracles, to another prophecy, to another the discernment of spirits, to another the diversity of languages, to another the interpretation of tongues.
But it is one and the same Spirit who produces all this, distributing to each one separately what he wants.
For as the body is one and has many members, and all the members of the body, being many, form but one body, so it is with Christ.
For it is in one Spirit that we have all been baptized into one body, Jews or Greeks, slaves or free, and that we have all been watered in one Spirit.
For the body is not one member, but many.
If the foot says, "I am not the hand, I am not part of the body," then it is not part of the body.
If the ear said, "Because I am not the eye, I am not part of the body," then it would not be part of the body.
If the whole body were an eye, where would hearing be? If the whole body were hearing, where would smell be?
But now God has placed the members, each of them, in the body, as He willed.
If they were all one member, where would the body be?
But now they are many members, but one body.
The eye cannot say to the hand, "I don't need you," nor from head to toe, "I don't need you."
No, rather, the members of the body that seem weaker are necessary.
The parts of the body which seem less honorable to us, we honor more abundantly; and our non-visible parts have more modesty,
while our visible parts do not need it. But God has composed the body together, giving more honor to the lower part,
so that there may be no division in the body, but that the members may have the same care for each other.
If one limb suffers, all the limbs suffer with it. When a member is honored, all members rejoice with him.
Now you are the body of Christ, and its members individually.
God has appointed some in the assembly: first apostles, secondly prophets, thirdly teachers, then thaumaturgists, then gifts of healing, assistance, government, and various languages.
Are all apostles? Are they all prophets? Are they all teachers? Are they all miracle workers?
Do they all have healing gifts? Do they all speak in various languages? Do they all interpret?
But ardently desire the best gifts. Besides, I am showing you an excellent way.
If I speak the tongues of men and angels, but have not charity, I am only a brass that resounds or a cymbal that sounds.
If I have the gift of prophecy, if I know all the mysteries and all the science, if I have all the faith to move mountains, but I have not charity, I am nothing.
If I give all my goods to feed the poor, and if I give up my body to be burned, but I do not have charity, it is of no use to me.
Love is patient and it is good. Love is not envious. Love does not boast, is not proud,
does not behave inappropriately, does not seek his own way, does not allow himself to be provoked, does not take evil into account;
does not rejoice in injustice, but rejoices in the truth;
excuse all, believe all, hope all, and endure all.
Love is never lacking. But where there are prophecies, they will be suppressed. Where there are diverse languages, they will cease. Where there is knowledge, it will disappear.
For we know in part and prophesy in part;
but when that which is complete has arrived, that which is partial will disappear.
When I was a child, I spoke like a child, I felt like a child, I thought like a child. Now that I have become a man, I have gotten rid of childish things.
For now we see in a mirror, faintly, but then face to face. Now I know in part, but then I will know fully, as I have also been fully known.
But now there remains faith, hope and charity, these three. The greatest of these is love.
Follow love and long for spiritual gifts, but especially that of prophesying.
For he who speaks in another tongue does not speak to men, but to God; for no one understands, but it is by the Spirit that he speaks mysteries.
But he who prophesies speaks to men to edify, exhort and console them.
He who speaks in a foreign tongue edifies himself, but he who prophesies edifies the assembly.
Now I desire that you should all speak in other tongues, but still more that you should prophesy. For he who prophesies is greater than he who speaks in other tongues, unless he interprets, so that the assembly may be edified.
But now, brethren, if I come to you speaking in other languages, what shall I serve you, if I do not speak to you by revelation, or by knowledge, or by prophecy, or by teaching?
Even lifeless things that make noise, whether the flute or the harp, if they did not give a distinction in the sounds, how would anyone know what is flute or harp?
For if the trumpet emitted an uncertain sound, who would prepare for war?
In the same way, if you did not speak words that were easy to understand in your tongue, how would anyone know what is being said? For you would be talking in the air.
There may be so many different languages in the world, and none of them is meaningless.
If, therefore, I do not know the meaning of the language, I would be a stranger to him who speaks, and he who speaks would be a stranger to me.
So you also, since you are zealous for spiritual gifts, seek to abound for the edification of the assembly.
Let him who speaks another language pray that he may interpret .
For if I pray in another language, my spirit prays, but my understanding is fruitless.
What must I do? I will pray by the spirit, and I will also pray by the understanding. I will sing with the spirit, and I will also sing with the understanding.
Otherwise, if you bless with the spirit, how will he who fills the place of the ignorant say "Amen" to your thanksgiving, since he does not know what you say?
For you certainly give thanks, but the other is not edified.
I thank my God, I speak other languages more than all of you.
However, in the assembly, I prefer to say five words with my understanding, in order to instruct others also, than ten thousand words in another language.
Brethren, do not be children in your thoughts, and do not show malice, but be mature in your thoughts.
It is written in the law: "It is by men of foreign tongues and by the lips of strangers that I will speak to this people. They will not even listen to me in this way, says the Lord. »
Therefore other tongues are a sign, not to those who believe, but to the unbelievers; but prophecy is a sign, not to the unbelievers, but to those who believe.
If, then, the whole assembly is assembled, and all speak in other tongues, and uneducated or unbelieving persons enter, will they not say that you are mad?
But if all prophesy, and anyone who is an unbeliever or uncultured enters, he is rebuked by all, and he is judged by all.
And so the secrets of his heart are revealed. Then he will bow down on his face and worship God, declaring that God is truly in your midst.
What then, brothers? When you come together, each of you has a psalm, a teaching, a revelation, another language or an interpretation. Let everything be done to edify each other.
If anyone speaks in another language, let there be two, or at most three, and in turn, and let only one interpret.
But if there is no interpreter, let him be silent in the assembly, and speak to himself and to God.
Let two or three of the prophets speak, and let the others discern.
But if a revelation is made to another sitting next to him, let the first one be silent.
For you can all prophesy one by one, so that all may learn and all may be exhorted.
The spirits of the prophets are subject to the prophets,
for God is not a God of confusion, but of peace, as in all assemblies of saints.
Let the women be silent in the assemblies, for they have not been permitted to speak, except with submission, as the law also says,
if they want to learn something. "Let them ask their husbands at home, for it is shameful for a woman to speak in the assembly."
What!? Is it from you that the word of God has come? Or has it reached you alone?
If anyone thinks he is a prophet or spiritual, let him recognize the things that I am writing to you, that they are the commandment of the Lord.
But if anyone is ignorant, let him be.
Therefore, brethren, have an ardent desire to prophesy, and do not forbid the speaking of other tongues.
That everything happens in a proper and orderly manner.
I now declare to you, brethren, the good news which I have preached to you, which you have also received, in which you also stand,
by which also you are saved, if you hold fast to the word which I have spoken to you - unless you have believed in vain.
I have conveyed to you first of all what I myself have received, namely, that according to the Scriptures, Christ died for our sins,
that he was buried, that he rose again on the third day, according to the Scriptures,
and that he appeared to Cephas, and then to the twelve.
Then he appeared to more than five hundred brothers at a time, most of whom have remained until now, but some of whom have also fallen asleep.
He then appeared to James, and then to all the apostles,
and finally, as to the child born out of time, to me too he appeared.
For I am the least of the apostles, who is not worthy to be called an apostle, because I have persecuted the assembly of God.
But it is by the grace of God that I am what I am. The grace granted to me was not in vain; but I have worked harder than all of them, not I, but the grace of God who was with me.
So whether it is I or them, so we preach, and so you have believed.
Now, if it is preached that Christ rose from the dead, how do some of you say that there is no resurrection of the dead?
But if there is no resurrection of the dead, neither is Christ risen.
If Christ is not risen, then our preaching is in vain, and your faith also is in vain.
Yes, we are also found to be false witnesses of God, because we have testified to God that he raised Christ, that he did not rise, if it is true that the dead do not rise.
For if the dead do not rise, neither is Christ risen.
If Christ is not risen, your faith is in vain; you are still in your sins.
And those who fell asleep in Christ perished.
If we have hoped in Christ only in this life, we are of all men the most to be pitied.
But now, Christ has risen from the dead. It has become the first fruit of those who sleep.
For since death came from man, the resurrection of the dead also came from man.
For as in Adam all die, so in Christ all will be made alive.
But each according to his own order: Christ, the firstfruits, and then those that will belong to Christ at his coming.
Then will come the end, when he will hand over the Kingdom to God the Father, when he will have abolished all dominion, all authority, and all power.
For he must reign until he has put all his enemies under his feet.
The last enemy that will be abolished is death.
For "he has subdued all things under his feet." But when he says, "All things are subject to him," it is evident that it is he who has subjected all things to him.
When all things have been submitted to him, then the Son also will be subject to him who has subjected all things to him, so that God may be all in all.
Or what will those who are baptized for the dead do? If the dead do not rise at all, why then are they baptized for the dead?
Why are we too, every hour, in danger?
I affirm, by the boasting that I have in you in Christ Jesus our Lord, that I die every day.
If in Ephesus I fought with animals for human purposes, what does that bring me? If the dead do not rise, then "let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we will die".
Don't let that fool you! "Bad company corrupts good morals".
Wake up righteously, and do not sin, for some do not know God. I say this for your shame.
But someone will say, "How do the dead rise?" and "What kind of bodies do they come with?"
You, the fool, what you sow yourself is not made alive unless it dies.
What you sow, you do not sow the body, which will be, but a naked grain, perhaps of wheat, or of another kind.
But God gives him a body as he pleases, and to each seed a body of its own.
Not all flesh is the same flesh, but there is the flesh of men, another of animals, another of fish, another of birds.
There are also heavenly bodies and terrestrial bodies; but the glory of the celestials differs from that of the earthly.
There is a glory of the sun, another glory of the moon, and another glory of the stars; for one star differs from another star in glory.
The same is true of the resurrection of the dead. The body is sown perishable, it rises again imperishable.
He was sown in dishonor, he rises in glory. He is sown in weakness, he rises in power.
It is sown in a natural body, it rises again in a spiritual body. There is a natural body, and there is also a spiritual body.
Thus, it is also written: "The first man, Adam, became a living soul." The last Adam became a life-giving spirit.
However, what is spiritual is not first, but what is natural, then what is spiritual.
The first man is of the earth, made of dust. The second man is the Lord of heaven.
Such is he who is made of dust, so are those who are also made of dust; and such is the celestial, such are also those who are celestial.
As we have borne the image of those who are made of dust, let us also bear the image of those who are heavenly.
Now I say this, brethren: flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom of God, and perishable things do not inherit imperishable things.
Behold, I tell you a mystery. We will not all sleep, but we will all be changed,
in an instant, in the twinkling of an eye, at the last trumpet. For the trumpet shall sound, and the dead shall rise incorruptible, and we shall be changed.
For this perishable body must become imperishable, and this mortal must put on immortality.
But when this perishable body shall have become imperishable, and this mortal shall have put on immortality, then shall that which is written shall come to pass: "Death has been swallowed up in victory."
"Death, where is your sting? Hades, where is your victory? »
The sting of death is sin, and the power of sin is the law.
But thanks be to God, who gives us victory through our Lord Jesus Christ.
Therefore, my beloved brethren, be steadfast, steadfast, persevering in the Lord's work, knowing that your labor is not in vain in the Lord.
Now, as to the collection for the saints, as I commanded the assemblies of Galatia, do likewise.
On the first day of each week, let each of you make the savings that suits you, so that there will be no collection when I arrive.
When I arrive, I will send the one you approve with letters to carry to Jerusalem the gift you have given me.
If it is appropriate for me to go there also, they will go with me.
I will come to you when I have passed through Macedonia, for I am passing through Macedonia.
But it may be that I will stay with you, or even that I will winter with you, so that you may send me on a journey, wherever I go.
For I do not want to see you now in passing, but I hope to stay with you for some time, if the Lord permits.
But I will remain in Ephesus until Pentecost,
for a great and effective door has been opened to me, and the adversaries are many.
Now, if Timothy comes, see that he is with you without fear, for he is doing the work of the Lord, as am I.
Let no one despise him. But make him go forward in peace in his journey, that he may come to me; for I am waiting for him with the brethren.
As for Brother Apollos, I strongly urged him to come to you with the brothers, but he did not want to come now; but he will come when he has the opportunity.
Look! Stand firm in the faith! Be brave! Be strong!
Let everything you do be done in love.
Now, I pray you, brethren, you know the house of Stephanas, which is the first in Achaia, and which has placed itself at the service of the saints.
to be subject equally to them, as well as to all those who participate in the work and work.
I rejoice at the coming of Stephanas, Fortunatus, and Achaicus, for they have filled what you lacked.
For they have refreshed my spirit and yours. Recognize therefore those who do so.
The assemblies of Asia greet you. Aquila and Priscilla greet you warmly in the Lord, as well as the congregation that is in their house.
All the brothers greet you. Greet one another with a holy kiss.
This greeting is from me, Paul, in my own hand.
If anyone does not love the Lord Jesus Christ, let him be cursed. Come, Lord!
May the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with you!
I greet you all in Jesus Christ. Amen.
Paul, apostle of Jesus Christ, according to the will of God, and Timothy, our brother, to the assembly of God which is at Corinth, with all the saints who are in all Achaia.
Grace and peace be to you, from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of mercies and God of all consolation,
who comforts us in all our affliction, that we may console those who are in some affliction, by the consolation with which we ourselves are consoled by God.
For as the sufferings of Christ abound us, so our consolation also abounds through Christ.
But if we are afflicted, it is for your consolation and salvation. If we are consoled, it is for your consolation, which produces in you patience in the same sufferings as we do.
Our hope for you is unshakeable, knowing that, since you share in suffering, you also share in consolation.
For we do not wish to leave you, brethren, ignorant of the trial which has befallen us in Asia: we have been overwhelmed beyond our strength, to the point of despairing even of life.
Yes, we ourselves have had the sentence of death within ourselves, so that we may not trust in ourselves, but in God who raises the dead,
who delivered us from so great a death, and who delivers, in whom we have placed our hope that he will deliver us again,
You also join in our favor by your supplications, so that, for the gift that has been made to us through the intermediary of many, thanks may be rendered by many persons in your favor.
For our boasting is this, the testimony of our conscience, that in the holiness and sincerity of God, not in carnal wisdom, but in the grace of God, we have conducted ourselves in the world, and more abundantly towards you.
For we write to you nothing other than what you read or even acknowledge, and I hope that you will recognize to the end -
as you have also acknowledged us in part - that we are your boast, as you are also ours, in the day of our Lord Jesus.
In this confidence, I was resolved to come first to you, so that you might derive a second advantage from it,
to go through you into Macedonia, and again from Macedonia to come to you, and to be sent by you on a journey to Judea.
When I designed these projects, was I inconsistent? Or do the things that I project, do I project them according to the flesh, so that there may be "yes, yes" and "no, no" in me?
But as God is faithful, our word to you has not been "Yes and no".
For the Son of God, Jesus Christ, whom we, I, Silvanus, and Timothy preached among you, was not "yes and no," but in him it is "yes."
In fact, whatever the number of God's promises, the "yes" is in him. Therefore also through him is the "Amen", to the glory of God through us.
Now he who has established us with you in Christ and anointed us is God,
who also sealed us and gave us the down payment of the Spirit in our hearts.
But I call upon God as a witness of my soul, that, to spare you, I have not come to Corinth.
We do not control your faith, but we are fellow workers with you for your joy. For you stand firm in the faith.
But I have decided for myself not to come to you in sorrow anymore.
For if I grieve you, who will rejoice me, but the one whom I grieve?
And I have written this very thing to you, so that when I come, I may not be grieved by those whom I should rejoice, trusting in you all that my joy may be shared by you all.
For it was in distress and anguish of heart that I wrote to you with many tears, not to grieve you, but to make you know the love I have so abundantly for you.
But if anyone has caused pain, it is not to me that he has caused it, but partly to all of you, so that I may not press you too much.
This punishment inflicted by the multitude is sufficient for such a man;
therefore, on the contrary, you should rather forgive and comfort him, lest such a man be swallowed up by his too great sorrow.
That is why I beg you to confirm your love for him.
For it is for this purpose that I have also written, in order to know the trial of you, to know whether you are obedient in all things.
Now, I also forgive whoever you forgive something. For if I have forgiven anything, it is for you that I have done it in the presence of Christ,
so that Satan may not gain an advantage over us, for we are not ignorant of his designs.
Now when I came to Troas for the Good News of Christ, and a door was opened to me in the Lord,
I had no relief for my spirit, because I had not found Titus, my brother; but, taking leave of them, I went to Macedonia.
Now thanks be to God, who always leads us in triumph in Christ, and who reveals through us everywhere the pleasant odor of his knowledge.
For we are a sweet smell of Christ to God, to those who are saved and to those who perish:
for some, a smell of death to death, for others, a pleasant smell of life to life. Who is sufficient for these things?
For we are not like so many others, peddling the word of God. But as of sincerity, as of God, before God, we speak in Christ.
Are we starting to recommend ourselves again? Or do we need, as some do, letters of recommendation for you or on your behalf?
You are our letter, written in our hearts, known and read by all men,
being revealed that you are a letter of Christ, served by us, written not with ink, but with the Spirit of the living God; not in tables of stone, but in tables that are hearts of flesh.
It is through Christ that we have this trust in God,
not that we are capable of accounting for anything on our own; but our self-sufficiency comes from God,
which has also made us sufficient as servants of a new covenant, not of the letter, but of the Spirit. For the letter kills, but the Spirit gives life.
But if the service of death, written on stones, came with glory, so that the children of Israel could not look steadfastly on the face of Moses, because of the glory of his countenance, which passed away,
will not the service of the Spirit be with much more glory?
For if the service of condemnation has glory, the service of justice has much more glory.
For, most certainly, that which has been made glorious has not been so in this respect, because of the glory which surpasses.
For if what passes away was with glory, much more is what remains in glory.
Having therefore such a hope, we have great boldness of speech,
and not like Moses, who put a veil over his face so that the children of Israel would not look firmly at the end of what was passing.
But their minds have become hardened, for to this day, when the old covenant is read, the same veil remains, because in Christ it passes.
But to this day, when one reads Moses, a veil remains over their hearts.
But as soon as anyone turns to the Lord, the veil is removed.
Now the Lord is the Spirit; and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom.
And all of us, with our faces unveiled, seeing the glory of the Lord as in a mirror, are transformed into one image, from glory to glory, as by the Lord, the Spirit.
Therefore, since we have this ministry, just as we have obtained mercy, we do not falter.
But we have renounced the hidden things of shame, not walking by cunning and not handling the word of God with deceit, but recommending ourselves to the conscience of every man before God, by the manifestation of the truth.
If our Good News is veiled, it is also veiled in the dying,
in whom the god of this world has blinded the understanding of the unbelievers, so that the light of the Good News of the glory of Christ, who is the image of God, should not appear upon them.
For it is not ourselves that we preach, but Christ Jesus as Lord, and ourselves as your servants for Jesus' sake,
for it is God who has said, "Light shall shine out of darkness," who has shone in our hearts to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ.
But we have this treasure in vessels of clay, so that the extreme greatness of the power may be of God and not of ourselves.
We are pressed on all sides, but not crushed; perplexed, but not desperate;
pursued, but not abandoned; felled but not destroyed;
always bearing in the body the condemnation to death of the Lord Jesus, so that the life of Jesus may also be manifested in our body.
For we who live are always given over to death for Jesus' sake, so that the life of Jesus may also be revealed in our mortal flesh.
Thus death acts in us, but life acts in you.
But having the same spirit of faith, as it is written, "I believed, and therefore I spoke." We also believe, and that is why we also speak,
knowing that he who raised up the Lord Jesus will also raise us up with Jesus, and present us with you.
For all this is for your sake, so that grace, being multiplied by the many, may cause thanksgiving to abound to the glory of God.
That is why we do not falter; but, although our external person is decomposing, our inner person is renewed day by day.
For our slight tribulation, which is for the moment, procures us more and more an eternal weight of glory,
while we do not look at the things that are visible, but at those that are not seen. For the things that are seen are temporal, but the things that are not seen are eternal.
For we know that if the earthly house that serves us as a tent is destroyed, we have a building that comes from God, a house not made with hands, eternal, in heaven.
For there we groan, longing to be clothed with the dwelling place in heaven,
if, however, being clothed, we are not to be found naked.
For we who are in this tent groan and are overwhelmed, not that we desire to be despoiled, but we desire to be clothed, that life may swallow up that which is mortal.
Now, the One who created us for this is God, who also gave us the down payment of the Spirit.
That is why we are always trusting and we know that while we are at home in the body, we are absent from the Lord;
for we walk by faith and not by sight.
We are courageous, I say, and we rather want to be absent from the body and be at home with the Lord.
That's why we strive to be pleasing to him, whether we're at home or away.
For we must all be revealed before the judgment seat of Christ, so that each one may receive what is due to him in the body according to what he has done, for good or for evil.
Knowing therefore the fear of the Lord, we persuade men, but we are revealed to God, and I hope that we are also revealed in your consciences.
For we do not recommend ourselves to you again, but we speak as if to give you an opportunity to glory in our behalf, so that you may have something to answer those who glory in appearance and not in heart.
For if we are beside ourselves, it is for God's sake. And if we are sober of mind, it is for you.
For the love of Christ compels us to do so; for we judge thus: One died for all, therefore all died.
He died for all, so that those who live no longer live for themselves, but for Him who died and rose for them.
That is why we now know no one according to the flesh. If we have known Christ according to the flesh, now we no longer know Him in this way.
Thus, if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation. The old things have disappeared. Behold, all things have become new.
Now everything comes from God, who has reconciled us to himself through Jesus Christ, and who has entrusted us with the ministry of reconciliation,
that is, God has reconciled the world to himself in Christ, without imputing to them their faults, and has entrusted to us the word of reconciliation.
We are therefore ambassadors in the name of Christ, as if God were praying through us: we beseech you in the name of Christ, be reconciled to God.
For he who did not know sin he caused him to become sin in our place, so that we might become in him the righteousness of God.
Working together, we also beseech you not to receive God's grace in vain.
For he says, "At an acceptable moment, I listened to you. On the day of salvation, I helped you. Behold, now is the acceptable time. Behold, now is the day of salvation.
We give no occasion for sin in anything, so that our service may not be blamed,
but we commend ourselves in all things as servants of God: in great perseverance, in afflictions, in privations, in distresses,
in beatings, in prisons, in riots, in work, in vigils, in fasts,
in purity, in knowledge, in perseverance, in goodness, in the Holy Spirit, in sincere love,
in the word of truth, in the power of God, with the weapons of righteousness on the right hand and on the left,
by glory and dishonor, by bad and good name, as deceitful and yet truthful,
as unknown and yet well known, as dying, and here we live, as punished and not killed,
as afflicted and yet always joyful, as poor and yet enriching many people, as having nothing and yet possessing all things.
Our mouth is open to you, Corinthians. Our hearts have expanded.
You are not limited by us, but you are limited by your own affections.
Now, in return - I speak as to my children - you too, open your hearts.
Do not put yourselves under a foreign yoke with the infidels, for what is the connection between righteousness and iniquity? Or what is the communion of light with darkness?
What agreement does Christ have with Belial? Or what part does a believer have with an unbeliever?
What agreement does God's temple have with idols? For you are the temple of the living God. Just as God said, "I will dwell in them and walk in them. I will be their God and they will be my people. »
Wherefore, 'Come out from among them, and be separated,' says the Lord. Do not touch anything impure. I will receive you.
I will be a Father to you. You shall be sons and daughters to me, saith the Lord Almighty. »
Having therefore these promises, beloved, let us purify ourselves from all defilement of the flesh and spirit, perfecting holiness in the fear of God.
Open your hearts to us. We have not harmed anyone. We have not corrupted anyone. We didn't take advantage of anyone.
I do not say this to condemn you, for I have already said that you are in our hearts to die together and to live together.
Great is the boldness of my words towards you. Great is my boasting in your favor. I am filled with comfort. I overflow with joy in all our affliction.
For when we entered Macedonia, our flesh was not relieved, but we were afflicted on all sides. The fighting was outside. Fear was within.
However, he who comforts the humble, God, has consoled us by the coming of Titus,
and not only by his coming, but also by the consolation he received in you, when he told us of your desire, your mourning, and your zeal for me, so that I rejoiced still more.
For if I have saddened you with my letter, I do not regret it, although I have regretted it. For I see that my letter has saddened you, though only for a time.
I rejoice now, not that you have been sorrowful, but that you have been sorrowful unto repentance. For you have been piously afflicted, that you may suffer no loss through us.
For pious sorrow produces repentance which leads to salvation, which entails no regret. But the sadness of the world produces death.
For behold, this same thing, that you have been afflicted in a pious manner, what earnest care it has produced in you. Yes, what a defence, what indignation, what fear, what desire, what zeal, what demand! In all, you have shown yourselves to be pure in this matter.
Therefore, if I have written to you, it is not for the cause of him who has done evil, nor for the cause of him who has suffered evil, but that the solicitude you have shown towards us may be revealed in you before God.
That is why we have been consoled. In our consolation, we rejoiced all the more in the joy of Titus, because his spirit was refreshed by all of you.
For if in any way I have boasted to him in your favor, I have not been disappointed. But as we have told you all things in truth, so our glorification which I have done before Titus has been found to be the truth.
His affection is more abundant towards you, while he remembers all your obedience, how with fear and trembling you received him.
I am glad that I am confident in you in everything.
Moreover, brethren, we make known to you the grace of God which has been bestowed in the assemblies of Macedonia,
how, in a severe trial of distress, the abundance of their joy and their deep poverty abounded even to the richness of their generosity.
For, according to their power, I testify, yes, and beyond their power, they have given of their own accord,
begging us with great insistence to receive this grace and communion in the service of the saints.
It didn't happen as we had planned, but they first gave themselves to the Lord and to us by the will of God.
We have therefore exhorted Titus to complete this grace in you, as he had begun it before.
Now, as you abound in all things, in faith, in word, in knowledge, in all that is serious, and in your love for us, let you also abound in this grace.
I do not speak as a commandment, but as a proof, by the seriousness of others, of the sincerity of your love.
For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, who, though rich, became poor for your sake, that you might become rich through his poverty.
Here is the advice I give you: it is opportune that you, who were the first to begin a year ago, not only do, but also have the will.
But now, finish also doing, so that, as there was the will to do, there may also be completion according to your ability.
Indeed, if the eagerness is there, it is according to what you have, and not according to what you do not have.
For it is not that others may be relieved and you afflicted,
but for there to be equality. For the abundance which you have at this moment fills their lack, so that their abundance may also fill your lack, and there may be equality.
As it is written, "He who hoarded much lacked nothing, and he who amassed little lacked nothing."
But thanks be to God, who puts in the heart of Titus the same zeal for you.
Indeed, he welcomed our exhortation, but being very serious himself, he went to you of his own accord.
We have sent with him the brother whose praise of the Good News is known in all the congregations.
Not only this, but he has also been appointed by the assemblies to travel with us in this grace, which is served by us to the glory of the Lord himself, and to show our eagerness.
We avoid this, so that no one will blame us for this abundance that is administered by us.
Having regard to honorable things, not only in the sight of the Lord, but also in the eyes of men.
We have sent with them our brother, whose seriousness we have often proved in many things, but who is even more so now, because of the great confidence he has in you.
As for Titus, he is my partner and my work companion for you. As for our brethren, they are the apostles of the assemblies, the glory of Christ.
Therefore testify to your love for them before the assemblies, and to our boasting on your behalf.
For it is useless for me to write to you about the service of the saints,
for I know your eagerness, of which I boast in your name to those of Macedonia, that Achaia has been prepared for a year. Your zeal has given rise to a very large number of them.
But I have sent the brethren that our boasting in your behalf may not be in vain in this respect, so that, as I have said, you may be prepared,
lest if any one from Macedonia comes with me and finds you unprepared, we (not to mention you) should be disappointed in this confident boasting.
I therefore thought it necessary to pray to the brethren to precede you and to arrange in advance the generous gift which you had previously promised, so that this gift might be ready out of generosity and not out of greed.
Know that he who sows sparingly will also reap sparingly. He who sows abundantly will also reap abundantly.
Let each one give according to what he has decided in his heart, without reluctance or constraint, for God loves the one who gives with joy.
And God can make you abound in all graces, so that, always having all sufficiency in all things, you may abound for every good work.
As it is written, "He scattered the people. He gave to the poor. His justice remains forever. »
Now let him who furnishes seed for the sower and bread for food, furnish and multiply your seed for sowing, and increase the fruits of your righteousness,
enriching you in everything for all the generosity that produces thanksgiving to God through us.
For the liberality which you discharge not only fills the gaps among the saints, but also abounds in thanksgiving to God,
for, by the proof it brings, they glorify God for the obedience of your confession to the Good News of Christ and for the generosity of your contribution to them and to all,
while they themselves, in supplication to you, aspire to you because of the immense grace of God in you.
Thanks be to God for his ineffable gift!
Now I, Paul, beseech you by the humility and meekness of Christ, I who, in your presence, am humble among you, but who, in your absence, am bold towards you.
Yes, I beg you to see to it that, when I am present, I do not show courage with the boldness with which I intend to be emboldened against some, who consider that we walk according to the flesh.
For although we walk according to the flesh, we do not fight according to the flesh;
for the weapons of our battle are not those of the flesh, but they are powerful before God to overthrow the strongholds,
to overthrow imaginations and every loftiness that rises up against the knowledge of God, and to bring every captive thought to the obedience of Christ,
being ready to avenge every disobedience, when your obedience is complete.
Do you look at things only as they appear before you? If anyone believes in himself that he is Christ's, let him consider again in himself that, as he is Christ's, we also are Christ's.
For if I boast a little of our authority, which the Lord has given to edify you and not to bring you down, I will not be ashamed,
so that it does not seem that I wish to frighten you by my letters.
For, they say, "his letters have weight and force, but his bodily presence is weak, and his word is despised."
Let such a person consider this: what we are in word by letter when we are absent, we are also in deed when we are present.
For we dare not number ourselves or compare ourselves with some of those who recommend themselves. But they themselves, measuring themselves against themselves, and comparing themselves with themselves, are without understanding.
But we will not boast beyond the proper limits, but within the limits which God has assigned to us, and which extend to you.
For we do not dwell too far, as if we had not reached you. Indeed, we have come to you with the Good News of Christ,
without boasting too much of the work of others, but hoping that as your faith grows, we will be abundantly enlarged by you in our sphere of influence,
in order to preach the Good News to the regions beyond you, without boasting of what another has already done.
But "he who glorifies himself may glory in the Lord."
For it is not he who boasts that is approved, but he whom the Lord boasts.
I would like you to put up with me with a little madness, but you put up with me.
For I am jealous of you with a pious jealousy. For I have promised you in marriage to one spouse, that I might present you to Christ as a pure virgin.
But I fear that as the serpent deceived Eve by his cunning, so your minds will be corrupted by the simplicity that is in Christ.
For if the one who comes preaches another Jesus whom we have not preached, or if you receive another spirit which you have not received, or another "good news" which you have not accepted, you will be very happy with it.
Because I believe that I am not at all behind the best apostles.
If I am not very gifted for speech, I am not so for knowledge. No, in every way, we have been revealed to you in all things.
Or have I committed a sin in humbling myself to exalt you, because I have freely preached to you the Good News of God?
I have despoiled other assemblies, taking their wages to serve you.
When I was present among you and was in need, I was not a burden to anyone, for the brethren who came from Macedonia provided for the measure of my need. In all things, I have taken care not to be a burden to you, and I will continue to do so.
As the truth of Christ is in me, no one will prevent me from boasting thus in the regions of Achaia.
What for? Because I don't like you? God knows.
But what I am doing, I will continue to do, in order to cut off the opportunity of those who desire an opportunity, so that, in what they boast, they may be recognized as we are.
For such men are false apostles, deceitful workers, masquerading as the apostles of Christ.
And this is not surprising, because even Satan pretends to be an angel of light.
It is therefore no great thing if his servants also pretend to be servants of righteousness, whose end will be according to their works.
I repeat, let no one think me foolish. But if this is the case, receive me as a fool, so that I too may glory a little.
What I say I do not say according to the Lord, but as folly, in this assurance of boasting.
Since many glory according to the flesh, I will also boast.
For you willingly bear with fools, being wise.
For you endure the man who enslaves you, who devours you, who takes you captive, who exalts himself, who hits you in the face.
To my great shame, I speak as if we had been weak. But in whatever way someone is bold (I am talking like a fool), so am I.
Are they Hebrews? Me too. Are they Israelites? I am too. Are they the descendants of Abraham? Me too.
Are they servants of Christ? (I am more so: more work, more prisons, more beatings, and more deaths.
Five times, I received forty lashes from the Jews with a stick minus one.
Three times, I was beaten with rods. Once, I was stoned. Three times I was shipwrecked. I spent a night and a day in the depths.
I have often been on a journey, in the perils of rivers, in the perils of robbers, in the perils of my countrymen, in the perils of the heathen, in the perils of the city, in the perils of the desert, in the perils of the sea, in the perils of false brethren;
in work and work, in frequent vigils, in hunger and thirst, in frequent fasting, in cold and nakedness.
Besides these external things, there is what presses me every day: anxiety for all the assemblies.
Who is weak, and I am not? Who is led to stumble, and I do not burn with indignation?
If I must boast, I will glory in what concerns my weakness.
The God and Father of the Lord Jesus Christ, the one who is blessed forever, knows that I am not lying.
At Damascus, the governor of King Aretas, who guarded the city, wanted to arrest me.
I was made to go down into a basket through a window near the wall, and I escaped from his hands.
It is probably not useful for me to boast, but I will have visions and revelations of the Lord.
I know a man in Christ who was caught up to the third heaven fourteen years ago – whether in the body, I don't know, or out of the body, I don't know; God knows.
I know such a man (whether he is in the body, or out of the body, I do not know; God knows),
I will glory in behalf of such a man, but I will not glory in my name, except in my weaknesses.
For if I wanted to boast, I would not be stupid, for I would tell the truth. But I abstain, so that no one thinks of me anything other than what he sees in me or hears of me.
Because of the immensity of the revelations, so that I might not be exalted beyond measure, a thorn in the flesh was given to me: a messenger of Satan to torment me, so that I would not be exalted beyond measure.
About this thing, I have begged the Lord three times that it will depart from me.
He said to me, "My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is fulfilled in weakness." Therefore I prefer to glory in my weaknesses, that the power of Christ may rest upon me.
Therefore I delight in weaknesses, wounds, necessities, persecutions, and distresses, for Christ's sake. Because it's when I'm weak that I'm strong.
I went crazy bragging. You have constrained me, for it is you who ought to have recommended me, for I am in no way inferior to the best apostles, although I am nothing.
For the signs of an apostle were wrought among you with perseverance, by signs, wonders, and miracles.
For in what way have you been made inferior to the rest of the assemblies, except that I myself have not been a burden to you? Forgive me for this fault!
Behold, this is the third time that I am ready to come to you, and I will not be a burden to you; for I do not seek your goods, but you. Because it is not the children who should save for the parents, but the parents for the children.
I will spend and will be spent very willingly for your souls. If I love you more abundantly, am I less loved?
Even so, I have not burdened you myself. But you could say that being cunning, I have taken you by cunning.
Have I profited by you through any of those whom I have sent you?
I exhorted Titus, and sent the brother with him. Did Titus take advantage of you? Were we not walking in the same spirit? Have we not followed in the same footsteps?
Again, do you think we apologize to you? It is before God that we speak in Christ. But all things, beloved, are for your edification.
For I fear that perhaps, when I come, I shall not find you as I wish, and that I shall be found by you as you do not desire, that perhaps there will be quarrels, jealousies, fits of anger, factions, calumnies, murmurings, proud thoughts, or riots,
that again, when I come, my God will humble me before you, and I will mourn many who have sinned before, and who have not repented of the impurity, sexual immorality, and lust they have committed.
This is the third time I have come to you. "Every word shall be established by the mouth of two or three witnesses."
I have warned before, and I warn again, as when I was present the second time, so now, being absent, I write to those who have sinned before and to all others that, if I return, I will not spare them,
since you are looking for a proof of Christ who speaks in me, who is not weak, but who is powerful in you.
For he was crucified by weakness, but he lives by the power of God. For we also are weak in him, but we will live with him by the power of God toward you.
Examine yourselves, to know if you are in the faith. Examine yourself. Or do you not know, as far as your own person is concerned, that Jesus Christ is in you? unless you are disqualified.
But I hope you know that we are not disqualified.
Now, I pray God that you do not do evil; not that we appear to be approved, but that you do what is honourable, although we seem to have failed.
For we can do nothing against the truth, but for the truth.
For we rejoice when we are weak and you are strong. We also pray for this: that you may become perfect.
Therefore I write these things in my absence, that I may not be too severe in my presence, according to the authority which the Lord has given me to edify, and not to demolish.
Finally, brothers, rejoice! Be perfect. Be comforted. Have the same spirit. Live in peace, and the God of love and peace will be with you.
Greet one another with a holy kiss.
All the saints greet you.
Paul, the apostle, not from men and by men, but by Jesus Christ and God the Father, who raised him from the dead,
and all the brethren who are with me, at the assemblies of Galatia.
Grace and peace be to you from God the Father and from our Lord Jesus Christ,
who gave himself up for our sins, that he might deliver us from the present evil world, according to the will of our God and Father,
to whom be glory forever and ever. Amen.
I wonder that you are so quick to abandon the one who called you in the grace of Christ for another "good news."
But there is no other "good news". Only, there are people who trouble you and who want to pervert the Good News of Christ.
But if we ourselves, or an angel from heaven, announce to you any other "good news" than the one we have announced to you, let him be cursed.
What we have already said, I repeat now: if anyone tells you any other "good news" than the one you have received, let him be cursed.
For do I now seek the favor of men, or that of God? Or am I trying to please men? For if I were still trying to please men, I would not be a servant of Christ.
But I let you know, brethren, concerning the Good News which has been preached by me, that it is not according to man.
For I did not receive it from a man, nor was it taught to me, but it came to me by revelation from Jesus Christ.
For you have heard how I once lived in the religion of the Jews, and how I persecuted the assembly of God and ravaged it.
I was more advanced in the Jewish religion than many of my countrymen of my age, being more zealous for the traditions of my fathers.
But when God, who separated me from my mother's womb and called me by his grace, had the good pleasure
to reveal his Son in me, that I might proclaim him among the Gentiles, I did not immediately converse with flesh and blood,
and I did not go up to Jerusalem to those who were apostles before me, but I went to Arabia. Then I went back to Damascus.
Then, at the end of three years, I went up to Jerusalem to visit Peter, and I stayed with him fifteen days.
But of the other apostles I have seen only James, the brother of the Lord.
Now, as for the things I write to you, behold, before God, I do not lie.
Then I arrived in the regions of Syria and Cilicia.
I was still unknown in face to the assemblies of Judea which were in Christ,
but they only heard it said, "He who once persecuted us now preaches the faith which he once strove to destroy."
So they glorified God in me.
Then, after a period of fourteen years, I went back to Jerusalem with Barnabas, taking Titus with me as well.
I ascended by revelation, and I set forth before them the Good News which I preach among the Gentiles, but privately before those who were respected, lest I run, or have run, in vain.
But even Titus, who was with me, was not compelled to be circumcised, being a Greek.
It was because of the false brethren who had been secretly introduced, who had entered to spy on the liberty we have in Christ Jesus, in order to reduce us to servitude,
and to whom we have not given way in the way of submission, not even for an hour, so that the truth of the Good News may be maintained among you.
But of those who had the reputation of being important - whoever they were, it makes no difference to me; God does not differentiate between men. Those, I say, who were respected, communicated nothing to me,
but on the contrary, when they saw that I had been entrusted with the Good News for the uncircumcised,
for he who acted through Peter in the apostleship to the circumcised, also acted through me to the Gentiles,
and when they saw the grace that had been given me, James, Cephas, and John, the reputed pillars, gave Barnabas and me the right hand of communion, that we might go to the Gentiles, and they to the circumcised.
They only asked us to remember the poor, which I also did with zeal.
But when Peter came to Antioch, I resisted him to his face, because he was condemned.
Indeed, before people came from James, he ate with the pagans. But when they came, he withdrew and stood aside, fearing those who were of circumcision.
And the other Jews joined him in his hypocrisy, so that Barnabas himself allowed himself to be carried away by their hypocrisy.
Seeing that they did not walk upright according to the truth of the Good News, I said to Peter, in the presence of all, "If you, who are a Jew, live like the Gentiles and not like the Jews, why do you force the Gentiles to live like the Jews?
We, who are Jews by nature and not sinful pagans,
yet knowing that it is not by the works of the law that man is justified, but by faith in Jesus Christ, we also believed in Jesus Christ, that we might be justified by faith in Christ and not by the works of the law, for no flesh shall be justified by the works of the law.
But if, while we were seeking justification in Christ, we too were found to be sinners, is Christ a servant of sin? Certainly not!
For if I rebuild what I have destroyed, I myself am a transgressor of the law.
For by the law I have died to the law, that I might live for God.
