I was crucified with Christ, and it is no longer I who live, but Christ who lives in me. The life I now lead in the flesh I lead by faith in the Son of God, who loved me and gave himself up for me.
I do not reject the grace of God. For if righteousness comes through the law, then Christ died for nothing! »
Foolish Galatians, who bewitched you so that you would not obey the truth, and before whose eyes Jesus Christ was openly presented in your midst as crucified?
I want to learn this from you: Have you received the Spirit by the works of the law, or by the hearing of faith?
Are you so foolish? After beginning in the Spirit, are you now finished in the flesh?
Have you suffered so many things in vain, if it is in vain?
Whosoever furnishes you with the Spirit, and works miracles in your midst, does he do it by the works of the law, or by the hearing of faith?
In the same way, Abraham "believed in God, and this was counted to him for righteousness."
Know therefore that those who have faith are children of Abraham.
The Scripture, foreseeing that God would justify the Gentiles by faith, announced the Good News beforehand to Abraham, saying, "In you all nations shall be blessed."
So then, those who have faith are blessed with the faithful Abraham.
For all those who practice the works of the law are under the curse. For it is written, "Cursed is everyone who does not do all that is written in the book of the law."
Now it is evident that no one is justified before God by the law, for it is written, "The righteous shall live by faith."
The law is not of faith, but, "The man who does them shall live by them."
Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law, having become a curse for us. For it is written: "Cursed is everyone who hangs from a tree."
that the blessing of Abraham may come upon the Gentiles through Jesus Christ, that we may receive by faith the promise of the Spirit.
Brethren, in human terms, although it is only a covenant of man, when it has been confirmed, no one cancels it or adds to it.
Now the promises were made to Abraham and his descendants. He does not say, "To one offspring, as to many, but as to one, 'To your descendants,' which is Christ."
Now I say this: A covenant confirmed beforehand by God in Christ, the law, which came four hundred and thirty years after, does not annul it, so as to render the promise ineffective.
For if the inheritance comes from the law, it no longer comes from the promise; but God granted it to Abraham by promise.
So why does the law exist? It was added because of transgressions, until the seed to whom the promise was made came. It was ordained by angels, by the hand of a mediator.
Now, there is no mediator between the one and the other, but God is one.
Is the law, then, against God's promises? Certainly not! For if there had been given a law that could give life, most certainly justice would have been of the law.
But Scripture has imprisoned all things under sin, that the promise by faith in Jesus Christ might be given to those who believe.
But before faith came, we were kept under the law, locked up for the faith that was to be revealed next.
So that the law became our preceptor to bring us to Christ, that we might be justified by faith.
But now that faith has come, we are no longer under a guardian.
For you are all children of God, through faith in Jesus Christ.
For all of you who have been baptized into Christ have put on Christ.
There is no longer Jew or Greek, there is no longer slave or freeman, there is no longer male or female, for you are all one in Christ Jesus.
If you belong to Christ, then you are the seed of Abraham and the heirs according to the promise.
But I say that as long as the heir is a child, he is no different from a slave, although he is the master of everything,
but he is under the guardianship and stewardship until the day fixed by the father.
Thus, we too, when we were children, were enslaved to the elementary principles of the world.
But when the time was fulfilled, God sent his Son, born of a woman, born under the law,
that he might redeem those who were under the law, that we might be adopted as children.
And because you are children, God has sent into your hearts the Spirit of his Son, who cries out, "Abba, Father!"
Thus you are no longer slaves, but sons; and if you are a son, you are heirs of God through Christ.
But at that time, not knowing God, you were enslaved to those who, by nature, are not gods.
But now that you have come to know God, or rather to be known by God, why do you return to the elementary, weak and miserable principles to which you want to be enslaved again?
You observe the days, months, seasons, and years.
I fear for you that I have wasted my work for you.
I beg you, brothers, become like me, for I too have become like you. You have done me no wrong,
but you know that it was because of my weakness in the flesh that I preached the Good News to you the first time.
What was a temptation to you in my flesh, you have neither despised nor rejected; but you received me as an angel of God, as Christ Jesus.
What was the blessing you received? For I testify to you that, if it had been possible, you would have plucked out your eyes and given them to me.
Have I become your enemy by telling you the truth?
They do not zealously seek you out with good intentions. No, they want to take you away, so that you will look for them.
But it is always good to be zealous for a good cause, and not only when I am present with you.
My little children, for whom I am still in labor until Christ is formed in you -
But I would like to be present with you now, and change my tone, because I am perplexed about you.
Tell me, you who want to be under the law, do you not listen to the law?
For it is written that Abraham had two sons, one by the handmaid, the other by the free woman.
Now the son of the slave was born according to the flesh, but the son of the free woman was born by promise.
These things contain an allegory, for they are two covenants. One is that of Mount Sinai, bearing children to bondage, which is Hagar.
For this Hagar is Mount Sinai in Arabia, and she corresponds to the present Jerusalem, for she is in bondage with her children.
But the Jerusalem above is free, it is the mother of us all.
For it is written, "Rejoice, you barren who do not give birth. Go out and shout, you who are not working. For the desolate woman has more children than the one who has a husband. »
We, brethren, are, like Isaac, children of promise.
But just as then he who was born according to the flesh persecuted him who was born according to the Spirit, so it is now.
Now, what does Scripture say? "Drive out the handmaid and her son, for the son of the handmaid shall not inherit with the son of the free woman."
Therefore, brothers, we are not children of the handmaid, but of the free woman.
Stand firm therefore in the freedom by which Christ has freed us, and do not allow yourselves to be caught again under the yoke of servitude.
Behold, I, Paul, say to you, that if you receive circumcision, Christ will be of no use to you.
Yes, I also testify to every man who receives circumcision that he is indebted to the whole law.
You are strangers to Christ, you who want to be justified by the law. You have fallen from grace.
For we, by the Spirit, wait by faith for the hope of righteousness.
For in Christ Jesus neither circumcision nor uncircumcision have any value, but faith acting through charity.
You were running well! Who has meddled with you so that you do not obey the truth?
This persuasion does not come from the one who calls you.
A little yeast grows throughout the mass.
I trust in you, in the Lord, that you will not think otherwise. But whoever troubles you will pass judgment, whatever it may be.
But I, brethren, if I still preach circumcision, why am I still persecuted? Then the stumbling block of the cross was removed.
I would like those who disturb you to cut themselves off.
For you, brethren, have been called to freedom. Only, do not use your freedom as an opportunity for the flesh, but, out of love, be servants of one another.
For the whole law is fulfilled in one word, in this: "You shall love your neighbor as yourself."
But if you bite and devour one another, take care that you do not consume one another.
But I say, walk by the Spirit, and you will not fulfill the lust of the flesh.
For the flesh has desires contrary to those of the Spirit, and the Spirit to those of the flesh; and these desires are contrary to each other, so that you do not do what you will.
But if you are led by the Spirit, you are not under the law.
Now the deeds of the flesh are manifest, they are adultery, fornication, impurity, lust,
idolatry, magic, hatred, quarrels, jealousies, outbursts, rivalries, divisions, heresies,
envy, murders, drunkenness, orgies, and the like; of which I warn you, as I have also warned you, that those who practice such things will not inherit the kingdom of God.
But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, patience, goodness, benevolence, faith,
gentleness and self-control. Against such things, there is no law.
Those who belong to Christ have crucified the flesh with its passions and lusts.
If we live by the Spirit, let us also walk by the Spirit.
Let's not get big-headed, let's not provoke each other, let's not envy each other.
Brethren, if a man is found to be at fault, you who are spiritual, restore him in a spirit of meekness, taking heed of yourselves, so that you too may not be tempted.
Bear one another's burdens, and thus you will fulfill the law of Christ.
For if someone thinks he is something when he is nothing, he is deceiving himself.
Let each one examine his own work, and he will have reason to glory in himself, and not in another.
For each one will bear his own burden.
But let him who is instructed by the word share all good things with him who teaches.
Make no mistake. God is not mocked, for what man sows, he will also reap.
For he who sows for his own flesh will reap corruption from the flesh. But he who sows for the Spirit will reap eternal life through the Spirit.
Let us not tire of doing good, for we will reap in due time, if we do not grow weary.
Therefore, according to the opportunity given us, let us do good to all men, and especially to those in the house of faith.
See with what large letters I write to you in my own hand.
All those who want to make a good impression in the flesh require you to be circumcised, so that you will not be persecuted for the cross of Christ.
For the circumcised themselves do not keep the law, but they want to have you circumcised, so that they may glory in your flesh.
But far be it from me to glory in it, except in the cross of our Lord Jesus Christ, by which the world was crucified for me, and I for the world.
For in Jesus Christ there is no longer circumcision or uncircumcision, but a new creation.
All who walk according to this rule, peace and mercy be upon them, and upon the Israel of God.
From now on, let no one make any difficulty for me, for I bear on my body the marks of the Lord Jesus.
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit, my brethren. Amen.
Paul, apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, to the saints who are in Ephesus, and to the faithful in Jesus Christ:
Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who has blessed us with every spiritual blessing in the heavenly places in Christ,
as he chose us in himself before the foundation of the world, that we might be holy and without blemish before him in love,
having predestined us to adoption as children by Jesus Christ to himself, according to the good pleasure of his desire,
to the praise of the glory of his grace, by which he has freely favored us in the Beloved.
In him we have our redemption through his blood, the forgiveness of our trespasses, according to the riches of his grace
whom he has caused to abound towards us in all wisdom and prudence,
by making known to us the mystery of his will, according to the good pleasure which he willed in him,
until the administration of the fulness of times, to sum up in him all things in Christ, those which are in heaven and those which are on earth.
We have also received an inheritance in him, having been predestined according to the purpose of him who does all things according to the counsel of his will,
that we may be to the praise of his glory, we who had previously hoped in Christ.
In him you also, after hearing the word of truth, the Good News of your salvation, and having believed, were sealed with the promised Holy Spirit,
which is the pledge of our inheritance, for the redemption of the property of God, to the praise of his glory.
Therefore I also, having learned faith in the Lord Jesus who is among you, and the love you have for all the saints,
I do not cease to give thanks for you, mentioning you in my prayers,
that the God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of glory, may give you a spirit of wisdom and revelation in his knowledge,
enlightening the eyes of your hearts, that you may know what is the hope of his calling, and what are the riches of the glory of his inheritance in the saints,
and what is the immensity of his power towards us who believe, according to the operation of the force of his power
which he worked in Christ by raising him from the dead and making him sit at his right hand in the heavenly places,
far above all dominion, all authority, all power, all power, and all name that is named, not only in this century, but also in the one to come.
He has subdued all things under his feet, and has made him head of all things for the Church,
which is his body, the fullness of Him who fills all in all.
You became alive, when you were dead in your transgressions and in your sins,
in which you once walked according to the course of this world, according to the prince of the power of the air, the spirit that now works in the children of disobedience.
We too all once lived among them in the lusts of our flesh, fulfilling the desires of the flesh and of the intellect, and we were by nature children of wrath, like the others.
But God, rich in mercy, because of the great love with which he has loved us,
when we were dead by our trespasses, made us alive with Christ – by grace you were saved –
he raised us up with him, and made us sit with him in heavenly places in Christ Jesus,
in order to show in the ages to come the immense richness of his grace in goodness to us in Jesus Christ;
For by grace you were saved, through faith, and it is not from you; it is the gift of God,
and not of works, so that no one may boast.
For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus for good works, which God has prepared beforehand, that we may do them.
Remember, then, that in the past you, pagans in the flesh, called uncircumcised by what is called circumcision (in the flesh, made with hands),
you were at that time separated from Christ, strangers to the community of Israel, strangers to the covenants of promise, without hope and without God in the world.
But now, in Christ Jesus, you who were once far away, have become near through the blood of Christ.
For it is he who is our peace, who has made one and the other one being, and who has broken down the wall of separation,
having abolished in his flesh enmity, the law of the commandments contained in the ordinances, in order to create in himself one new man from the two, making peace,
and to reconcile them both in one body with God by the cross, having by it killed enmity.
He has come to proclaim peace to you who are far away and to those who are near.
For it is through him that we have access to the Father in one Spirit.
Therefore you are no longer strangers and people of the land, but you are fellow-citizens of the saints and of the house of God.
being built upon the foundation of the apostles and prophets, Jesus Christ himself being the chief cornerstone,
in whom the whole edifice, adjusting itself to one another, rises to form a holy temple in the Lord,
in whom you are also built up to be a dwelling place of God in the Spirit.
Therefore I, Paul, am the prisoner of Jesus Christ in your behalf, you Gentiles,
if you have heard of the administration of the grace of God which has been given to me towards you,
how, by revelation, the mystery was revealed to me, as I have written before in a few words,
by which, when you read, you can perceive my understanding in the mystery of Christ,
who, in other generations, has not been revealed to the children of men, as he has now been to his holy apostles and prophets in the Spirit,
namely, that the Gentiles are joint-heirs and joint-heirs of the body, and that they have a share in its promise in Christ Jesus through the Good News,
of whom I have been made a servant according to the gift of the grace of God which has been granted to me according to the operation of his power.
To me, the least of all the saints, was given this grace to proclaim to the Gentiles the unfathomable riches of Christ,
and to make known to all the administration of the mystery hidden for centuries in God, who created all things through Jesus Christ,
so that now, through the assembly, the manifold wisdom of God may be revealed to the principalities and powers in the heavenly places,
according to the eternal purpose which he has accomplished in Christ Jesus our Lord.
In Him, we have assurance and trusting access through our faith in Him.
Therefore I ask that you do not lose heart because of my sorrows for you, who are your glory.
Therefore I bow my knees before the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ,
from whom every family in heaven and on earth takes its name,
that he may grant you, according to the riches of his glory, to be strengthened with power by his Spirit in the inward person,
that Christ may dwell in your hearts by faith, that, rooted and founded in love,
you may be strengthened to understand with all the saints what is the breadth, the length, the height, and the depth,
and to know the love of Christ, which surpasses all knowledge, that you may be filled with all the fullness of God.
Now, to him who can do infinitely more than all that we ask or think, according to the power that acts in us,
to him be glory in the assembly and in Christ Jesus, for all generations, forever and ever. Amen.
I, therefore, a prisoner in the Lord, beg you to walk in a manner worthy of the call to which you have been called,
in all humility, with patience, bearing with one another in charity,
striving to preserve the unity of the Spirit by the bond of peace.
There is one body and one Spirit, as also you have been called in one hope of your calling,
one Lord, one faith, one baptism,
one God and Father of all, who is above all, through all and in all of us.
But to each one of us, grace has been given according to the measure of Christ's gift.
That is why he says, "When he ascended into heaven, he led captivity into captivity, and gave gifts to the people."
Now, this sentence, "He ascended," what does it mean, if not that He first descended into the depths of the earth?
He who came down is the one who also ascended far above all the heavens, in order to fill all things.
He gave some as apostles, others as prophets, others as evangelists, others as shepherds and teachers;
for the perfecting of the saints for the work of service, for the building up of the body of Christ,
until we have all come to the unity of the faith and the knowledge of the Son of God, to the state of a complete man, to the measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ,
so that we may no longer be children, tossed about and carried away by every wind of doctrine, by the cunning of men, by artifices, according to the ways of error;
but that, speaking the truth in charity, we may grow in all things towards him who is the head, Christ,
from which the whole body, adjusted and welded together by what each joint furnishes, according to the work in measure of each individual part, makes the body grow for its edification in charity.
Therefore I say and testify in the Lord that you no longer walk like the rest of the Gentiles, in the futility of their thoughts,
being obscured in their understanding, far from the life of God because of the ignorance that is in them, because of the hardness of their hearts.
Having become insensitive, they gave themselves up to covetousness, to commit all kinds of impurities with greed.
But this is not how you learned Christ,
if you have heard him and have been instructed in him, as the truth is in Jesus:
that you get rid of the old man who corrupts himself according to the lusts of deceit as far as your old way of life is concerned,
that you may be renewed in the spirit of your understanding,
and that you put on the new man, who, in the likeness of God, was created in the righteousness and holiness of truth.
Therefore, renouncing lies, speak the truth to each other, for we are members of one another.
"Be angry, and sin not." Don't let the sun set on your anger,
and do not give in to the devil.
Let him who flew no longer steal; but let him rather work, producing with his hands something good, that he may have something to give to him who is in need.
Let no corrupt speech come out of your mouth, but only that which is good for edifying others according to need, so that it may be gracious to those who hear.
Do not grieve the Holy Spirit of God, in which you were sealed for the day of redemption.
Let all bitterness, all wrath, all anger, all protest and all calumny be removed from you, with all malice.
And be kind to one another, with a tender heart, forgiving one another, as God also in Christ has forgiven you.
Be imitators, therefore, of God, as beloved children.
Walk in love, as Christ also loved us and gave himself up for us, as an offering and a sacrifice to God, in a sweet-smelling perfume.
But sexual immorality, and all impurity or lust, let not be mentioned among you, as befits saints;
nor defilements, nor foolish words, nor jests, which are not proper, but rather thanksgiving.
Know for sure that no sexually immoral person, no impure person, no greedy man (who is an idolater), has an inheritance in the Kingdom of Christ and God.
Let no one deceive you with vain words, for it is because of these things that the wrath of God comes upon the children of disobedience.
Therefore have no part with them.
For you were once darkness, but now you are light in the Lord. Walk like children of light,
for the fruit of the Spirit is in all goodness, in all righteousness, and in truth,
proving what is pleasing to the Lord.
Do not commune with the fruitless actions of darkness, but rather reprove them.
For it is a shame to talk about the things they do in secret.
But all things, when they are reprobated, are revealed by light, for everything that reveals is light.
Therefore he says, "Awake, you who sleep, and rise from the dead, and Christ will shine upon you."
Take heed therefore in the manner in which you walk, not as imprudent, but as wise,
by redeeming time, for the days are bad.
Therefore, do not be foolish, but understand what is the will of the Lord.
Do not let yourselves be intoxicated by wine, which is a source of dissipation, but be filled with the Spirit,
speaking to one another in psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs, singing and making your hearts sound to the Lord,
always giving thanks to God the Father for all things, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ,
submitting yourselves to one another in the fear of Christ.
Wives, be subject to your husbands, as to the Lord.
For the husband is the head of the wife, as also Christ is the head of the assembly, being himself the saviour of the body.
Now, as the congregation is subject to Christ, so wives must be subject to their husbands in all things.
Husbands, love your wives, as Christ loved the church and gave himself up for her,
in order to sanctify it, after having purified it by bathing it with water with the word,
to present to himself the glorious Church, without spot, wrinkle, or anything of the kind, but holy and without blemish.
Similarly, husbands must love their wives as their own bodies. He who loves his own wife loves himself.
For no man has ever hated his own flesh, but feeds and cherishes it, as the Lord also does for the congregation,
because we are members of his body, flesh and bones.
"Therefore a man will leave his father and mother and cleave to his wife. Then the two will become one flesh. »
This mystery is great, but I speak about Christ and the congregation.
Nevertheless, let each of you love his own wife as himself, and let the wife see that she respects her husband.
Children, obey your parents in the Lord, for this is right.
"Honor your father and your mother," which is the first commandment with a promise:
"That you may be happy and live long on earth."
Fathers, do not provoke your children to anger, but bring them up in the discipline and instruction of the Lord.
Servants, be obedient to those who, according to the flesh, are your masters, with fear and trembling, in the simplicity of your hearts, as to Christ,
not by serving only when the eyes are on you, as pleasure-seekers, but as servants of Christ, doing with all your heart the will of God,
of good will, rendering service to the Lord and not to men,
knowing that, whatever good each one does, he will again receive the same good from the Lord, whether bound or free.
You, masters, do the same with regard to them, and renounce the threat, knowing that he who is both their master and yours is in heaven, and that there is no partiality in him.
Finally, be strong in the Lord and in the strength of his power.
Put on all the armor of God, that you may be able to resist the wiles of the devil.
For it is not against flesh and blood that we are fighting, but against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the world, against the darkness of this world, and against the spiritual forces of wickedness in the heavenly places.
Wherefore, clothe yourselves with all the armor of God, that ye may be able to resist the evil day, and, after having done all, to stand firm.
Stand then, having fastened the girdle of truth at your waist, and put on the breastplate of righteousness,
Having shod your feet with the preparation of the Good News of peace,
and above all, taking up the shield of faith, with which you can extinguish all the fiery darts of the evil one.
And take up the helmet of salvation, and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God;
making all kinds of prayers and petitions, praying at all times by the Spirit, and watching for this end in all perseverance and making requests for all the saints.
Pray for me, that it may be given to me to open my mouth, to make known with boldness the mystery of the Good News,
of which I am the ambassador in chains, that I may speak boldly, as I ought to do.
But that you may also know how I am, Tychicus, beloved brother and faithful servant in the Lord, will make all things known to you.
It is for this purpose that I have sent it to you, that you may know our state and that it may comfort your hearts.
Peace be with the brethren, and love with faith, from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
May grace be with all those who love our Lord Jesus Christ with incorruptible love. Amen.
Paul and Timothy, servants of Jesus Christ, to all the saints in Christ Jesus who are in Philippi, with the overseers and servants:
Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
I give thanks to my God every time I remember you,
always in all the requests that I make on behalf of you all, presenting them with joy,
for the collaboration you have given in the proclamation of the Good News from the first day until now,
knowing that he who has begun a good work in you will finish it until the day of Jesus Christ.
It is even right that I should think thus in favor of all of you, for I carry you in my heart, since, both in my bonds and in the defense and confirmation of the Good News, you all share in grace with me.
For God is my witness that I desire you all in the tender mercies of Jesus Christ.
I beg you to make your love increase more and more in knowledge and discernment,
that you may approve of good things, that you may be sincere and blameless in the day of Christ,
being filled with the fruits of righteousness which are through Jesus Christ, to the glory and praise of God.
Now, brethren, I want you to know that what has happened to me has rather contributed to the progress of the Good News,
so that it became evident to all the guard of the palace and to all others that my bonds are in Christ,
and that most of the brethren in the Lord, trusting because of my bonds, have more audacity to proclaim the word of God without fear.
For there are some who preach Christ even out of envy and quarrel, and others also out of good will.
The former preach Christ without conviction, out of ambition, thinking that they add sorrow to my chains;
but the latter, out of love, knowing that I am appointed for the defense of the Good News.
What does that matter? Only that in every way, whether in appearance or in truth, Christ be proclaimed. I am delighted with it, yes, and I will rejoice.
For I know that through your prayers and the bringing of the Spirit of Jesus Christ, it will result in my salvation,
according to my earnest expectation and hope, that I shall not be disappointed in the least, but that in all boldness, as always, now also Christ will be magnified in my body, either by life or by death.
For to me, to live is Christ, and to die is to gain.
But if I live in the flesh, it will yield the fruit of my labor; but I don't know what I will choose.
But I am torn between the two, having the desire to leave and be with Christ, which is much better.
But it is more necessary, for your sake, to remain in the flesh.
Having this assurance, I know that I will remain, yes, and that I will remain with you all for your progress and joy in the faith,
so that your boasting may abound in Jesus Christ in me, through my coming presence among you.
Only, let your way of life be worthy of the Good News of Christ, so that, whether I come to see you or I am absent, I may hear of your state, that you stand firm in one mind, with one soul, striving for the faith of the Good News;
and in no way frightened by the adversaries, which is for them a proof of destruction, but for you of salvation, and that from God.
For it has been granted to you, in the name of Christ, not only to believe in him, but also to suffer in his name,
by having the same conflict that you saw in me and now hear it in me.
If, then, there be any exhortation in Christ, any consolation of love, any fellowship of the Spirit, any tenderness and compassion,
fill my joy by being animated by the same feelings, the same love, the same agreement, the same thought;
doing nothing out of rivalry or vanity, but with humility, each one counting the others better than himself;
each of you not only looking at your own things, but also at those of others.
Have this thought within you, which was also that of Jesus Christ,
who, existing in the form of God, did not consider equality with God as a thing to be grasped,
but stripped himself, taking the form of a servant, being made in the likeness of men.
And having been found in human form, he humbled himself, becoming obedient unto death, yes, the death of the cross.
Therefore God has exalted him supremely and given him the name which is above every name,
so that at the name of Jesus every knee may bow in heaven, on earth and under the earth,
and let every tongue confess that Jesus Christ is Lord, to the glory of God the Father.
Therefore, my beloved, as you have always obeyed, not only in my presence, but now much more in my absence, work for your own salvation with fear and trembling.
For it is God who acts in you, both to will and to do, according to his good pleasure.
Do all things without complaining and without arguing,
that you may become blameless and harmless, children of God without blemish in the midst of a crooked and perverse generation, in the midst of which you are seen as lights in the world,
upholding the word of life, that I might boast in the day of Christ that I had not run in vain or labored in vain.
Yes, and if I am poured out on the sacrifice and service of your faith, I am happy and rejoice with you all.
In the same way, you also rejoice and rejoice with me.
But I hope in the Lord Jesus that he will soon send you Timothy, so that I too may be comforted when I know how you are.
Because I don't have anyone else who has the same feelings as me and who is really interested in you.
For all seek their own interests, and not those of Jesus Christ.
But you know that it has proven itself. As a child serves his father, he has served with me to advance the Good News.
That's why I hope to send it right away, as soon as I see how it goes for me.
But I trust in the Lord, for I too will come soon.
But I have deemed it necessary to send you Epaphroditus, my brother, my fellow worker, my comrade-in-arms, your apostle, and my servant in need,
for he desired you all, and he was very anxious because you had heard that he was ill.
For he was sick almost to death, but God had mercy on him, and not only on him, but also on me, so that I might not have sorrow upon sorrow.
I have therefore sent it with all the more diligence because, when you see it again, you will rejoice and I will be less sad.
Receive him therefore in the Lord with all joy, and honor such men,
for, for the work of Christ, he came close to death, at the risk of his life, to make up for what was lacking in your service to me.
Finally, my brethren, rejoice in the Lord! Writing the same things to you, to me certainly is not tiring, but for you it is certain.
Beware of dogs, beware of bad workmen, beware of false circumcision.
For we are the circumcision, who worship God by the Spirit, who rejoice in Christ Jesus, and who have no trust in the flesh,
even if I had confidence in the flesh. If anyone else thinks they trust in the flesh, I even more:
circumcised on the eighth day, of the race of Israel, of the tribe of Benjamin, Hebrew of Hebrews, Pharisee as to the law,
persecutor of the Church as far as zeal is concerned, irreproachable as regards the justice of the law.
However, I consider the things that have been acquired for me to be a loss to Christ.
Yes, assuredly, and I regard everything as a loss, because of the excellence of the knowledge of Jesus Christ, my Lord, for whom I have suffered the loss of all things, and I regard them only as waste, in order to gain Christ
and to be found in him, not having a righteousness of my own, that of the law, but that which comes from faith in Christ, the righteousness that comes from God by faith,
that I may know him, and the power of his resurrection, and the fellowship of his sufferings, becoming conformed to his death,
if I can, by any means, attain to the resurrection of the dead.
Not that I have already obtained, or that I am already perfect; but I persevere, in order to grasp what I have been seized by Jesus Christ.
Brethren, I do not yet consider myself to have gained a foothold, but I do know one thing: forgetting what is behind and clinging to what is ahead,
I strive to attain the goal for the prize of God's high calling in Jesus Christ.
Let us therefore think thus, all of us who are perfect. If, in anything, you think otherwise, God will reveal it to you too.
Nevertheless, insofar as we have already arrived, let us proceed according to the same rule. Let us have the same spirit.
Brethren, be imitators of me together, and observe those who walk in this way, as you have us for an example.
For many walk, of whom I have often spoken to you, and of whom I speak to you now weeping, like the enemies of the cross of Christ,
whose end is perdition, whose god is the belly, and whose glory is in their shame, who think of earthly things.
For our city is in heaven, from which we also look for a Saviour, the Lord Jesus Christ,
who will transform the body of our humiliation to make it conform to the body of his glory, according to the operation by which he can even subjugate all things to himself.
Wherefore, my brethren, beloved and desired, my joy and crown, stand firm in the Lord in this way, my beloved.
I exhort Euodia, and I exhort Syntyche, to think the same in the Lord.
Yes, I beg you also, faithful partner, help these women, for they have worked with me in the Good News, with Clement too, and the rest of my fellow workers, whose names are in the book of life.
Rejoice in the Lord always! I will also say: "Rejoice!"
Let your gentleness be known to all men. The Lord is near.
Do not worry about anything, but in all things, by prayer and request, with thanksgiving, make your requests known to God.
And the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and minds in Christ Jesus.
Finally, brethren, all that is true, all that is honorable, all that is just, all that is pure, all that is beautiful, all that is of good repute, if there is any virtue and if there is anything worthy of praise, think of these things.
Do what you have learned, received, heard, and seen in me, and the God of peace will be with you.
But I rejoice greatly in the Lord that now at last you have revived your thoughts for me, which you were indeed thinking of, but you lacked the opportunity.
Not that I speak for lack of it, for I have learned, in whatever state I may be, to be content with it.
I know how to be humiliated, and I also know how to abound. In every circumstance, I have learned the secret of being full and hungry, of being in abundance and of being in need.
I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.
Now you have done well to share my affliction.
You yourselves know, Philippians, that at the beginning of the Good News, when I left Macedonia, no congregation participated with me in the giving and reception, except you.
For, even in Thessaloniki, you have always met my needs.
Not that I am looking for the gift, but I am looking for the fruit that increases on your account.
But I have everything and I abound. I am satisfied, having received from Epaphroditus that which comes from thee, a pleasant odor, a pleasing and satisfying sacrifice unto God.
My God will provide for all your needs, according to his riches in glory in Christ Jesus.
To our God and Father be the glory for ever and ever! Amen.
Greet every saint in Jesus Christ. The brothers who are with me greet you.
All the saints greet you, especially those who are of the house of Caesar.
The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.
Paul, apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, and Timothy, our brother,
To the holy and faithful brethren in Christ who are in Colossae: Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
We give thanks to God, the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, always praying for you,
having heard of your faith in Jesus Christ and of the love you have for all the saints,
because of the hope that is reserved for you in heaven, and of which you have heard before in the word of truth of the Good News
which has come to you, as it is in all the world, and bears fruit and grows, as it also grows in you, since the day you heard and knew the grace of God in the truth,
as you have learned from Epaphras, our beloved companion in service, faithful servant of Christ on your behalf,
who also declared to us your love in the Spirit.
Wherefore, we also, from the day we learned, have not ceased to pray and ask for you, that you may be filled with the knowledge of his will in all spiritual wisdom and understanding,
that you may walk in a manner worthy of the Lord, to please Him in every respect, bearing fruit in every good work, and increasing in the knowledge of God,
strengthened with all might, according to the power of his glory, for all endurance and perseverance in joy,
giving thanks to the Father, who has enabled us to share in the inheritance of the saints in the light,
who delivered us from the power of darkness and carried us into the kingdom of the Son of his love,
in whom we have our redemption, the forgiveness of our sins.
He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn of all creation.
For by him all things were created in heaven and on earth, visible things and invisible things, whether they be thrones, dominions, principalities, or powers. All things were created by him and for him.
He is before all things, and all things subsist in him.
He is the head of the body, of the assembly, he who is the beginning, the firstborn from the dead, in order to have pre-eminence in all things.
For it pleased all the fullness to dwell in him,
and to reconcile all things to Himself through him, both those on earth and those in heaven, having established peace through the blood of his cross.
You who were once alienated and enemies in your minds by your evil deeds,
He has now reconciled you by death in the body of his flesh, in order to present you holy, blameless, and without blemish before him,
if at least you persevere in the faith, grounded and unshakeable, without turning away from the hope of the Good News which you have heard and which is proclaimed in all creation under heaven, of which I, Paul, have been made servants.
Now I rejoice in my sufferings for your sake, and I make up for what is lacking in the sufferings of Christ in my flesh, for the sake of his body, which is the congregation,
of whom I have been made a servant according to the office of God entrusted to me to you for the fulfillment of the word of God,
a mystery hidden for centuries and generations. But now he has been revealed to his saints,
to whom God has willed to make known what is the richness of the glory of this mystery among the Gentiles, which is Christ in you, the hope of glory.
We proclaim it, exhorting every man and instructing him in all wisdom, that we may make every man perfect in Christ Jesus.
This is what I also strive to do, according to his operation which acts powerfully in me.
For I want you to know how much I strive for you, for those of Laodicea, and for all those who have not seen my face in the flesh;
that their hearts may be comforted, that they may be united in charity, and that they may acquire all the riches of the full assurance of understanding, to know the mystery of God, of the Father, and of Christ,
in whom are hidden all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge.
Now, I say this so that no one can deceive you with persuasive speeches.
For, though I am absent in the flesh, I am with you in the spirit, rejoicing, and seeing your order, and the steadfastness of your faith in Christ.
Therefore, as you have received the Lord Jesus Christ, walk in him,
rooted and edified in him, and established in the faith, as you have learned, by giving thanks to it.
Take heed that no one robs you by his philosophy and vain deception, according to the tradition of men, according to the elementary spirits of the world, and not according to Christ.
For in him dwells bodily all the fullness of the divinity,
and in him you are filled, he who is the head of all principality and power.
In him you were also circumcised with a circumcision that was not done with hands, in the stripping of the body from the sins of the flesh, according to the circumcision of Christ,
having been buried with him in baptism, in which you also rose with him by faith in the action of God, who raised him from the dead.
You were dead by your sins and by the uncircumcision of your flesh. He has made you live with him, forgiving us all our trespasses,
by erasing the writing of the ordinances that was against us. He took her from the way, nailing her to the cross.
Having despoiled the principalities and powers, he openly made a spectacle of them, thereby triumphing over them.
Let no one judge you, therefore, in regard to eating or drinking, or in regard to a feast day, a new moon, or a Sabbath day,
who are a shadow of things to come; but the body is Christ's.
Let no one rob you of your prize by humbling himself and prostrating himself before the angels, by clinging to what he has not seen, by vainly puffing himself up with a carnal spirit,
and by not attaching himself firmly to the head, from which the whole body, nourished and united by the joints and ligaments, grows according to the growth of God.
If you have died with Christ to the elemental spirits of the world, why, as if you were living in the world, do you submit to ordinances,
"Do not touch, nor taste, nor touch"
(which all perish with use), according to the precepts and doctrines of men?
For these things have the appearance of wisdom in self-imposed worship, in humility, and in severity toward the body, but they have no value against the complacency of the flesh.
If, therefore, you have been raised with Christ, seek the things above, where is Christ, seated at the right hand of God.
Fix your thoughts on the things above, and not on those that are on earth.
For you are dead, and your life is hidden with Christ in God.
When Christ, our life, appears, you will also appear with him in glory.
Therefore put to death your members who are on earth: sexual immorality, impurity, depraved passion, evil desire, greed, which is idolatry.
It is because of these things that the wrath of God comes upon the children of disobedience.
You also walked in these things in the past, when you lived in these things,
but now you must cast them all away: anger, anger, malice, calumny, and the shameful words that come out of your mouth.
Do not lie to one another, since you have stripped the old man and his deeds,
and that you have put on the new man, who is renewed in knowledge, in the image of his Creator,
where there is neither Greek nor Jew, neither circumcised nor uncircumcised, neither barbarian nor Scythian, neither slave nor free, but where Christ is all and in all.
Clothe yourselves, therefore, as God's elect, holy and beloved, with a heart of compassion, goodness, modesty, humility, and perseverance;
bear with one another, and forgive one another, if anyone has anything to reproach himself with; as Christ has forgiven you, do it too.
Above all these things, walk in love, which is the bond of perfection.
And may the peace of God reign in your hearts, to which you have also been called in one body, and be thankful.
Let the word of Christ dwell richly in you; in all wisdom, teach and exhort one another with psalms, hymns, and spiritual songs, singing to the Lord with grace in your hearts.
Whatever you do, in word or deed, do everything in the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks through him to God the Father.
Wives, be subject to your husbands, as befits the Lord.
Husbands, love your wives, and do not be bitter against them.
Children, obey your parents in all things, for it pleases the Lord.
Fathers, do not provoke your children, so that they may not be discouraged.
Servants, obey in all things those who are your masters according to the flesh, not only when they look, as if to please men, but in simplicity of heart, fearing God.
And whatever you do, work with a good heart, as for the Lord and not for men,
knowing that you will receive from the Lord the reward of the inheritance; for you serve the Lord Christ.
But he who does evil will receive again for the evil he has done, and there is no partiality.
Masters, give to your servants what is just and equal, knowing that you also have a Master in heaven.
Persevere in prayer, watching over it with thanksgiving,
praying together for us too, so that God may open a door for us to speak, to proclaim the mystery of Christ, for which I am also in bonds,
so that I may reveal it as I must say.
Walk in wisdom toward those who are outside, redeeming time.
Let your discourse always be full of grace, seasoned with salt, so that you may know how you should answer each one.
All my affairs will be communicated to you by Tychicus, beloved brother, faithful servant and companion in service in the Lord.
For this purpose I am sending him to you, that he may know your situation and console your hearts,
with Onesimus, the faithful and beloved brother, who is one of you. They will let you know everything that is going on here.
Aristarchus, my companion in captivity, greets you, as well as Mark, the cousin of Barnabas, of whom you have been told: "If he comes to you, receive him."
and Jesus, who is called Justus. These are my only fellow laborers for the kingdom of God, who are circumcision, and who have been of great comfort to me.
Epaphras , who is one of yours , servant of Christ , greets you , always striving to support you in his prayers , that you may be perfect and complete in all the will of God .
For I testify to him that he has great zeal for you, for those of Laodicea and for those of Hierapolis.
Luke, the beloved physician, and Démas greet you.
Greet the brethren who are in Laodicea, with Nymphas, and the congregation that is in his house.
When this letter has been read among you, have it read also in the assembly of the Laodiceans, and let you also read the letter from Laodicea.
Say to Archippus, "Take heed of the ministry which you have received in the Lord, that you may fulfill it."
I, Paul, write this greeting with my own hand. Remember my chains. Grace be with you. Amen.
Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy, to the assembly of the Thessalonians, in God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ: Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
We always give thanks to God for all of you, mentioning you in our prayers,
remembering unceasingly your work of faith, your work of love, and your perseverance of hope in our Lord Jesus Christ, before our God and Father.
We know, brothers loved by God, that you are the elect,
and that our Good News has come to you not only in words, but also in power, and in the Holy Spirit and with great boldness. You know what sort of men we have shown ourselves in your midst because of you.
You have become imitators of us and of the Lord, having received the word in great affliction, with the joy of the Holy Spirit,
so that you have become an example to all who believe in Macedonia and Achaia.
For it is through you that the word of the Lord has been proclaimed, not only in Macedonia and Achaia, but also in every place where your faith in God has spread, so that we have nothing to say.
For they themselves relate to us what reception we have received from you, and how you have been converted from idols to God to serve a living and true God,
and to wait from heaven for his Son, whom he raised from the dead: Jesus, who delivers us from the wrath to come.
As you yourselves, brethren, know that the visit we have made to you has not been in vain,
but, having suffered before and having been shamefully treated, as you know, at Philippi, we have emboldened ourselves in our God to preach to you the Good News of God, in a great conflict.
For our exhortation is not made in error, nor in impurity, nor in deceit.
But just as we have been accepted by God to be charged with the Good News, so we speak, not to please men, but to God, who tests our hearts.
For it has never happened to us to use flattering words, as you know, nor a mantle of lust (God is witness),
nor to seek the glory of men (neither of you nor of others), when we could have claimed authority as apostles of Christ.
But we have been gentle in your midst, like a mother who suckles her children.
Therefore, ardently desiring you, we wanted to communicate to you, not only the Good News of God, but also our own souls, because you had become very dear to us.
You remember, brothers, our work and our pain; for, working night and day, that we may not be a burden to any of you, we have preached to you the Good News of God.
You are witnesses before God of the holiness, justice, and blamelessness with which we have conducted ourselves toward you who believe.
You know, we have exhorted, consoled and begged each one of you, as a father does for his children,
that you may walk in a manner worthy of God, who calls you to his kingdom and glory.
For this reason we also give thanks to God unceasingly for the fact that, when you received from us the word of God's message, you received it not as the word of men, but as the truth, the word of God, which also works in you who believe.
For you, brethren, have become imitators of the assemblies of God which are in Judea in Christ Jesus; for you also have suffered the same things at the hands of your countrymen, as they have done at the hands of the Jews
who have killed the Lord Jesus and their own prophets, and who have cast us out, and who are not pleasing to God, and who are contrary to all men,
preventing us from speaking to the Gentiles so that they may be saved, so that they may always fulfill their sins. But the anger came on them to the extreme.
But we, brethren, deprived of you for a short time, in the presence and not in the heart, have endeavored to see your face with great desire,
for we wanted to come to you, I, Paul, once and again, but Satan prevented us.
For what is our hope, or our joy, or our crown of rejoicing? Is it not you, before our Lord Jesus at his coming?
For you are our glory and our joy.
That is why, unable to bear it any longer, we thought it best to remain alone in Athens,
and we have sent Timothy, our brother and servant of God in the Good News of Christ, to strengthen and comfort you about your faith,
so that no one may be moved by these afflictions. Because you know that we have been appointed for this task.
For when we were with you, we told you beforehand that we were going to suffer affliction, as it happened, and you know it.
Therefore I also, when I could not bear it any longer, sent to know your faith, lest by any means the tempter should tempt you, and our work should be in vain.
But Timothy has just arrived from you, and has brought us the good news of your faith and love, and that you always have a good memory of us, desiring to see us, as we also desire to see you.
Wherefore, brethren, we have been comforted by you in all our distress and affliction, by your faith.
For now we live, if you stand firm in the Lord.
What thanksgiving can we give to God again for you, for all the joy with which we rejoice for your sake before our God,
By praying night and day insistently to see your face and to perfect what is lacking in your faith?
May our God and Father himself, and our Lord Jesus Christ, direct our steps to you.
May the Lord make you grow and abound in love for one another and for all men, as we also do for you,
that he may establish your blameless hearts in holiness before our God and Father, at the coming of our Lord Jesus with all his saints.
Finally, brethren, we beseech and exhort you in the Lord Jesus, so that, as you have received from us the way in which you should walk and please God, you may abound more and more.
For you know what instructions we have given you through the Lord Jesus.
For this is the will of God: your sanctification, by abstaining from all immorality,
so that each one of you may know how to dispose of his body in sanctification and honor,
and not in the passion of lust, like the pagans who do not know God,
so that no one may abuse or injure a brother or sister in this matter; for the Lord is the avenger in all these things, as we have also announced and testified to you.
For God has not called us to impurity, but to sanctification.
Therefore he who rejects this does not reject man, but God, who has also given you his Holy Spirit.
But as for brotherly love, you don't need to be written to. For you yourselves are instructed by God to love one another,
which you do to all the brethren who are in all Macedonia. But we exhort you, brethren, to abound more and more,
and to apply yourselves to leading a quiet life, to do your own business, and to work with your own hands, as we have taught you,
so that you may behave well towards those outside and have need of nothing.
But we do not want you, brethren, to be ignorant about those who have fallen asleep, so that you may not grieve like others, who have no hope.
For if we believe that Jesus died and rose again, so God will bring back with him those who have fallen asleep in Jesus.
For we say to you according to the word of the Lord, we who are alive, who remain until the coming of the Lord, will not precede those who have fallen asleep.
For the Lord himself will come down from heaven with a loud cry, at the voice of the archangel and at the sound of the trumpet of God. The dead in Christ will rise first,
then we who are alive, who are left, will be caught up together with them in clouds, to meet the Lord in the air. So we will be with the Lord forever.
Console one another, therefore, with these words.
But as for the times and seasons, brothers, you do not need to be written to you.
For you yourselves know well that the day of the Lord comes like a thief in the night.
For when they say, "Peace and security," a sudden ruin will surprise them, like the pains of childbirth for a pregnant woman. And they will have no chance of escaping.
But you, brethren, are not in darkness, so that the day may overtake you like a thief.
You are all children of light and children of the day. We belong neither to the night nor to the darkness.
Let us not sleep, therefore, like the others, but let us watch and be sober.
For those who sleep sleep in the night, and those who are drunk get drunk in the night.
But since we belong to the day, let us be sober, putting on the breastplate of faith and charity, and the hope of salvation as our helmet.
For God has not ordained us to wrath, but to obtain salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ,
who died for us, so that, awake or asleep, we might live together with him.
Therefore exhort one another, and edify one another, as you also do.
But we beseech you, brethren, to know those who work among you, who are above you in the Lord, and who warn you,
and to respect and honor them with love because of their work. Be at peace with each other.
We exhort you, brethren: Warn the disorderly; encourage the faint-hearted; support the weak; Be patient with everyone.
See to it that no one returns evil for evil, but always seek what is good for the other and for all.
Always rejoice.
Pray without ceasing.
In all things, give thanks, for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus for you.
Do not quench the Spirit.
Do not despise prophecies.
Put everything to the test, and hold fast to what is good.
Abstain from all forms of evil.
May the God of peace himself sanctify you entirely. May your whole mind, soul, and body be preserved unblemished at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.
Whoever calls you is faithful, he will do it too.
Brethren, pray for us.
Greet all the brethren with a holy kiss.
I solemnly command thee by the Lord that this letter be read to all the holy brethren.
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you. Amen.
Paul, Silvanus, and Timothy, to the assembly of the Thessalonians, in God our Father and in the Lord Jesus Christ:
Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
We are bound to give thanks to God always for you, brethren, as is fitting, because your faith grows more and more, and the love of each and every one of you for one another abounds.
so that we boast of you in the assemblies of God for your perseverance and faith in all your persecutions and in the afflictions you endure.
This is a clear sign of God's righteous judgment, that you may be counted worthy of the kingdom of God, for which you also suffer.
For it is right that God should repay affliction to those who afflict you,
and may he relieve you, who are afflicted with us, when the Lord Jesus appears from heaven with his mighty angels in a blazing fire,
to punish those who do not know God and those who do not obey the Good News of our Lord Jesus,
who will pay the price: the eternal destruction of the face of the Lord and the glory of his power,
when he comes in that day to be glorified in his saints and to be admired by all who believe, because our testimony to you has been believed.
Therefore we also always pray for you, that our God may judge you worthy of your vocation, and that he may accomplish with power every desire for goodness and every work of faith,
that the name of our Lord Jesus may be glorified in you, and you in him, according to the grace of our God and of the Lord Jesus Christ.
Now, brethren, concerning the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ and our gathering to him, we ask you
not to be speedily shaken in your mind, nor troubled, either by a spirit, or by a word, or by a letter, as coming from us, saying that the day of Christ has already arrived.
Let no one deceive you in any way. For this will not happen, unless rebellion comes first, and the man of sin is revealed, the son of destruction.
He opposes and rises up against everything that is called God or that which is worshipped, so that he sits as God in the temple of God, setting himself up as God.
Do you not remember that when I was still with you, I told you these things?
You now know what is holding him back, so that he may reveal himself in his own time.
For the mystery of iniquity is already at work. Only, there is one who holds back now, until he is taken out of the way.
Then the ungodly will appear, whom the Lord will put to death by the breath of his mouth, and whom he will destroy by the manifestation of his coming,
the one whose advent is in accordance with the work of Satan, with all mightiness, lying signs and wonders,
and with all the seductions of wickedness to those who are lost, because they have not received the love of the truth, that they may be saved.
Because of this, God sends them a powerful illusion, so that they believe in falsehood,
so that all those who have not believed in the truth, but have taken pleasure in injustice, may be judged.
But we are bound to give thanks to God always for you, beloved brethren of the Lord, because God has chosen you from the beginning for salvation through the sanctification of the Spirit and faith in the truth.
to whom he has called you by our Good News, for the obtaining of the glory of our Lord Jesus Christ.
Therefore, brethren, stand firm and preserve the traditions which we have taught you, either by word or by letter.
Now our Lord Jesus Christ himself, and God our Father, who has loved us and given us by grace eternal consolation and good hope,
comfort your hearts and strengthen you in all good works and words.
Finally, brethren, pray for us, that the word of the Lord may spread quickly and be glorified, as also among you,
and that we may be delivered from unreasonable and wicked men; for not all have faith.
But the Lord is faithful, he will strengthen you and protect you from the evil one.
We trust in the Lord in you, for you do and will do what we command you.
May the Lord direct your hearts in the love of God and in the perseverance of Christ.
Now we command you, brethren, in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, to withdraw yourselves from every brethren who walk in rebellion and not according to the tradition which they have received from us.
For you know how you must imitate us. For we have not behaved among you in a rebellious way,
and we have not eaten bread out of anyone's hand without paying for it, but we have worked night and day with labor and toil, so that we may not be a burden to any of you.
It is not that we have no right to do so, but it is to serve as an example for you, so that you may imitate us.
In fact, when we were with you, we had already given you this order: "If anyone does not want to work, let him not eat".
For we have heard of some who walk among you in revolt, who do not work at all, but who occupy themselves.
Now we ordain and exhort in the Lord Jesus Christ those who are in this way, that they may work quietly and eat their own bread.
But you, brethren, do not tire of doing what is right.
If anyone does not obey what we have said in this letter, note him and do not associate with him, so that he may be ashamed.
Do not consider him an enemy, but exhort him as a brother.
Now, may the Lord of peace Himself give you peace at all times and in every way. The Lord be with you all.
I, Paul, write this greeting with my own hand, which is the sign in every letter. This is how I write.
May the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.
Paul, apostle of Jesus Christ, according to the command of God our Saviour and of the Lord Jesus Christ our hope,
to Timothy, my true child in the faith: Grace, mercy and peace from God our Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.
As I begged you when I was going to Macedonia, remain at Ephesus, that you may command certain men not to teach a different doctrine,
and not to cling to endless myths and genealogies, which provoke disputes rather than to the stewardship of God, who is in the faith.
Now, the purpose of this commandment is love coming from a pure heart, a good conscience, and a sincere faith.
things from which some, having missed the goal, have turned away to give themselves up to vain speeches,
who want to be doctors of the law, although they understand neither what they say nor what they forcefully affirm.
But we know that the law is good, if someone makes legitimate use of it,
knowing that the law was not made for the righteous, but for the ungodly and the insubordinate, for the ungodly and the sinners, for the ungodly and the profane, for the murderers of fathers and the murderers of mothers, for the murderers of men,
for fornicators, for homosexuals, for slaveholders, for liars, for perjurers, and for anything else contrary to sound doctrine,
according to the Good News of the glory of the blessed God, which has been entrusted to me.
I give thanks to him who made me capable, Christ Jesus our Lord, because he numbered me among the faithful, by appointing me to the service,
although I was once a blasphemer, a persecutor, and an insolent. But I have obtained mercy, because I have acted out of ignorance, in unbelief.
The grace of our Lord abounded all the more through the faith and charity that is in Christ Jesus.
The word is faithful and worthy of being received, that Jesus Christ came into the world to save sinners, of whom I am the first.
But that is why I have obtained mercy, so that in me first Jesus Christ may display all his patience to serve as an example to those who would believe in him for eternal life.
Now, to the eternal, immortal, invisible King, to God who alone is wise, honor and glory forever and ever. Amen.
I entrust this instruction to you, my son Timothy, according to the prophecies that have been given to you before, so that by them you may fight the good fight,
by keeping the faith and the good conscience, which some have rejected and who have been shipwrecked in the faith,
among whom are Hymenaeus and Alexander, whom I have delivered to Satan to teach them not to blaspheme.
I therefore exhort, first of all, to make requests, prayers, intercessions and thanksgiving for all men,
for kings and for all those who hold high positions, that we may lead a quiet and peaceful life in all piety and respect.
For this is good and pleasing in the sight of God our Saviour,
who wants all men to be saved and to come to the full knowledge of the truth.
For there is but one God and one mediator between God and men, Jesus Christ, man,
who gave himself as a ransom for all, the testimony at the proper time,
for which I was appointed a preacher and apostle - I speak the truth in Christ, I do not lie - an educator of the Gentiles in the faith and the truth.
I therefore desire that men pray in every place, lifting up holy hands, without anger and without doubt.
In the same way, let women adorn themselves with decent clothing, with modesty and propriety, not with braided hair, gold, pearls, or expensive garments,
but with good works, which is suitable for women who profess piety.
Let the woman learn calmly, with complete submission.
But I do not allow a woman to teach, nor to exercise authority over a man, but let her be silent.
For Adam was formed first, and then Eve.
Adam was not deceived, but the woman, being deceived, fell into disobedience;
but she will be saved by childbirth, if she perseveres in faith, charity, and holiness with sobriety.
This saying is true: he who seeks to be an overseer desires a good deed.
The overseer must therefore be irreproachable, the husband of one wife, temperate, reasonable, modest, hospitable, knowing how to teach;
not a drinker, not violent, not greedy for money, but gentle, not quarrelsome, not greedy;
knowing how to govern his own house well, subduing children in all reverence;
(For how could someone who does not know how to govern his own house take care of God's assembly?
and not a new convert, lest puffed up with pride he should fall into the same condemnation as the devil.
He must also have a good testimony from those outside, so as not to fall into reproach and the snare of the devil.
In the same way, servants must be respectful, not have a sharp tongue, not be given to wine, not be greedy for money,
to keep the mystery of faith in a pure conscience.
Let them also be tried first, and then let them serve, if they are blameless.
Likewise, their wives must be respectful, not backbiting, temperate, and faithful in all things.
Let the servants be husbands of one wife, let them manage their children and their own household well.
For those who have served well acquire a good reputation and great confidence in the faith that is in Christ Jesus.
I am writing these things to you, hoping to come to you soon,
but if I delay, it is that you may know how to conduct oneself in the house of God, which is the assembly of the living God, the pillar and foundation of truth.
Without dispute, the mystery of piety is great: God was revealed in the flesh, justified in the spirit, seen by angels, preached among the nations, believed in the world, and received in glory.
But the Spirit expressly says that in the course of time some will forsake the faith, clinging to deceiving spirits and doctrines of demons.
by the hypocrisy of men who tell lies, branded with a hot iron in their own conscience,
forbidding marriage and commanding abstaining from the foods that God has created to be received with thanksgiving by those who believe and know the truth.
For every creature of God is good, and nothing is to be rejected if he is received with thanksgiving.
For it is sanctified by the word of God and prayer.
If you instruct your brethren in these things, you will be a good servant of Jesus Christ, nourished by the words of faith and the good doctrine which you have followed.
But refuse profane fables and those of old women. Train yourself in piety.
For bodily exercise has some value, but godliness has value in all things, having the promise of the present life and the life to come.
This word is faithful and worthy of all acceptance.
For it is to this end that we labor and suffer reproach, because we have put our trust in the living God, who is the Saviour of all men, especially of those who believe.
Command and teach these things.
Let no one despise your youth; but be an example to those who believe, in word, in your way of life, in love, in spirit, in faith, and in purity.
While waiting for me to come, devote yourselves to reading, exhortation, and teaching.
Do not neglect the gift that is in you, and which was given to you by prophecy, with the laying on of hands of the elders.
Attend to these things. Give yourself entirely to them, so that your progress may be revealed to all.
Take care of yourself and your teaching. Persevere in these things, for in this way you will save yourself and those who listen to you.
Do not rebuke an old man, but exhort him like a father; young men as brothers;
older women as mothers; young women as sisters, in all purity.
Honor widows who are truly widows.
But if a widow has children or grandchildren, let them first learn to show piety to their own family and to reciprocate their parents, for this is pleasing in the sight of God.
She who is a widow and desolate puts her hope in God and perseveres night and day in supplications and prayers.
But she who gives herself up to pleasure is dead during her life.
Order these things also, that they may be blameless.
But if someone does not provide for his needs, and especially those of his family, he has denied the faith and is worse than an unbeliever.
That no one be registered as a widow under sixty years of age, having been the wife of one man,
approved by good works, if she has brought up children, if she has been hospitable to strangers, if she has washed the feet of the saints, if she has relieved the afflicted, and if she has practiced every good work.
But refuse young widows, for when they have debauched themselves against Christ, they desire to marry,
by being condemned, because they rejected their first engagement.
In addition, they also learn to be idle, going from house to house. Not only are they idle, but they are also talkative and busy, saying things that they should not say.
I therefore want young widows to marry, to have children, to run the house, and not to give the adversary the opportunity to insult.
For already some have turned away after Satan.
If a man or woman who believes has widows, let him relieve them, and let not the assembly be overwhelmed, so that it may relieve those who are truly widows.
Let the elders who govern well be considered worthy of a double honor, especially those who labor in speech and teaching.
For the Scripture says, "Thou shalt not muzzle the ox when it treads the grain." And: "The worker deserves his wages."
Do not receive an accusation against an elder, except on the word of two or three witnesses.
Those who have sinned, rebuke them in the presence of all, so that others also may be in fear.
I command you, under the gaze of God, the Lord Jesus Christ, and the elect angels, to observe these things without prejudice, without partiality.
Don't lay hands on anyone in a hurry. Do not participate in the sins of others. Stay pure.
No longer be a drinker of water only, but use a little wine for the good of your stomach and your frequent infirmities.
The sins of some men are evident, they precede them at the judgment, and others also follow later.
Similarly, there are good works that are obvious, and others that cannot be hidden.
Let all those who are slaves under the yoke consider their own masters worthy of all honor, so that the name of God and the doctrine may not be blasphemed.
As for those who have believing teachers, let them not despise them because they are brothers, but let them serve them, because those who share in the benefit are believers and beloved. Teach and exhort these things.
If anyone teaches any other doctrine and does not conform to the sound words, the words of our Lord Jesus Christ, and the doctrine that is suitable for godliness,
he is a vain man, who knows nothing, but who is obsessed with discussions, disputes and quarrels over words, from which come envy, quarrels, insults, bad suspicions,
the constant friction of people with corrupt minds and devoid of truth, who think that piety is a means of gain. Remove yourself from such people.
But piety with contentment is a great gain.
For we have brought nothing into the world, and we certainly cannot take anything away.
But if we have food and clothing, we will be satisfied with them.
But those who want to get rich fall into temptation, a snare, and many foolish and harmful lusts, such as drown men in ruin and perdition.
For the love of money is a root of all kinds of evils. Some have gone astray from the faith by their greed, and have pierced themselves with many sorrows.
But you, man of God, flee from these things, and pursue righteousness, godliness, faith, love, perseverance, and meekness.
Fight the good fight of faith. Grasp the eternal life to which you have been called, and you have confessed the right confession before many witnesses.
I command you, before God who gives life to all things, and before Christ Jesus who bore witness to good confession before Pontius Pilate,
to keep the commandment spotless, without reproach, until the appearance of our Lord Jesus Christ,
whom he will show at the proper time, he who is the blessed and only head, the king of kings and the lord of lords.
He alone has immortality, dwelling in an inaccessible light, which no man has seen or can see, to whom belong honor and eternal power. Amen.
Ask those who are rich in the present age not to be puffed up with pride, and not to base their hope on the uncertainty of riches, but on the living God, who provides us with abundance all that we can enjoy;
that they do good, that they be rich in good works, that they be ready to distribute, that they are willing to share;
that they may form a good foundation for the time to come, that they may lay hold of eternal life.
Timothy, keep what has been entrusted to you, turning away from the vain speeches and oppositions of what is falsely called knowledge,
some of whom professed , and who have thus strayed from the faith . Grace be with you. Amen.
Paul, apostle of Jesus Christ by the will of God, according to the promise of life which is in Christ Jesus,
To Timothy, my beloved child: Grace, mercy, and peace, from God the Father and Jesus Christ our Lord.
I give thanks to God, whom I serve as my ancestors, with a pure conscience. As I remember you unceasingly in my requests, night and day
desiring to see you, remembering your tears, that I might be filled with joy;
having remembered the sincere faith that is in you, which lived first in your grandmother Lois and in your mother Eunice and, I am convinced, in you too.
That is why I remind you that you must stimulate the gift of God that is in you by the laying on of my hands.
For God has not given us a spirit of fear, but of power, love, and self-control.
Therefore do not be ashamed of the testimony of our Lord, nor of me, his prisoner, but endure suffering for the Good News, according to the power of God,
who saved us and called us by a holy calling, not according to our works, but according to his purpose and grace, which were granted to us in Christ Jesus before eternal time,
but which have now been revealed by the appearance of our Savior, Jesus Christ, who abolished death and brought life and immortality to light through the Good News.
For this reason I was appointed preacher, apostle, and teacher of the Gentiles.
That's why I also suffer these things. But I am not ashamed, for I know the one in whom I have believed, and I am convinced that he is able to keep what I have entrusted to him for that day.
Keep the pattern of the sound words you have heard from me, in the faith and charity that is in Christ Jesus.
This good that has been entrusted to you, guard it by the Holy Spirit who dwells in us.
You know that all those who are in Asia have turned away from me, including Phygelus and Hermogenes.
May the Lord have mercy on the house of Onesiphorus, for he has often refreshed me, and has not been ashamed of my chain,
but, when he was in Rome, he sought me diligently and found me
(may the Lord grant him to find the Lord's mercy in this day); and in how many things he served Ephesus, you know very well.
You, therefore, my child, be strengthened in the grace that is in Christ Jesus.
What you have heard from me in the presence of many witnesses, entrust it to faithful men, who are able to instruct others also.
So you must endure trials like a good soldier of Jesus Christ.
No soldier on duty meddles in the affairs of life, in order to please the one who has enlisted him as a soldier.
