Similarly, if someone participates in an athletics competition, he is not crowned if he did not compete according to the rules.
The working farmer must be the first to receive a share of the crops.
Consider what I say, and may the Lord give you understanding in all things.
Remember Jesus Christ, risen from the dead, the seed of David, according to my Good News,
in which I suffer privations until I am chained like a criminal. But the word of God is not chained.
Therefore I endure all things for the sake of the elect, that they also may obtain salvation which is in Christ Jesus, with eternal glory.
These words are worthy of belief: "For if we died with him, we will also live with him.
If we endure, we will also reign with him. If we deny him, he will also deny us.
If we are unfaithful, he remains faithful; because he cannot deny himself. »
Remind them of these things, recommending them, before the Lord, not to discuss the words unnecessarily, to the detriment of those who hear.
Strive to present yourself before God, as a workman who has nothing to be ashamed of, carefully handling the Word of Truth.
But flee from empty speeches, for they go further in impiety,
and these speeches are consumed like gangrene. Among them are Hymenaeus and Philetus,
men who have gone astray in the truth, saying that the resurrection is already past, and overturning the faith of some.
However, the solid foundation of God remains, having this seal: "The Lord knoweth them that are his" and "Whosoever calls on the name of the Lord depart from iniquity."
In a large house, there are not only vases of gold and silver, but also vases of wood and clay. Some are for honor, others for dishonor.
If, therefore, anyone purifies himself from these, he will be a vessel of honor, sanctified, fit for the use of the master, prepared for every good work.
Flee from the lusts of youth, but seek justice, faith, love and peace with those who call on the Lord with a pure heart.
But refuse foolish and ignorant questions, knowing that they give rise to quarrels.
The servant of the Lord must not quarrel, but be gentle to all, able to teach, patient,
gently correcting those who oppose him. Perhaps God will give them a repentance that will bring them to the full knowledge of the truth,
and they will recover from the devil's snare, after having been taken away by him to do his will.
But know that, in the last days, difficult times will come.
For men will be lovers of themselves, lovers of money, boastful, arrogant, blasphemers, rebels against their parents, ungrateful, impious,
without natural affection, pitiless, slanderers, incapable of self-control, ferocious, not loving the good,
traitors, stubborn, conceited, lovers of pleasure rather than God,
having an appearance of piety, but denying his power. Turn away from these also.
For there are among them people who break into the houses and take credulous women prisoners, laden with sins, carried away by various lusts,
who learn incessantly and never attain to the knowledge of the truth.
As Jannes and Jambres opposed Moses, so do these oppose the truth, men of corrupt minds, who are rejected as far as faith is concerned.
But they will not go any further. For their folly will be evident to all men, as theirs has been also.
But you have followed my teaching, my conduct, my resolution, my faith, my patience, my love, my firmness,
my persecutions and sufferings, those which have befallen me at Antioch, at Iconium, and at Lystra. I endured these persecutions. The Lord has delivered me from all .
Yes, and all those who want to live godly in Christ Jesus will suffer persecution.
But the wicked and the impostors will go further and further, deceiving and being deceived.
But you, you remain in the things which you have learned and of which you have been assured, knowing from whom you have learned them.
From childhood you have known the Holy Scriptures which can make you wise for salvation through the faith that is in Jesus Christ.
All Scripture is inspired of God and useful for teaching, for convicting, for correcting, and for instructing in righteousness,
so that every man who belongs to God may be complete, perfectly equipped for every good work.
I command you, therefore, before God and before the Lord Jesus Christ, who will judge the living and the dead at his coming and in his kingdom:
preach the word; be pressing in season and out of season; rebuke, rebuke, exhort, with all the patience and instruction required.
For the time will come when men will not listen to sound doctrine, but will itch to hear, and gather teachers according to their own desires,
will turn their ears away from the truth and turn to fables.
But you, be sober in all things, suffer privations, do the work of an evangelist, and carry out your ministry.
For I am already offered, and the time for my departure has arrived.
I fought the good fight. I completed the course. I have kept the faith.
From now on, I reserve for myself the crown of righteousness which the Lord, the righteous judge, will give to me in that day, and not only to me, but also to all those who loved his appearance.
Be diligent to come and see me soon,
for Demas left me, having loved the present world, and went to Thessalonica; Crescens, in Galatia; and Titus, in Dalmatia.
Luke alone is with me. Take Mark and bring him with you, for he is useful to me for service.
But I have sent Tychicus to Ephesus.
Bring to Carpus, when you come, the cloak which I left at Troas, and the books, especially the parchments.
Alexander, the coppersmith, has done me a lot of harm. The Lord will repay him according to his deeds.
Beware of him, for he has been very opposed to our words.
During my first defense, no one came to help me, but all abandoned me. Let them not be reproached for this.
But the Lord stood by me and strengthened me, so that through me the message might be fully proclaimed, and all the Gentiles might hear it. Thus I was delivered from the lion's mouth.
And the Lord will deliver me from all evil works and keep me for his heavenly kingdom. To him be the glory for ever and ever. Amen.
Greet Prisca and Aquila, and the house of Onesiphorus.
Erastus remained at Corinth, but I left Trophimus ill at Miletus.
Take care to come before winter. Eubulus greets you, as well as Pudens, Linus, Claudia, and all the brothers.
The Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Grace be with you. Amen.
Paul, servant of God and apostle of Jesus Christ, according to the faith of the elect of God and the knowledge of the truth that befits godliness,
in the hope of eternal life, which God, who cannot lie, promised before the beginning of time,
but who in his time revealed his word in the message with which I was charged, according to the command of God our Saviour,
to Titus, my true child, according to a common faith: Grace, mercy and peace from God the Father and the Lord Jesus Christ our Saviour.
For this reason I have left you in Crete, that you may put in order what is lacking, and that you may appoint elders in every city, as I have commanded you,
if anyone is blameless, husband of one wife, having children who believe, who are not accused of having a wanton or undisciplined conduct.
For the overseer must be irreproachable, like God's steward, not indulge in self-satisfaction, not easily irritated, not given to wine, not violent, not greedy for dishonest gain,
but let him practice hospitality, let him love the good, let him have a sober mind, let him be just, let him be holy, let him be master of himself,
let him stick to the faithful word, conformable to the teaching, in order to be able to exhort in sound doctrine, and to convince those who contradict him.
For there are also many turbulent men, vain talkers and deceivers, especially those of circumcision,
whose mouths must be shut: men who overturn whole houses, teaching things they ought not, for dishonest gain.
One of them, a prophet of theirs, said, "The Cretans are always liars, wicked beasts, and idle gluttons."
This testimony is true. Wherefore, rebuke them severely, that they may be sound in the faith,
without paying attention to Jewish fables and the commandments of men who turn away from the truth.
To those who are pure, all is pure, but to those who are unclean and unbelieving, nothing is pure; their minds and consciences are defiled.
They profess that they know God, but they deny Him by their deeds, being abominable, disobedient, and unfit for any good work.
But say the things that are suitable to sound doctrine,
namely, that old men should be temperate, reasonable, sober of spirit, solid in faith, in charity and in perseverance,
and that old women should likewise have a respectful conduct, be neither backbiters nor slaves of wine, teachers of what is good,
so that they may teach young women to love their husbands, to love their children,
to be sober of spirit, chaste, hard-working in the home, amiable, submissive to their husbands, so that the word of God may not be blasphemed.
In the same way, exhort young men to be sober of mind.
In all things, set yourself an example of good works. In your teaching, show integrity, seriousness, incorruptibility,
and with a sound and blameless word, so that he who opposes you may be ashamed, having nothing evil to say about us.
Exhort the servants to be submissive to their masters and to be pleasing in all things, without contradicting,
without stealing, but showing all good faithfulness, in order to adorn in all things the doctrine of God, our Saviour.
For the grace of God has appeared, bringing salvation to all men,
instructing ourselves that, renouncing impiety and worldly lusts, we may live soberly, justly, and devoutly in the present world,
while waiting for the blessed hope and the appearance of the glory of our great God and Saviour, Jesus Christ,
who gave himself for us, in order to redeem us from all iniquity and to purify for himself a people of his own, zealous for good works.
Say these things, exhort and rebuke with all authority. Let no one despise you.
Remind them to be subject to rulers and authorities, to be obedient, to be ready for any good work,
not to speak ill of anyone, not to be quarrelsome, to be gentle, showing all humility towards all men.
For we too were once foolish, disobedient, deceived, enslaved to various lusts and pleasures, living in malice and envy, hateful and hating one another.
But when the goodness of God our Saviour and his love for men appeared,
not by works of righteousness that we ourselves have done, but according to his mercy, he has saved us by the washing of regeneration and renewal by the Holy Spirit,
that he has poured out upon us abundantly through Jesus Christ our Saviour;
so that, justified by his grace, we may be made heirs according to the hope of eternal life.
This word is true, and I desire that you should insist on these things with boldness, that those who have believed in God may take care to preserve good works. These things are good and profitable to men;
but avoid foolish questions, genealogies, quarrels, and disputes about the law, for they are useless and vain.
Avoid a factious man, after a first and a second warning,
knowing that such a man is perverted and sinful, and that he condemns himself.
When I send you Artema or Tychicus, take care to come and join me at Nicopolis, for I have decided to spend the winter there.
Send Zenas the jurist and Apollos quickly, so that they may lack nothing.
Let our people also learn to maintain good works to provide for the necessary needs, so that they may not be fruitless.
All those who are with me greet you. Greet those who love us in faith. Grace be with you all. Amen.
Paul, a prisoner of Jesus Christ, and Timothy, our brother, to Philemon, our beloved fellow laborer,
to the beloved Apphia, to Archippus, our comrade-in-arms, and to the assembly that is in your house:
Grace and peace to you from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ.
I always give thanks to my God, by mentioning you in my prayers,
hearing of your love and faith in the Lord Jesus and in all the saints,
so that the communion of your faith may become efficacious in the knowledge of all the good that is in us in Christ Jesus.
For we have much joy and comfort in your love, because the hearts of the saints have been refreshed by you, brother.
Wherefore, though I have in Christ all the boldness to command you what is proper,
I prefer, out of love, to appeal to you, being such a Paul, old, but also a prisoner of Jesus Christ.
I appeal to you for my son Onesimus, whom I have begotten in my chains,
which formerly was useless to you, and which is now useful to you and to me.
I send it back to you. Receive it, therefore, that is to say, my own heart,
which I have wished to keep with me, so that it may serve in my favor in my chains for the Good News.
But I would do nothing without your consent, so that your goodness might not be as a necessity, but as a free will.
Wherefore, perhaps, he was separated from you for a time, that you might possess him forever,
no longer as a slave, but more than a slave, a beloved brother, for me especially, but how much more for you, in the flesh and in the Lord.
If, therefore, you consider me a partner, receive him as you would receive me.
But if he has wronged you or if he owes you something, put it on my account.
I, Paul, write this with my own hand: I will repay you (without telling you that you also owe me your own person).
Yes, brother, let me rejoice in you in the Lord. Refresh my heart in the Lord.
Trusting in your obedience, I am writing to you, knowing that you will even do more than I say.
Prepare also a bed and breakfast for me, for I hope that, thanks to your prayers, I can be restored to you.
Epaphras, my companion in captivity in Jesus Christ, greets you,
as well as Mark, Aristarchus, Demas and Luke, my fellow workers.
The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with your spirit. Amen.
God, having formerly spoken to the fathers at various times and in various ways through the prophets,
spoke to us, at the end of these days, through his Son, whom he made heir of all things, by whom he also created the worlds.
His Son is the radiance of his glory, the very image of his substance, and he sustains all things by the word of his power; After He had cleansed us of Himself from our sins, He sat down at the right hand of the Majesty of heaven,
having become as superior to the angels as the more excellent name which he has inherited is superior to theirs.
For to whom of the angels has he ever said, "You are my son. Today, I have become your father? And again, "I will be a Father to him, and he will be a Son to me?" »
When he again introduced the firstborn into the world, he said, "Let all the angels of God bow down to him."
Of the angels, he says, "He makes winds to his angels, and his servants a flame of fire."
But he says of the Son, "Thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever. The scepter of righteousness is the scepter of your Kingdom.
You loved righteousness and hated iniquity; That is why God your God has anointed you with an oil of jubilation above your fellow men. »
And, "You, Lord, in the beginning you laid the foundations of the earth. The heavens are the work of your hands.
They will perish, but you continue. They will all age like a garment.
You shall wrap them up like a cloak, and they shall be changed; but you're the same. Your years will not be missed. »
But which of the angels said at some point, "Sit at my right hand, until I make your enemies the footstool of your feet?"
Are they not all servant spirits, sent to serve those who are to inherit salvation?
Therefore we must be more attentive to the things we have heard, lest we go astray.
For if the word spoken by the angels has proved to be unshakable, and if every transgression and disobedience has received a just punishment,
how shall we escape if we neglect so great a salvation, which, first announced by the Lord, has been confirmed to us by those who have heard it?
God by bearing witness with them, by signs and wonders, by various works of power, and by gifts of the Holy Ghost, according to his own will?
For he did not subject the world to come, of which we speak, to angels.
But somebody testified somewhere, saying, "What is man, that you should think of him? Or the son of man, that you may care for him?
You made it a little lower than the angels. You have crowned him with glory and honor.
You have subdued everything under his feet. For in subjecting all things to him, he has left nothing that is not subject to him. Now we do not yet see all things that are subject to him.
But we see him who was made a little lower than the angels, Jesus, because of the sufferings of death, crowned with glory and honor, so that, by the grace of God, he might taste death for all.
For it pleased Him, for whom all things are and through whom all things are, by bringing many children to glory, to perfect the author of their salvation by sufferings.
For he who sanctifies and those who are sanctified are all of one, and therefore he is not ashamed to call them brothers,
saying, "I will declare your name to my brethren. In the midst of the assembly, I will sing your praises. »
Again: "I will trust him." And again: "Here I am with the children that God has given me."
Since the children had a share in flesh and blood, he himself had a share in the same thing, so that by death he might annihilate him who had the power of death, that is, the devil,
and that he delivers all those who, through the fear of death, have been all their lives enslaved.
For it is not to the angels that he comes to the aid, but to the seed of Abraham.
Therefore he was obliged in all things to be made like his brethren, that he might become a merciful and faithful high priest in the things of God, to make atonement for the sins of the people.
For having himself suffered to be tempted, he is able to succor those who are tempted.
Therefore, holy brethren, partakers of a heavenly calling, consider the Apostle and High Priest of our confession: Jesus,
who was faithful to him who appointed him, as also Moses was in all his house.
For he was counted worthy of more glory than Moses, since he who built the house has more honor than the house.
For every house is built by someone; but he who built everything is God.
Moses was faithful in all his house, as a servant, to bear witness to the things that were to be said later;
but Christ is faithful as a Son to his house. We are his house, if we hold fast to our confidence and the glory of our hope to the end.
Therefore, as the Holy Spirit says, "Today, if you would hear his voice,
Do not harden your hearts as in rebellion, in the day of trial in the wilderness,
where your fathers tested and tried me, and saw my deeds for forty years.
That's why I was dissatisfied with this generation, and said, "They always err in their hearts," but they didn't know my methods.
As I swore in my anger, "They shall not enter into my rest."
Beware, brethren, that there is not in one of you an evil and unbelieving heart that departs from the living God;
but exhort one another, day by day, as long as it is called "today," so that none of you may be hardened by the deceitfulness of sin.
For we have become partakers of Christ, if we hold fast to the end the beginning of our trust,
while it is said, "Today, if you will hear his voice, do not harden your hearts, as in rebellion."
For who, when they heard, rebelled? Were they not all those who had come out of Egypt under the leadership of Moses?
With whom was he discontented for forty years? Was it not with those who sinned and whose bodies fell into the desert?
To whom did he swear that they would not enter into his rest, but to those who disobeyed?
We see that they were not able to enter because of their unbelief.
Let us therefore fear that any one of you will appear to have broken the promise to enter into his rest.
For the good news has been preached to us, as to them also; but the word which they heard did not profit them, because it was not mixed with faith by those who heard it.
But we, who have believed, enter into this rest, as he said, "As I have sworn in my wrath, they shall not enter into my rest," although the works were finished from the foundation of the world.
For he has said somewhere concerning the seventh day, "God rested on the seventh day from all his works";
and again here: "They will not enter into my rest."
Since, therefore, there remain that some enter into it, and those to whom the good news was previously preached have not entered it because of their disobedience,
he again defines a certain day, "today," saying by David so long afterwards (as has been said), "Today, if ye will hear his voice, harden not your hearts."
For if Joshua had given them rest, he would not have spoken of another day afterwards.
So there remains a Sabbath rest for God's people.
For he who has entered into his rest has also rested from his works, as God has done from his.
Let us therefore strive to enter into this rest, lest anyone fall into the same example of disobedience.
For the word of God is living and effective, sharper than any two-edged sword, it penetrates to the division of soul and spirit, of joints and marrows, and it is able to discern the thoughts and intentions of the heart.
There is no creature that is hidden from his sight, but everything is naked and exposed to the eyes of him to whom we must give an account.
Having therefore a high priest who has passed through the heavens, Jesus, the Son of God, hold fast to our confession.
For we have not a high priest who cannot be touched by the sense of our infirmities, but one who has been tempted like us in all things, but without sinning.
Let us therefore approach the throne of grace with boldness, that we may obtain mercy and find grace to be helped in times of need.
For every high priest, taken from among men, is appointed for men in things concerning God, to offer both gifts and sacrifices for sins.
The high priest can treat with gentleness those who are ignorant and misguided, because he himself is surrounded by weakness.
Therefore he must offer sacrifices for the sins of the people, as well as for himself.
No one takes this honor upon himself, but he is called by God, just like Aaron.
In the same way, Christ did not boast of being made high priest, but it was he who said to him, "You are my son. Today, I have become your father. »
As he also says in another place, "You are a priest forever, according to the order of Melchizedek."
He, in the days of his flesh, having addressed with loud cries and tears, prayers and supplications to him who could save him from death, and having been heard because of his pious fear,
although he was a Son, he nevertheless learned obedience by the things he suffered.
Having been perfected, he became the author of eternal salvation to all who obey him.
and he was appointed by God high priest according to the order of Melchizedek.
Concerning him, we have many words to say, and difficult to interpret, since you have become deaf.
For, although you are now teachers, you still need to be taught the rudiments of the first principles of God's revelations. You need milk, not solid food.
For he who lives on milk has no experience of the word of righteousness, for he is a baby.
But solid food is for those who have grown up, and who, by use, have their senses trained to discern good and evil.
Therefore, leaving the teaching of the first principles of Christ, let us strive for perfection, laying anew the foundation of repentance from dead works, of faith in God,
of the teaching of baptisms, the laying on of hands, the resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment.
This is what we will do, God permitting.
For as for those who were once enlightened, who tasted the heavenly gift, who were made partakers of the Holy Spirit,
who have tasted the good word of God and the powers of the age to come,
and who afterwards fell, it is impossible to bring them back to repentance, since they crucify the Son of God again for themselves and expose him to ignominy.
For the land that has drunk the rain that often falls upon it, and that produces a suitable harvest for those for whom it is also cultivated, receives the blessing of God;
but if it bears thorns and thistles, it is rejected and nearly cursed, its end being to be burned.
But, beloved, we are persuaded of better things for you, and of things that go with salvation, although we speak thus.
For God is not unjust, so much so as to forget your work and the work of love which you have shown towards his name, in that you have served the saints, and are still serving them.
We desire that each of you show the same eagerness until the end of the fullness of hope,
so that you may not be lazy, but imitators of those who, by faith and perseverance, have inherited the promises.
For when God made a promise to Abraham, as he could not swear by anyone greater, he swore by himself,
saying, "I will bless you, and I will multiply you."
Thus it was that, having borne patiently, he obtained the promise.
Men, in fact, swear by a greater one, and in any dispute on their part, the oath is final for confirmation.
Thus it is that God, desiring to show more abundantly to the heirs of the promise the immutability of his counsel, interposed himself by an oath,
so that, by two immutable things, in which it is impossible for God to lie, we who have fled to find refuge may be strongly encouraged to grasp the hope that is set before us.
This hope we have as an anchor of the soul, a hope at once sure and unshakeable, and which penetrates into that which is beyond the veil,
where Jesus entered for us as a forerunner, having become high priest forever according to the order of Melchizedek.
For that Melchizedek, king of Salem, priest of the Most High God, who met Abraham on his return from the slaughter of kings, and blessed him,
to whom Abraham also shared the tenth part of everything (being first, by interpretation, "king of righteousness", then also "king of Salem", which means "king of peace",
without father, without mother, without genealogy, having neither beginning of days nor end of life, but made like the Son of God), remains a priest in perpetuity.
Now consider the greatness of this man, to whom even the patriarch Abraham gave tithes on the best booty.
For those of the sons of Levi who receive the office of priest have been commanded to take tithes from the people according to the law, that is, from their brethren, although they have come out of the body of Abraham.
but he whose genealogy is not numbered from them has accepted the tithe of Abraham, and has blessed him who has the promises.
The smaller is blessed by the greatest, without any dispute.
Here people who die receive tithes, but there someone receives tithes from the one who is attested to be living.
We can say that, through Abraham, even Levi, who receives tithes, paid tithes,
for he was still in his father's body when Melchizedek met him.
Now, if perfection was obtained by the Levitical priesthood (for it was under it that the people received the law), what need was there that another priest should arise according to the order of Melchizedek, and not be called according to the order of Aaron?
For the priesthood being changed, it is necessary that the law should also be changed.
For the one here spoken of belongs to another tribe, whose altar no one has taken care of.
For it is evident that our Lord is descended from Judah, a tribe of which Moses did not speak concerning the priesthood.
What is even more obvious is that, like Melchizedek, there is another priest,
who was created, not according to the law of a carnal commandment, but according to the power of an endless life;
for it is testified, "You are a priest forever, after the order of Melchizedek."
For there is a nullification of a previous commandment because of its weakness and uselessness
(for the law has not perfected anything), and the introduction of a better hope, by which we draw near to God.
In fact, he was not established as a priest without an oath
(for they were made priests without oath), but he was ordained priest with oath by him who said of him, "The Lord has sworn and will not change his mind, You are a priest forever, according to the order of Melchizedek."
In this way, Jesus became the guarantee of a better covenant.
For many have been priests, because death prevented them from continuing.
But he, because he lives eternally, has an immutable priesthood.
Therefore he can also save to the extreme those who draw near to God through him, since he lives eternally to intercede for them.
For it is such a high priest who is befitting us, holy, innocent, spotless, separate from sinners, exalted above heaven,
who does not need, like those high priests, to offer sacrifices every day, first for his own sins, and then for those of the people. For he did it once and for all, by offering himself.
For the law appoints as high priests men who have a weakness, but the word of the oath, which is subsequent to the law, establishes forever a Son who has been perfected.
Now, in what we say, the essential thing is this: we have such a high priest, who has sat at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in heaven,
servant of the sanctuary and of the true tabernacle which the Lord has set up, and not a man.
For every high priest is called to offer gifts and sacrifices. It is therefore necessary that this high priest also has something to offer.
For if he were on earth, he would not be a priest at all, since there are priests who offer gifts according to the law,
which serve as a copy and shadow of heavenly things, as Moses was warned by God when he was going to build the tabernacle, for he said, "Behold, you shall do all things according to the pattern that was shown to you on the mountain."
But now he has obtained a more excellent ministry, inasmuch as he is also the mediator of a better covenant, which, on better promises, has been given as law.
For if this first alliance had been without defect, no attempt would have been made to establish a second.
For when he found them at fault, he said, "Behold, the days are coming," says the Lord, "that I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel and with the house of Judah;
not according to the covenant I made with their fathers on the day I took them by the hand to bring them out of the land of Egypt; for they have not persevered in my covenant, and I have neglected them," says the Lord.
"For this is the covenant which I shall make with the house of Israel after those days," says the Lord: "I will put my laws in their spirits; I will also write them on their hearts. I will be their God, and they will be my people.
They will not teach every man his fellow citizen and every man his brother, saying, "Know the Lord." for all will know me, from the least to the greatest.
For I will be merciful to their iniquity. I will remember no more their sins and their unlawful deeds. »
By saying, "A new covenant," he has rendered the first one null and void. But what becomes obsolete and ages is close to disappearing.
Now, even the first covenant had ordinances of divine service and an earthly sanctuary.
In fact, a tabernacle had been prepared. In the first part were the candlestick, the table and the shewbread, which is called the holy place.
After the second veil, there was the tabernacle called the Holy of Holies,
with a golden altar for incense, and the ark of the covenant, covered with gold on all sides, in which were a golden vessel containing manna, the staff of Aaron that had grown, and the tablets of the covenant;
and above them, cherubim of glory, which overshadowed the mercy seat, of which we cannot now speak in detail.
These things being thus prepared, the priests continually enter into the first tabernacle, performing the services,
but in the second, the high priest alone, once a year, not without blood, which he offers for himself and for the sins of the people.
The Holy Spirit thus indicates that access to the holy place has not yet been revealed while the first tabernacle was still standing.
It is a symbol of the present age, where gifts and sacrifices are offered, which are incapable, so far as conscience is concerned, of making the worshipper perfect,
being only carnal ordinances (with food and drink and various purifications), imposed until a time of reform.
But Christ, having come as high priest of the good things to come, through the greater and more perfect tabernacle, which is not made with hands, that is, which is not of this creation,
nor again by the blood of goats and calves, but by his own blood, entered once for all into the holy place, having obtained eternal redemption.
For if the blood of goats and bulls, and the ashes of a heifer that sprinkles those who have defiled themselves, sanctify for the purity of the flesh,
how much more will the blood of Christ, who, by the eternal Spirit, offered Himself without blemish to God, cleanse your conscience from dead works to serve the living God?
Therefore he is the mediator of a new covenant, since a death has come for the redemption of the transgressions committed under the first covenant, so that those who have been called may receive the promise of the everlasting inheritance.
For where there is a last will and testament, it is necessary that the one who made it should be dead.
For a will is in force where there has been death, for it is never in force as long as the one who made it lives.
That is why even the first covenant was not consecrated without blood.
For when Moses had spoken all the commandments of the law to all the people, he took the blood of the calves and goats, with water, scarlet wool, and hyssop, and sprinkled the book himself and all the people,
saying, "This is the blood of the covenant which God has commanded you."
He sprinkled blood in the same way on the tabernacle and all the utensils of the ministry.
According to the law, almost everything is purified with blood, and without bloodshed, there is no remission.
It was therefore necessary that the copies of the things that are in the heavens should be purified by these, but that the heavenly things themselves should be purified by sacrifices better than these.
For Christ did not enter the holy places made with hands, which are representations of the truth, but into heaven itself, in order to appear now for us in the presence of God.
Nor must he have offered himself often, as the high priest enters the holy place every year with a blood that is not his own.
Otherwise, he would have had to suffer often since the foundation of the world. But now, once, at the end of the ages, he was revealed to blot out sin by his own sacrifice.
As it is foreseen that men die once and after that there is judgment,
so Christ, after having been offered once to bear the sins of many, will appear a second time, not to take upon himself sin, but to save those who are impatiently waiting for him.
For the law, which is but a shadow of the good things to come, and not the very image of these goods, can never, with the same sacrifices that are offered every year, make perfect those who draw near.
Or would they not have ceased to be offered, because the worshippers, once purified, would no longer have been conscious of their sins?
But in these sacrifices, there is an annual remembrance of sins.
For it is impossible for the blood of bulls and goats to take away sins.
That is why, when he comes into the world, he says, "You have not desired a sacrifice and an offering, but you have prepared a body for me.
You did not love whole burnt offerings and sacrifices for sin.
And I said, "Behold, I have come" (it is written of me in the scroll of the book). to do your will, O God. »
Having said before, "You did not desire sacrifices and offerings, whole burnt offerings and sacrifices for sin, nor did you take pleasure in them" (those offered according to the law),
then he said, "Behold, I have come to do your will." He removes the former, in order to establish the latter,
by which we have been sanctified by the offering of the body of Jesus Christ once and for all.
For every priest stands every day to serve and offer often the same sacrifices, which can never take away sins.
But he, after having offered forever one sacrifice for sins, sat down at the right hand of God.
Since then, he has been waiting for his enemies to become the footstool of his feet.
For by one offering he has perfected forever those who are sanctified.
The Holy Spirit also testifies to us, for after having said,
"This is the covenant that I will make with them. after those days," says the Lord, "I will put my laws on their hearts, I will write them also on their minds;" then he says,
"I will remember their sins and iniquities no more."
But where there is remission, there is no longer an offering for sin.
Having therefore, brethren, the boldness to enter the sanctuary through the blood of Jesus,
by the way he has made for us, a new and living way, through the veil, that is, his flesh,
and having a high priest over the house of God,
let us approach with a sincere heart, in the fullness of faith, with our hearts purified from a bad conscience and our bodies washed with pure water,
holding on to the confession of our hope, for he who has promised is faithful.
Let us think of ways to stir one another up to love and good works,
without giving up the idea of meeting together, as is the custom of some, but exhorting one another, and all the more so as you see the Day approaching.
For if we sin willfully after we have received the knowledge of the truth, there is no sacrifice left for sins,
but a formidable expectation of judgment, and an ardor of fire that will devour the adversaries.
The man who does not respect the law of Moses dies without mercy, on the word of two or three witnesses.
What worse punishment do you think will be counted worthy of him who trampled under foot the Son of God, who held the blood of the covenant by which he was sanctified to be ungodly, and who insulted the Spirit of grace?
For we know him who said, "Vengeance is mine. I will reciprocate, says the Lord. And again: "The Lord will judge his people."
It is a dreadful thing to fall into the hands of the living God.
But remember the days of old, when, after being enlightened, you endured a great struggle in sufferings:
on the one hand, by being exposed to opprobrium and oppression, on the other hand, by becoming partakers of those who were thus treated.
But you have had mercy on me in my chains, and you have gladly accepted the plundering of your goods, knowing that you have a better and lasting good in heaven for you.
Do not therefore throw away your audacity, which has a great reward.
For you need endurance, so that, having done the will of God, you may receive the promise.
"In a very short time, he who comes will come and will not wait.
But the righteous will live by faith. If he retracts, my soul has no pleasure in him. »
But we are not of those who retreat to destruction, but of those who have faith for the salvation of the soul.
Now faith is the assurance of things that we hope for, the proof of those that we do not see.
For it is by this that the ancients obtained approval.
By faith, we understand that the universe was formed by the word of God, so that what is seen was not made from visible things.
By faith, Abel offered to God a more excellent sacrifice than that of Cain, by which he received the testimony that he was righteous, God testifying with regard to his gifts, and by which, although dead, he still speaks.
It was by faith that Enoch was taken up, that he might not see death, and that he was not found, because God translated him. For it has been testified to him that before his translation he had been very pleasing to God.
Without faith, it is impossible to please Him, for he who draws near to God must believe that He exists and that He is the rewarder of those who seek Him.
By faith, Noah, warned of things not yet seen, and animated by pious fear, prepared a ship to save his house, by which he condemned the world and became heir of righteousness according to faith.
It was by faith that Abraham, when he was called, obeyed to go out to the place he was to receive as an inheritance. He went out, without knowing where he was going.
It was by faith that he lived as a stranger in the promised land, as in a land that did not belong to him, dwelling in tents with Isaac and Jacob, heirs with him of the same promise.
For he was waiting for the city which has foundations, and of which God is the builder and the craftsman.
It was by faith that Sarah herself received the power to conceive, and that she bore a child at an advanced age, for she considered him faithful who had promised.
Therefore one man has begotten as many children as the stars of heaven are numerous, and as innumerable as the sand that is by the sea, and he is as if dead.
All these died in the faith, not having received the promises, but having seen and embraced them from afar, and having confessed that they were strangers and pilgrims on earth.
For those who say such things make it clear that they are looking for a country of their own.
If indeed they had thought of the country from which they left, they would have had time to return.
But now they desire a better country, that is, a heavenly country. Therefore God is not ashamed of them, of being called their God, for he has prepared a city for them.
By faith, Abraham, put to the test, offered Isaac. For he who had received the promises with joy offered his only son,
to whom it was said, "Your seed shall be numbered as that of Isaac,"
concluding that God is able to rise even from the dead. Figuratively speaking, he also raised him from the dead.
It was by faith that Isaac blessed Jacob and Esau, even in regard to things to come.
It was by faith that Jacob, at his death, blessed each of Joseph's sons and prostrated himself, leaning on the top of his staff.
It was by faith that Joseph, when his end drew near, mentioned the departure of the children of Israel, and gave instructions concerning his bones.
It was by faith that Moses, at his birth, was hidden for three months by his parents, because they saw that he was a beautiful child; and they did not fear the king's order.
It was by faith that Moses, when he had grown up, refused to be called the son of Pharaoh's daughter,
preferring to share in the mistreatment of God's people rather than enjoy for a time the pleasures of sin,
considering the reproach of Christ as greater wealth than the treasures of Egypt, for he expected the reward of it.
It was by faith that he left Egypt, without fearing the wrath of the king, for he endured, as if he saw Him who is invisible.
By faith he kept the Passover and the sprinkling of blood, so that the destroyer of the firstborn would not touch them.
It was by faith that they crossed the Red Sea as on dry land. When the Egyptians tried to do so, they were swallowed up.
It was by faith that the walls of Jericho fell after being surrounded for seven days.
It was by faith that Rahab the harlot did not perish with the disobedient, having received the spies in peace.
What more shall I say? For I would lack time if I spoke of Gideon, Barak, Samson, Jephthah, David, Samuel, and the prophets.
who, by faith, have subdued kingdoms, exercised justice, obtained promises, shut the mouths of lions,
extinguished the power of fire, escaped the edge of the sword, strengthened themselves from their weakness, became powerful in war, and put foreign armies to flight.
Women received their dead by resurrection. Others were tortured, not accepting their deliverance, in order to obtain a better resurrection.
Others have been tried by mockery and flogging, and even by chains and imprisonment.
They were stoned. They were sawn off. They were tempted. They were killed by the sword. They came and went, dressed in sheep's skins and goatskins, in misery, affliction, ill-treatment,
they whom the world was not worthy, wandering in the deserts, the mountains, the caves and the holes of the earth.
All these, after having been commended for their faith, have not received the promise,
God having planned something better for us, so that, without us, they would not be perfect.
Wherefore, we who are surrounded by so great a cloud of witnesses, cast off every burden and the sin which so easily envelops us, and run with perseverance in the race that is set before us,
looking to Jesus, the father and finisher of the faith, who, for the joy that was reserved for him, endured the cross, despising his shame, and sat down at the right hand of the throne of God.
For consider him who has endured such a contradiction of sinners against himself, so that you may not grow weary, failing in your souls.
You have not yet resisted to the point of blood, fighting against sin.
You have forgotten the exhortation which resonates with you as with children, "My son, do not take lightly the punishment of the Lord, and do not let yourselves be discouraged when he rebukes you;
for he whom the Lord loves, he disciplines, and chastises every son he receives. »
It is for the discipline that you endure. God treats you like children; for what son is there that his father does not correct?
But if you are deprived of the discipline, in which all have had a part, you are illegitimate, and not children.
Besides, the fathers of our flesh have chastised us, and we have respected them. Shouldn't we rather be subject to the Father of spirits and live?
For they chastised us for a few days, as they saw fit, but he did it for our good, so that we might share in his holiness.
All chastisement seems for the moment not joyful, but painful; but then he brings forth the peaceful fruit of righteousness for those whom he has formed.
Therefore lift up the hands that hang down and the knees that are weak,
and make straight paths for your feet, so that what is lame may not be dislocated, but rather healed.
Seek peace with all men and sanctification, without which no one will see the Lord,
seeing that there is no man who fails in the grace of God, that no root of bitterness sprouts in you and defiles many people,
that there should be no fornicator or profane, like Esau, who sold his birthright for a meal.
For you know that when he wanted to inherit the blessing, he was rejected, because he could not find a place where he could change his mind, although he sought it with tears.
For you have not come to a mountain that could be touched and that burned with fire, nor to darkness, nor to darkness, nor to storm,
nor at the sound of a trumpet, nor at the voice of words, that those who heard it begged that not one more word should be addressed to them,
for they could not endure what had been commanded: "If any animal touches the mountain, it shall be stoned."
The apparition was so frightening that Moses said, "I am terrified and trembling."
But you have come to Mount Zion, to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem, to an innumerable multitude of angels,
to the gathering and assembly of the firstborn inscribed in heaven, to God, the judge of all, to the spirits of the righteous made perfect,
to Jesus, the mediator of a new covenant, and to the blood of sprinkling, which is better than that of Abel.
Be careful not to refuse the one who speaks. For if they have not escaped the rejection of him who warned on earth, how much more shall we who turn away from him who warns from heaven,
whose voice shook the earth then, but which he has now promised, saying, "Once more, I will shake not only the earth, but also the heavens."
This expression "once more" means that what is shaken is taken away, as are things done, so that what is not shaken remains.
Therefore, receiving a Kingdom that cannot be shaken, let us have grace, by which we serve God pleasantly, with reverence and fear,
for our God is a devouring fire.
May fraternal love continue.
Do not forget to give hospitality to strangers, for by acting in this way, some have received angels without knowing it.
Remember those who are in bonds, as bound to them, and those who are abused, since you are also in the body.
Let marriage be honored above all, and let the bed be free from defilement; but God will judge fornicators and adulterers.
Be free from the love of money, content with what you have, for he said, "I will not leave you, nor will I forsake you."
Thus, it is with courage that we say, "The Lord is my helper. I fear nothing. What can man do to me? »
Remember your leaders, the men who preached the word of God to you, and, considering the results of their conduct, imitate their faith.
Jesus Christ is the same yesterday, today and forever.
Do not let yourselves be carried away by various and strange teachings, for it is good that the heart should be strengthened by grace, and not by food, which has not been enjoyed by those who were thus occupied.
We have an altar on which those who serve the sanctity of the tabernacle are not allowed to eat.
For the bodies of these animals, whose blood is brought into the holy place by the high priest as a sacrifice for sin, are burned outside the camp.
That is why Jesus also, in order to sanctify the people with his own blood, suffered outside the gate.
Let us therefore go to him outside the camp, bearing his reproach.
For we do not have a lasting city here, but we are looking for the one that is to come.
Through him, therefore, let us offer unceasingly to God a sacrifice of praise, that is, the fruit of lips that proclaim fidelity to his name.
And do not forget to do good and to share, for such sacrifices are pleasing to God.
Obey your leaders and submit to them, for they watch over your souls, as those who will have to give an account, in order to do it with joy and not with groans, for it would be of no use to you.
Pray for us, for we are convinced that we have a good conscience, desiring to live honorably in all things.
I beg you earnestly to do this, so that I may be restored to you sooner.
May the God of peace, who raised from the dead the great shepherd of the sheep with the blood of an everlasting covenant, our Lord Jesus,
accomplish you in every good work to do his will, working in you that which is pleasing in his eyes, through Jesus Christ, to whom be glory forever and ever. Amen.
But I exhort you, brethren, to endure the word of exhortation, for I have written to you in a few words.
Know that our brother Timothy has been released, with whom, if he comes soon, I will see you.
Greet all your leaders and all the saints. The Italians greet you.
Grace be with you all. Amen.
James, servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes that are in the Scattering: Greetings.
Rejoice, my brethren, when you fall into various temptations,
knowing that the trial of your faith produces endurance.
Let endurance do its perfect work, so that you may be perfect and complete, lacking nothing.
But if any of you lack wisdom, let him ask it of God, who gives to all freely and without reproach, and it will be given to him.
But let him ask in faith, without doubt, for he who doubts is like a wave of the sea, driven by the wind and agitated.
For this man must not think that he will receive anything from the Lord.
He is a man of double thinking, unstable in all his ways.
Let the brother in humility glory in his high position;
and the rich, because he is made humble, for, like the flower in the grass, he will pass away.
For the sun rises with a burning wind and withers the grass; the flower it contains falls off, and the beauty of its appearance perishes. Thus, the rich man will also wither in his occupations.
Blessed is he who endures temptation, for after he has been accepted, he will receive the crown of life which the Lord has promised to those who love him.
Let no one say, when he is tempted, "I am tempted by God," for God cannot be tempted by evil, and he himself tempts no one.
But everyone is tempted when he is attracted by his own lust and seduces.
Then covetousness, when it has conceived, engenders sin. And sin, when it has become an adult, produces death.
Make no mistake, my beloved brethren.
Every pleasant gift and every perfect gift comes from above, from the Father of lights, in whom there is no variation or shadow.
Of his own will, he has begotten us by the word of truth, so that we may be a kind of firstfruits of his creatures.
Therefore, my beloved brethren, let every one be quick to hear, slow to speak, and slow to be angry;
for the wrath of man does not produce the righteousness of God.
Therefore, rejecting all defilement and all overflow of wickedness, humbly receive the implanted word, which can save your souls.
But put the word into practice, and do not be content to listen, deceiving yourselves.
For if anyone listens to the word and does not do it, he is like a man who looks at his natural face in a mirror;
for he sees himself, and goes away, and immediately forgets what sort of man he was.
But he who looks at the perfect law of liberty and perseveres, not being a hearer who forgets, but a doer, he will be blessed in what he does.
If any of you believe himself to be religious when he does not bridle his tongue, but deceives his heart, the religion of that man is worthless.
This is what a pure and spotless religion is before our God and Father: to visit orphans and widows in their distress, and to guard against the defilements of the world.
My brethren, hold back with partiality the faith of our glorious Lord Jesus Christ.
For if a man dressed in fine clothes, with a golden ring, enters your synagogue, and a poor man dressed in filthy clothes enters also,
and let you pay special attention to the one who is dressed in fine clothes, and say, "Sit here in a good place," and say to the poor, "Stand there," or "Sit down on my footstool."
Have you not shown partiality among yourselves, and have you not become judges of evil thoughts?
Listen, my beloved brethren. Has not God chosen the poor of this world to be rich in faith and heirs of the Kingdom He has promised to those who love Him?
But you have dishonored the poor man. Don't the rich oppress you and take you personally to court?
Do they not blaspheme the honorable name by which you are called?
But if you fulfill the royal law according to Scripture, "You shall love your neighbor as yourself," you are doing well.
But if you show partiality, you commit a sin, being found guilty by the law as transgressors.
For he who observes the whole law, and who stumbles at one point, becomes guilty of all.
For he who said, "Do not commit adultery," also said, "Do not commit murder." Now, if you do not commit adultery, but commit murder, you have become a transgressor of the law.
Thus speak and act like men who are to be judged by the law of liberty.
For judgment is merciless to him who has not shown mercy. Mercy triumphs over judgment.
What is it, my brethren, for a man to say that he has faith, but has no works? Can faith save him?
And if a brother or sister is naked and lacks daily food,
and let one of you say to them, "Go in peace. Warm yourselves and be satisfied"; but you have not given it what the body needs, what is the use of it?
In the same way, faith, if it has no works, is dead in itself.
Yes, a man will say, "You have faith, and I have works." Show me your faith without works, and I will show you my faith by my works.
You believe that God is unique. You are doing well. The demons also believe, and they tremble.
But do you want to know, vain man, that faith without works is dead?
Was not Abraham, our father, justified by works, by offering his son Isaac on the altar?
You see that faith has acted with its works, and that it is by works that faith has been perfected.
Thus was fulfilled the Scripture which says, "Abraham believed in God, and it was imputed to him as righteousness," and he was called the friend of God.
You see, then, that it is by works that a man is justified, and not by faith alone.
Similarly, was not Rahab the harlot justified by the works when she received the messengers and sent them out by another way?
For as the body without the spirit is dead, so faith without works is dead.
Let not many of you become masters, my brethren, knowing that we shall receive a more severe judgment.
For we all stumble into many things. He who does not stumble in words is a perfect person, capable also of bridling the whole body.
For we put bits in the horses' mouths to make them obey us, and we guide their whole bodies.
Here are the ships also, although they are so large and driven by violent winds, are guided by a very small rudder, where the pilot desires.
Thus the tongue is also a small member, and it boasts of great things. See how a small fire can spread into a large forest!
And the tongue is a fire. The world of iniquity among our members is the tongue, which defiles the whole body, which sets fire to the course of nature, and which is set ablaze by hell.
For every kind of animals, birds, reptiles, and sea creatures can be tamed and has been tamed by man;
but no one can tame the tongue. It is a restless evil, full of a deadly poison.
With it we bless our God and our Father, and with it we curse men made in the image of God.
From the same mouth come blessing and curse. My brothers, it must not be so.
Does a spring spring spring from the same opening fresh and bitter water?
Can a fig tree, my brethren, produce olives, or a vine figs? Thus, no spring produces both salt water and fresh water.
Who is wise and intelligent among you? Let him show by his good conduct that his deeds are done with the meekness of wisdom.
But if you have bitter jealousy and selfish ambition in your heart, do not boast or lie against the truth.
This wisdom is not that which descends from above, but it is earthly, sensual and demonic.
For where there is jealousy and selfish ambition, there is confusion and every evil deed.
But the wisdom that comes from above is first pure, then peaceable, gentle, reasonable, full of mercy and good fruits, without partiality and without hypocrisy.
Now the fruit of righteousness is sown in peace by those who make peace.
Where do wars and battles come from among you? Do they not come from your pleasures which are disputed in your limbs?
You covet, and you have not. You kill and covet, and you can't get. You fight and you make war. You don't have , because you don't ask .
You ask, and you do not receive, because you ask with evil motives, in order to spend it for your pleasures.
Do you not know that friendship with the world is hostility to God? Whoever wants to be the friend of the world, therefore, makes himself an enemy of God.
Or do you think that Scripture says in vain, "The Spirit that lives in us groans jealously"?
But it gives more grace. Therefore it is said, "God resists the proud, but he gives grace to the humble."
Be subject to God. Resist the devil, and he will flee from you.
Draw near to God, and he will draw near to you. Purify your hands, sinners. Purify your hearts, you who are double-minded.
Complain, mourn and weep. May your laughter turn into mourning and your joy into sadness.
Humble yourselves before the Lord, and he will exalt you.
Do not speak against one another, brothers. He who speaks against a brother and judges his brother, speaks against the law and judges the law. But if you judge the law, you are not a practitioner of the law, but a judge.
Only one is the legislator, who has the power to save and destroy. But who are you to judge others?
Come now, you who say: "Today or tomorrow, let us go to this city, let us spend a year there, do trade and make a profit."
Yet, you don't know what your life will be like tomorrow. Because what is your life? For you are a vapour that appears for a little while and then vanishes.
For you ought to say, "If the Lord wills, we will both live, and do this or that."
But now you are glorifying in your pride. Now, any boasting of this kind is bad.
Thus, whoever knows that good must be done and does not do it, he commits a sin.
Come now, rich people, weep and cry over the misfortunes that befall you.
Your riches are corrupted and your clothes are eaten away by moths.
Your gold and silver are corroded, and their corrosion will serve as a testimony against you; they will devour your flesh like fire. You have amassed your treasure in the last days.
Behold, the wages of the laborers who have mowed your fields, whom thou hast withheld by fraud, cry out; and the cries of those who have reaped have entered the ears of the Lord of hosts.
You have lived in luxury on earth, and you have taken your pleasure. You have nourished your hearts as in a day of carnage.
You have condemned and murdered the righteous. He can't resist you.
Be patient, therefore, brethren, until the coming of the Lord. Behold, the farmer waits for the precious fruit of the earth, with patience with it, until he receives the rain of the morning and the afternoon.
You too, be patient. Strengthen your hearts, for the coming of the Lord is at hand.
Do not grumble against one another, brothers, so that you will not be judged. Here the judge is standing at the door.
Take, brethren, as an example of suffering and perseverance, the prophets who spoke in the name of the Lord.
Behold, we call them blessed are those who have endured. You have heard of Job's perseverance and you have seen the Lord in the denouement, and how the Lord is full of compassion and mercy.
But above all, my brethren, swear not - neither by heaven nor by earth, nor by any other oath; but let your "yes" be "yes," and your "no," "no," so that you do not fall into hypocrisy.
Is any of you suffering? Let him pray. Is anyone cheerful? Let him sing praises.
Is any of you sick? Let him call the elders of the assembly, and let them pray for him, anointing him with oil in the name of the Lord.
The prayer of faith will heal the sick person, and the Lord will raise him up. If he has committed sins, he will be forgiven.
Confess your sins to one another and pray for one another, that you may be healed. The insistent prayer of a righteous person is powerfully effective.
Elijah was a man of a nature similar to ours. He prayed earnestly that it would not rain, and it would not rain on the earth for three years and six months.
He prayed again, and heaven gave rain, and the earth brought forth its fruit.
Brethren, if any of you deviate from the truth and someone brings him back,
let him know that he who brings a sinner back from error from his way will save a soul from death and cover a multitude of sins.
Peter, apostle of Jesus Christ, to the elect who live as strangers in Dispersion, in Pontus, Galatia, Cappadocia, Asia, and Bithynia,
according to the foreknowledge of God the Father, in the sanctification of the Spirit, that ye may obey Jesus Christ, and be sprinkled with his blood: grace and peace be multiplied unto you.
Blessed be the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, who, according to his great mercy, has caused us to be reborn to a living hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ from the dead,
for an incorruptible, unalterable, and imperishable inheritance, which is reserved for you in heaven,
you who, by the power of God, are kept by faith for a salvation ready to be revealed at the last moment.
This is your great joy, although for a little while longer, if need be, you have been afflicted by various trials,
so that the trial of your faith, which is more precious than perishable gold, even if it is tried by fire, may give rise to praise, glory and honor, at the revelation of Jesus Christ,
that you love without knowing him. In him, though now you do not see him, but in believing, you rejoice in unspeakable joy full of glory,
receiving the result of your faith, the salvation of your souls.
As for this salvation, the prophets have sought and sought carefully. They have prophesied the grace that will be granted to you,
seeking to know to whom or at what time the Spirit of Christ who was in them referred when he foretold the sufferings of Christ and the glories that would follow them.
It has been revealed to them that they are not serving themselves, but you, in those things which have been preached to you now by those who have preached the Good News to you through the Holy Spirit sent from heaven, which the angels want to examine.
So prepare your minds for action. Be sober, and put all your hope in the grace that will be granted to you at the revelation of Jesus Christ.
as obedient children, not conforming to your former lusts as in your ignorance,
but as he who called you is holy, you also be holy in all your conduct,
for it is written, "You shall be holy, for I am holy."
If you call upon him as Father, who, without respect for persons, judges according to the work of each one, spend here the time of your life as strangers in reverent fear,
knowing that you have been redeemed, not with corruptible things, such as silver or gold, from the useless way of life handed down by your fathers,
but by a precious blood, like that of a lamb without blemish or spot, the blood of Christ,
which was already known before the foundation of the world, but which has been revealed in this last century for your sake,
you who, through him, believe in God, who raised him from the dead and gave him glory, so that your faith and your hope may be in God.
Having purified your souls by obeying the truth by the Spirit, in sincere fraternal affection, love one another with all your heart fervently,
being born again, not of a corruptible seed, but of an incorruptible seed, by the word of God, which lives and abides forever.
For, "All flesh is like grass, and all the glory of man like the flower in the grass. The grass withers, and its flower falls;
but the word of the Lord endures forever. This is the word of the Good News that has been preached to you.
Rejecting therefore all malice, all fraud, all hypocrisy, all envy, all backbiting,
yearn, like newborn children, to pure spiritual milk, that you may grow with it,
if you have tasted the goodness of the Lord.
Come to him, living stone, rejected by men, but chosen by God, precious.
You too, as living stones, are built up into a spiritual house, to be a holy priesthood, to offer spiritual sacrifices, acceptable to God through Jesus Christ.
For this is contained in the Scripture, "Behold, I lay in Zion a cornerstone, chosen and precious. Whoever believes in him will not be disappointed. »
To you who believe, then, it is honor, but to the disobedient, "The stone which the builders rejected has become the chief cornerstone,"
and, "a stumbling block and a rock of offense." For they stumble upon the word, disobeying what they were destined for.
But you are a chosen race, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people won over to God, to proclaim the excellence of Him who has called you out of darkness into his marvellous light.
Formerly you were not a people, but now you are the people of God, you who did not obtain mercy, but who now have obtained mercy.
Beloved, I beg you, as strangers and pilgrims, to abstain from carnal lusts that wage war on the soul,
and to have good conduct among the nations, so that in those who are spoken of against you as evildoers, your good works may be seen, and God may be glorified in the day of punishment.
Wherefore, for the Lord's sake, submit yourselves to every ordinance of man, whether it be the king, as sovereign,
or governors, as sent by him to punish the wicked and praise those who do well.
For it is the will of God that you silence, by your good deeds, the ignorance of fools.
Live as free people, not using your freedom as a cover for wickedness, but as slaves of God.
Honor all men. Love fraternity. Fear God. Honor the king.
Servants, be subject to your masters in all respect, not only to those who are good and meek, but also to the wicked.
Indeed, it is praiseworthy that someone endures pains, unjust sufferings, out of conscience towards God.
For what glory is there in that, when you sin, you patiently endure the blows? But if, when you do well, you patiently endure suffering, this is praiseworthy before God.
For this you have been called to, because Christ also suffered for us, leaving you an example, that you should follow in his footsteps,
he who did not sin, "and in his mouth there was no deceit."
When he was cursed, he did not curse in his turn. When he suffered, he did not threaten, but he left it to him who judges justly.
He Himself bore our sins in His body on the tree, so that, dead to sins, we might live for righteousness. It is by his wounds that you have been healed.
For you went astray like sheep; but now you have returned to the shepherd and overseer of your souls.
In the same way, wives, be subject to your husbands, so that, if any do not obey the Word, they may be won over by the conduct of their wives, without a word,
seeing your pure conduct in fear.
Let not your beauty come from an outward adornment, such as braiding your hair, wearing gold ornaments, or dressing yourself in fine clothes,
but of the hidden person of the heart, in the incorruptible adornment of a gentle and tranquil spirit, which is very precious in the sight of God.
For this is how the holy women who hoped in God were formerly adorned by being subject to their husbands.
So Sarah obeys Abraham, calling him lord, whose children you are now, if you do well and do not allow yourself to be frightened by any terror.
You, husbands, likewise, live with your wives according to knowledge, honoring the wife as the weakest vessel, as being also co-heirs of the grace of life, so that your prayers may not be hindered.
Finally, be all animated by the same sentiments, compassionate, loving like brothers, full of tenderness, courteous,
not returning evil for evil, nor insult for injury, but blessing on the contrary, knowing that you have been called to this, in order to inherit a blessing.
For, "Whoever wants to love life and see good days, let him keep his tongue from evil and his lips from uttering lies.
Let him turn away from evil and do good. Let him seek peace and pursue it.
For the eyes of the Lord are upon the righteous, and his ears open to their prayer; but the face of the Lord is against those who do evil. »
Now, who will hurt you if you become imitators of what is good?
But even if you have to suffer for righteousness, you are blessed. "Do not fear what they fear, and do not be troubled."
But sanctify the Lord God in your hearts. Be always ready to respond to all those who ask you for the reason of the hope that is in you, with humility and fear,
by having a good conscience. Thus, while you are spoken of as evildoers, those who curse your right way of living in Christ may be disappointed.
For it is better, if it be the will of God, that you suffer for having done good than for having done evil.
Because Christ also suffered once for sins, the righteous for the unrighteous, that he might bring you to God, being put to death in the flesh, but made alive in the Spirit,
in which he also went to preach to the spirits in prison,
who before were disobedient when God waited patiently in the days of Noah while the ship was being built. In it, few persons, that is to say, eight souls, were saved by the water.
This is a symbol of baptism, which now saves you - not by ridding yourself of the filth of the flesh, but by responding to a good conscience toward God - through the resurrection of Jesus Christ,
who is at the right hand of God, having ascended into heaven, the angels, authorities, and powers being subject to him.
Therefore, since Christ suffered for us in the flesh, arm yourselves also with the same spirit; for he who has suffered in the flesh has ceased to sin,
so that you may no longer live the rest of your time in the flesh according to the lusts of men, but according to the will of God.
For we have spent enough time in satisfying the desires of the heathen, and in walking in fornication, lusts, drunkenness, orgies, carousels, and abominable idolatries.
They find it strange that you do not run with them in the same rioting excesses, and they speak ill of you.
They will give an account to him who is willing to judge the living and the dead.
For it is for this purpose that the Good News has been preached even to the dead, that they may be judged as men in the flesh, but that they may live as before God in the spirit.
But the end of all things is near. Therefore, be sane, self-controlled, and sober in prayer.
And above all, be serious in your love among yourselves, for love covers a multitude of sins.
Be welcoming to each other, without complaining.
As each has received a gift, devote yourselves to serving one another, as good stewards of the grace of God in its various forms.
If anyone speaks, let it be as if it were God's own words. If anyone serves, let it be with the strength that God provides, so that in all things God may be glorified by Jesus Christ, to whom belong glory and dominion forever and ever. Amen.
Beloved, do not be surprised at the fiery trial that has been imposed on you to test you, as if a strange thing were happening to you.
But because you share in the sufferings of Christ, rejoice, that at the revelation of his glory you may also rejoice with exceedingly joy.
If you are reviled for the name of Christ, you are blessed, for the Spirit of glory and of God rests upon you. On their side, he is blasphemed, but on your side, he is glorified.
Let none of you suffer as a murderer, or a thief, or a malefactor, or as meddling in the affairs of others.
But if any of you suffer because he is a Christian, let him not be ashamed, but let him glorify God about it.
For the time has come when judgment must begin with the house of God. If it begins with us first, what will happen to those who do not obey the Good News of God?
"If it is difficult for the righteous to be saved, what will happen to the ungodly and the sinner?"
Let those who suffer according to the will of God in doing good entrust their souls to Him as to a faithful Creator.
Wherefore I exhort the elders among you, who am also an elder and a witness of the sufferings of Christ, and who will also share in the glory that shall be revealed:
lead the flock of God that is in your midst, exercising surveillance, not by compulsion, but voluntarily; not for dishonest gain, but voluntarily;
not as if to dominate those entrusted to you, but by serving as an example to the flock.
When the chief shepherd appears, you will receive the crown of glory that does not fade.
In the same way, you younger people, be subject to the oldest. All of you, clothe yourselves with humility and submit yourselves to one another, for "God resists the proud, but gives grace to the humble."
Humble yourselves, therefore, under the mighty hand of God, that he may exalt you in due time,
by casting all your worries on him, for he cares for you.
Be sober and self-controlled. Be vigilant. Your adversary, the devil, walks around like a roaring lion, looking for whom he can devour.
Resist him firmly in faith, knowing that your brethren who are in the world are also suffering.
But may the God of all grace, who has called you to his eternal glory through Jesus Christ, after you have suffered a little, perfect you, strengthen you, strengthen you, and fix you.
To him is glory and power for ever and ever. Amen.
By Silvanus, our faithful brother, as I consider him, I have written to you briefly, exhorting you and testifying to you that it is the true grace of God in which you find yourself.
She who is in Babylon, chosen with you, greets you. Mark, my son, greets you also.
Greet each other with a kiss of love. Peace be with all of you who are in Christ Jesus. Amen.
Simon Peter, servant and apostle of Jesus Christ, to those who have obtained with us such precious faith in the righteousness of our God and Savior, Jesus Christ:
May grace and peace be multiplied to you in the knowledge of God and Jesus our Lord,
seeing that his divine power has granted us all that pertains to life and godliness, through the knowledge of him who has called us by his own glory and virtue,
by which he has granted us his precious and immense promises, that by them you may become partakers of the divine nature, having escaped the corruption that is in the world through covetousness.
Yes, and for this very reason, adding on your part all diligence, in your faith provide moral excellence; and in moral excellence, knowledge;
and in knowledge, self-control; and in self-control, perseverance; and in perseverance, piety;
and in piety, fraternal affection; and in fraternal affection, love.
For if these things are yours and if they abound, they enable you not to be idle or fruitless in the knowledge of our Lord Jesus Christ.
For he who lacks these things is blind, seeing only what is near, having forgotten the purification of his former sins.
Therefore, brethren, apply yourselves to making your calling and your election more secure. For if you do these things, you will never stumble.
For thus you will be richly provided to enter into the eternal kingdom of our Lord and Savior, Jesus Christ.
Therefore I will not neglect to remind you of these things, although you know them and are established in the present truth.
I find it good, while I am in this tent, to stimulate you by reminding you,
knowing that the stripping of my tent will not be long in coming, as our Lord Jesus Christ has made me understand.
Yes, I will make every effort so that you can always remember these things, even after I am gone.
For we did not follow cunning fables when we made known to you the power and advent of our Lord Jesus Christ, but we were eyewitnesses to his majesty.
For he received honor and glory from God the Father, when the voice came to him from the majestic glory: "This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased."
We heard this voice from heaven when we were with him on the holy mountain.
We have a surer prophetic word; and you do well to pay attention to it as to a lamp that shines in a dark place, until the day rises and the morning star rises in your hearts,
knowing first of all that no prophecy of Scripture is of private interpretation.
For no prophecy ever came from the will of man, but holy men of God spoke, moved by the Holy Spirit.
But false prophets have arisen among the people, just as false teachers will arise among you, who will secretly introduce destructive heresies, denying even the Master who bought them, and bringing upon themselves speedy destruction.
Many will follow their immoral ways, and, as a result, the way of truth will be slandered.
Out of covetousness, they will exploit you with deceitful words; their sentence, coming from the past, does not linger, and their destruction does not slumber.
For if God did not spare the angels when they sinned, but cast them into Tartarus and committed them to pits of darkness to be reserved for judgment;
and did not spare the ancient world, but preserved Noah with seven others, a preacher of righteousness, when he brought a flood upon the world of the ungodly,
and turning the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah into ashes, condemned them to destruction, after having made them an example to those who would live in an ungodly manner,
and delivered the righteous Lot, who was greatly afflicted by the lascivious life of the wicked
(for this righteous man who dwelt in the midst of them was tormented in his righteous soul, day by day, to see and hear unlawful acts),
then the Lord knows how to deliver the righteous from temptation and keep the unrighteous under punishment for the day of judgment,
